column2: ALBANY, March 13 -- A new version of a modified "no-fault" automobile accident insurance plan that is said to have strong bipartisan support in the Senate is expected to be introduced tomorrow by Senator John H. Hughes, a Syracuse Republican.

GENEVA, March 13 -- A new examination, the international baccalaureate, has been set up here to provide the equivalent of an international high school diploma for students who attend school outside their own countries.

Seventy Americans returned yesterday from a l0-day visit to Bangladesh convinced that if the new nation does not receive vital economic and material assistance within the next three months it might cease to be "a viable nation."
LABRADOR CITY, Newfoundland -- The band struck up "I'se the Bye," a popular tune in Newfoundland. Mainlanders would call it "I'm the Boy."
PARIS, March 13 -- Discretion surrounds the contacts being made here between the United States and China, which suits the man at the American end -- Arthur K. Watson.
George M. Duff Jr., a lawyer who lives in Riverdale, was installed yesterday afternoon as president of the Council of Churches of the City of New York.

" This winter, in my 70th year, I thought I would be respected but neglected," says John Houseman. Instead, the distinguished producer and director is having one of his most active and visible seasons.

PRINCETON, N. J., March 13 -- Vince Cartier of Scotch Plains High School established a national-indoor high school record for the one-mile run today in the 14th annual New Jersey State Interscholastic Athletic Association track championships.

My surprise at a statement in your March 3 editorial "The I.T.T. Hearings" prompts me to write. I refer to the assertion that Mr. Kleindienst was guilty of impropriety in discussing the I.T.T. case several times with a New York investment banker representing I.T.T., in setting up a conference with officials of the antitrust division and in attending that conference.
WASHINGTON, March 13 -- Almost all of the Democratic candidates for President agree that the antitrust laws need more vigorous enforcement and that some new laws may also be required.
E. I. du Pont de Nemours Co., Inc., announced yesterday that it had reduced prices by a range of 3 per cent to 20 per cent on most gauges and types of Mylar polyester film, effective immediately.

A player who is considering slam prospects often needs to know the length and strength of his partner's suit. Using standard methods some guesswork is often necessary, but the growing number of players using the Precision System have a conventional device at their disposal.
SAN JOSE, Calif., March 13 -- A black woman who was the center of a heated controversy last week was removed today as a possible juror in the trial of Angels Davis.

It may not have been winter's worst day, but it hardly seemed the right one for moving 236 patients, up to 107 years in age, from he Home and Hospital of the Daughters of Israel in Manhattan to the Jewish Institute of Geriatric Care at the Queens-Nassau border where Bellerose meets New Hyde Park.

Unfortunately, anyone unfamiliar with the subject would conclude upon reading Commissioner Alan D. Miller's letter (Feb. 26), in which he points out the statistical errors made in Senator William T. Conklin's previously published letter, that everything necessary was being done to aid the retarded and that conditions in the state residential schools are now all that they should be.

WASHINGTON, March 14 -The House Ways and Means Committee, which is moving slowly toward agreement on a revenue-sharing bill, voted today to require state to maintain present levels of financial aid to the cities and counties within their borders or lose some of the money that revenue sharing would provide them.

RAMALLAH, Israeli occupied Jordan, March 14 -- Palestinian political leaders were thrown into confusion today at the start of their municipal election campaign by reports of an imminent decision by King Hussein of Jordan on the Palestinians' future.
FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla., March 14 -- While the New York Yankees lost to the Montreal Expos, 5-4, today, Ron Swoboda looked on quietly from the dugout.
Following are the salaries, including profit sharing and deferred compensation, paid to senior officers of the nation's largest banking concerns last year:

The statement by Arthur F. Burns, chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, that American interest rates have hit their lows and will be trending upward may have reassured European central bankers, but it certainly jarred the New York stock market. Not long ago it was conventional for American economic and financial analysts to say that international monetary disorder might be desperate but was not of serious moment to the huge domestic United States economy.

WASHINGTON, March 14 -Former Attorney General John N. Mitchell disclosed today that he discussed the Government's antitrust policies privately with Harold S. Geneen, the president of the International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation, for some 35 minutes during a 1970 meeting, but he said he refused to talk about the Government's three cases against the company.
Mrs. Aristotle Onassis stepped down from the witness stand at 3:30 P.M. yesterday after five days of cross-examination in her suit against Ronald E. Galella, a freelance photographer.

Hundreds of students assigned to Adlai E. Stevenson High School in the Clason Point section of the Bronx have not attended classes since September because they, as well as their parents, fear for their safety, a Board of Education meeting was told last night.
WASHINGTON, March 14 -The Bureau of Labor Statistics reported today the following spot primary prices for the week ended March 3:

BEIRUT, Lebanon, March 14 -- King Hussein has reportedly proposed to the Big Four powers a plan for rejoining the Israeli-held west bank with the east bank of Jordan in a federal system to be called the United Arab Kingdom instead of the Hashemite Kingdom of Jordan.
Four men were selected as jurors yesterday in the murder trial of Mark Holder, a 17-year-old Black Panther who is accused of slaying a fellow Panther, Samuel Napier, in an alleged intraparty feud.

The State Assembly has stooped to a disgraceful and probably unconstitutional maneuver to block construction of the controversial public-housing project in Forest Hills. It has rushed through a bill requiring countywide referendums on all such projects and made it apply retroactively to the one in Queens.

DURHAM, N. C. -- The fall of 1971 saw the introduction of widespread busing of pupils in many parts of the United States, particularly the South. Its aim was to achieve racial balance in formerly segregated school systems. Politicians ranging from the nation's Chief Executive to Congressmen to state and municipal officials have made pious statements about the sanctity of neighborhood schools -- which busing interfered with.

SAN DIEGO, March 14 -The financial chairman of San Diego's Republican convention committee urged today "a full disclosure" of all contributions to a $400,000 fund that is being raised to meet the city's commitment to the Republican National Committee.

KANSAS CITY, March 14 (AP) -- The Cincinnati Royals, plagued by poor home attendance, capped a three-month search for a new home base today by shifting their National Basketball Association franchise to Kansas City.

ZURICH, Switzerland, March 14 -- The Zurich prosecutor said today that the passage in a Federal indictment in New York implicating one of the largest Swiss banks in the Clifford and Edith Irving fraud "does not correspond to the facts."

SAN JUAN, P. R., March 14 (AP) -- Fire swept through a Brazilian cargo vessel in the southern Caribbean today, leaving eight dead, one missing and four seriously injured, according to the Coast Guard.
The manager of George Foreman, boxing's undefeated heavyweight contender and the 1968 Olympic champion, challenged Floyd Patterson to fight Foreman in a "winner-take-all" charity match this year.

WASHINGTON, March 14 -- In a move important to historians and scholars, President Nixon has ordered the State Department to cut the time lag in publishing its annual official documentary series "Foreign Relations of the United States" from 26 years to 20.

Why not pull out all the stops? You don't get a chance very often. But "Chinese Calligraphy," which opened to the public yesterday at the Metropolitan Museum of Art, is an exhibition that leaves a reporter groping for adjectives better than "stunning, magnificent and exciting" to describe it.

MANTES-LA-JOLIE, France, March 14 (Reuters) -- An express turbotrain jumped its rails at high speed and caught fire near this town west of Paris today, killing four people and injuring 41, railroad officials said.
LONDON, March 14 (UPI) -- David Bingham began serving a 21-year prison term today because he listened to a wife who loved to play bingo and buy new clothes.
NEW LONDON, Conn. March 14 (AP) -- The Army Corps of Engineers today proposed a $12.51-million dredging project that would allow New London harbor to accommodate larger ships.

The extraordinary news report in The Times of Feb. 7 concerning the City Planning Commission comes as no surprise. Asked in an interview if public hearings had ever led him to change his mind on any significant issue, chairman Donald H. Elliott, an appointee of Mayor Lindsay, answered, "I think . . . No."

BRIARCLIFF MANOR, N. Y., March 14 -- The skeptics said it could not be done, but this attractive little village, in the garbage business for less than a year, is breaking even on recycling. By the end of the year, it may even be turning a profit.
ALBANY, March 14 -- The State Senate unanimously approved a bill today that would expand the state's college tuition loan program to students in families earning $15,000 or more a year.

WASHINGTON, March 14 -President Nixon told Congress today that any substantial cut in the $2.15-billion he had requested for foreign military aid for the fiscal year beginning July 1 would jeopardize his plan for stable, peaceful relations with China and the Soviet Union.
ATHENS, March 14 -- Archbishop Makarios, the President of Cyprus, after delaying for more than a month, delivered his reply today to the Greek note of Feb. 11 that demanded his submission to Athens.

WASHINGTON, March 14 (UPI) -- The A.F.L.-C.I.O. said today that a rare type of cancer was afflicting an increasing number of asbestos plant workers and their families and that the situation might prove to be "the largest epidemic of occupational cancer ever recorded."

ASKOV, Minn. -- Terry Wolfe and Vern Ward had a few free hours the other day. So they drove to this little crossroads community 125 miles north of Minneapolis and set out into the woods, struggling several miles on snowshoes into a frozen swamp.
Stock prices firmed yesterday as investors overcame some of their nervousness over the dollar's weakness abroad that triggered on Monday the biggest setback in four months.

The United States Court of Appeals here ruled yesterday that Federal District Judge Marvin E. Frankel had acted too quickly when he freed Edwin Goodman, the general manager of radio station WBAI, from jail 10 days ago.
WASHINGTON, March 14 -- Following is a list of 121 contributors of $1,000 or more to the Hubert H. Humphrey campaign, released today by the Humphrey for President headquarters here:
A Columbia freshman class that had some semblance of unity last year, if only because of its rawness, is dissolving now into the university's and the city's variegated life.

WASHINGTON, March 14 -- A lawyer with Ralph Nader's Center for Study of Responsive Law asserted today that the Freedom of Information Act of 1967 "has foundered on the rocks of bureaucratic self-interest and secrecy."
WASHINGTON, March 14 -Senator Hubert H. Humphrey of Minnesota disclosed today a list of 121 contributors of $1,000 or more each to his campaign for the Demcratic Presidential nomination.

The contract of Mike Gordon, Adelphi University's varsity basketball coach for the last six years, will not be renewed for next season, James Bedell, the athletic director, announced yesterday. Bedell was notified two weeks ago that his own contract would not be renewed past this August.

HONGAY, North Vietnam, March 13 -- The villagers in this important coal-producing city, scene of heavy American bombing attacks five years ago, have a popular saying borrowed in part from a former Air Force Chief of Staff:

MIAMI, March 14 (UPI) -An alleged member of the militant National Black Liberation Army was named by the Federal Bureau of Investigation today as one of the two men who hijacked a Chalk's Flying Service amphibian plane to Cuba on March 7.
Those brave if foolhardy crocuses that have been poking their heads up in eager anticipation of spring were covered yesterday with several inches of snow or slush.

There are a lot of theories about why the economy's been like it has been for the last few years. Here's another: Corporate decision makers have been too busy responding to questionnaires seeking their opinions on this and that to make decisions.

WASHINGTON, March 14 -The International Telephone and Telegraph case flared up for the first time on the Senate floor today as Senator Thomas F. Eagleton of Missouri charged that a Presidential aide, Peter Flanigan, had become "Mr. Fixit" for big business, and the White House responded with indignant denials.

WASHINGTON, March 14 -- Testimony before a House sub-committee disclosed today that the major stock exchanges are still unable to agree on how to take the first step toward a unified market for stocks: the creation of a consolidated tape.

MEMPHIS, March 14 (UPI) -- A. S. (Bert) Hart resigned today as president of the Memphis Pros so his investment banking company could handle financial arrangements for the American Basketball Association team.

TALLAHASSEE, Fla., March 14 (UPI) -- Senator Barry Goldwater, Republican of Arizona, congratulated Gov. Reubin Askew today on his stand in favor of school busing but said that he did not fully agree with Mr. Askew's position that busing was a necessary, temporary means of ending segregation.
VIENTIANE, Laos, March 14 (UPI) -- Heavy fighting was reported under way tonight along the outer defenses of the Americanbacked base at Long Tieng just south of the Plaine des Jarres.

TAMPA, Fla., March 14 -In the latest episode of "One Man's Family," the New York Mets lost Wayne Garrett because of a strained shoulder today and thereby added another name to the longest sick-call list in baseball.

WASHINGTON, March 14 (UPI) -- Congress was all set to stamp its final approval on a long-pending $1-billion drug abuse bill, but the Senate according to Representative Harley O. Staggers, Democrat of West Virginia, lost the papers.
GENEVA, March 14 -- Sweden charged today that the four-year-old treaty prohibiting the spread of nuclear weapons has entered "a kind of twilight zone."
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., March 14 -- Jordan's, new Ambassador, Abdul Hamid Sharaf, said here today that there had been no secret negotiations between King Hussein and Israel.
Bobby Allison was late for the drivers' meeting that preceded Sunday's 500-mile stock-car race at Rockingham, N.C.

The city of Washington has made up for the loss of its baseball team by gaining a pair of pandas -- not a bad exchange considering that pandas are rare and highly prized while the Senators finished the season in next to last place.

McGraw-Hill, Inc., the center of two recent book-publishing storms, removed Robert S. Stewart yesterday as editor in chief of the company's trade book division, charging he had received $1,700 as a "gift or loan" from two of his authors.
The Charlie Scott case erupted in a flurry of legal actions and threats yesterday, compounding confusion in the latest squabble between the National and American Basketball Associations.
A bill that is designed to end the five-year fight by a group of homeowners in Corona, Queens, to save their homes from condemnation for a new high school was approved today by the City Council.
Twelve young men were indicted yesterday on charges growing out of rioting at the Rikers Island Adolescent Remand Shelter on Feb. 27 in which five correction officers were taken hostage.
The era of open tennis has ended as far as the 1972 Wimbledon championships are concerned.

Prices of silver futures on the Commodity Exchange of New York declined 2 cents an ounce yesterday owing to the strengthening of the dollar in relation to sterling abroad. The decline followed commissionhouse and trade liquidation.

All organizations devoted to the presentation of new plays are bound to have a variable track record, and the Negro Ensemble Company is understandably no exception. Its latest offering, at the St. Marks Playhouse, is "A Ballet Behind the Bridge," by Lennox Brown, a Trinidadian author who now lives in Canada.

MONTGOMERY, Ala., March 14 (AP) -- Approximately 150 blacks have applied for jobs as state troopers since a Federal judge last month ordered the Alabama Highway Patrol integrated, the State Personnel Board reports.
BIRMINGHAM, Ala., March 14 (AP) -- Postal inspectors have found a railroad car missing for more than two years with a load of parcel post packages, a Postal Service official said today.

Three New York psychiatrists say they are seeing more cases of sexual impotence among young men than ever before. They say the cause appears to be that the increased sexual freedom of women in recent years is leading women to demand more of their male partners.
The Pyles twins, who twice in the last week were tear-gassed by Correction Department personnel and carried to their trial, appeared in court yesterday without coercion.

WASHINGTON, March 14 -The National Aeronautics and Space Administration has decided to use solid-fuel rockets for launching the space shuttle system, Senator Frank E. Moss, Democrat of Utah, said today.

Your March 6 editorial "The Goodman Jailing" misses the main issue in the conflict between the Manhattan District Attorney and radio station WBAI-FM. While you correctly assess the indefensibility of the court in jailing station manager Edwin A. Goodman for his refusal to surrender subpoenaed materials relating to the city's investigation of the 1970 Tombs riots, your editorial dwells too heavily on legal distinctions of dubious applicability.

Harvey J. Klaris, president of the Sayre Fisher Company, announced yesterday that the company has entered into a letter of intent to acquire the real estate assets of Wam Builders, Inc., a closely held real estate developer owned by Warren McFadden and his family.

WASHINGTON, March 14 -Faced with the possibility of being overruled by his own House Rules Committee, Representative, William M. Colmer, Democrat of Mississippi, agreed today to schedule action next month on a stalled bill to increase the Federal minimum wage.

HONOLULU -- The one gap in summitry that must be filled by President Nixon, most itinerant of American Presidents, is the Japanese gap. Mr. Nixon met Emperor Hirohito at Anchorage, Alaska, in 1971 when Japan's sovereign stopped off on a flight to Europe.
The various segments of New York's garment industry have agreed on a program to promote the city's fashion trades.

A co-defendant presented evidence on the witness stand yesterday that contradicted the grand jury testimony of former State Senator Seymour R. Thaler about arrangements to sell $800,000 in stolen United States Treasury bills.

HARRISBURG, Pa., March 14 -- The judge in the Berrigan conspiracy case threatened Paul O'Dwyer, defense counsel, with a contempt citation today after Mr. O'Dwyer said that the judge was "frustrating" the cross-examination of the Government's star witness, Boyd F. Douglas Jr., a paid F.B.I. informer.

President Nixon last fall described Cambodia as a model recipient of United States assistance -- running at about one-third of a billion dollars a year -- under his new foreign policy. "Cambodia is the Nixon Doctrine in its purest form," the President told a news conference.

TOKYO, March 13 -- They go in groups of 10 or so, mostly older people, often accompanied by Buddhist priests, and they scour the jungles of Pacific islands for the bones and relics of the Japanese war dead.
Prices on the American Stock Exchange and in over-the-counter trading finished slightly higher yesterday in moderate activity.

Mrs. Gertrude M. Bacon, a former Family Court judge, wife of a successful businessman and grandmother of three, considers her day a success when she gets a lot of telephone calls from strangers. When the strangers call back repeatedly, she is even more pleased because she is almost certain that, eventually, she will meet them in person.

DARIEN, Conn., March 14 -Virginia and Connecticut, favorites for the title, were forced to rally tonight to score first-round victories in the national intercollegiate indoor polo championships at the Ox Ridge Hunt Club.
MANAMA, Bahrein, Wednesday, March 15 (UPI) -- A Danish chartered jetliner with 112 persons aboard crashed in the mountains east of Dubai on the Persian Gulf, Dubai airport officials said today.

WASHINGTON, March 14 (UPI) -- A Federal Trade Commission heating examiner ordered today a nationwide bill collection agency to repay franchise holders and merchants money they allegedly lost as a result of the agency's deceptive practices.

Paying without Jerry Lucas and with only token help from Earl Monroe, the New York Knicks polished off the Atlanta Hawks, 115-107, at Madison Square Garden last night before a capacity crowd of 19,588, their 25th sellout at home this season.

KUCHING, Malaysia, March 6 -- The state government of Sarawak has launched a Vietnamstyle civic-action program to contest a tenacious Chinese guerrilla movement for the allegiance of isolated tribal villagers and restless Chinese youth in the towns.

Three illegal Albanian immigrants and a part-time television actress were arrested and charged with murder early yesterday morning after what the police called a "well-planned revenge" slaying outside Maxwell's Plum, a popular restaurant at 64th Street and First Avenue.
PEKING, March 14 (Reuters) -- Britain's first embassy in Communist China opened today, replacing a mission established 22 years ago.

WILBERFORCE, Ohio -- Dr. Rembert Stokes, president of Wilberforce University, did not attempt to hide his enthusiasm over the three new buildings that form the beginning of a new campus for one of the oldest black colleges in the nation.

The 14th annual Grammy Awards were announced last night at the Felt Forum and in a television show on the American Broadcasting Company network. The prizes are presented by the National Academy of Recording Arts and Sciences to performers and technicians in 44 categories.
BOSTON, March 14 (AP) -John Havlicek scored 38 points tonight in leading the Boston Celtics to a 124-110 victory over the Golden State Warriors.

It is not enough to be a star anymore; one has to be a superstar. In the stone way, piano virtuosos are so plentiful that one has to be a supervirtuoso to make an impression. The extravagant term can be applied to Michael Ponti.

Tina Kaplan is, as her name seems to suggest, a teeny, tiny girl. But she is singing with such energetic high spirits at the Downstairs at the Upstairs that there are times when she appears to be 10 feet tall.

The 150 physicians who serve the Sea View Hospital and Home on Staten Island plan to leave en masse at 5 o'clock this afternoon to protest the seating of a community advisory board that includes only one doctor.
MIAMI, March 14 -- Florida voters in a straw ballot overwhelmingly voiced today their opposition to court-ordered compulsory busing of school children to achieve racial integration.

" N.B.C., Reports," a 36-week series of weekly one-hour prime-time news programs devoted to investigative reporting and topical issues, will be televised next season on the network of the National Broadcasting Company.
DETROIT, March 14 (AP) -The boom in auto sales apparently came to at least a temporary end in early March.
NEW DELHI, March 14 -- Prime Minister Indira Gandhi's New Congress party has gained control of 14 of the 16 states and one of the two union territories that elected new governments last week.

The City Center of Music and Drama, whose two chief constituents are the New York City Ballet and the New York City Opera, is considering the creation of its own drama unit, according to Norman Singer, executive director of the City Center.

BELFAST, Northern Ireland, March 14 -- The tribunal investigating the killing of 13 civilians by British soldiers in Londonderry on Jan. 30 ended today with testimony of a plea by the city police chief to one of the army commanders.

NASHVILLE -- Elected officials of a fragmented Democratic party here are counting on Representative Wilbur D. Mills to protect them from internal warfare in the state's first Presidential primary on May 4.

The listing by the International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation of those Government officials with whom Harold S. Geneen, the company's president, met during the litigation of the company's antitrust suits is a roster of power in Washington. It includes Cabinet officers and White House advisers. Among them was John Mitchell, then the Attorney General.

WASHINGTON, March 14 -- Two high Government officials sought today to dispel the impression that the United States was taking a neglectful attitude toward the continuing international monetary problem, as Secretary of the Treasury John B. Connally prepared a speech on the issue that he will deliver tomorrow.
A rape suspect who had been arrested one year after his alleged crimes because of a police sketchy a detective always carried with him was convicted yesterday in Supreme Court in the Bronx.

DENVER, March 14 -- A Roman Catholic priest from Brooklyn told delegates to the National Federation of Priests' Councils today that it might seem they were being asked during their current convention to become social workers, sociologists, economists and political scientists.

One of Japan's industrial leaders, whose countrymen have often criticized him for his liberal views, said here yesterday that Japanese export prices would be 5 per cent to 10 per cent higher if determined on the same basis as domestic prices.
The Ampex Corporation reported yesterday that it lost $86.3-million in the nine months ended Jan. 30 and estimated that it would lose $3-million in its fourth fiscal quarter, which ends April 29.

TRENTON, March 14 -- Former Gov. Richard J. Hughes announced today that in New Jersey's Democratic primary of June 6, he will lead a statewide slate of convention delegate candidates pledged to the Presidential nomination of Senator Edmund S. Muskie of Maine.

WASHINGTON, March 14 -The Pay Board formally took up today the potentially explosive West Coast longshore contract and heard its own staff report that there might be justification for approving a wage increase in excess of its guidelines.

WASHINGTON, March 14 -The House Public Works Committee reported out today a water pollution control bill that is significantly weaker in some respects than the bill unanimously passed by the Senate four and one-half months ago.

In newspaper clippings over the last six years or so, Dr. Allan Murray Cartter's name usually appears rather far down in articles about academic conferences or analyses of the problems of universities.

ALBANY, March 14 -- The state Democratic chairman, Joseph F. Crangle, met with skeptical Democratic State Senators today on his proposal to have aspiring delegates for the Democratic National Convention compete in the June 20 primary on the basis of State Senate rather than Congressional district lines.

MIAMI, March 14 -- Gov. George C. Wallace of Alabama scored a dramatic victory in the Florida Presidential primary today, capturing 75 of the state's 81 delegates to the Democratic National Convention.

The Kaiser Industries Corporation sold 5,245,000 shares of the American Motors Corporation yesterday in the largest trade ever executed on the New York Stock Exchange, in terms of shares. It topped the previous record block of 3.25 million shares of the Allis-Chalmers Manufacturing Company traded Feb. 8, 1971.

The principal creditors of the bankrupt Penn Central Transportation Company, including the trustee of the New Haven Railroad and some of the country's biggest banks and insurance companies, questioned yesterday the income projections recently advanced by the trustees in the reorganization of the Penn Central.

ALBANY, March 14 -- Representatives of 63 civic, labor and religious groups from New York City today sought the restoration of about $34-million in state funds for the City University in the state budget that takes effect April 1.
Henry J. Brock has been elected senior vice president and associate general counsel of the Prudential Insurance Company, while Charles J. Jordan has been named vice president, group pensions.
SARASOTA, Fla., March 14 (AP) -- Dick Allen bounced in and out of the Chicago White Sox camp today, but the club discounted the holdout star's parting remark he was "going home to mother."

MILAN, Italy, March 14 -- A special convention desk in the lobby of the Milan Hilton is fielding inquiries these days from Soviet, functionaries, Vietnamese women in flowing dresses, Hungarian and Czechoslovak party functionaries and secretive types from Arab countries, Africa and Latin America -- all attending the 13th Congress of the Italian Communist party.
DETROIT, March 14 (AP) -- General Motors Corporation announced today a new program for the development of minority-group automobile dealers.

Governor Rockefeller wants Dr. William J. Ronan, chairman of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority, to be named executive director of the Port of New York Authority, an aide to the Governor said last night.
The heads of many of the nation's largest banking concerns, despite a sharp squeeze on their own companies' profits, received substantial increases in salary last year.
SAN JOSE, Calif., March 14 -- An all-white jury was seated today for the murder, kidnapping and criminal conspiracy trial of Angela Davis.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, March 14 (AP) -- United States military sources reported today that B-52 aircraft destroyed a major North Vietnamese jungle headquarters in eastern Cambodia last night as they flew raids to open the way for a South Vietnamese armored drive.

WASHINGTON, March 14 (AP) -- Senator Edward M. Kennedy's criticism of the United States relief commitment to Bangladesh is "a classic example of tempest in a teapot," the State Department said today.

Interest rates on short-term credit instruments jumped again yesterday in hectic money market dealings, while bond rates showed little change.
Herman Badillo, the nation's first Puerto Rican Representative, announced yesterday that he would seek re-election from the new 21st Congressional District in the South Bronx.

Dr. Geoffrey Richstone, a Park Avenue internist and cardiologist, was indicted by a Manhattan grand jury yesterday on charges of conspiracy and attempted grand larceny in the death of Gail Richards, his employe and girlfriend.

A revised capital budget for New York City was adopted early today, but two possible problems were built into it -a threatened mayoral veto over restrictions on some spending and a possible confrontation between the city and the Metropolitan Transportation Authority.

WASHINGTON, March 14 -King Hussein's reported proposal for the eventual establishment of an autonomous Palestinian state is described by United States offiicals and by diplomats here as a bold effort to shore up his deterioraing position in the Arab world.
WASHINGTON, March 14 -President Nixon will go to Canada on April 13 for two days of talks with Prime Minister Pierre Elliott Trudeau, the White House said today.

BRASILIA, March 14 -- Almost one year of high-level diplomatic activity in South America came to a chilly climax here today in a meeting of the Presidents of Brazil and Argentina, the two largest and most militarized nations on the continent.

BLOOMINGTON, Minn., March 14 (AP) -- Rich Martin, a rookie, scored two goals, including the winning one with six minutes to play, and Gil Perrault contributed two assists as the Buffalo Sabres beat the Minnesota North Stars, 4-3, tonight to snap a three-game National Hockey League losing streak.

While state losses from the strike at Aqueduct headed toward the $3-million mark yesterday, the city's Offtrack Betting Corporation continued making hay from separate action on races at out-of-state Pimlico.

SAN FRANCISCO, March 14 -- Howard R. Hughes, lean, healthy and wearing a Van Dyke beard, left Managua, Nicaragua, early today after a social visit with the President of Nicaragua and the United States Ambassador aboard his private jet.

Donald Rumsfeld, the director of the Cost of Living Council, said yesterday that he was hopeful but could not "guarantee" that the annual rate of inflation would decline to between 2 and 3 per cent by the end of this year.

If I seem to have a little glint in my eye today, a little extra spring in my step, it's because today is Kick Irving Wallace Day. Kick Irving Wallace Day is a day set aside by Eastern Establishment critics for highjinks and revelry -- a sort of literary faschung, a rag day when the critical fraternity subjects poor Mr. Wallace to a hazing with verbal paddles.

WASHINGTON, March 14 (AP) -- The United States has quietly mounted a worldwide campaign to portray the murder-conspiracy trial of Angela Davis as an example of democracy at work and to counter contentions that she is being persecuted because she is a black and a Communist.

Testing of a controversial treatment for heroin addiction -- called "carbon dioxide rapid coma therapy" -- at Philadelphia's Hahnemann Hospital has been suspended after the deaths of two addicts in the program and the exhaustion of funds.

I note that in the March 6 edition of The Times a letter writer felt it a sad commentary on our values when political leaders and zoologists sink to playing politics and one-upmanship with giant pandas. In view of our relationship with China over the past years it is very encouraging that our two countries can at least discuss something -- including giant pandas.
WASHINGTON, March 14 -- The moderate rise in total business inventories continued in January, the Commerce Department reported today.
SANTIAGO, March 14 (AP) -The president of Chile's right-wing National party was indicted today on charges brought by the leftist Government that he violated the country's internal security law.

WASHINGTON, March 14 -Transportation Secretary John A. Volpe asked Congress today to allow part of the Federal money that is carmarked for highways to be used for public transportation in the nation's cities.

Vice Adm. Noel Gayler, who flew fighters from the decks of aircraft carriers during World War II, has been named commander in chief of all United States forces in the Pacific area. The 57-year-old officer, now head of the National Security Agency, will succeed Adm. John S. McCain Jr., who is retiring this summer.

MIAMI, March 14 -- After a year of campaigning, during which most politicians and every poll agreed that Senator Edmund S. Muskie of Maine led the Democratic Presidential race, a new contest appeared to have started tonight.

A State Supreme Court jury ordered General Motors yesterday to pay $479,000 to the widow of a Bronx butcher who died following an automobile accident caused by a defective steering mechanism in his 1965 Pontiac Catalina.
YONKERS, March 14 -There was action at Yonkers Raceway tonight, but not until 4:45 P.M. less than four hours before post-time for the first race, was the decision made to go ahead.

KIAMESHA LAKE, N. Y., March 14 -- A prominent figure in world Jewish affairs warned today against what he described as "an extreme tendency" in Israel to disregard the role of the Diaspora, or Jews living outside Israel, and the Jewish state's attempt to dominate its thinking and actions.

ALBANY, March 14 -- Senate Majority Leader Earl W. Brydges announced today that he would appoint a committee of Senators to investigate the downgrading of the state's credit rating by the Standard Poor's Corporation.

Sammy Reshevsky, eight-time chess champion of the United States and the current titleholder, gave a simultaneous exhibition at the Manhattan Chess Club recently. He played 25 players and posted 22 victories, two defeats and one draw.

JERUSALEM, March 15 -- A spokesman for Premier Golda Meir said today that King Hussein "negates the cause of peace" with his new proposal for a Jordanian federation in which the West Bank, now occupied by Israel, would be an autonomous province.

The city's Housing Authority announced plans yesterday to impose a "reluctant" and "minimal" 7.5 per cent "across the board" rent increase on public housing that would affect 100,000 families beginning May 1.

ATLANTA, March 15 (UPI) -- Lieut. Gov. Lester G. Maddox today called the selection of Georgia's delegates to the Democratic National Convention a "farce, shame and disgrace" and said, "It is altogether possible that many delegates were elected by Communists, anarchists, Republicans and ragtag bands from out of state."
Trans World Airlines announced yesterday the nomination of Mrs. Jewel Stradford Lafontant, a Chicago attorney, and David Packard, former Secretary of Defense, to its board of directors.

It would surely be more appropriate if Mayor Lindsay wore a black armband at the St. Patrick's Day parade in New York in remembrance of the innocent people who have died in Northern Ireland at the hands of the I.R.A. [Mayor Lindsay on March 1 said he would wear a black armband as a memorial tribute to the thirteen killed on "Bloody Sunday."]
A customs Inspector and three other persons have been arrested in connection with a $20-million marijuana smuggling operation from Jamaica in the West Indies to Kennedy International Airport here.

The proposed new city expense budget contains a startling 48 per cent increase in the cost of debt service. Debt service for the year 1972-73 is estimated to cost $1.023 billion, an increase of $330 million over the current figure of $693 million.

WASHINGTON, March 15 -- Secretary of the Interior Rogers C. B. Morton set aside today 274 million acres of Federal land in Alaska for possible selection by Alaskan natives and the state government and for a reserve for possible future use.
Philadelphia dock workers staged a wildcat walkout that closed the port at midday yesterday and threatened to blossom into a full-fledged strike today.
WASHINGTON, March 15 -- The House voted today to authorize an additional $174-million subsidy for the Government-backed network of passenger trains.
A 34-year-old Queens man was indicted yesterday for the murder of his wife last October in what a county grand jury said was an effort to reap $600,000 in life insurance payments.

WASHINGTON, March 15 -- A Miami-based company that is reported to have a link with Haiti's National Defense and Interior Minister is employing a group of former American marines to train members of the Hatian armed forces, and the United States Government is investigating the legality of the arrangement.
WASHINGTON, March 15 (AP) -- The Postal Service absolved the Penn Central Railroad today of any blame in the disappearance for more than two years of a railroad car loaded with parcel post packages.
DALLAS, March 15 (AP) -- Duane Thomas is optimistic about continuing his career in professional football but not, he insists, at the sacrifice of his individuality and pride.

Dr. Frank Stanton, vice chairman of the Columbia Broadcasting System, and Mrs. Ellen Peck, author of "The Baby Trap," differed sharply yesterday on the role of television in informing the public on the population crisis.

Wiltold Malcuzynski has not given a recital here since 1963. Perhaps one reason the Polish pianist decided to return once more is that this is the 30th anniversary of his American debut, which he made in Carnegie Hall.

WASHINGTON, March 15 (UPI) -- A ceiling imposed last year on subsidies to big farmers had "no significant effect'' because they were allowed legally to subdivide their farms, an Agriculture Department report to Congress said today.

WASHINGTON, March 15 -- The vice chairman of the Federal Reserve Board assailed the news media today, contending that they are "being used to undermine the credibility of everyone who represents authority."
WASHINGTON, March 15 -- Representative John M. Murphy charged today that an investigation into heroin smuggling into the United States had touched the "highest levels" of the Government of Panama.

BONN, March 15 -- West Germany's Economics and Finance Minister, Karl Schiller, announced today that a 10 per cent anti-inflationary surtax imposed for 12 months on all taxpayers in 1970-71 would be repaid on June 15.

BRADENTON, Fla., March 15 -- The New York Mets, who seem to keep winning in spite of their troubles, treated themselves today to a 9-4 victory over the world-champion Pittsburgh Pirates, against whom they open the season three weeks from tomorrow.

The Florida Power Corporation reported yesterday that operating revenues increased by 11.6 per cent to $176,539,619 in 1971 This compared with $158,144,572 a year earlier. Net income of $35,231,529, or $3.14 a share, compared with $31,204,306, or $3.08 a share on fewer shares, in 1970.

Taking a best-selling novel of more drive than genius (Mario Puzo's "The Godfather"), about a subject of something less than common experience (the Mafia), involving an isolated portion of one very particular ethnic group (first-generation and second-generation Italian-Americans), Francis Ford Coppola has made one of the most brutal and moving chronicles of American life ever designed within the limits of popular entertainment.

Human Resources Administrator Jule M. Sugarman said yesterday that the disruption and expense generated by a rapidly expanding number of addicts on welfare -- many of whom use their relief checks to buy drugs -- threatened to "paralyze" the city's welfare system.
" Do you like your dress?" the designer asked solicitously. Michele Biondi, aged 2, blew him a kiss. Adolfo beamed.
BURNSIDE, La., March 15 -- A protest is building against the resumption of United States imports of strategic materials from Rhodesia.

The upward thrust in short-term interest rates spread noticeably to other sectors of the credit markets yesterday as underwriters and investors expressed increased fears of renewed inflation and heavy demands for credit.

DATIL, N. M., March 15 -- The Federal Government proposed plans today to build the world's largest scientific instrument -- a mammoth radio telescope to view the horizons of the universe -- east of here inside a huge playa guarded by mountains where Geronimo once roamed.

Mrs. Eleanor Holmes Norton, chairman of the New York City Commission on Human Rights, is quoted in The Times of March 7 as stating that "reverse quotas" or preferential hiring of minority workers is "clearly unconstitutional." This assertion is directly contradicted by an extensive body of legal decisions in which Federal courts have recognized that race-conscious injuries require race-conscious remedies.

LONDON, March 15 -- Prime Minister Heath today invited Brian Faulkner, Prime Minister of Northern Ireland, to London next week amid indications that, after weeks of agonizing, the British Government was near a decision on a plan of political reform aimed at breaking the deadlock and reducing the violence in the province.
The over-the-counter market did somewhat better than the American Stock Exchange yesterday although neither market showed a definite trend.

His Presidential candidacy alive but hardly healthy after the Florida primary, Mayor Lindsay said yesterday that his immediate job was to raise at least $300,000 to wage an effective campaign in the Wisconsin primary less than three weeks away.

Miss Alyce Patricia Hill, an instructor of French at Vassar College and a doctoral candidate at New York University, was married here last evening to Criminal Court Judge Bruce McM. Wright. Criminal Court Judge Alfred Kleiman performed the ceremony at the bridegroom's apartment.

EVANSVILLE, Ind., March 15 (AP) -- Top-ranked Tennessee State used its height to dominate the backboards today and overwhelmed Southampton of Long Island, 95-55, in the quarterfinals of the National Collegiate college-division basketball tournament.
VAL GARDENA, Italy, March 15 -- Bernhard Russi of Switzerlan became the fastest ski racer in history today when he won a World Cup downhill race at an average speed of 66.4 miles an hour.
Eight men from Wall Street and elsewhere in American industry have been selected for the sensitive task of nominating a new board of directors for the New York Stock Exchange.

The promotion of four vice presidents to new positions of senior vice president and appointment of a new vice president were announced yesterday by Arthur Ochs Sulzberger, president and publisher of The New York Times.

WASHINGTON, March 15 -- Hubert H. Humphrey left Florida for Wisconsin today with apparently undiminished confidence in a campaign strategy that includes a decidedly indirect approach to the political phenomenon of George C. Wallace.
NEW HAVEN, March 15 (AP) -- Yale University's 46-man police force will put a woman on the beat tomorrow. She is 22-year-old Mary Almasov, who has a college degree herself.
BEIRUT, March 15 -- Palestinian guerrilla leaders have been meeting here to work out their strategy toward King Hussein's plan.

The Continental Corporation, one of the nation's leading insurance holding companies, told stockholders at the annual meeting here yesterday that its efforts to bring Diners' Club operations into the black were showing improvement.

Faulkner, Dawkins Sullivan Securities, Inc., manager of the underwriting group, has announced a public offering of 400,000 shares of Telco Marketing Services, Inc., common stock at $21 per share. Telco leases medical and scientific equipment to hospitals and clinical laboratories.

WASHINGTON, March 15 -- "Send Them a Message," said George Wallace's billboards in Florida, and no one can deny that his 42 per cent of the Democratic primary vote in that state has delivered the word, loud and clear, to the politicians, the press, the pointy-headed intellectuals, the bureaucrats and the liberals.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, March 15 -- King Hussein of Jordan today announced his plan to convert his kingdom into a federated state with two autonomous regions but gave no indication of how he would return one of the regions -- the Israeli-occupied West Bank -- to Jordanian control.
TOKYO, March 15 -- The United States and Japan today exchanged documents ratifying the agreement signed last June on restoration of the Ryukyu Islands to Japanese administration.

NEWARK, March 15 -- The Public Service Electric and Gas Company announced plans today to anchor two floating nuclear-generating stations three miles off New Jersey and to put them into operation by 1980.
WASHINGTON, March 15 (AP) -- Congress gave approval today to an increase of the national debt ceiling.

The Bowater Paper Corporation, Ltd., omitted its year-end dividend for the first time in years, reflecting the 50.1 per cent drop in earnings last year. Net income plummeted to $9,445,000 from $18,964,000 in 1970, the company reported in London yesterday.
WASHINGTON, March 15 -- The deficit in the nation's "basic" balance of international payments shrank in the fourth quarter of last year, the Commerce Department reported today.

WASHINGTON, March 15 -- The sense of satisfaction at the White House over yesterday's favorable vote for President Nixon in the Florida primary was tempered somewhat today by another reminder that the Republican right wing was not yet prepared to give full support to the Nixon candidacy.

BOSTON, March 15 -- The Boston branch of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People, accusing the city's school officials of racial segregation and discrimination, filed suit in United States District Court here today calling for equalized school spending and the linking of city and suburban schools to achieve integrated classrooms.

Long before the 1971 election, it was clear that Uruguay's traditional democracy could survive only if large segments of the two big parties would work together to revive the economy, end Tupamaro terrorism and rebuild national unity. The failure of a leftist coalition at the polls showed that President Allende's pattern in Chile was not the inexorable wave of the future in the Americas, but it did not insure Uruguay's survival in freedom.

LONDON, March 15 -- The Government tonight announced allocations of new blocks in the North Sea for oil and gas exploration, with the hope that by 1980 they might be supplying Britain with 50 million tons of oil a year.
ABILENE, Tex., March 15 (AP) -- Gus Mutscher, Speaker of the Texas House, and two aides were convicted today of conspiracy to accept a bribe.

The Chicago Mercantile Exchange, which plans to start trading soon in foreign currencies, announced yesterday that it was offering 250 memberships in the International Monetary Market, the exchange's new currency-trading division, at a cost of $10,000 each.

SAN JOSE, Calif., March 15 (UPI) -- Angela Davis took a personal hand in her murder-kidnapping trial again today by interrogating a potential alternate juror at length about racism, violence in America and the rhetoric of revolutionaries.

The fad of lawlessness will very soon cross the threshold into anarchy when the first airliner disintegrates in midair. This historic event is in the immediate future. It may occur before this letter is read.
PHOENIX, Ariz., March 15 (AP) -- Charlie Scott made his National Basketball Association debut tonight as the Phoenix Suns rallied for a 110-106 victory over the Milwaukee Bucks.

MIAMI, March 15 -- There were not many cheers for democracy here this morning as the Democrats' round-robin spring tournament packed off to the Middle West. The men who finished fourth, fifth and sixth were denouncing 40 per cent of the electorate as dupes of the demagogues.

Needham, Harper Steers, the country's 16th largest agency, with gross billings last year of $143.8-million, yesterday filed a registration statement with the Securities and Exchange Commission o make a public stock offering.
ALBANY, March 15 -- Although black and Jewish legislators differed sharply today, the Assembly approved a bill to ban antipoverty elections in New York City on the Sabbath.
WASHINGTON, March 15 -- Antiwar groups announced today plans for a demonstration at the White House March 26 as the start of their spring protests against President Nixon's policy on the Vietnam war.

ALBANY, March 15 -- Senator Roy M. Goodman, today was named chairman of a Senate committee to investigate the private concerns that determine the state's credit rating by evaluating the state's tax-exempt bonds.

The Ansonia Hotel, which has been the home of many intellectuals, musicians and artists, has been designated an official landmark, it was announced yesterday by the city's Landmarks Preservation Commission.

BRASILIA, March 15 -- Argentina and Brazil agreed today to ignore, at least formally, their differences over trade and hydroelectric power development in rivers that flow through both countries, and to seek means of cooperation.
WASHINGTON, March 15 -- The Federal Communications Commission took a step today toward the long-sought goal of setting up the nation's first domestic communications satellite system.
BELFAST, Northern Ireland, March 15 (AP) -- Two British Army bomb experts were killed tonight by a bomb they were trying to defuse.
Although the poodle ranks No. 1 of the 116 breeds in the American Kennel Club stud book, a proud perch he has occupied since displacing the beagle in 1960, in Japan he's just another breed.

A State Supreme Court justice has ruled that the State Commissioner of Environmental Conservation acted "in excess of his authority and in violation of law" in granting a water quality standards certificate for Consolidated Edison's proposed Storm King power plant.
When Albert Frank opened his one-room, two-man ad agency in lower Manhattan it caused no stir in the Wall Street community.

A challenge to the constitutionality of jury panels in State Supreme Court in Queens was dismissed yesterday before two more jurors were seated in the murder-arson trial of Mark Holder, a Black Panther.

PARIS, March 15 (AP) -- The Communist delegations to the Vietnam peace talks agreed today to a proposal by the United States and South Vietnamese negotiators that they meet tomorrow. It will be the first session of the peace talks in three weeks.
MIAMI, March 15 -- Senator Edmund S. Muskie, abandoning a low-key centrist style, sought today to recast himself as an underdog liberal challenger for the Democratic Presidential nomination.

The John Hancock Mutual Life Insurance Company recommended yesterday to the Federal District Court in Philadelphia the "immediate discharge" of the Penn Central Transportation Company from reorganization under Section 77 of the Federal Bankruptcy Act.

ATLANTA, March 15 (UPI) -- The Atlanta Hawks trounced the crippled Seattle SuperSonics, 134-96, tonight. The victory gave the Hawks a four-game lead over the Cincinnati Royals in the race for a Central Division playoff berth.

FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla., March 15 -- For the fifth time in their 13 exhibition games, the Yankees were shut out tonight as the Minnesota Twins beat them, 3-0. But at least three observers were impressed by the New Yorkers.
PHILADELPHIA, March 15 -- The Governors of Pennsylvania and New Jersey met here this afternoon in an effort to avert a shutdown of the Central Railroad of New Jersey.

WASHINGTON, March 15 -- Thelma Catherine Ryan Nixon, better known as Pat to her husband and as the First Lady of the land to the nation, will be 60 tomorrow. But she will celebrate her birthday, with a nod to her Irish ancestry, on St. Patrick's Day, Friday.

Some 90 physicians from the Sea View Hospital and Home on Staten Island, who tendered resignations to the Health and Hospitals Corporation to protest the make-up of the hospital's community board, refused to remain at the hospital and left yesterday, a spokesman for the corporation said.

The Justice Department yesterday opposed the proposed merger of Northwest Airlines and National Airlines. In a brief filed with the Civil Aeronautics Board, the Justice Department said that the "very modest public benefits" that the merger would produce are outweighed by its " anticompetitive effects." In its brief, the Justice Department also warned the C.A.B. against the potential for " undue concentration" in the airline industry posed by pending mergers of carriers.

PHILADELPHIA, March 15 -- The informer who collaborated with the Federal Bureau of Investigation in the "Camden 28" case said in an affidavit filed today that the bureau had used him as a "provocateur."
Any mayoral veto of a restriction on some spending written into the city's $1.8-billion capital budget would be overridden, a poll of the Board of Estimate indicated yesterday.

A State Appellate Division judge yesterday granted a stay of a 30-day jail term ordered for Edwin A. Goodman, manager of radio station WBAI, on contempt-of-court charges.

WASHINGTON, March 15 -- A coalition of Senate Republicans and Southern Democrats succeeded today in killing legislation that would have established a national system of voter registration by postal card.
Representative William F. Ryan said yesterday that he would seek re-election in the 20th Congressional District and that he could not "conceive" of Representative Bella Abzug's running against him.

ALBANY, March 15 (AP) -- Correction officers at four New York State prisons have voted to strike at the end of the month unless the state meets their pay demands and speeds up its promised prison reform.

WASHINGTON, March 15 -- The Price Commission, after reviewing staff studies projecting the results of its current price policies, embarked today on a program of more restrictive controls.

WASHINGTON, March 15 -- Harold S. Geneen, president of the International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation, swore today that "there was absolutely no connection" between his company's pledge of up to $200,000 toward the expenses of the Republican National Convention and the Justice Department's settlement of three antitrust suits against the concern.

DUBAI, Union of Arab Emirates, March 15 (Reuters) -- There apparently were no survivors in the crash yesterday of a Danish chartered airliner with 112 persons aboard as it wag trying to land here to refuel.

EAST BURKE, Vt., March 15 -- Here near the Green Mountain State's rooftop, Burke Mountain is getting ready to join the St. Patrick's Day parade. It is following the shamrock trail blazed by Brodie Mountain in the Berkshires and subsequently by Hunter in the Catskills.

MOSCOW, March 15 -- The most direct route for fresh produce from farm to dinner table, as any Soviet housewife knows, is not through the Government's bureaucracy-ridden food marketing network but through the collective-farm markets, the last remnants of private enterprise.

LONDON, March 15 -- Basil Reay, secretary of the International Lawn Tennis Federation, said today that World Championship Tennis's decision not to allow its professionals to play at Wimbledon need not mean the end of open tennis.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, March 15 (UPI) -- Iraq offered tonight to join with Egypt and Syria immediately to prevent a breakup of Arab solidarity that she said was threatened by King Hussein's plan to create a Palistanian state within his kingdom, the Baghdad radio said.

GARY, Ind., March 15 -- Mayor Richard G. Hatcher sought today to soften the sense of antibusing resolutions passed last weekend by the National Black Political Convention here, and he called a resolution to "dismantle" Israel "very unfortunate."

WASHINGTON, March 15 (UPI) -- President Nixon told Congress today that he thought the economy would expand enough this year to provide many new jobs, but he said that additional manpower training efforts were also needed to cut back the unemployment rate.
American Baptists stopped supplying military chaplains to the Navy yesterday in protest against that service's handling of a case against a chaplain.
Ronald E. Galella, a freelance photographer, testified in Federal Court here yesterday that two young women had helped him get pictures of Mrs. Aristotle Onassis and members of her family.

UNIONDALE, L. I., March 15 -- Rick Barrel exploded for 20 points in the last quarter and led all scorers with 43 points tonight while leading the New York Nets to a 119-112 victory over the Memphis Pros before 6,321 fans in the Nassau Coliseum.

Parents of children in four downstate schools for the retarded took to the streets yesterday to demonstrate for improvements in the care for their children. They said everything else -- protests, pleas and publicity -- had failed.

MIAMI, March 15 (UPI) -- Farewell Party, a 4-year-old grandson of Native Dancer, won his first race since he captured the Governor Handicap at Belmont Park last September, as he recorded a half-length victory today in the $33,100 Royal Palm Handicap at Hialeah.

STANFORD, Calif. -- Now that the People's Republic of China has been admitted to the United Nations and American leaders are jetting to Peking, it is inevitable that we will be hearing more proposals for trade and aid to help the Chinese bring themselves up to "our standard of living."

KIAMESHA LAKE, N. Y., March 15 -- The newly elected president of the Rabbinical Assembly, the international movement of Conservative rabbis, called on the American Jewish community today to meet "head on" the problems raised by the black revolution and the role of Jewish women in religious life.

WASHINGTON, March 15 (AP) -- Major stock exchanges urged today that if the negotiated commission rate was further lowered it should be done on a gradual step-by-step basis to test the over-all impact on the securities market.

SEOUL, South Korea, March 15 -- South Korea is taking a skeptical attitude toward the recent overtures by North Korea for a peace agreement and political discussions between the two parts of this divided country.

MIAMI, March 15 -- The Democratic Presidential cavalcade moved from Southern sunshine into the blustery Midwest today after a Florida primary that seemed to all the candidates to have opened wide the contest for the nomination.

WASHINGTON, March 15 -- Secretary of Defense Melvin R. Laird told Congress today that it would have to assume responsibility for "a gap in free world security" if it failed to approve the full $2.l5-billion in foreign military aid that the Administration had requested for the year beginning July 1.

SAN DIEGO, Calif., March 15 (UPI) -- Willie C. Henderson, convicted of killing a policeman was senteced to death yesterday even though such a sentence has been held unconstitutional by the California Supreme Court.

VIETNIANE, Laos, March 15 (AP) -- Control of a ridge over-looking the key base of Long Tieng reportedly passed to the North Vietnamese yesterday and back to the Laotians today as enemy pressure slackened somewhat.
MINEOLA, L. I., March 15 -- Long Island's population growth rate has slowed to the lowest in nearly two decades, according to the Long Island Lighting Company.

The strike that has kept Aqueduct racetrack closed to thoroughbred racing since March 6, continued yesterday, with picket lines drawn up at the entrances to the Big A. So far nine racing days have been canceled, with a financial loss to the state treasury calculated at $3-million.

The score sheet of the Florida primary indicates that a majority of the voters were united on just one issue -- opposition to school busing. This message is certain to affect those who plan their candidates' campaign strategies, Republican and Democrat alike.

PHILADELPHIA, March 15 (AP) -- The Boston Celtics clinched at least a tie for the National Basketball Association's Atlantic Division title tonight with a 120-115 victory over the Philadelphia 76ers behind a late scoring outburst by Dave Cowens.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, March 15 (UPI) -- The United States command today ordered its second largest pullout of troops from the war zone, with the deactivation of 42 Air Force and Army units that total 5,700 men. Last July 42 units totaling 6,100 men were withdrawn.

HONOLULU -- Military withdrawal from Asia causes the United States to fall back strategically upon its huge Pacific empire about which most Americans are almost wholly unaware. They do, of course, know that Hawaii is now a state of the Union and that this same political condition applies to Alaska's barren and sparsely inhabited Aleutian archipelago extending toward Soviet Siberia and Japan.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, March 16 (AP) -- A large increase in enemy attacks in South Vietnam was reported today by the Saigon command.

WASHINGTON, March 16 -Lending by banks to borrowers in foreign countries contributed a substantial amount to the deficit in the nation's balance of international payments last year for the first time since controls on this kind of lending were imposed, a member of the Federal Reserve Board said today.

Two men convicted of murdering six persons and wounding several others in Salt Lake City in 1966 will be the subject of a one-hour documentary Tuesday, April 18, at 8:30 P.M. on the National Broadcasting Company network.

WASHINGTON, March 16 -Transportation Secretary John A. Volpe's plan to use some of the Federal highway money for public transportation received a cool reception today from the first Congressional committee to get a crack at it.

MOSCOW, March 16 -- President Zulfikar Ali Bhutto of Pakistan arrived in Moscow today in an apparent effort to mend political and economic relations impaired by the Soviet Union's advocacy of independence for Bangladesh, the former East Pakistan.

JACKSONVILLE, Fla., March 16 (AP) -- Frank Beard registered a 4-under-par 68 today to gain the first-round lead in the $125,000 Greater Jacksonville open golf tournament, which was interrupted for almost an hour by a heavy rain shower.

WASHINGTON, March 16 -- A Presidential study commission formally recommended today that all states -- following New York's example -- greatly liberalize abortion laws and permit a doctor to perform an abortion at a patient's request.

Fifty years ago this day, a young exiled Irishman, Patrick Conner, made the mistake of coming to Fifth Avenue to witch the green-decked marchers on Saint Paddy's Day. He should have stayed at home. Conner was trapped into being the victim of the only known shooting staged by the Irish Republican Army on the sidewalks of New York.

AMES, Iowa, March 16 (AP) -- Louisville contained Southwestern Louisiana's two leading scorers tonight and registered an 88-84 victory in a Midwest Regional semifinal of the National Collegiate basketball tournament.

WASHINGTON, March 16 -House Democratic leaders assailed the Administration's economic policies today as they proposed a $5-billion crash program to construct community facilities and provide jobs for the unemployed.

ROME, March 16 -- The Milan police said tonight that Giangiacomo Feltrinelli, a left-wing millionaire publisher, had been found dead in a field near the city, apparently the victim of an explosive charge as he was preparing to blow up a power line pylon.

The unspoken premise of Harold A. Meriam Jr.'s letter of March 6 is that our original Federal Constitution of 1787 treated slaves as "nonpersons." On the contrary, in no fewer than three clauses, slaves were explicitly referred to as "Persons" -- the Enumeration clause (art. 1, 2, cl. 3), the Slave Trade clause (art. 1, 9 cl. 1), and the Fugitive Slave clause (art. IV, 2 cl. 3).

ALBANY, March 16 -- A special state panel created after the Attica prison revolt in September offered more than 30 recommendations today for changes in the state's prison system, but skirted the question of how much money such changes would require.

PROVO, Utah, March 16 (AP) -- The University of California, Los Angeles, getting excellent outside shooting from Henry Bibby and Larry Farmer, defeated Weber State tonight for its 42d straight victory, 9058, in a Far West Regional semifinal of the National Collegiate basketball tournament.

Though I've lived more than half my life in the States, am an American citizen (which I expect to remain), have acquired a short a and that wonderful verb gotten and have learned to say aside from instead of apart from. I cannot, of course, call myself an American. I do, however, think of myself as a New Yorker and believe that I shall continue to think so, even in Oxford.

WARSAW, March 17 -- A 24-year-old student from New York has been held by the Polish authorities for a month, as part of an investigation into the smuggling of synthetic diamonds, a United States Embassy spokesman said today.

BOSTON, March 17 (AP) -- Dave Westner, a senior from Toronto, scored four goals for Cornell tonight to lead his team to a 7-2 victory over Denver in a semifinal of the 25th National Collegiate hockey tournament at Boston Garden.

Federal Judge Anthony J. Travia yesterday rejected a plea by Carmine J. Persico for a new trial on hijacking charges. The petition was made after a key prosecution witness had recanted his testimony.

JACKSONVILLE, Fla., March 17 -- The examination of prospective jurors continued today in the military trial of Comdr. Andrew F. Jensen, who is believed to be the first chaplain in the 197-year history of the Navy to face a general court-martial.

An over-the-counter aerosol spray sold to relieve asthma suffering has come under attack from Attorney General Louis K. Lefkowitz's Consumer Frauds and Protection Bureau for the advertising claims made for it on the speed of its action.
The American Stock Exchange and the over-the-counter market showed no definite trend yesterday as both lists finished mostly mixed in slower trading.

Some of the surprise was dissipated in Philharmonic Hall Thursday night, when Mr. Levine conducted the New York Philharmonic for the first time.

ATHENS, March 17 -- Fifteen persons, including three lawyers and three physicians, went on trial today before a military tribunal on charges of illegal possession and use of explosives, which carry possible life sentences.

The city's two other dailies have discussed the positive and negative aspects of the proposal while The Times has only treated the matter peripherally.

WASHINGTON, March 17 -- President Nixon's move against busing, like the rapprochement with China and the resort to wage and price controls, will stand among his bold reversals of the policies of several Administrations.

WASHINGTON, March 17 -- President Nixon's call for a halt in forced busing of school-children left Democratic candidates for the Presidency further divided today, Southerners far from satisfied and some Congressional leaders dubious about the constitutionality of the move.

The Public Service Electric and Gas Company reported yesterday a gain of 35 per cent in net income for 1971 on an increase of 19 per cent in total operating revenues. The company's annual report placed revenues at $8885,506,000 against $741,252,000 a year earlier.

Directors of the Kendall Company and the Colgate-Palmolive Company agreed yesterday on a plan for Colgate to acquire Kendall, an ethical-drug, textile and hygienic-products producer, in a tax-free transaction.

The United States Postal Serivce will issue a stamp today commemorating family planning -- a move that proponents of birth control feel constitutes an important recognition of their respectability by the Nixon Administration.

WASHINGTON, March 17 (UPI) -- Senator Henry M. Jackson, Democrat of Washington, announced today that Representative Samuel S. Stratton, Democrat of upstate New York, would be chairman of the Jackson for President organization in New York.

No one whose ears are properly connected to his central nervous system can possibly fail to become excited at an Earl Wild recital. PARIS, March 17 -- The dollar put on a good show of strength in the European financial centers today in response to higher interest rates in New York and President Pompidou's signal that French monetary attacks against the United States are being called off, at least for the time being.

Paced by Eastman Kodak blue-chip stocks provided a generally flat market yesterday with some hefty gains. The net result was an upswing of 6.17 in the Dow-Jones industrial average, which closed at 942.88, while advances and declines were nearly even on the New York Stock Exchange.

WASHINGTON, March 17 -- The boom in housing continued in February at a record annual rate of almost 2.7 million starts, the Commerce Department reported today.

President Pompidou's decision to call a referendum in France on expansion of the European Economic Community to ten members is baffling, to put it mildly. WASHINGTON, March 17 -- A long-lived heart pacer with a radioactive power source has been invented for the Atomic Energy Commission and the National Heart and Lung Institute. David L. Purdy, an electromechanical cal engineer, was granted Patent 3,649,367 this week.

WASHINGTON, March 17 -- The Citizens Advisory Council on the Status of Women called on President Nixon today to endorse the proposed equal rights amendment to the Constitution.

WASHINGTON, March 17 -- A proposed trademark treaty, which may save considerable sums for American companies doing an international business, will be discussed next week. Economies are expected not only in filing fees but in administrative expense for both government and industry.

WARSAW, March 17 -- The possibility that the West German Parliament will fail to ratify nonaggression treaties with Warsaw and Moscow this spring is creating a climate of apprehension throughout Eastern Europe.

HANOI, North Vietnam, March 17 -- Three American labor leaders were greeted with bouquets today on their arrival to begin a one-week visit whose aim is, in the words of one, "to do what we can to see an end to this immoral and senseless war."

SANTA CLARA, Calif., March 17 (AP) -- A young woman who took fertility drugs for four years gave birth to seven babies today. Two were stillborn and two died five hours after their birth.

GRAFTON, N. H. -- Running far ahead of the dogs on two feet of snow and under a bright New Hampshire sky, the Gray Ghost of the Grafton Hills eluded us all afternoon.

The article "Reforming Pension Plans" (Feb. 27) repeated an insistent clamor for he establishment of portability in pension plans. This is one of the few topics about the provisions in pension plans which has been presented almost invariably in a favorable light.

PHILADELPHIA, March 18 -- The New York Rangers overcame the rough-hitting Philadelphia Flyers tonight in the Spectrum, 5-3, scoring four goals in the final period. One of them came on a power-play and another slid into an empty cage.
If we're not careful, someone's going to give advertising a good name.

BRUSSELS, March 19 -- Suddenly, there is a boom for convertible securities on the Eurobond market.
WASHINGTON, March 19 -China has become in recent months an outspoken champion of the claim made by Latin-American countries to sovereignty over 200 miles of sea adjoining their coasts.

It is unfortunate Senator Muskie plans only minimal rank-and-file participation in his choice of national convention delegates who will run in the June Democratic primary here. Unlike your report that Senator McGovem will hold open public caucuses to set up slates, Senator Muskie can do no better than "setting a time and place in each district for interested Democrats to apply" to run for delegate (news story March 2).

Albert Shanker, the teachers union leader, refused to attend the annual luncheon of the Jewish Teachers Association yesterday because the guest speaker was Rabbi Meir Kahane, head of the militant Jewish Defense League.

HONG KONG, March 19 (UPI) -- Hsinhua, the Chinese press agency, reported today that Chinese archeologists had recently discovered the huge tombs of two medieval princes near the tomb of Empress Wu Tsetien of the Tang Dynasty, who ruled from 690 to 705 A.D.

MILWAUKEE, March 19 -Democratic contenders in Wisconsin's April 4 Presidential primary have begun returning here for a grueling final two weeks of campaigning in what is widely considered to be a showdown vital to the interests of several of them.

CINCINNATI, March 19 -- The national open pair championship, the opening event in the American Contract Bridge League's Spring Nationals here, was won last night by Barry Crane of Los Angeles and Dr. John Fisher of Dallas.

The water-pollution control bill, which Senator Muskie sponsored and his colleagues long ago approved by a vote of 86 to 0, is even more far-reaching and hence in worse trouble. Between heavy fire from industry and moderate fire from the Administration the Senate bill may be shot down, or existing controls may be seriously weakened in the name of improvement.

Elisabeth Schwarzkopf, her famous million - candlepower smile beaming light to the farthest crannies of Carnegie Hall, stood onstage at the conclusion of her recital Sunday afternoon like a queen accepting the homage of her loving subjects.

MOSCOW, March 19 -- The Soviet Union, after much delay, has begun production of a new series of advanced computers on which Russian economic planners have been counting to solve their country's critical shortage of computing power.

LOS ANGELES, March 19 -In the New Hampshire and Florida primaries, young people tended to vote for candidates who were more liberal than those the electorate as a whole tended to support. But the young did not vote differently enough, or often enough, to have a drastic effect on the results.
One of the oldest civil rights organizations in the country celebrated its 34th anniversary here yesterday by reaffirming its goals and by changing its guard.

CHICAGO, March 19 -- About 1,600 representatives of black, Spanish-speaking and white ethnic community groups in 50 cities organized an angry national protest here this weekend against the institutions they say are responsible for the systematic destruction of large areas of the central cities.

At the Theater of the Lost Continent (113 Jane Street) in Westbeth, Donald L. Brooks has staged an all-male "Trojan Women." Next month Joseph Papp will open an all-male "Antony and Cleopatra" at the Public Theater.
WESTON, Conn., March 19 -- Mrs. Marila Russell, wife of the owner of Meadowbrook Farm in Canton, rode Park Avenue to the regular working hunter championship today at the Nimrod Farm horse show.
WHITE PLAINS, March 19 -Of 20 villages holding elections, there will be contests in 15 for trustees and in one, Buchanan, for Mayor.

ACCRA, Ghana, March 19 -- Two months after staging the coup d'etat in which one of Africa's last democracies fell, Col. Ignatius K. Acheampong has gained firm control of this steamy land, and his popularity seems to be growing.

Your editorial "Scrooge Goes to the Races" (March 9), pointing out that as soon as New York City finds a device for increasing its revenues -- in this instance, offtrack betting -- "the state comes along to grab control of the money," underlines, all too unhappily, the omnipotence of the state and the impotence of the city in the control of public revenues.
BRANDS HATCH, England, March 19 (AP) -- Emerson Fittipaldi of Brazil turned in a superb display of driving today for an impressive victory in the Formula 1 Race of Champions auto race.

For Frank Abruzzo, a bartender, and the rest of the staff of the Lincoln Square Motor Inn on West 66th Street, the rapprochement between Peking and the West became a harsh and inconvenient reality yesterday, spelling unemployment.
MILWAUKEE, March 19 -Mayor Lindsay proposed today a Federal Bill of Rights for workers that would include guaranteed employment, job security and free health care.
Spring, a little early this year, thanks to Leap Year, arrives at 7:22 A.M. today as the sun crosses the equator to spend six months in the Northern Hemisphere.
The city administration is redoubling its efforts to keep any neighborhood-government referendum off this year's ballot. It looks as if the effort will work.
HINCKLEY, Ohio, March -19 -- The buzzards returned to Hinckley today pursued by 25,000 curious sightseers eager for some reason, for a glimpse of the bald-headed birds.
