For the last two years, Mr. Sit has managed the IDS New Dimensions Fund, an aggressive growth fund with assets now totaling $240-million.

WASHINGTON, March 19 -- The Justice Department has refused to provide the Senate Judiciary Committee with the departments files on the settlement of antitrust suits against the International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation.

CHICAGO, March 19 -- Democratic primaries in Chicago and the rest of Illinois have usually been comfortable affairs, a relaxed time in which to oil up the party machinery and give the precinct captains a warm-up for November.

I question the analogy between the suggestion for a cease-fire in Vietnam and the conciliatory British proposal of the Carlisle Peace Commission in the American Revolution. Prof. North Callahan [letter March 5] is correct in his observation that in fact the Continental Congress did turn down what amounted to a cease-fire proposal, but I take issue with his explanation.

A month-long advance in short-term interest rates, which accelerated last week as Wall Street became convinced that the Federal Reserve had modified its aggressively easy credit policy, seems likely to continue for some time.

MINNEAPOLIS -- Laurie Hanson is a bouncing, blond 4-year-old whose day begins at 7:30 each weekday morning when her mother, who works in a nearby factory, leaves her at the Learning Tree day-care center in suburban Robbinsdale.
PRA LOUP, France, March 19 -- Gustavo Thoeni, who speaks four languages but is usually quiet, let his skis do his talking today and won the men's World Cup for the second straight season.

OAKLAND, Calif., March 19 (AP) -- Senator George McGovern won the backing of the California Democratic Council today after two days of back-room politicking and bickering by the grass-roots group of party volunteer workers.
LAHORE, Pakistan, March 19 -- President Zulfikar Ali Bhutto, who returned here last night from Moscow, indicated today that a peace settlement on the subcontinent was as distant as ever.

PEKING, March 19 -- Premier Chou En-lai charged tonight at a banquet for the former Cambodian Head of State, Prince Norodom Sihanouk, that "certain powers" were creating a "third force" to seek a compromise solution in Cambodia in an attempt to split the ranks of the Prince's government in exile.

SELEMANI, Cyprus, March 19 -- Two old people came home today -- a man, bent and gnarled like the branches of the battered trees of this hillside village, and his wife, so aged and spent that when she was lifted off the truck that brought her she could only sit on the ground with her back leaning against the shins of a woman posted behind her.
WEST PALM BEACH, Fla., March 19 -- Orlando Cepeda and Jerry Koosmen impressed Gil Hodges today as the Atlanta Braves defeated the New York Mets, 3-1.

ALBANY, March 19 -- In the Congressional reapportionment approved by the Republican-controlled Legislature 11 days ago, the new districts were often molded to exclude or include specific ethnic groups to the advantage of favored incumbent Congressmen.
ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 19 (UPI) -- Carol Mann shot a four-under-par 68 today to win the $20,000 Orange Blossom golf tournament with a three-round total of 213.
Earl Monroe is the latest Knick casualty.
PATCHOGUE, L. I., March 19 -- There will be contests in four of 12 villages holding elections in Suffolk County. A total of 17 other villages will hold elections in June.

Was ever a pop group more accurately named than Bread? For those who've lived in Afghanistan for the last five years, "bread" is a commonly used euphemism for money, and the pleasantly melodic rock produced by Bread -- the group -- has made it one of the most successful rock bands in the country.

A secondary offering of 435,000 shares of Seaboard Coast Line Industries, Inc., common stock, which a Morgan Stanley Co. group had been expected to make on March 9, now is scheduled for this Thursday. The shares are being offered for sale by estates of one of the founders of the former Atlantic Coast Line Railroad.
WASHINGTON, March 19 -President Nixon will ask Congress tomorrow to enact legislation aimed at providing more private investment money to help minority business.
PARIS, March 19 -- This year's Theatre des Nations Festival will have some novel, experimental features, according to its new director, Jean-Louis Barrault.
WASHINGTON, March 19 -- To his admirers, Peter M. Flanigan is a skilled "problem solver." To his critics, the White House aide is a manipulating "fixer."

JACKSONVILLE, Fla., March 19 (AP) -- Tony Jacklin, the former British and United States open champion from England, defeated John Jacobs on the first hole of a sudden-death playoff today and won the $25,000 first prize in the Greater Jacksonville open golf tournament.

The National Collegiate Athletic Association regional basketball championships took an odd bounce Saturday. As a result of Louisville's victory, the Cardinals' coach, Denny Crum, now takes his club to Los Angeles to try to beat the University of California, Los Angeles, a team he recruited.

WASHINGTON, March 19 -- Some recent court decisions that feminists regard as defeats for women are expected to provide much of the argument in favor of the equal rights amendment when the Senate starts serious debate tomorrow on the issue.

Although the Iberian Peninsula has a chess tradition dating to the 11th century (the earliest European reference to the game is included in a Spanish will written in 1008), neither Spain nor Portugal has contributed much to the modern chess scene. Spain has only two players, Grandmaster Arturo Pomar and International Master Antonio Medina, who compete regularly in international tournaments, and Portugal has none.

CHICAGO -- On the morning after the Florida primary, the politicians lounged around the swimming pools of Miami and Miami Beach and guessed, like everyone else. One of the things they guessed, as they mulled over the muddled Florida results, was that no one would be able to put together a firstballot majority at the Democratic National Convention and that this would help Edward M. Kennedy.

BOCA RATON, Fla., March 19 -- Two top advertising executives, whose agencies place over $1-billion a year in advertising, yesterday charged the media with unfair coverage of their Industry and said that something should be done about it.

NEW DELHI, March 19 (AP) -- The Indian Government has refused permission for Ambassador Kenneth B. Keating to use his embassy plane to fly to the dedication of a hospital built mostly with United States aid and donations, an American spokesman said today.
NEW DELHI, March 19 -- Prime Minister Indira Gandhi returned here today after signing a friendship treaty with Bangladesh, and said that peace talks with Pakistan would begin "some time or other."
The American Medical Association has called attention to the growing concern about pollution of water supplies in this country with viruses that cause infectious hepatitis and other diseases.
DETROIT, March 19 -- Michigan's Democrats and Republicans have found a new common ground: money.

BOSTON, March 19 (AP) -- Phil Esposito scored three goals today, including one that broke the National Hockey League record on power-play scoring, as he led the Boston Bruins to a 7-3 victory over the Minnesota North Stars.

A Government technical committee urged yesterday that serious consideration be given to easing laws on air pollution by automobiles and changing some auto safety rules due to take effect by 1976.

PITTSBURGH, March 19 -- Steel users spent last week building inventories. After reducing stocks by 12 million tons since last August, users were in the process of adding as much as one-half million tons in March.

WASHINGTON, March 19 -- President Nixon will fly to New York tomorrow to confer with state, local and Federal officials on the problems of drug abuse. Among those with whom Mr. Nixon will confer at Federal Plaza in downtown Manhattan are Governor Rockefeller and officials in charge of the first of nine regional centers for drug abuse law enforcement.
" Sesame Street," the television series for children will soon be shown on a regular basis in Poland and Yugoslavia and perhaps in Rumania, Hungary and Czechoslovakia.
INDIANAPOLIS, March 19 (AP) -- John Roche scored 15 points in the fourth quarter, and lifted the New York Nets to a 121-117 American Basketball Association victory, over the Indiana Pacers tonight.

Ten and a half million people get on tennis courts often enough to be termed players, according to the United States Lawn Tennis Association, but that's just the tip of the iceberg, manufacturers of tennis fashions insist.
FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla., March 19 -- On second thought, Bobby Murcer thinks that Vida Blue is absolutely right to stick by his salary demands and to quit baseball.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass. -- Some commentators saw the statements about Taiwan in the Shanghai communique of Feb. 27 as the only concrete results emerging from President Nixon's talks with Chou En-lai. They said that the United States had made great concessions on Taiwan, without compensatory concessions from China, and that the settlement of the Taiwan issue was now clear because the door had been closed to a separate Taiwan.

DACCA, Bangladesh, March 19 -- The friendship treaty signed by India and Bangladesh today contains mutual defense clauses similar to those in the treaty India signed with the Soviet Union last August, linking the three nations in a kind of collective security arrangement.

DETROIT, March 19 (UPI) -- Marcel Dionne scored his third goal of the game with 1:15 left, giving the Detroit Red Wings a 7-6 victory over the Montreal Canadiens tonight. The Canadiens' 12-game unbeaten string was snapped.

OAKLAND, Calif., March 19 (AP) -- Vida Blue, the Oakland Athletics' pitcher who announced his retirement from baseball rather than accept a $50,000 contract, talked with his former boss over the weekend. It was the first personal contact between Blue and the A's owner, Charles O. Finley, since Jan. 8.

An accidental morning scratch cost offtrack bettors a chance at a $44,517 superfecta payoff at Yonkers Raceway Saturday night and an unidentified OTB man, who made the error, his job. He was discharged yesterday.

In an action reflecting a basic reassessment of the dangers facing New York City, the Police Department is reducing by half the size of the Tactical Patrol Force and the Special Events Squad, the two units created to handle riots, demonstrations and parades.

WASHINGTON, March 19 (Reuters) -- The General Accounting Office has accused the Navy of misleading Congress by understating the cost of developing and producing a new, submarine-killer torpedo by up to $800-million, a Representative said today.

Unlike many young pianists, Andre Watts plays like one -- and in the very best sense. He is full of fresh ideas and eager to communicate them; furthermore his polished virtuoso keyboard address is always governed by a constantly developbility.

Leo Joseph Cardinal Suenens, Roman Catholic Archbishop of Malinese-Brussels, Belgium, and an outspoken advocate of church reform, warned churchgoers yesterday against "breaking with the past."

Some $200 million of the $1.8 billion contained in the city's new capital construction budget is reserved for "lump sum" appropriations, only vaguely defined by broad category. The lump-sum appropriation is not new, but the growth in its use under the Lindsay administration has now pitted the Mayor against members of the City Council and the Board of Estimate. The dispute ranges one good principle of budget-making against another good one.

WALPOLE, Mass., March 19 (AP) -- Prison guards clashed with 18 inmates resisting a prison lockup today at the Massachusetts State Prison here, the authorities said, and five prisoners and two officers were injured.
TOKYO, March 19 -- Japan's foreign-exchange reserves are so embarrassingly large, maybe she should just buy Papua New Guinea. There are a lot of minerals there.

NEW ORLEANS, March 19 (UPI) -- A shipment of Rhodesian chrome ore -- the first to enter the United States since the United Nations placed trade sanctions on Rhodesia's white minority Government six years ago -- passed quietly through the port of New Orleans today.
Vitas Gerulaitis, the 17yearo-ld Queens wunderkind, became the youngest player to win the Eastern men's indoor tennis championship Sunday.
LE PIN-AU-HARAS, France, March 13 -- Even here in the Cradle of the Race, the Percheron is fallen on hard times.

KINSHASA, Zaire, March 19 (UPI) Troops from Zaire backed by tanks disarmed Angolan guerrillas in a training camp 160 miles west of here after the guerrillas mutinied and shot three of their officers to death, Government officials said today.

Two major bills for improving the environment are approaching legislative crises that will determine whether they are to be mere gestures or serious advances. A revised pesticide control law passed by the House will have to be greatly strengthened in the Senate if it is to afford more than weak protection against toxic substances that kill not only insects and fungi but fish, birds and mammals as well, including humans.
GORDON, Neb., March 19 -- Like many towns lying near American Indian reservations, Gordon is mostly owned and operated by and for the white man.

CHAMPAIGN, Ill. -- The night of President Nixon's speech on busing, Senator George McGovern was here at the University of Illinois, speaking to nearly 3,000 students jammed into the auditorium. Just before nine o'clock he said he thought everyone should hear the President.

LONDON, March 19 -- Prime Minister Heath and President Pompidou of France ended two days of talks today in general agreement on the major goals of an enlarged European community, but apparently still at odds on some of the methods to achieve them.

INGEWOOD, Calif., March 19 (UPI) -- Gail Goodrich sank 30 points tonight to reach the points tonight to reach 2,000 points for the season as he paced the Los Angeles Lakers to a 162-99 romp over the Golden State Warriors.

The police yesterday examined several cars that seemed to match the description of the one used by two gunmen who killed an off-duty patrolman in a Brooklyn meat market Saturday night. A police spokesman said later that "the car has not been recovered" and that there were no leads yet.

After wading through military historian Martin Blumenson's eighth book, "The Patton Papers, 1885-1940," I confess that what springs first to mind are about a dozen reasons why not to recommend this bulky tome. Nearly a thousand pages of personal correspondence, articles, lecture notes, and so forth by a soldier primarily remembered as a man of action?

Two doctors have solved the mystery of why a 50-year-old female electronics worker suffered 40 attacks of gripping chest pain, fever to 104 degrees, sweating, shivering, sore throat, difficult breathing and weakness during a nine-month period.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, March 19 (AP) -- The three Western-owned oil companies operating in Iraq have agreed in principle to a 20 per cent participation by the Iraqi Government in the ownership of their concessions, the official Iraqi news agency reported today.
MEXICO CITY, March 19 (AP) -- Rafael Herrera of Mexico won the world bantamweight title tonight with an eighth-round knockout over a fellow Mexican, Ruben Olivares.

Muskie in October 1970 voluntarily made public the names of those who had contributed funds to the "Muskie election committee." This organization was raising money both for Mr. Muskie's re-election campaign in Maine that year and also for his prospective Presidential campaign.

MARTINSVILLE, Va., March 19 (UPI) -- Sonny Hutchins of Richmond and Carl (Bugs) Stevens of Rehoboth, Mass., drove their Chevrolets to victory today in the Dogwood 500 Double-header Classic at Martinsville Speedway.

Thomas Wolfe, the novelist, wrote about himself with all the frenzy of a man with a lot to discover and a short time to live. All his novels -- although disputed by the author -- were to a greater or lesser extent autobiographical, from "Look Homeward, Angel," and its sequel "Of Time and the River" to the posthumous "The Web and the Rock," published in 1939, the year after Wolfe's death.

BOCA RATON, Fla., March 19 -- Officers and members of the Advertising Council, the advertising industry's esteemed volunteer public service organization, heard the suggestion here yesterday that they disband the council because it is no longer relevant.

WARSAW, March 19 -- "Sesame Street," aimed at giving preschool-age children some basic learning skills in an amusing fashion, will be shown on Polish educational television after some major pruning and adaptation to make it suitable for Polish viewers.

BELFAST, Northern Ireland, March 19 -- Since William Christie was named the next Lord Mayor of Belfast, two of his paint stores here have been blown up. Two other Christie stores have been burned elsewhere in Ulster and another has been reduced to half size.
ROXBURY, Conn. -- In the age of the missile and the nuclear warhead, the Indian Ocean, the world's third largest, represents a vast launching pad for missile-firing submarines.

ALBANY, March 19 -- Assemblyman Stanley Steingut, the Democratic minority leader, has quietly introduced in the Legislature a bill providing for a two-candidate runoff election if the primary election for Mayor of New York City next year does not produce a single candidate with a majority of his party's vote.

BELFAST, Northern Ireland, March 19 (AP) -- About 10,000 demonstrators marched in a Roman Catholic district of Belfast today at the end of a St. Patrick's Day weekend that saw gunfire in scattered areas.

BOSTON, March 19 (AP) -- Mike Riordan, starting in place of Jack Marin, scored 30 points tonight as the Baltimore Bullets clinched the Central Division title of the National Basketball Association with a 125-112 victory over the Boston Celtics.
Once upon a time, public television used to be known as educational television. The change in name was made intentionally because, depressingly enough, education had become synonymous with dullness.

The Lindsay administration has initiated sweeping management changes that strengthen the superagencies by enabling them to hire, promote, transfer and grant merit increases to city employes without the approval of the Budget Bureau.

New Yorkers can now apply for passports at any of 61 post offices in the city, a spokesman for the post office announced yesterday. The passport applications are processed at the post offices and sent on to the State Department. The fee is $12.

For those morning commuters on the 7:36 from Hartford who are anxious to get on to the financial section of the paper, Princeton defeated Indiana, 68-60, and Niagara defeated the University of Texas-El Paso, 76-57, in the final opening-round double-header of the 35th annual National Invitation Tournament yesterday.

Protestant militants had two related objectives Saturday in organizing Northern Ireland's biggest political rally in half a century. They sought to strengthen Prime Minister Faulkner's hand for crucial talks with Prime Minister Heath in London Wednesday, and to warn of a violent Protestant backlash if Britain should concede too much to Ulster's nationalist and Catholic minority.

With President Nixon's visit to Moscow now only two months away, an unusually thoughtful and candid proposal for sweeping East-West cooperation has just been published in this country by a loyal Soviet citizen who is also a high-ranking United Nations official.

HEMPSTEAD, L.I., March 19 -- A touch of radicalism that may rock the staid table-tennis powers, a disappointing men's final and the first appearance of the new Chinese United Nations Mission to a sports event in this country marked the last day of the United States open championship tonight.
NEWARK, March 19 -- The Irish marched today down Broad Street in Newark, a city they have largely abandoned.

PARIS, March 19 -- Earlier this year in the debate between two Common Market commissioners over some vitally, important principles of the farm policy, it was said that Sicco Mansholt won the battle but lost the war.
The New York Stock Exchange announced yesterday that it has begun a pilot project to test the automated execution of 100-share market orders on the trading floor.
SPRING VALLEY, N. Y., March 19 -- Contests are scheduled in seven of the 13 Rockland County villages holding elections, with zoning questions and reassessment programs as the main issues.

Two new natural breads -- one by Arnold Bakers, the other by Pepperidge Farms -- are now available in supermarkets in the metropolitan area. Neither contains any chemical preservatives or softeners. Arnold calls its bread Health Loaf Naturel, and it is firm and rough textured, light brown in color and has a pleasing, nut-like flavor.

The city reported yesterday that it had speeded the placement of home relief clients in public-service jobs, assigning 3,880 to work out their grants in January and February, compared with an average of slightly more than 1,000 a month for the last five months of 1971.

MONTREAL, March 19 -- Judge Francois Auclair has rejected an application by the Montreal brokerage house of Holland Andrews Perrier Co., Ltd., for an interlocutory injunction preventing the Montreal and Canadian Stock Exchanges from hearing charges against it.

Ed Giacomin gets paid to block pucks, but last night in Madison Square Garden before the usual capacity crowd of 17,250, the Ranger goaltender wrote his name into the National Hockey League record book.
PEKING, Monday, March 20 -- China's top table tennis players, including the nation's foremost sports idol, will leave here March 28 for an extended tour of Canada, the United States and Mexico.

MOSCOW, March 19 -- American businessmen are cultivating new markets here in the expectation that President Nixon's visit in May will lead to a relaxation of restrictions on United States trade with the Soviet Union.

Your March 9 editorial "Scrooge Goes to the Races" demonstrates a woeful misapprehension of the economics of pari-mutuel racing. One assumes that you have been listening to one of the most expensive and certainly the most irresponsible publicity machines in the country, that of New York City's Off-Track Betting Corporation.

The Times of Feb. 27 published an article concerning a study by a state panel and recommendations with reference to a proposed uniform law pertaining to the acquisition of real property by reason of eminent domain. Such cases are referred to in some jurisdictions as appropriation cases and in others as condemnation cases. These recommendations leave much to be desired.
" The bus!" someone shouted. Ten-year-old Bobby Gill picked up his bulky briefcase and his violin and trudged out of the laundromat, into the raw wind and up the steps of the yellow schoolbus.

WASHINGTON, March 19 -- Secretary of the Treasury John B. Connally has decided that the Secret Service will protect five Democratic candidates for the Presidency. The protection, which begins tomorrow morning, will not include Senator Edward M. Kennedy of Massachusetts, who has said he is not a candidate, Mayor Lindsay of New York or Representative Shirley Chisholm of Brooklyn.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, March 19 -- More than 50 United States planes attacked enemy troops for 24 hours to cover the rescue today of three downed American airmen on the Ho Chi Minh Trail network in southern Laos.
RACHGOI, South Vietnam, March. 9 -- When Duong Van Nho enters a village he heads straight for the central marketplace.

AMSTERDAM, the Netherlands, March 20 (AP) -- Chess officials decided today that the match between the world champion, Boris Spassky of the Soviet Union and Bobby Fischer of the United States would begin in Belgrade, Yugoslavia, on June 22.

MILWAUKEE, March 20 -- Senator Hubert H. Humphrey reversed his stand tonight from the generally favorable position he took last week on President Nixon's proposals to limit the busing of school children.

A year ago the Department of the Interior issued a preliminary statement declaring that, despite some adverse environmental impact, an oil pipeline across Alaska along the route eagerly desired by the international oil consortium was acceptable. That draft statement was so cursory in its analysis and so biased in its premises that intense criticism developed at the departmental public hearings.

Price, Waterhouse Co., the accounting firm, has refused to express an opinion on the financial statements of the Sheffield Watch Corporation through Oct. 31, 1971, the watch company disclosed yesterday.

The Interstate Commerce Commission approved yesterday the purchase of the Chicago North Western Railway by a group of the carriers' employes. The employe group, the North Western Employes Transportation Corporation, known as Netco, had proposed to buy the railroad from Northwest Industries, Inc., the parent company.

A black revue from San Francisco has arrived at the City Center Downstairs, which is the official title for the theater that has been quite neatly tucked into the basement of the New York City Center.

An informer for the Federal Bureau of Investigation in last year's raid on draft board files in Camden, N. J., has accused the F.B.I. of complicity in that criminal act. His charges implicate high-ranking officials in planning, financing and equipping the illegal and potentially dangerous raid.
The average interest rate on conventional home mortgage loans that were closed during February dropped sharply from the month before, the Federal Home Loan Bank Board reported yesterday.

Franco Rossi displayed a big, though seriously worn, bass voice in his recital Sunday night at Carnegie Recital Hall. Mr. Rossi kept one interested in his demanding program, which ranged back as far as Carissimi and Purcell and up to Ravel, by his ability to step inside a character.

PHOENIX, Ariz., March 20 (AP) - Attorneys for Charlie Scott of the Phoenix Suns introduced letters in United States District Court today to show that Virginia Squires' owner Earl Foreman defaulted on a contract with the then -- American Basketball Association scoring leader.

LAHORE, Pakistan, March 20 -- Britain's Foreign Secretary, Sir Alec Douglas-Home, conferred today with President Zulfikar Ali Bhutto of Pakistan and later appeared pessimistic bout progress toward a peace settlement on the subcontinent.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, March 20 (UPI) -- The Saudi Arabian press agency asserted today that Southern Yemen's Marxist Government invited 40 exiled leaders to a "peace conference" last week and subsequently killed them.

WASHINGTON, March 20 -Jack Anderson, the syndicated columnist, said tonight that the International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation, working closely with the Central Intelligence agency, attempted to to stop the election of President Salvador Allende Gossens of Chile in 1970.

LOS ANGELES, March 20 -Edmund G. Brown Jr., the California Secretary of State, filed a suit today against the International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation, charging it with violating Federal law by contributing $100,000 to the Republican National Convention in San Diego next August.
Record sales and earnings were attained by General Mills, Inc., in the three and nine-month periods ended Feb. 27, the Minneapolis-based food and special-chemical company reported yesterday.
CHICAGO, March 20 -- Eugene J. McCarthy approached today the climax of his first, and what could be his last, serious political campaign of 1972.

BRUSSELS, March 20 (AP) -- Sicco L. Mansholt will take over the presidency of the Common Market Executive Commission for the rest of this year, Nobert Schmelzer, Dutch Foreign Minister, announced today.
A Canadian leader asserted yesterday that it was unrealistic for the United States to demand exactly equal treatment in its trade with Canada.
The Chesapeake Ohio Railroad will ask its stockholders at their annual meeting on April 20 in Cleveland to approve an $81-million debt-refunding plan for its Baltimore Ohio Railroad subsidiary.

WASHINGTON, March 20 -- Another allocation next year of Special Drawing Rights, or "Paper Gold," is not "vital" on economic grounds, but there may be "psychological" reasons for avoiding a hiatus in issuing the new international currency, Paul A. Volcker said today.

WASHINGTON, March 20 (UPI) -- House liberals denounced today President Nixon's proposed moratorium on busing as a return to segregated schools, but Senator James O. Eastland, Democrat of Mississippi, urged the President to go further and support a constitutional amendment to prohibit busing.
WASHINGTON, March 20 -- The redemptions of mutual fund shares exceeded sales in February by $88-million, on a seasonally adjusted basis, the Investment Company Institute reported today.

Some members didn't pay yesterday to get into the annual conference and exhibition of the Institute of Electrical and Electronic Engineers. Instead, they just had "discreetly" to show proof that they were unemployed.

BOSTON, March 20 -- From the mooing sounds and odors rising from the basement of Boston City Hospital these days, you might think the hospital ran its own dairy farm. In fact, the 300-pound calves that startled visitors sometimes glimpse in the white brick corridors are residents of something called the "intensive cow unit."
The American Stock Exchange and the over-the-counter market took a beating yesterday as prices fell sharply in moderate trading.

HONOLULU, March 20 (AP) -- Commissioner Pete Rozelle said today he had cautioned the assembled National Football League owners about several problems facing the sport, even as an offiical count of regular-season attendance showed that the 10-million mark was exceeded for the first time.

Julia Kallay was having trouble with her landlord, so the week before last -- after two months of sending in her rent check and having it returned as "insufficient" -- she and a fellow tenant went to a lawyer.
Bill Walton, the 6-foot-11 center for the University of California, Los Angeles, has been selected unanimously on the all-America team selected by the National Basketball Association coaches.

More than half a century after it was due, Scott Joplin is beginning to get the recognition he deserves. A complete collection of his piano rags has been published. His previously unproduced opera, "Treemonisha," was put on in Atlanta this season.

The New York Times has demonstrated it has the courage of Mr. Grossberger's convictions. That is to say, the piece which recommends doing nothing does seem to add up to nothing and if one multiplies by zero the inches of newsprint turned over to this nothing, well then. . . .

BURNSIDE, La., March 20 (UPI) -- Deputy sheriffs aimed shotguns today at 40 blacks protesting the unloading of 25,000 tons of Rhodesian chrome ore from the Argentine ship Santos Vega and arrested two for having trespassed on port terminal property.

The anonymous United Airline official quoted in a recent article on the "weight problem" among airline stewardesses unwittingly summed up the incredible obtuseness of some airline executives. "You run a $1.5-billion business," he declared, "and it boils down to whether some chicks look good in their uniforms. If you have fat stewardesses, people aren't going to fly with you."

At first glance, the notion that the money bail system as it now exists in New York should be declared unconstitutional seems ludicrous. Especially since the "defendants" in this action brought by the Legal Aid Society in the Appellate Division are every one of "the judges and justices authorized to sit in the New York City Criminal Court and the New York State Supreme Court in New York County."

FIREBASE PHU XUAN, South Vietnam, March 20 -- South Vietnamese forces, after a week of sharp battles in the mountain west of Hue, appear to have won the first part of an annual struggle to prevent the Communist forces from attacking the populated lowland cities from their jungle base areas.

The program of films by John Lennon and Yoko Ono that opened yesterday at the Whitney Museum may be divided into three parts. The first part, very brief and very inconsequential, consists of "The Ballad of John and Yoko" and "Cold Turkey," both compilations of assorted film clips, a kind of personality montage.

The flat assertion by the Office of Economic Opportunity that performance contracting has failed as a means of improving learning in the public schools is an oddly quick and sweeping judgment after only one year's experimentation.

A revised plan for a large new containerport facility on the South Brooklyn waterfront that floated about considerably in the minds of planners' before landing in Red Hook was adopted yesterday by the City Planning Commission.

LUSAKA, Zambia, March 20 -- The police arrested 97 suspected members of the Lumpa religious sect yesterday arrested on charges of trying to revive the movement, banned seven years after a rebellion in which 800 people were killed.
WASHINGTON, March 20 -- Down in the cellar we went, the whole family, to light the box and watch the Presidential election.

NICOSIA, Cyprus, March 20 -- Archbishop Makarios, President of Cyprus, made public today a reply rejecting the demand by the three other bishops of the Holy Synod that he resign as chief of state. The Archbishop said, however, that if they persisted in their demand, "I would regard it as my obligation to accept it."

In what is likely to be one of the most bitter primary contests in recent year, Representative Bella S. Abzug will challenge a fellow Reform Democrat, Representative William F. Ryan, in the June 20 Democratic primary, persons close to Mrs. Abzug reported last night.

At least two of the three major television networks are considering a request by Roy Wilkins, executive director of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People, that he be granted equal time to reply to President Nixon's statements last week on school busing to dsegregate public schools.

Two teen-aged suspects in Saturday's fatal shooting of an off-duty patrolman in Brooklyn were jailed yesterday in Union County, N.J., following their arrest Sunday by "a very sharp" Plainfield, N.J., policeman.
Ohrbach's semiannual shopping spree cure fashion show was on yesterday. As usual, there was something for everyone:

A major public employes' union yesterday made public Health Department reports that, according to the union, show "most city hospitals to be rodent- and roach-infested to the point where the health of patients and employes alike is endangered."

VERO BEACH, Fla., March 20 -- Despite permitting three runs and three hits in four innings, Tom Seaver was "completely satisfied" today with his performance as the New York Mets lost to the Los Angeles Dodgers, 4-3.

DRIPPING SPRINGS, Tex., March 19 -- A group of Dallas promoters experimented with a new kind of mass music festival this weekend on a lonesome ranch near this hill country village 25 miles west of Austin.

TRENTON, March 20 -- The State Assembly unanimously approved a legislative resolution today aimed at blocking the construction of two floating nuclear-power generating plants off New Jersey's southern coast.
BELFAST, Northern Ireland, March 20 -- A large time bomb exploded today in a central Belfast street crowded with shoppers and office workers, killing six and injuring 146.
The addicts arrived in the smoky morning at the Bergen-Willis Welfare Center in the South Bronx and waited through the junk-sick afternoon for the checks to come out.
The Princeton University Art Museum, with a little help from the industrialist and art patron Norton Simon, is about to enter the big time.

Organized labor and Senator Jacob K. Javits of New York both urged mandatory Federal standards for workmen's compensation yesterday, but business spokesmen recommended Federal guidelines rather than compulsory standards.
WASHINGTON, aMrch 20 -- The Bureau of Labor Statistics reported today the following spot primary prices for the week ended March 14;

Marty Reisman, one of table tennis's long-time stars and its most theatrical exponent, yesterday asked, "for old-times' sake," that he and Dick Miles be on the United States team that will face a Chinese team in this country next month.

NEW HAVEN -- A profound 17th-century Spanish classic, "Life Is a Dream," by Pedro Calderon de la Barca, and a trivial Italian domestic comedy, "I Married You for the Fun of It," are alternating in repertory at the Yale Repertory Theater.

WASHINGTON, March 20 -- With new stress placed by baseball's representatives on the argument that Curt Flood's suit against the reserve clause was really a matter for labor-management bargaining. Organized Baseball's status with respect to the antitrust laws was argued before the Supreme Court today for the third time in 50 years.

Some months ago, Dr. Janet Travell, who was President Kennedy's personal physician, said that Luci Baines Johnson Nugent, because of her "concern for people," would be the ideal choice as the nation's first woman President.

SATU-MARE, Rumania, March 11 -- It was May 14, 1970, and the rain had been coming down steadily for three days. The residents of this northwestern town were uneasy. Many of them, especially those living near the river, had spent the day reinforcing the 21-foot dikes.
In a reversal of his position, the lawyer for Black Panther Mark Holder asked yesterday that the arson-murder trial of the slightly built youth be closed to the press and public.

Although the atmosphere was more agreeable than at any other time since the strike started, there was still no accord yesterday between the pari-mutuel clerks and the New York Racing Association. As a result Aqueduct Race Track will be closed again today.
It was shocking to hear that Mihajlo Mihajlov was criminally sentenced in Yugoslavia for a letter in The New York Times.

WASHINGTON, March 20 -- The Supreme Court agreed today to review the Warren Court's controversial Miranda v. Arizona decision on confessions. It will be the first review of the decision since President Nixon's four nominees joined the Court.

CHICAGO, March 20 -- With a primary registration of 2.7 million in Chicago's Cook County a record, and an open ballot throughout the state for the first time, Illinois voters will have the opportunity tomorrow to choose 160 delegates to the Democratic National Convention and express a limited preference for the Democratic Presidential nomination.

WASHINGTON, March 20 (UPI) -- Representative Morris K. Udall, opposing plans for what he termed a "sudden death" national Presidential primary, has proposed that candidates run in state primaries to be held on three specific dates.

Verdi's Requiem, like his operas, is so unquenchably vital that its eloquence shines through even when the performance conditions are less than ideal. As heard in Carnegie Hall Sunday night in a program sponsored by the Northeastern Conference of Seventh-Day Adventists, the essence of the work made its familiar impact despite an uneven execution.

Frank Thornton, president of Barnes-Chase Advertising Company and chairman of the 1968 Nixon Presidential campaign in San Diego, told The Associated Press yesterday that $2,068 was donated by the Yellow Cab Company in that city to the campaign as reported in the current issue of Life magazine; but he said that it had later been returned to the donor.

Footwear prices will rise between $1 and $6 a pair next fall as a result of abnormally large buying of American hides by foreign countries, according to domestic manufacturers, retailers and tanners. Speaking at a news conference yesterday at the National Shoe Fair, leaders of the four principal trade associations in the footwear industry said that prices would advance still higher unless temporary hide export quotas were imposed immediately.

WASHINGTON, March 20 -- The Government opened its case today against the United Mine Workers president, W. A. Boyle, and two other union officials on charges, that mine workers' funds were illegally funneled to political candidates and campaigns.
NEWARK, March 20 (AP) -- Pressmen at The Evening News of Newark rejected a proposed contract today that would have lead to the resumption of publication after 10 months of suspension.

When he was a very small boy, Paul Bowles used to be put out in the backyard of his family's brownstone to "play" for an hour. The yard was shut in by a very high wooden fence, which blocked out the view of everything but the house with its nine widows looking out at him like nine eyes.

Columbia University made public yesterday a government-approved plan to centralize in its president's office the final approval of all hiring, promotion and dismissal of faculty members, to guard against job discrimination and to promote the employment and advancement of women and racial minorities on the faculty.

LONDON, March 20 -- The British Government indicated today that it would ease the controversial internment policy and pump more economic aid into Northern Ireland as part of its effort to end the crisis in the troubled province.

The New York Stock Exchange's Block Automation System will undergo a reorganization involving the replacement of much of its existing equipment as a result of internal difficulties that finally are surfacing after months of speculation in Wall Street.

WASHINGTON, March 20 -- The House Ways and Means Committee reached agreement today on the next-to-last major issue in the revenue-sharing bill. Committee members said that they might complete action tomorrow on the legislation, which provided a new form of Federal financial assistance to state and local governments.
Sgt. John David Herndon, who in 1968 was sent home wounded after 15 months in Vietnam, returned to the United States again yesterday to be a test case in a campaign for amnesty for deserters.

HAUPPAUGE, L. I., March 20 -- Representatives of Long Island labor unions, the construction industry and civil rights groups signed today an "affirmative action plan" for hiring minorities in the construtcion trades. It was the first such action in the suburbs in the country, according to Federal officials.

WINTER HAVEN, Fla., March 20 -- The Boston Red Sox have long been convinced that they possess the game's best left fielder. They also have long had the strong suspicion that they probably have as competent a first baseman as there is in the business. The trouble with such thinking is that it becomes a cerebral jam-up because both their highly regarded left fielder and their esteemed first baseman happen to be Carl Yastrzemski.

WASHINGTON, March 20 (UPI) -- Citing 54 deaths in five years, the Food and Drug Administration today ordered "children proof" packaging for all furniture polishes that contain 10 per cent or more petroleum distillates.

Sometimes Dal-Joon Lee gets up before dawn when a business idea strikes him. "I ask him what's the matter, and he tells me that he's thinking, and he has to get it down on paper," his wife, Linda, said yesterday.

Production of steel in the week ended Saturday totaled 2,561,000 net tons, the American Iron and Steel Institute reported yesterday. This represented a gain of three-tenths of 1 per cent over the 2,553,000 tons poured the week before.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, March 20 -- The Palestinian guerrilla leader Yasir Ararat and Iraqi leaders announced today that they had agreed on "practical steps" to combat King Hussein's proposal to create a federation of the East Bank and West Bank under his leadership.

WASHINGTON, March 20 -International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation released here tonight an affidavit sworn to by one of its former secretaries saying that she had typed a memo relating to the Republican convention in San Diego but that the memorandum had not contained some of the sentences in a memo made public by Jack Anderson, the columnist.

LONDON, March 20 -- David Rockefeller chairman of the Chase Manhattan Bank, said today that until there was more confidence in the dollar, the United States could not resume freely converting dollars into gold for foreign central banks.
ALBANY, March 20 -- A bill that modifies the extent to which an alleged rape victim's testimony must be corroborated was passed today by the Assembly.

JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, March 20 (AP) -- Val Ziegenfuss of San Diego and Linda Tuero of Metairie, La., won singles matches today as the United States beat Rhodesia in the first round of the women's Federation Cup international tennis tournament.

The New York Stock Exchange announced yesterday that Lee D. Arning, senior vice president for operations, had resigned, effective Aug. 15, to join Tucker, Anthony R. L. Day, a member firm, as a senior partner.
LONDON, March 20 -- Britain today ended her official inquiry into the killing of 13 Roman Catholics during a civil rights march in Londonderry on Jan. 30.
A conversation with a Wall Street analyst brought nothing but praise for the annual report published some months back by Quaker Oats.
John K. Castle has been elected executive vice president of Donaldson, Lufkin Jenrett, Inc.
DUBLIN, March 20 -- Three bombs were received in the mail today by I.R.A. leaders and two exploded when they were opened.
Peter Duchin, the pianist, and his wife, Cheray, yesterday disputed testimony given last week by Ronald E. Galella, the freelance photographer, who is accused of harassing Mrs. Aristotle Onassis.

PNOMPENH, Cambodia, Tuesday, March 21 -- Enemy forces fired 200 rockets and artillery shells into Pnompenh, the Cambodian capital, and its outskirts early today and official estimates put the casualties at 50 dead and 120 wounded.

LAKELAND, Fla., March 20 -- "You can't tell how good a baseball club is in the spring," Ralph Houk was saying today, just before his New York Yankees lost to the Detroit Tigers, 3-1. "We're moving guys in and out of the line-up, and the pitchers are not using their best stuff.

CAIRO, March 20 -- Well-informed sources in Cairo say that the Soviet Union has agreed to assist Egypt in overcoming guidance-system problems that have held up development of medium-range missiles capable of reaching targets in Israel.

WASHINGTON, March 20 -- A labor member of the Pay Board, Floyd F. Smith, the president of the International Association of Machinists, said today he was ready to leave the board and would recommend that other labor leaders do the same when a special meeting of the executive council of the A.F.L.-C.I.O. convenes Wednesday.

ALBANY, March 20 -- Reports that the new Congressional District line for Representative Joseph P. Addabbo, Democrat of Queens, would be amended by the Legislature to strengthen his vote-getting power elicited cries of "anti-Semitism" today from a lawyer running against Mr. Addabbo in the primary.

JACKSONVILLE, Fla., March 20 (AP) -- The wife of a Navy commander testified today that she had sexual relations four times with the Rev. Andrew F. Jensen, a Navy chaplain, who is on trial charged with misconduct by committing adultery.

The United Church of Christ, one of the most active of the major Protestant denominations in the area of social issues, announced yesterday that it was disbanding its Council for Christian Social Action.
WASHINGTON, March 20 -- The Department of the Interior said today that no single pipeline system could be built to tap Alaska's oil riches without damage or potential threat to the environment.

WASHINGTON, March 20 (UPI) -- The Supreme Court refused today to block from taking effect a California Supreme Court ruling abolishing the death penalty in that state, possibly meaning that 108 Death Row inmates will serve life sentences and may not be re-sentenced to death.

The Rangers' top right wing, Rod Gilbert, will miss some of his team's most important games of the National Hockey League season after the New York club disclosed yesterday he had been sidelined with "a strained neck muscle."

MIAMI, March 20 (UPI) -- Queen Louie, a 10-1 outsider, rallied from just off the pace to win the $35,450 Mimosa Stakes for fillies and mares today at Hialeah Park.
WASHINGTON, March 20 -- Representative Martha W. Griffiths, Democrat of Michigan, proposed today that every American baby be assigned a Social Security number at birth.

ALBANY, March 20 -- The State Senate passed a bill today that would permit prisoners in New York City prisons to be freed, without supervision, for periods up to three days.

Interest rates on tax-exempt bonds rose sharply yesterday while rates on other money and capital market securities edged up slightly. Activity was generally light.
WASHINGTON, March 20 (AP) -- The majority of United States servicemen and women are being left out of the nation's political process because of uninterest in high places, a new study asserts.

A doctor at New York's Hospital for Special Surgery has reported a previously unpublicized side effect of using LSD -- constriction of the blood vessels of the hands and feet that could be severe enough in some cases to cause gangrene requiring amputation.

More than 70 per cent -- 16,622 -- of births to mothers on welfare in the city last year were outside of wedlock, according to a study made public yesterday by Assemblyman Andrew Stein. The figure represents a continuous rise in the proportion of out-of-wedlock births to welfare mothers since 1960, when the rate was 57 per cent.

WASHINGTON, March 20 (Reuters) -- Joseph J. Sisco, the Assistant Secretary of State for Near Eastern and South Asian Affairs, said today that continued Soviet provision of large amounts of modern weapons to Egypt and other Arab countries had led the United States to act to maintain the Middle Eastern arms balance.

LONDON, March 18 -- The season of new work being given by Ballet Rambert at the Young Vic has been designed with special purpose. Many new theaters are now being built, like this one, with thrust stages in which the performing area has members of the audience sitting on three sides.

WASHINGTON, March 20. -- Senator J. W. Fulbright threatened today to block Congressional action on the United States Information Agency's budget unless the agency reversed its refusal to supply documents to the Senate Foreign Relations Committee.

EL FERROL, Spain, March 20 (Reuters) -- Hundreds of striking workers returned to their jobs at the state-owned Razan naval shipyards here today after the Government threatened to impose martial law unless they ended a strike for higher pay.
The annual meeting of the Kings Lafayette Corporation ended yesterday as it began -- in a guessing game as to the intentions of its largest stockholder, Edmond J. Safra, an international financier.
The Parks Administration began selling permits yesterday for play on its 503 municipal tennis courts. The season opens April 8 and closes Nov. 28.

The Knicks-Bullets National Basketball Association playoff will open in Baltimore on Friday, March 31, the Bullets getting the extra home game in the four-of-seven series for winning the Central Division title while the Knicks were finishing second in the Atlantic Division.

DACCA, Bangladesh, March 20 (UPI) -- Western eyewitness reports reaching here today said that Indian troops had returned to Bangladesh within a week of their official withdrawal and were going into action against tribal rebels in the Chittagong Hill Tracts district of southern Bangladesh.

MILWAUKEE, March 20 -- Mayor Lindsay accused Senator Hubert H. Humphrey today of moving to the right and said Mr. Humphrey could not defeat President Nixon.

The current effort to prohibit foreign vessels from fishing any closer than 200 miles from the United States coast is gaining momentum. Tomorrow at 8 P.M. at the Sheepshead Bay Yacht Club, the Emergency Committee to Save America's Marine Resources will hold its first public meeting.

William R. Phillips, the suspended patrolman who was the chief witness at the Knapp Commission hearings into police corruption, was indicted yesterday in the slaying of a procurer and his teen-age companion on Christmas Eve, 1968.

WASHINGTON, March 20 (UPI) -- The Ripon Society, an organization of liberal Republicans, ranked the Senate voting record of Hubert A. Humphrey today as the highest among candidates for the Democratic Presidential nomination.

The Metropolitan Opera has promoted two assistant technical administrators, Charles Riecker and Michael Bronson, to newly created posts in the upper echelon of the company, Goeran Gentele, the Metropolitan's new general manager, disclosed yesterday that Mr. Riecker would become artistic administrator and that Mr. Bronson would be technical administrator.

YONKERS, March 20 -- Richard L. Ottinger, who gave up his seat in Congress for an unsuccessful Senate race in 1970, announced today that he would seek re-election to the House from the new 23d Congressional District.

BRUSSELS, March 20 -- The possibility of bloc-to-bloc negotiations to arrange trade relations between Eastern and Western Europe after 1975 was evoked today as Common Market sources cautiously welcomed Mr. Brezhnev's declaration that the Kremlin finally recognized the Western European bloc.

SAN JUAN CAPISTRANO, Calif., March 20 (UPI) -- The swallows' return to Capistrano last night on schedule after a 3,000-mile trip from Argentina was just accidental, an ornithologist at the Museum of Natural History at Balboa Park in San Diego says.

WASHINGTON, March 20 (AP) -- Senator Edmund S. Muskie plans to concentrate on certain key states for the rest of the spring, and Maryland's Presidential primary May 16 is one contest the Maine Democrat is expected to de-emphasize.

Soviet Communist party chief Leonid I. Brezhnev confirmed yesterday foreign suspicions that the Kremlin is far from fully satisfied with some major recent developments in the international arena. He betrayed a certain nervousness, particularly over the uncertain fate of the Bonn-Moscow treaty now being debated in West Germany and also over the possibility that secret agreements may have been concluded during President Nixon's visit to China.

SALT LAKE CITY, March 20 -- A suit on file in Federal Court here puts on the record the story of how Howard R. Hughes, the billionaire, believes he was swindled of about $8-million by a group that included one of his trusted employes.

PORT MORESBY, Papua New Guinea, March 13 -- At the busy Port Moresby international airport, the gateway to this Australian - administered territory, each of the two Australian-owned airlines employs bilingual Japanese hostesses to assist arriving Japanese businessmen and tourists.
CINCINNATI, March 20 (AP) -- Twenty-eight prisoners, many of them armed with pistols and four of them women, escaped tonight from the Hamilton County Jail and Courthouse in downtown Cincinnati.

The Ebinger Baking Company of 2290 Bedford Avenue, Brooklyn, one of the largest manufacturers and distributors of quality breads and cakes in the metropolitan area, applied in Brooklyn Federal Court yesterday for an arrangement with creditors under Chapter XI of the Bankrutcy Act.
PARIS, March 20 -- The United States and Chinese Ambassadors to France held their second meeting today amid even more secrecy than surrounded first meeting last Monday.

HARRISBURG, Pa., March 20 -- The Government's contention that the Rev. Philip F. Berrigan and another antiwar priest secretly checked a utility tunnel system in Washington to see whether its destruction was feasible received circumstantial support today from witnesses at the Berrigan trial.

CHICAGO, March 20 -- An interfaith consultation on Soviet Jewry, described as the first of its kind in this country, established a permanent secretariat today to mount pressure against what it called "extreme and special acts of discrimination" against Jews in the Soviet Union.
MOSCOW, March 20 -- Leonid I. Brezhnev, the Soviet Communist party leader, expressed hope today that talks with President Nixon in Moscow in May would help strengthen world peace.

PHILADELPHIA, March 20 -- The Penn Central railroad opened a three-day auction here today of more than a million items of railroad memorabilia to raise some cash.
WASHINGTON, March 20 (AP) -- The Senate agreed today to start voting tomorrow on amendments to the constitutional amendment that would outlaw all legal forms of discrimination based on sex.

BRUSSELS, March 21 -- Gruff, sensitive, irascible, yet deeply tolerant, Dr. Sicco Leendert Mansholt is a man who can shut out the world when he wants to.

MANCHESTER, N. H., March 21 -- Roger Crowley Jr., who was the unsuccessful Democratic gubernatorial nominee in 1970, today declared himself a candidate for Governor again.
WASHINGTON, March 21 -- President Nixon signed today legislation that puts statutory authority and $1-billion behind the Special Action Office for Drug Abuse Prevention.
QUANTICO, Va., March 21 -- An administrative board at the Marine Corps base here recommended today that Lance Cpl. Jeffrey Arthur Dunbar, an avowed homosexual, be given an undesirable discharge.
A gasoline-fed fire, apparently set off by a fire bomb, raced through a house in Jamaica, Queens, last night, seriously damaging it and slightly injuring three persons, the police said.
Prices on the American Stock Exchange and in the over-the-counter market continued to fall sharply yesterday for the second consecutive session in stepped-up trading.

WASHINGTON, March 21 (AP) -- The former president and three former officers of the International Latex Corporation were indicted today on charges of conspiring to conceal from the Government nearly half a million dollars in payments to keep union activities out of the concern, the Justice Department announced.
Americans continue to favor legislation that would require every young man to give a period of service to the nation, according to the Gallup Poll.
WASHINGTON, March 21 -- The Senate, by unexpectedly large margins, defeated today attempts to dilute a constitutional amendment that would bar all legal forms of discrimination based on sex.

Three months after hostilities ceased on the Indian subcontinent India is still holding more than 90,000 Pakistani prisoners, including some sick and wounded. This is contrary both to international law and to India's own interest in restoring peace based on mutual confidence and cooperation on the subcontinent.

HONOLULU, March 21 (AP) -- The National Football League awarded next year's Super Bowl to Los Angeles tonight, selected Houston as the site of the 1974 game and announced it was shifting the Los Angeles-based Pro Bowl to another city.

PARIS, March 21 (AP) -- Representatives of the National Football League Players Association announced plans today to bring 42 of the league's top stars to Paris May 27 for a demonstration that will be part of a charity sports week for the benefit of the American Hospital in Paris.

Carlos Barbosa-Lima, a Brazilian guitarist in his late 20's, demonstrated in his New York debut recital Monday night enough talent and schooling to put him on the upper levels among performers on his instrument.

William R. Phillips, the suspended patrolman who was indicted Monday on a murder charge, was released yesterday from a city detention facility after posting $50,000 bail, but he later surrendered to Federal authorities as a material witness in pending cases. Federal Judge Charles L. Brieant Jr. set bail at $10,000 and ordered Mr. Phillips held in protective custody. Mr. Phillips was a key witness in the Knapp Commission hearings last October on police corruption.

WASHINGTON, March 21 (AP) -- A top foreign aid official confirmed today that Meo guerrillas in Laos got hospital treatment under American humanitarian assistance but denied that any aid had gone to the Central Intelligence Agency's combat role.

WASHINGTON, March 21 -- The United States moved quickly today to praise key sections of Leonid I. Brezhnev's speech on foreign policy yesterday and to assure the Soviet leader that President Nixon's recent trip to China had not been directed against Moscow's interests.
WASHINGTON, March 21 -- Candidates of both parties for this year's Presidential nominations are estimated to have spent nearly $4-million in the primary struggles in New Hampshire and Florida.

A campaign to raise $150-million to help needy and endangered Jews overseas was begun by the United Jewish Appeal of Greater New York at a dinner last night at the Americana Hotel. MIAMI, March 21 (UPI) -- Riva Ridge, the champion juvenile colt in 1971 and early favorite for the Kentucky Derby, is expected to get a stern workout in Hialeah's $25,000 added Hibiscus Stakes tomorrow.

VIENTIANE, Laos, March 21 (AP) -- As heavy fighting was reported for the fourth day at Long Tieng, American officials here said they believed enemy forces had sustained heavy losses because of waves of assaults against entrenched defenders.

GENEVA, March 21 -- The East-West deadlock over how to verify compliance with any disarmament agreement arose again today when the Geneva disarmament conference addressed itself to a proposal for the prohibition of chemical weapons.

Lockheed's L-1011 Tristar -- the jetliner that almost foundered with the collapse of Britain's Rolls - Royce, Ltd. -- came to New York for the first time yesterday, and company officials insisted that the trouble-beset airliner was now out of trouble.

WASHINGTON, March 21 -- President Nixon has authorized the use of Government funds to underwrite joint economic ventures in Yugoslavia and Rumania by private American investors. This was the first time such United States-backed protection has been granted for use in Communist countries.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, March 21 -- Yasir Arafat, leader of the Palestine Liberation Organization, said last night that King Hussein met recently with Premier Golda Meir of Israel at the Jordanian port of Aqaba and that a Jordanian Army officer who accompanied the King had defected to Cairo and told about the meeting.

SAN DIEGO, March 21 (AP) -- Two former Federal investigators described today as accurate portions of a Life magazine article charging that the Nixon Administration had "seriously tampered with justice in San Diego."
Police Commissioner Patrick V. Murphy has rethought the police needs of the City of New York and advanced detailed plans for meeting them more effectively.

HONG KONG, March 21 -- For a long time, and increasingly during the last year, President Chiang Kai-shek has been letting his son and presumed successor in power, Deputy Premier Chiang Ching-kuo, Vice President C. K. Yen and other subordinates take over more and more of his duties, reserving to himself only key decisions and unavoidable ceremonial obligations.
WASHINGTON, March 21 -- The Supreme Court declared unconstitutional today lengthy residency requirements for voting in state and local elections.

TAIPEI, Taiwan, March 21 -- Generalissimo Chiang Kai-shek, receiving a record total of more than 99.9 per cent of the votes, was elected by the National Assembly today to his fifth six-year term as President.

WASHINGTON, March 21 -- The House Commerce Committee voted today to kill legislation designed to encourage the production of automobiles that are less prone to costly damage in crashes than present models are.
CINCINNATI, March 21 -- A team including two of the reigning world champions rallied to capture the men's team championship at the American Contract Bridge League's Spring Nationals early today.
ARCADIA, Calif., March 21 (AP) -- Hail The Grey, paying $54.80, rallied in midstretch and defeated Manta by two lengths today in the $65,500 Santa Barbara Handicap at Santa Anita.
BURNSIDE, La., March 21 (AP)--A controversial shipment of Rhodesian chrome ore was stored on barges in the Mississippi River today, awaiting delivery to an inland alloy plant.
JANESVILLE, Wis., March 21 -- Senator Henry M. Jackson came under heavy questioning here today about who was financing his campaign for the Presidential nomination.
FISHERS ISLAND, L. I., March 21 -- A 2.5-million gallon tanker ran aground and split open early today, spilling more than 60,000 gallons of oil into Long Island Sound.

ALBANY, March 21 -- Governor Rockefeller said today that President Nixon's proposed moratorium on busing as a tool for desegregating schools was "an approach which seems to me is very constructive under the circumstances."
ATHENS, March 21 -- The general who has been the regent, or acting chief of state, of Greece was dismissed today, and Premier George Papadopoulos assumed the office in addition to his three others.

Lawyers for Mrs. Aristotle Onassis completed their case yesterday in their efforts to get a permanent injunction that would bar the photographer Ronald E. Galella from approaching within 100 yards of Mrs. Onassis or her children.

WASHINGTON, March 21 -- Dr. Jesse L. Steinfeld, the Surgeon General, today urged "appropriate and immediate remedial action" to counter the overdose of violence television provides for children.

WASHINGTON, March 21--The Pay Board is considering the broadening of exemptions from pay controls, including reducing the number of workers whose wages are controlled and easing the controls on low wage earners, board officials disclosed today.

WASHINGTON, March 21 -- The United States Information Agency said today that it had prepared pamphlets on the benefits of private oil exploration to be distributed in Ecuador by a Texaco-Gulf oil combine.

BELFAST, Northern Ireland, March 21 (AP) -- Four bomb blasts rocked Londonderry today and gunmen fought a two-hour battle with British troops that the army called the city's biggest confrontation since street fighting began in August, 1969.
YONKERS, March 21 -- Stanley Dancer will not be at Yonkers Raceway to drive Scarpia in one of the three semifinal divisions of the Hopeful Pacing Series tomorrow night.

Executive Council (as transmitted by United Press International) in connection with the resignation of three labor members from the Pay Board, by Judge George H. Boldt, chairman of the Pay Board. on behalf of the board's public members, and by Ronald L. Zeigler, White House press secretary (as transmitted by The Associated Press):

At the end of his performance of Mahler's Ninth Symphony with the Philadelphia Orchestra in Philharmonic Hall Tuesday night, Carlo Maria Giulini was vigorously cheered by the audience and roundly applauded by the players themselves.

Albert Shanker said yesterday that the United Federation of Teachers would ask the Board of Education to provide "school district attorneys" to prosecute those who commit crimes in schools and to" take other measures to protect pupils and teachers.

Greater New York's Blue Cross yesterday received state permission to institute a 14.8 per cent increase in rates for hospitalization insurance charged to community-rated subscribers. The Federal Price Commission last Tuesday approved a 17.9 per cent rise.

WASHINGTON, March 22 -- The National Commission on Marijuana and Drug Abuse, issuing its formal report calling for abolition of criminal penalties for the personal possession and private use of the drug, said today that the time had come to end politicizing the issue.

The Grateful Dead play New York often enough so that one might reasonably expect some of the shine to have rubbed off their local appeal. But watching them and listening to them Tuesday night at the start of their sold-out, two-week engagement at the Academy of Music, I realized that the magic glow of the seminal San Francisco rock group was as strong as ever.

WASHINGTON, March 21 -- The House passed unanimously today a bill authorizing $105-million for a program over three years to diagnose, prevent and treat sickle cell anemia, a blood disease that primarily afflicts young blacks. The vote was 391 to 0.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 22 -- Despite disavowals to the contrary, the trade was made out of petulance. At least that's what the more perceptive baseball men believe. The St. Louis Cardinals were balking at the salary demands of Steve Carlton, their 20-game winner, at the same time that the Phillies were resisting the salary demands of Rick Wise, their 17-game winner.

The decision of the A.F.L.-C.I.O. to withdraw its three members from the Pay Board is a destructive act -- as harmful to labor as it is to all other citizens. It cannot be allowed to wreck the joint effort of the Administration and Congress to check the ruinous wage-price spiral.

ALBANY, March 22 -- Fiscal committees of the Legislature today began intensive, last-minute deliberations to firm up cuts and revisions in the Governor's "no-growth" $7.9-billion budget in an effort to come up with an acceptable bill in time for the start of the fiscal year, which begins April 1.

WASHINGTON, March 22 -- The United States has protested to the Soviet Government over the detention and forcible search of two assistant United States naval attaches in Leningrad last week, the State Department said today.

JACKSONVILLE, Fla., March 22 (AP) -- Two Navy wives, one a Sunday school teacher, came to the defense of a Navy chaplain today, testifying that one of two officer wives with whom he is accused of having sexual relations acted "very aggressive" toward the chaplain.

Both the original supportive reaction by Mr. Humphrey to President Nixon's televised address and his subsequent reversal had the unfortunate trappings of a man who would rather be President than right.

CHICAGO, March 22 -- Senator Edmund S. Muskie of Maine came out of the Illinois primary today with 59 convention delegates committed to him and 63 per cent of the Presidential preference vote.

The Allied Stores Corporation, a retail chain operating 150 units in 28 states, did better in the final quarter ended Jan. 29 than in the full fiscal year ended on that date, according to the annual results released yesterday.

PETERSBURG, Fla., March 22 -- The American League approved unanimously today the sale of the Cleveland Indians to a group headed by Nick Mileti, who already operates the Cleveland Cavaliers of the National Basketball Association, the Cleveland Barons of the American Hockey League and the Cleveland Arena.

BUFFALO, March 22 -- Defying an order by the State Education Commissioner, Ewald B. Nyquist, the Buffalo Board of Education voted 4 to 3 at a tumultuous meeting today to refuse to submit a plan for achieving racial balance in its 98 schools.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, March 22 -- Mrs. Ngo Ba Thanh, a leading critic of the Saigon Government and the war, who has been in prison and has been suffering asthmatic attacks for six months, was carried to military court in downtown Saigon on a stretcher today to face charges of having engaged in activities harmful to national security.
CHICAGO, March 22 -Mayor Richard J. Daley tried today to make the best of his loss yesterday of two important primary races.

Once again, the Environmental Defense Fund, with cooperation from state and local interests, is challenging the validity of a United States Army Corps of Engineers flood control project already under way.

The Times' editorial of March 3 is entirely correct in pointing out that Mr. Kleindienst's admitted interventions in the settlement of the I.T.T. antitrust suit constitute "impropriety." There has never been in recent history a more flagrant and potentially dangerous violation of principles both of antitrust law and insurance regulation than I.T.T.'s take-over of Hartford, one of the nation's largest insurance companies.

BELFAST, Northern Ireland, March 22 -- A large bomb exploded in the center of Belfast today, wrecking rooms in the city's biggest hotel and leaving more than 70 persons injured. There were no serious injuries.

CLEVELAND, March 22 (AP) -- The Cleveland Cavaliers pulled the biggest upset of their two-year history tonight by stopping Los Angeles, 124-120, preventing the Lakers from tying the National Basketball Association record for the most victories in one season.
NEW DELHI, March 22 -- Official sources said today that India was not eager to open a serious dialogue with either the United States or Pakistan until the two countries recognized Bangladesh.

BRUSSELS, March 22 -France and West Germany reached a provisional agreement tonight in a farm policy dispute that created new frictions in the European Economic Community just as the members were drawing closer in the monetary field.
NEW ORLEANS, March 22 -- Winning the professional grand slam in golf "is not an impossible dream," Jack Nicklaus asserted today.

Eight years ago, Harlem Community Board 10 arranged with the Columbia University School of Architecture for a neighborhood-renewal study that the board chairman said aimed at "a substantially integrated Harlem based on excellence by 1975."

PARIS, March 22 -- It was the balmiest day of the year. Children were sailing boats around the fountain as mothers knitted in the sun, old men bowled and played cards, the trees burst into full foliage and the bees visited the first flowers of spring. But not a boy kissed a girl in the Luxembourg Gardens, unless they were foreigners.
Accusing New York's racing industry of "resorting to the 'Big Lie' technique," Howard Samuels proposed a plan yesterday he estimated could net an additional $29-million in pari-mutuel tax revenue.
Under heavy pressure from the oil industry, the Accounting Principles Board has softened considerably its proposed overhaul of the rules governing profit-and-loss reporting by petroleum producers.
Najeeb E. Halaby resigned as chairman and chief executive officer of Pan American World Airways yesterday after the airline's board of directors gave him an ultimatum to quit or be dismissed.

Historically, linguistically and culturally, Denmark, Iceland, Norway and Sweden form one sprawling community, a relationship recognized officially from time to time in various ways. Spurred by the sharp scaling back of Treasury financing plans, interest rates stopped advancing yesterday and staged a mild decline.

WASHINGTON, March 22 -- The Congressional Black Caucus has disassociated itself from a resolution to "dismantle" Israel that was passed last week at the National Black Political Convention in Gary, Ind.

WASHINGTON, March 22 -- The United States has proposed to the Soviet Union that negotiations to settle the multi-million dollar debt for lend-lease aid during World War II begin in Washington early next month, a high Administration official said today.

The American Stock Exchange and the over-the-counter market showed no definite trend yesterday as both lists ended mixed in slow trading.

C. K. Yen, Vice President of Nationalist China for six years, and unopposed for a second term, was re-elected in Taipei yesterday. Mr. Yen is also Premier, and it was expected that following the Presidential inauguration in May, when Chiang Kai-shek begins his fifth six-year Presidential term, Mr. Yen will resign as Premier and turn that post over to Chiang Ching-kuo, the President's elder son, who is now Deputy Premier.

About one out of every 13 policemen among the 925 assigned to arresting narcotics pushers and gamblers has been secretly recruited for another mission: providing top commanders with intelligence about any corrupt policemen in their ranks.

WASHINGTON, March 22 -- Following is a table of the funds each state would receive under the revenue-sharing bill agreed upon today by the House Ways and Means Committee and under the Administration's proposal. The figures are in millions of dollars.
WASHINGTON, March 22 -The once-zooming growth of investment in plant and equipment by foreign affiliates of United States corporations has begun to slow, the Commerce Department reported today.

MADISON, Wis., March 21 -Mayor Lindsay of New York has marshaled his campaign hierarchy for an all-out effort in Wisconsin in the hope that the results of the primary on April 4 will give a major thrust to his drive for the Democratic Preesidential nomination.
ALBANY, March 22 -- Governor Rockefeller today appointed Abe Lavine, director of the Office of Employe Relations, as the new Commissioner of Social Services.

PNOMPENH, Cambodia, March 22 -- President Lon Nol has emerged from Cambodia's latest political crisis with virtually unchallenged power, diplomats here agree, having, removed the last legal opposition to him and, in the process, the last semblance of democracy.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 22 -- Baseball's club owners voted 24-0 today not to increase their offer in pensionbenefit negotiations and sent John Gaherin, their representative, back to new bargaining sessions with Marvin Miller, director of the Players Association, in Arizona Friday.

UNIONDALE, L. I., March 22 -- The New York Nets, with a 20-point lead over Carolina in the third quarter, were apparently on their way to their eighth straight victory tonight when their attack suddenly stalled.

WASHINGTON, March 22 -- The Senate passed the Equal Rights Amendment today, thus completing Congressional action on the amendment, which would prohibit discrimination based on sex by any law or action of any government -- Federal, state or local.

WASHINGTON, March 22 -- President Nixon's proposals to curtail busing were attacked today by Democrats holding key positions on Congressional committees, indicating that the Administration's legislation faces a difficult road in Congress.

New top officers were named yesterday by Kaiser Resources, Ltd. MAYWOOD, N. J. -- The Seder, the Passover meal, is the culinary highpoint of the Jewish ritual year. But for the cook it is a paradoxical event, a feast that commemorates hunger, a banquet prepared -- and consumed -- at painstaking length in order to instruct the young about a hasty flight from Pharaoh's Egypt that forced Israelite housewives to forget about leisurely yeast-baking and rustle up matzoh on the double.

PARIS, March 22 -- The Government has chosen April 23 as the date for its planned referendum, whose ramifications may well go beyond simple approval of treaties widening the European Common Market from 6 to 10 members.

LONDON, March 22 -- The Government today put into effect eased exchange control regulations that will make it possible for foreign-owned companies to borrow money here for investment in Britain. Previously, such companies had to borrow investment funds abroad and bring them into Britain.

LONDON, March 22 -- After nearly 10 hours of hard bargaining with Prime Minister Heath, Prime Minister Brian Faulkner of Northern Ireland agreed tonight to present to his cabinet a series of proposals to end the crisis in the strife-torn province.

Two large utility holding companies and a natural gas company announced plans yesterday for expansion programs totaling more than $885-million this year. Financing requirements will be in excess of $722-million.

WASHINGTON, March 23 -The Senate Finance Committee indicated today that it was leaning toward sharp increases in Social Security benefits for those who have worked for many years at low-paying jobs.

LONDON, March 23 -- Prime Minister Brian Faulkner of Northern Ireland flew back to Belfast tonight after a new attempt to force changes in the long-awaited British proposals for the troubled province.
