JACKSONVILLE, Fla., March 23 (AP) -- A former Navy chaplain testified today that he had been the object of provocative overtures in his counseling office from one of two Navy wives who have accused Comdr. Andrew F. Jensen of adultery.

The trustees of the Penn Central Transportation Company reported yesterday a $47.2-million net loss, on a fully accrued basis (including charges for interest, taxes and the like which are not being paid currently), for the first two months this year.

Reflecting improved consumer spending and the upturn in the economy four retail merchandising companies reported yesterday improved operating results for the fiscal year ended last January. Rapid-American Corporation earnings rose 54.9 per cent; Mercantile Stores, 10 per cent; Manhattan Industries, 61.8 per cent and Marshall Field Co., 18.4 per cent.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., March 23 -- As the deadline for withdrawal from the Presidential primary here passed tonight, election officials placed 12 Democrats and three Republicans on the ballot for the May 16 election.

CHICAGO, March 23 -- Columbia and New York University, which tied for the team championship last year, each advanced all three of their fencers into tomorrow's second round of the National Collegiate Athletic Association's fencing championship. HAUPPAUGE, L. I., March 23 -- A joint-venture arrangement was inaugurated here today between Yugoslavia's largest copper and brass manufacturer and an American corporation. It was the indication of a new willingness by the Yugoslavs to engage in 50-50 profit-sharing with an American company.
The Children's Art Carnival occupies the dividing line between Wonderland and Harlem. More precisely, it sits at the junction of St. Nicholas Avenue, 141st Street and the rainbow.

A metal scaffold used for window washing crashed down from the 54th floor to an eighth floor roof at 1 Astor Plaza yesterday, killing a window washer who had been standing on the scaffold and crushing to death a man who had been working on the roof.

BELFAST, Northern Ireland, March 23 -- Twelve persons were injured and six shops completely wrecked today when a big bomb exploded in a stolen car in the seaside town of Carrickfergus, 10 miles from Belfast.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., March 23 -- The United States today announced a new $35.3-million cash contribution for relief to Bangladesh in a move aimed partly at offsetting criticism of lagging American assistance.

Fears about the hurtful effect of President Nixon's political game plan on busing have been dismally confirmed by the triple-play from Nixon to Rockefeller to Buffalo. There was no question during that city's noisy Board of Education meeting this week that the predominantly white audience had come armed with the President's "moratorium" on busing and Governor Rockefeller's vapid statement that he considered it "under the circumstances" a very constructive approach.

WASHINGTON, March 24 -The Navy and Air Force said today that they had temporarily suspended flight operations of 144 A-7 close support bombers because of potential engine problems. The A-7 aircraft on combat missions in Vietnam were excepted from the order, the Pentagon announcement said.

A 27 - year - old porter who was arrested and charged with homicide Thursday night in connection with a fatal fire at the Y.M.C.A.'s Sloane House was held without bail yesterday at his arraignment in Criminal Court in Manhattan.

WASHINGTON, March 24 -Federal District Judge George L. Hart Jr. dismissed today a suit against the Atomic Energy Commission that had sought a clarification of the potential hazards of fast breeder nuclear reactors.
At 7:40 P.M. on a mild evening this week, as 12,000 people were beginning to stream into the dazzling Lincoln Center plaza, an alarm went off in the little security office under the plaza.

NEW ORLEANS, March 24 -Billy Casper outscored Jack Nicklaus today, led by two strokes after 36 holes in the $125,000 Greater New Orleans open and changed his diet. With a four-under-par 68 Casper brought his aggregate at the Lakewood Country Club course to 134 or 10 under par.

The trustees of the Penn Central Transportation Company notified Judge John P. Fullam of the Federal District Court in Philadelphia yesterday that the company's loss from ordinary operations in 1971 was $284,520,523.

American Brands, Inc., announced yesterday that it had agreed in principle to acquire the Shatterproof Glass Corporation. This would be the diversified tobacco company's first move into the glass field. Robert B. Walker, chairman and chief executive officer of Amercan Brands, said the company would acquire about 67 per cent of the capital stock of Shatterproof from the family of William B. Chase, Shatterproof's chairman, for $28 a share in cash.
LONDON, March 24 -- The British Government suspended the provincial government and Parliament of Northern Ireland today and imposed direct rule from London.
WASHINGTON, March 24 (AP) -- The Justice Department branded as false today Life magazine's charges that the Nixon Administration had seriously tampered with justice in San Diego.
Rearrangements in the state budget will avert the threatened shutdown of Hunter College's elementary and high schools, State Senator Roy M. Goodman said yesterday.

WASHINGTON, March 24 (UPI) -- The Senate today voted down, 48 to 23, a bill that would have authorized the slaughter of millions of hens in an effort to drive up egg prices, which are at 40-year lows.

LONDON, March 24 -- Following are the texts of a statement made by Prime Minister Heath to the House of Commons today and a statement made at Stormont, Northern Ireland, by Prime Minister Brian Faulkner:

DUBLIN, March 24 -- Prime Minister Heath's announcement of direct rule for Northern Ireland by London was welcomed today by the Irish Republic's Government and members of the Opposition. The reaction from the leadership of the Irish Republican Army was hostile and bitter, however.

WASHINGTON, March 24 (UPI) -- The Interstate Commerce Commission issued today an emergency order authorizing the Lehigh Valley Railroad to take over operations of the New Jersey Central Railroad in Pennsylvania. The order is effective April 1.

PORT ST. LOUIS, Fla. March 24 (AP) -- Kathy Whitworth of Richardson, Tex., last year's leading money-winner on the Ladies' Professional Golf Association tour, scored a suddendeath victory today over Beth Stone of Muskogee, Okla., in the first round of match play in the Sears women's world golf tournament.

WASHINGTON, March 24 -President Nixon asserted today that Acting Attorney General Richard G. Kleindienst was "an able, honest man" and predicted that he would be confirmed as Attorney General despite allegations of impropriety against him.

HOLLYWOOD BEACH, Fla., March 24 -- The textile industry will embark on a billion-dollar program of expansion to meet demand this year and next, leaders of the industry indicated at the annual meeting here today of the American Textile Manufacturers Institute.

The 19-day strike by the Independent Association of Mutuel Employes against the New York Racing Association ended last night as the pari-mutuel union overwhelmingly accepted a one-year contract guaranteeing jobs for all clerks who worked in 1971 and providing a wage increase of $3.11 a day in wages and benefits.

NORFOLK, Va., March 24 -The New York Nets, down by 17 points in the second quarter, rallied to defeat the Virginia Squires, 105-104, and pulled to within one-half game of the Squires in their battle for second place in the American Basketball Association's Eastern Division.
WASHINGTON, March 24 (AP) -- The chairman of Merrill Lynch, Pierce, Fenner Smith, Inc., urged today that all commission rates on stock transactions be on a competitive basis.
JACKSONVILLE, Fla., March 24 (AP) -- The adultery courtmartial of Comdr. Andrew F. Jensen, a Navy chaplain, recessed today until Monday after his lawyer became ill.
Twelve persons were injured, three of them seriously, in an explosion that spewed glass and flames through a fourthfloor fur-processing company in the garment district early yesterday morning.

The Cleveland Electric Illuminating Company reported yesterday gains in operating revenues and net income for 1971. The big Ohio utility placed operating revenues at $270,720,587 against $245,381,168 a year earlier.

PITTSFORD, N. Y. -- Some students at the University of Michigan recently decided that both sexes could live together in the same room and select their partners by lot. The noble experiment was called off only because of excessive publicity.

LOS ANGELES, March 24 (AP) -- Jerry West hit a 15-foot jump shot with two seconds to play tonight, giving the Los Angeles Lakers a 112-110 victory over the Phoenix Suns and a tie for the National Basketball Association record for most victories in a season -- 68.
WASHINGTON, March 24 -President Nixon's antibusing legislation ran into sharp liberal opposition, including the threat of a filibuster, as Congress took up the measure today.

LONDON, March 24 -- Britain and Malta appeared tonight to have settled the long dispute over the use of defense bases on the Mediterranean island. The Defense Ministry said that Dom Mintoff, Prime Minister of Malta, would arrive tomorrow and was expected to sign an agreement Sunday.
The college basketball season will end today, as it always ends -- with U.C.L.A. winning the national championship.

Sir William Lyons, founder 50 years ago of Jaguar Cars Ltd., Coventry, England, has retired and R. W. England has been named chairman and chief executive of the company. Sir William, who was 70 years old last year, will assume the "advisory post" of president.
DETROIT, March 24 -Three Detroit policemen were charged today by the prosecutor's office with attempted murder in a shooting incident two weeks ago.

MILWAUKEE, March 24 -Oscar Robertson, the brains and guile of the Milwaukee Bucks offense, returned to action after missing six games tonight and led the defending National Basketball Association champions to an overwhelming 131-88 triumph over the New York Knicks at Milwaukee Arena.
Fistfights, stink bombs and scampering white mice interrupted a ceremonial opening last night of the first Cuban Film Festival at the Olympia Theater.
NEW ORLEANS, March 24 (AP) -- A three-judge Federal court struck down today a Louisiana law prohibiting biracial adoptions.

SEBRING, Fla., March 24 -- The prancing-horse Ferrari sports cars entered by the Italian factory team qualified today for three of the first four starting positions in tomorrow's Twelve Hours of Sebring.

PNOMPENH, Cambodia, March 24 -- Communist saboteurs knocked out Pnompenh's only bridge across the Tonic Sap River today in the third major attack on this area this week.

The stock market slipped lower yesterday in the most sluggish trading in nearly two months.

WARSAW, March 26 -- The Polish press today renewed its attacks on Radio Free Europe after a bill passed by the United States Congress last week provided funds to keep the station in operation at least until June 30.

By an overwhelming vote of 29 to 7, the Connecticut Senate late last week approved a new credit law that restricts retail stores to charging no more than 12 per cent, or 1 per cent a month, on their revolving charge accounts.
WASHINGTON, March 26--One of the most bitter political struggles of the 1972 campaign will be fought out on the unlikeliest of battlegrounds: the neighborhood supermarket.

The American Broadcasting Company's highly praised madefor-television movie, "Brian's Song," which detailed the true story of the friendship between two football players, one black and one white, was one of the 17 winners of 1971 George Foster Peabody Awards in broadcasting annuonced yesterday.

Robert R. Meehan, the Rockland County District Attorney, said yesterday that the school bus that was in a collision with a freight train Friday did not stop, as required by state law, before crossing the tracks.

BOSTON, March 26 (UPI) -Mike Walton scored two goals tonight as the Boston Bruins posted a 5-4 victory over the Montreal Canadiens and clinched first place in the National Hockey League East Division.

The 2,500th anniversary of the birth of Lord Mahavira, "great hero," spiritual leader and patron saint of Jainism, an ancient Indian religion that pre-dates Buddhism, was observed yesterday by more than 100 of the prophet's followers.

" I could talk about that man all night," said Walt Hazzard, who plays in the backcourt for the Buffalo Braves of the National Basketball Association.
HAIPHONG, North Vietnam, March 12 -- North Vietnam plans to expand its harbor facilities here at least 50 per cent in the next year.

NORTH SALEM, N. Y., March 26 -- Dr. George West's Daddy's Baby captured one class and finished fourth in another to win the Open Jumper championship today at the concluding session of the two-day The Hill Horse Show.

BELFAST, Northern Ireland, March 26 -- He speaks in a solemn monotone, rarely raising his voice. At packed rallies he steps to the rostrum and almost hypnotically, wills the crowd into silence. His voice is even and emotionless; his words are electric.
KAMPALA, Uganda, March 26 (Reuters) -- The departure of Israeli paratroop and army instructors from Uganda was almost complete tonight as President Idi Amin's deadline for their expulsion drew near.

WASHINGTON, March 26 -- A preliminary report by the General Accounting Office finds that there is evidence to support charges of mismanagement in the C-5A cargo plane program.

It is about 18 months since the Martha Graham Dance Company last appeared in New York, although it has, since then, toured extensively in other parts of the country. PITTSBURGH, March 26 -Domestic steel producers were waiting last week for word of a new import quota.

In most ways, the new production of Verdi's "Otello" at the Metropolitan Opera has been turned over to Franco Zeffirelli, who was both set designer and director. The production was unveiled Saturday night.

The Riverdale Speed Skating Club, paced by Billy Lanigan, scored 78 points and won its fifth consecutive title before 1,396 fans at the ninth annual Middle Atlantic meet at the Riverdale Arena yesterday.

Machine-tool orders in February soared 20 per cent over the January level, the National Machine Tool Builders Association reported over the weekend. At the same time the Machinery Dealers National Association said that February sales of used machine tools were "the best in 26 months," rising 31 per cent above the January level and 32.4 per cent above February, 1971.
LONDON, March 26 -- Britain and Malta signed an agreement here today for the continued use by the British of military bases on the Mediterranean island.

FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla., March 26 -- Mel Stottlemyre and Sparky Lyle faced on 27 batters today as they pitched a one-hit 2-0 victory over the Kansas City Royals and helped the New York Yankees sharpen their pitching staff for the approaching season.
LONGTHANH, South Vietnam, March 10 -- Nguyen Van Tien has a new tractor. Mrs. Mai Thi Hue, down at the rice mill, and her neighbors across the canal have new television sets.

GREENFIELD, Iowa, March 26 -- Roger Blobaum was right. The long knives started flashing and slashing at last night's district convention.

The Justice Department filed suit yesterday in United States District Court in Los Angeles to force Texaco, Inc., to dispose of 222 service stations it acquired last year from the Douglas Oil Company of California.

LONDON, March 27 -- Imports into Britain of tiger, snow leopard and clouded leopard skins will be banned from midnight tonight, in a move by the Government to protect these endangered species. WEST PALM BEACH, Fla., March 27 -- In little more than a week, major league baseball teams will be playing regular games and provoking the comment, "The pitchers are ahead of the hitters." The American Film Institute Theater in Washington is going ahead with plans to show next month the Cuban films that the Federal Government blocked from showing here last week -and is now trying to seize -under provisions of the Trading With the Enemy Act.

TRENTON, March 27--Legislative efforts to approve a Constitutional Congressional redistricting plan for New Jersey deadlocked in the Assembly this evening when rival Democratic and Republican plans were narrowly defeated.
A 14-year-old Queens boy stole his father's car yesterday afternoon and killed one man and sightly injured two other persons when he lost control of it, according to the police.
LONDONDERRY, Northern Ireland, March 27 -- In many of the hearts and homes of Londonderry's Bogside section, there is hope today where there was none before.

WASHINGTON, March 27 -- Senator William Proxmire said today he was asking for a criminal investigation of what was described as a $400-million overpayment by the Air Force to the Lockheed Aircraft Corporation for the C-5A cargo plane.
JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, March 27 (Reuters) -- The South African open tennis championship made history today by allowing South African nonwhites to play for the first time.

FRANKFORT, Ky., March 27 (UPI) -- Kentucky apparently became today the first state to certify a Presidential-Vice-Presidential ticket when it placed the names of Gov. George C. Wallace and T. Coleman Andrews, Virginia attorney, on its November ballot.
It was more than 30 years ago, when I was a teen-ager, that I first saw ducks being baited in a salt pond on Martha's Vineyard Island.

WASHINGTON, March 27 -- Senate Republican leaders, protesting that the Democrats were turning the investigation of the International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation into "a political circus," called today for termination of the earnings after the Easter recess.

MOSCOW, March 27 -- The Soviet Union announced today the launching of its eighth unmanned spacecraft for the exploration of Venus as it maintained an active pace in a vigorous program of planetary studies.
The National Maritime Union said yesterday it had reached agreement on a new labor contract with tanker and dry-cargo management interests operating out of Atlantic and Gulf Coast ports.

JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, March 27 -- Roy Wilkins, the head of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People, defended United States business involvement in South Africa today and said the condition of black workers there could worsen if the Americans pulled out.

HARRISBURG, Pa., March 27 -- Dr. Eqbal Ahmad, a Pakistani Moslem and the only non-Catholic among the Harrisburg Seven, was cleared today of two of the three counts against him in the Berrigan antiwar conspiracy case.

C. Sumner Stone has resigned as director of minority affairs at the Educational Testing Service, expressing doubt about the organization's ability "to commit itself to the change necessary to make tests more humanistic and relative to the minority experience."

UNYE, Turkey, March 27 (AP) -- Leftist guerrillas kidnapped three British radar technicians from this Black Sea coastal town last night, and reliable sources reported today that they were being held as hostages for three leftists sentenced to be executed.

WASHINGTON, March 27 (AP) -- Middlemen's prices for a "market basket" list of grocery store food items went up about 2.5 per cent in February while the farmer's share increased 0.9 per cent, the Agriculture Department said today.

President Nixon has again come strongly to the support of his welfare reform program, the Family Assistance Plan. After suggesting last summer that the wage-price freeze somehow made it desirable to postpone the effective date of the plan, Mr. Nixon in a special message to Congress yesterday reiterated his conviction that reform of the ramshackle welfare system is imperative.

PARIS, March 27 -- As the Allied armies of World War II were pressing toward Tokyo and Berlin, John Maynard Keynes and Harry Dexter White had a series of encounters in Washington that relate to the monetary reform talks about to be opened three decades later in Paris by Paul A. Volcker.

DENVER, March 27 -- In a sharply partisan attack, an attorney for Mrs. Dita D. Beard charged today that Jack Anderson, the columnist, and Senator Edward M. Kennedy were conducting "a purely political game" in an effort "to get I.T.T. and the Administration" by alleging a deal over the settlement of three antitrust suits against the International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation.

The nation's steel industry poured more steel in the week ended March 25 than in any week since last June 19.

Prices of world No. 11 sugar futures rose as much as the trading limit of 1/2 cent a pound on the New York Coffee and Sugar Exchange yesterday, reversing the downward trading limit that the prices hit more than once last week.

BIRMINGHAM, Ala. -- As it begins its second century, Birmingham has finally become sufficiently Americanized that Northerners who move here feel right at home. Some like it so well they refuse to leave.

HONG KONG, March 27 (UPI) -- A 16-member Chinese table tennis team left Peking today for an exhibition tour in Canada, the United States and Mexico, the New China News Agency (NCNA) said.

JAKARTA, Indonesia, March 27 -- Indonesia is training 60 Cambodian soldiers in commando techniques for the Lon Nol Government, military sources in Jakarta have disclosed.

The auditor for Botany Industries, Inc., S. D. Leidesdorf Co., explained yesterday at a special meeting of the men's apparel company some of the reasons why it gave only a qualified opinion on Botany's annual report.

YONKERS, March 28 -- Owners of Abatross, the 4-year-old pacer who was the 1971 Harness horse of the year, have voted 7-3 to replace Stanley Dancer as the standard bred's trainer-driver. Last season Albatross won 25 of 28 races and earned $558,009.

During his three years as Secretary of Housing and Urban Development, George W. Romney has tried without success to evolve an Administration policy for the cities and their suburbs. The other day in Detroit he rhetorically threw up his hands and said the job was too big for the Federal Government. Nothing that Washington could do, he suggested, would halt the terrible slide of inner-city housing into slums.
Please permit me to comment on your March 9 editorial "Free University in Danger."
GENEVA -- "You see," Darius Milhaud said with a smile of triumphant patience. "A score can lie forgotten in a drawer for years, but one day it will jump out again."

ROME, March 28 -- These are days of bombings and plots, spectacular robberies and urban guerrillas, an election campaign full of cabals and alarming rumors, and on top of it all the death of a famous publisher, a friend of Fidel Castro, in a mysterious explosion at the foot of a power pylon.

MEMPHIS, March 28 (UPI) -- The Memphis Pros of the American Basketball Association, fighting for survival, dipped into the college ranks today and signed David Brent of Jacksonville University, a 7-foot-1-inch sophomore.

While the Thad Jones-Mel Lewis band is touring the Soviet Union for the State Department, its Monday night gigs at the Village Vanguard have been taken over by Charles Mingus and a 20-piece band. Mr. Mingus recently gave a surprisingly bland concert at Philharmonic Hall with an expanded version of this band but things have changed now that he is back in a club.
MILWAUKEE, March 28--If George C. Wallace is wooing Wisconsinites with the "Grand Ole Political Opry," John V. Lindsay is superstarring in "Naked City."
Police in rural Holmdel Township, N. J., were puzzling over an inconclusive handful of objects yesterday in the slaying of a man and woman whose bodies were found Monday in a farm gully.

An underwriting group managed by Merrill Lynch, Pierce, Fenner Smith, Inc., offered yesterday 400,000 shares of the Ferro Corporation common stock at $33.50 per share, the price at which the stock closed yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange.

HANOI, North Vietnam, March 17 -- In a series of interviews, North Vietnamese officials have taken pains to say they want to reassure the United States that North Vietnam has no intention of pressing a political or ideological claim on the South if President Nguyen Van Thieu is ousted.
The money and capital markets maintained their remarkably steady course yesterday even as much of this week's new financing reached the market to test levels of interest rates.

ALBANY, March 28 -- Following are the tax increases already approved for the 15-month period that began Jan. 1 and the major parts of the state's $7.87billion budget, approved today for the fiscal year beginning Saturday:

It is warming that The Times is turning its attention to the plight of the German universities. [Editorial March 9.] Yet your news story of March 7 datelined Marburg, though enumerating a series of symptomatic facts, draws a picture that needs clarification.

WASHINGTON, March 28 (UPI) -- A civil rights lobbyist, Clarence Mitchell, said today that when President Nixon proposed a moratorium on forced school busing "he placed himself on the side of those who have stood in school doorways to bar black children."
NUREMBERG, West Germany -- Nuremberg, famed for its old buildings and its artists of old, has acquired 30 modern sculptures and in the process stirred up a bitter, sometimes violent controversy.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y. -- Kurt Waldheim, the U.N.'s Austrian Secretary General, has an eminently practical view of the United Nations and his own role. Aware of its imperfections, he is convinced the time has come for the organization to improve its administrative and financial efficiency. As for the major problem -political -- the U.N. does what its members permit it to do, no more, no less.
FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla., March 28 -- Bob Gladieux was charged with possession of marijuana today but the New England Patriots' back denied he had ever used it.

ARMAGH, Northern Ireland, March 28 -- William Cardinal Conway, the Roman Catholic Primate of All Ireland, said today that religion was not an issue in the present crisis and that his church had no desire to impose its moral outlook on Protestants in a united Ireland.

It now appears that I.T.T. lobbyist Dita Beard, who collapsed with a heart seizure while being questioned in a Denver hospital by Senate Judiciary Committee members, will not be able to testify again for six months or more.
HEMPSTEAD, L.I., March 28 -- Hempstead Town today symbolically leased a square mile of West Hempstead to an Orthodox Jewish congregation to enable the congregants to more easily observe Jewish laws.
DETROIT, March 28 -- George Romney, Secretary of Housing and Urban Development, said today that his department was not abandoning the central cities.
The American Stock Exchange is engaged in a series of presentations to securities-industry leaders in order to show them its ideas about the stock market of the future.

FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla., March 28 -- The life-is-real, lifeis-earnest aspect of baseball life overshadowed the gamesand-glory aspect for the Yankees today, and not because they lost a 6-5 decision to the Los Angeles Dodgers.
MINEOLA, L.I., March 28 -Detective Sgt. Matthew Bonora, the 44-year-old chief of the Nassau County Police Department's homicide squad, has applied for retirement after 22 years on the force.
A 42-year-old city high school teacher was appointed yesterday by Borough President Robert T. Connor of Richmond to replace Dr. Mary E. Meade as a member of the central Board of Education.

WASHINGTON, March 28 -A New York-New Jersey compact giving the Waterfront Commission of New York Harbor power to take over the cargo security fucntions at the metropolitan airports narrowly cleared a major hurdle today.

BRUSSELS, March 28 (Reuters) -- The Common Market had a trade surplus of $1.5-billion in 1971, compared with a deficit of $436-million in 1970, according to official figures released by the E.E.C. Executive Commission today.
The week-long celebration of Passover begins at sundown today.

Back in 1870 a sympathetic critic commended Eastman Johnson, who was then 46 years old, for his paintings of quaint ways and folk who were vanishing from the American scene -- thus beating to the draw by 102 years any critic expecting to approach the new Eastman Johnson exhibition at the Whitney Museum as neonostalgia.

JERUSALEM, March 28 -Nearly 14,000 Arabs on the Israeli-occupied West Bank of the Jordan River defied threats of terrorism from Palestinian guerrilla leaders and voted for town leaders today in the first general election on the West Bank since 1963.
WASHINGTON, March 28 -- Congress appears to be moving toward another radical increase in the wage base on which Social Security taxes are paid.

WASHINGTON, March 28 -- A group of former high Government officials and private economists said today it was "urgent" that negotiations for world monetary reform "be started at the earliest possible time."
An intensive antinarcotics campaign aimed at vulnerable "young kids who are not hooked" was disclosed yesterday at City Hall by Mayor Lindsay.
WASHINGTON, March 28 (AP) -- Two liberal Democratic Senators will propose that seniority be stripped from Senators who refuse to support the national party or its candidates.

Labeling to provide instructions on care of textile products was endorsed yesterday by the Textile Distributors Association. It represents mills and converters that distribute the great bulk of fabrics used in apparel and home furnishings.
Cresap, McCormick Paget, Inc., management consultants, has named Joseph P. Merriam as executive vice president.

PNOMPENH, Cambodia, March 28 (UPI) -- A bomb believed placed by a saboteur exploded in Pnompenh today, killing six persons, and the Cambodian Government warned residents to arm themselves and dig trenches in preparation for a possible enemy attack on the city.

WASHINGTON, March 28 -Senator William Proxmire produced a document today in which Adm. Elmo R. Zumwalt asked key commands for recommendations on how best to spend a newly available sum of more than $400-millton by June 30, the end of the fiscal year.

A Yonkers landlord was indicted by a Westchester County grand jury yesterday on charges of refusing to rent an apartment to a black family. The State Division of Human Rights and the District Attorney said it was the first indictment in the state under the Human Rights Law.

BLOOMINGTON, Minn., March 28 (AP) -- Goals by Philadelphia's Bob Kelly and Ross Lonsberry matched a pair by Minnesota's Dennis Hextall as the Flyers salvaged a 2-2 tie with the North Stars tonight in their fight for a West Division playoff berth.
LONDON, March 28 -- The British Government today urged Protestants demonstrating in Northern Ireland against London's take-over of the province to "settle down" and help ease the crisis.

BUENOS AIRES, Wednesday, March 29 -- The Fiat subsidiary here announced early today that the ransom demands of the leftwing kidnappers of Oberdan Salustro, a high Italian executive of the company, were "beyond reach" as the midnight deadline for his execution passed.

In December, 1944, in the midst of World War II and only seven months before the first atomic explosion, Albert Einstein proposed that the world's leading physicists -- including two Russians -- be mobilized to prevent a postwar weapons race.

WASHINGTON, March 28 (AP) -- The Pentagon asked Congress today for $30-million in bonuses for reservists effective Saturday, and $200-million more next year to try to attract enough doctors and men with other special skills into a voluntary military force.

OREGON, Wis., March 28 -Senator Edmund S. Muskie proposed today that the Federal Government give the states $7.2-billion to help them provide every elementary and secondary school pupil -- including those in private and parochial classrooms -- with the same quality of instruction.

City officials were generally happy with the state budget approved in Albany yesterday, but they warned that the next step in the budgeting process -in which the city hopes for $850-million more in state aid -- would be the most crucial.

MILWAUKEE, March 28 -Senator George McGovern accused President Nixon today of "shabby" treatment of the families of prisoners of war by failing to answer letters from them if they contain criticism of his Vietnam policies.

Ingrid Bergman is returning to Broadway for two weeks as Lady Cicely Waynflete in George Bernard Shaw's "Captain Brassbound's Conversion." The production will open on April 17 at a theater to be announced and will co-star Pernell Roberts in the title role.

Gothic, black comedy, parable, parody -- none of these terms can rationalize the clumsiness of Muriel Spark's "Not to Disturb." And the feeble far-off echoes of Beckett and Pinter only serve to set off invidious comparisons. In this short but heavy novel, Miss Spark is like someone dressed to the teeth for a costume party -but it is never clear whom she is impersonating.

WASHINGTON, March 28 (AP) -- The United States Postal Service has destroyed 8,000 pounds of matzoh originally mailed to the Russian Embassy for distribution to Jews in the Soviet Union. Senator Harrison A. Williams Jr. said today.
Vera Maxwell is, of course, best known as a designer of simple but casual clothes with a timeless style to them.

RIVERHEAD, L. I., March 28 -- The Suffolk County Executive, John V. N. Klein, told the County Legislature today that Suffolk County Airport in Westhampton Beach had lost more than $1-million in the last 18 months through mismanagement and inefficiency and would lost about $700,000 more this year.

DETROIT, March 28 -- A Federal judge said today that he was duty-bound to order some type of metropolitan-area plan to desegregate Detroit's largely black schools. Such a plan could mean large-scale busing.
CAIRO -- The big question in the Middle East today is: Is it time to fight or a time to make peace?

WASHINGTON, March 28 -- A Federal Power Commission presiding examiner ruled today that the agency had no jurisdiction over a company seeking to build a plant to make synthetic gas from naphtha but that it did have authority over the transportation and sale of the synthetic product after it was mixed with natural gas.
WARSAW, March 28 -- Parliament elected Henryk Jablonski, a noted academician, president of Poland today.
BERKELEY, Calif., March 28 -- The Berkeley City Council endorsed tonight a proposed state constitutional amendment to "decriminalize the use of marijuana."
Prison sentences ranging up to 40 years were imposed by a Federal judge here yesterday on four men taking part in some or all of a series of armed robberies in North Carolina and New York.

On Feb. 27, 1939, six months before the German attack on Poland, the great German physicist Max von Laue secretly wrote to Albert Einstein in the United States that certain German scientists wanted to "cleanse" his relativity theory of its "Jewish taint."

One of Europe's most distinguished and most exciting dance companies, the Netherlands Dance Theater, opened a two-week season at the Brooklyn Academy of Music last night. This is a company that was founded in 1959 and has established a unique character in contemporary dance.

ALBANY, March 28 -- The state's new budget is a bit like a hastily erected hut on a deserted island -- composed of bits and pieces of whatever is available and shrouded by a large question: can it survive a storm?
MILAN, March 28 -- Giangiacomo Feltrinelli, the millionaire leftist publisher who died in an explosion at the foot of a power pylon near here two weeks ago, was buried here today.

JERUSALEM -- The mood in Jerusalem this Easter week is remarkably calm. The Palm Sunday pilgrimage wandered over the stony hills of this lovely city in brilliant sunshine, and even the Israeli politicians, who pay little attention to the church bells and singing pilgrims, seem to have acquired a new serenity.
LONDON, March 28 -- Jose Napoles didn't need his smelling salts after all.

ORLANDO, Fla., March 28 (UPI) -- Glenn W. Turner announced his resignation today as chairman of the company that he built from a borrowed $5,000 into a multi-million dollar conglomerate within four and a half years.

Two mutual funds managed by the Dreyfus Corporation teamed up with two major banks yesterday to charge the Alodex Corporation, a Southhaven, Miss., real estate concern, its accountants and its investment banker with fraud in connection with a 1971 stock offering.
Elizabeth Holtzman, a 30year-old Brooklyn district leader, announced yesterday that she would oppose Representative Emanuel Celler for the Democratic Congressional nomination in the June 20 primary.

WASHINGTON, March 28 -- In the early nineteen-sixties, seven liberal Republican Representatives, calling themselves the Wednesday Group, began meeting once a week to discuss alternatives to the conservative programs advocated by the Republican leaders in Congress.
WASHINGTON, March 28 (UPI) -- The General Motors Corporation agreed today to pay a $90,000 fine for violating Federal safety standards for windshield mountings on its German-produced Opel automobile.
Edward A. McCabe, a vice president of Scali, McCabe, Sloves, rode to glory last night alternating between the back of a Perdue chicken and the driver's seat of a Volvo.

Two policemen assigned to a special roving squad guarding banks in Queens thwarted a holdup of a bank in the Jackson Heights section in which robbers tried to bargain their way out by using hostages. Four suspects were seized and a fifth was believed to have escaped.

GENEVA, March 28 -- The Soviet Union presented to the Geneva disarmament conference today a draft convention calling on all nations to agree "never in any circumstances to develop, produce, stockpile or otherwise acquire or retain" chemical means of warfare.

CHICAGO, March 28 (AP) -An independent study group said today that Chicago policemen killed more persons over an eight-month period than did the police in any of the four other largest cities in the nation.
A well-prepared and questioning stockholder from Chicago contributed yesterday to the longest annual meeting of The New Yorker Magazine in recent history.

WASHINGTON, March 28 -George Meany, president of the A.F.L.-C.I.O., told the Price Commission today that its price controls were a failure because the Nixon Administration was not providing the tools to enforce them.

WASHINGTON, March 28 -The Navy disclosed today that it was planning to pay the Grumman Aerospce Corporation an additional $40-million to compensate it for the loss of a test model of the F-14 aircraft and the subsequent slippage in production of the new carriers fighter plane.
DETROIT, March 28 (AP) -- The Detroit Red Wings scored four goals in the third period tonight to preserve its National Hockey League playoff hopes with a 6-3 victory over the Boston Bruins.

If David L. Benetar had read my testimony on strikes in public employment in the forum of the Workers Defense League before commenting on it, he might not have said in his letter of March 22 to The Times that I had put my stamp of approval on such strikes.
The Linde division of the Union Carbide Corporation announced yesterday new price schedules for distributable oxygen, nitrogen, argon, hydrogen and acetylene, effective April 1.

The American Gas Association reported yesterday a 4 per cent decline in proved gas reserves during 1971. The trade association estimated such reserves at 278.8 trillion cubic feet on Dec. 31, 1971, against 290.7 trillion cubic feet a year earlier.

LAKELAND, Fla., March 28 -- Brent Strom, a rookie lefthander getting his last inspection before tomorrow's squad cuts, twice dissipated leads in the final two innings, which enabled the Detroit Tigers to edge the Mets, 5-4 in the 10th today.
Supermarket stocks took another drop yesterday amid signs that the Nixon Administration plans to keep a closer eye on grocery pricing policies in an effort to hold down spiraling food costs.

WHITE PLAINS, March 28 -Stung by Representative Ogden R. Reid's defection to the Democratic party a week ago, the Westchester County Republican organization has decided to designate District Attorney Carl A. Vergari to run against him in the 24th Congressional District in November.

New York State's chief judge said yesterday that the implementation of the speedy-trial rule, which is to go into effect May 1 unless blocked by the Legislature, would not solve the problems plaguing the state court system.

Prices of silver future closed about 4/10 cent to 5/10 cent off the day's highs of 1.60 cents to 1.70 cents an ounce on the Commodity Exchange of New York yesterday. Commission houses provided good buying support throughout the trading session, aided by chartist buying.

The Standard Prudential Corporation announced yesterday it was holding preliminary discussions on acquiring the Inland Credit Corporation through an exchange of stock. Details of the negotiations were not disclosed, but trade sources said the transaction, if completed, would involve stock valued at more than $10-million.

ISLAMABAD, Pakistan, March 28 -- Military sources disclosed today that the air forces of Libya and Jordan had provided American-built combat aircraft to Pakistan during her war with India and that some of these planes were still in Pakistani service.

WASHINGTON, March 28 -The House decisively rejected today every attempt by environmentalists to correct what they regard as weaknesses in the water pollution control bill written by the Public Works Committee.

Denver, March 28 -- Mrs. Dita D. Beard, the ailing Washington lobbyist for the International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation, could be released from the hospital by this weekend, her doctor reported today.

WASHINGTON, March 28 (UPI) -- President Nixon's reelection organization denied today its campaign slowdown in the Wisconsin primary April 4 was aimed at encouraging Republican crossover votes for Gov. George C. Wallace of Alabama.

MILWAUKEE, March 28 (AP) -- The Golden State Warriors, down 13 points in the second quarter, rallied behind Jeff Mullins and Jim Barnett for a 117106 victory over the Milwaukee Bucks tonight and a 1-0 lead in their four-of-seven-game National Basketball Association Western Conference playoff.
Representative Charles Rangel in his letter of March 12 opposes heroin maintenance programs because they do nothing for the addict, and typify "colonialist attitudes" toward the addict population.
ANKARA, Turkey, March 28 -- Nihat Erim, the Turkish Premier, said today his Government would not yield to the demands of the kidnappers of three British radar technicians.

NORFOLK, Va., March 28 (AP) -- Wendell Ladner scored on a jump shot with 46 seconds left to break a tie and the Carolina Cougars went on to beat the Virginia Squires, 127-121, in an American Basketball Association game tonight.
Prices in the American Stock Exchange and in the over-thecounter market showed no definite trend and finished mixed yesterday in quiet trading.

HARRISBURG, Pa., March 28 -- In closing argument against the Harrisburg Seven, a Government attorney poured scorn today on the Rev. Philip F. Berrigan as a "priest of peace," contending that Father Berrigan and the other alleged antiwar conspirators planned acts of violence against the United States.

LA CROSSE, Wis., March 28 -- Gov. George C. Wallace of Alabama moved his campaign for the Presidency into the western reaches of Wisconsin today and assured those who questioned has past racial policies that he had never wronged the Negro.

Prof. Henry C. Johnson Jr.'s analysis in his March 4 letter falls short of completing the picture he depicts. There most definitely is a surplus in New York State and in most states.

When you win a 500-mile stock-car race by a couple of car lengths or so, it is easy to go back in review and find an array of incidents, any of which could have gone against you and robbed you of victory.

PHANRANG, South Vietnam, March 28 (AP) -- The United States Air Force deactivated its 315th Tactical Airlift Wing today and turned over to South Vietnam its Phanrang air base, built on the central coast six years ago at a cost of $60million.
Police Commissioner Patrick V. Murphy announced yesterday that he was establishing a compulsory weight-loss program for fat policemen.

BOSTON, March 29 (AP) -- Representative Wilbur D. Mills, Democrat of Arkansas, said today that the Administration's economic controls were not succeeding and that he was "just about ready to say we must go back to some sort of price freeze across the board."

Leo Durocher has been feeding at the baseball trough for all his adult life and it has been a rich repast. However, the brassy Leo had his youthful pretensions jarred ever so slightly last July when realization struck that he not only had joined the Medicare set but had started to collect payments on his baseball pension.

WASHINGTON, March 29 -- Secretary of the Treasury John B. Connally, after meeting with the heads of 12 major supermarket chains, predicted today that meat prices would decline over the next few weeks.

The Southern Pacific Company will continue to "press for approval from the Interstate Commerce Commission to purchase the Southern lines of the Chicago, Rock Island Pacific Railroad Company," Benjamin F. Biaggini, president of the Southern Pacific, said in an interview here yesterday.
James F. Regan, the new Staten Island appointee to the Board of Education, said yesterday that he would resign as a city teacher to avoid any possible conflict of interest.

WASHINGTON, March 29 -- The Securities and Exchange Commission made public today the names of members of three industry advisory committees that will help the commission develop the rules for implementation of its proposed changes in the structure of the securities markets.

MILWAUKEE, March 29 -- Senator George McGovern reported today that his Presidential campaign raised more than $240,000 from 2,984 contributors in February and early March, most of it before his unexpectedly strong second-place showing in the New Hampshire primary March 7.

LONDON -- The Northern Ireland Provincial Parliament is dead. But prospective mourners should not weep over the body as though once, in life and health, it was one of the hallowed institutions of Western democracy. The Stormont Government -- and the Constitution from which it sprang -- was founded on prejudice and sustained by bigotry.
A House Agriculture subcommittee, overriding its chairman, voted yesterday, 6 to 2, to ban potato-futures trading in all commodity markets in this country.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Thursday, March 30 -- North Vietnamese antiaircraft missiles shot down an Air Force AC-130 gunship over the Ho Chi Minh Trail in southern Laos early yesterday morning, and the 14 crewmen of the four-engine plane were declared missing today by the United States command.

It's rerun time again on the commercial networks. Except for the few new series that began earlier this year, the schedule for the next few months will be heavy with episodes already broadcast in the last year or so. If you managed to miss them the first time around, you're not safe yet.

LOS ANGELES, March 29 -- President Nixon's top environmental adviser, Russell E. Train, called today for a "national debate on the desirability of growth."

To the accompaniment of more lobbying activity than has been seen on Capitol Hill in a long while, the House of Representatives has turned down key amendments that would have made its Water pollution control bill comparable in strength to one passed unanimously last fall by the Senate. The pressure brought to bear against the amendments by industry was heavy but expected; pressure by the Administration to the same end was heavy and indefensible.

MIAMI, March 29 (AP) -- Alma North led from gate to wire today to win the $64,600 Black Helen Handicap at Hialeah Park. Her margin in the 1 1/8-mile race for fillies and mares was a length and a half.

WASHINGTON, March 29 -- Donald Blessing Rice, named today as president of the Rand Corporation, is known throughout the Federal bureaucracy as "a very good listener" and an unusually objective arbiter of highly competitive claims on the Government's tax dollar.

HARTFORD, March 29 -- An appeal by Ralph Nader to upset the merger of the International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation and the Hartford Fire Insurance Company was dismissed in Superior Court here today.

MILWAUKEE, March 29 -- A Midwest storm covered the campaign trail in Wisconsin with up to a foot of snow today, disrupting candidates' schedules and wiping out precious hours of stumping in this final week of the Presidential primary competition here.
PARIS, March 29 -- North Vietnam said today that it was waiting for the United States to take the initiative in resuming the stalled peace talks here.

And the owners, Richard Kennedy and his wife, Barbara, who are in their late twenties, look like walking advertisements for the clothes for men and women they've been making at 706 Avenue of the Americas for the last two years.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass. -- Over 500 law students gathered recently to hear Ralph Nader (class of '58) on a cold, wet, snowy Saturday night. Nader's message was a political one. He spoke of lawyers throwing out corrupt governments, of individual sacrifice and of commitment to the public interest.

Pan American World Airways confirmed yesterday that it had reached an agreement for the revolving credit arrangement for $270-million with 38 banks at an interest rate 1/2 per cent above the prime lending rate, currently at 4 3/4-5 per cent.

On the morning after a Soviet diplomat was showered with blood by a young Jewish Defense League militant at a Washington reception recently, Ambassador George Bush went before a Congressional committee to plead for legislation making it a Federal crime to harass or attack foreign diplomats in this country. Some such action is imperative.
Your March 17 editorial "Strange Spoiler" revives memories of forty years ago.
WASHINGTON, March 29 -- After voting overwhelmingly to restrict the right of citizens to file environmental suits, the House passed its version of a water pollution control bill today 378 to 14.

WASHINGTON, March 29 -- With Republican Senators complaining of dilatory tactics and Democrats warning of a whitewash, the Senate Judiciary Committee today scheduled a vote for Thursday of next week on Republican demands for an end to the hearings concerning the International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation.

Mattel, Inc., the nation's largest toymaker, operated in the red for the first time, during the fiscal year ended Jan. 29, with a net loss of $29,945,000, it was reported yesterday. This is in contrast to the $17,408,000 or $1.11 a share earned in the preceding fiscal year.
The four youths known as the "Harlem 4" will be released from jail on $5,000 bond each, probably tomorrow morning.

Conspicuously devoid of any rhyme, reason or rationality, Democratic party leaders have joined, from coast to coast, in a shrill, almost hysterical clamor of "We want Muskie!" No Particularly convincing argument has even been attempted as to why Muskie should be nominated or elected President, nor has there been any noticeable enthusiasm concerning his positive assets or qualifications.

STAMFORD, Conn. -- Nine years ago, when her older son was 2 1/2, Margaret Skutch scoured Stamford looking for a nursery school for him. She didn't find one she liked until a friend told her about a Montessori school an hour's drive away.
ALBANY, March 29 -- The Public Service Commission today granted the Consolidated Edison Company an increase in its electric rates to obtain an estimated total of $42.6-million in additional revenues.

WASHINGTON, March 29 -- Altimeters for about 300 Navy planes, bought last fall from a single manufacturer without competitive bidding, cost $1,700 apiece. Almost identical instruments, bought recently for about the same number of Air Force planes after competitive bidding by six manufacturers, cost $565 apiece.

JACKSONVILLE, Fla., March 29 (AP) -- A woman who has accused him of adultery offered him free love and became "angry and hostile" when he spurned her offer, Comdr. Andrew F. Jensen, a Navy chaplain, testified at his courtmartial today.
The old red firehouse at 48th Street and Eighth Avenue closed its doors for good yesterday as disgruntled firemen in Ladder Company 4 grumbled over their relocation to Engine Company 23.
The "surprising" Florida primary results contain an urgent message for the Democratic party politicos, if they but have the ears to hear and the common sense to heed.

WASHINGTON, March 29 -- The first major attempt to break up the Department of Health, Education and Welfare started today with almost 100 Congressmen backing a reorganization plan that the Nixon Administration strongly opposes.

BELFAST, Northern Ireland, March 29 -- Militant Protestants, buoyed by a two-day general strike that paralyzed Northern Ireland, met secretly today to plan further protests against Britain's take-over of the province.

MONTGOMERY, Ala., March 29 -- The Alabama Department of Public Safety, which was ordered by a Federal court in February to recruit more Negroes, announced today that the state's first three black state troopers had been hired.

HONG KONG, Thursday, March 30 (Reuters) -- China accused the United States today of arbitrarily suspending the Paris peace talks and urged the Nixon Administration to resume talks with the Vietnamese Communists in a serious manner.

Branch Industries, Inc., announced yesterday an agreement in principle with B. F. Goodrich Company for the purchase of all the outstanding stock of Motor Freight Corporation, a subsidiary of the rubber company, for an undisclosed amount of cash.

WASHINGTON, March 29 -- Senator J. W. Fulbright, Chairman of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee, asked the Justice Department today to restrain "forthwith" the use of a United States Information Agency film on Senator James L. Buckley's monthly television program to be shown starting this weekend on 12 stations in New York State.

At noon yesterday the siren at the West 68th Street police station sounded its last mournful blast and minutes later the green wooded doors of the 80-year old building -- with its grimy red-brick facade and its black iron carriage lamps -- were officially closed.

WASHINGTON, March 29 (AP) -- The Supreme Court today held, in a 6-to-1 decision, that the Topco cooperative association of about 25 small supermarket chains operating in 33 states violates Federal antitrust law.

Jerome Kretchmer, the city's Environmental Protection Administrator, said yesterday that the new Environmental Control Board had been so successful in speeding compliance with the Air Pollution Control Code that he was planning to extend the board's jurisdiction to other areas, such as littering.

The Lindsay administration announced plans yesterday to lay off 1,067 employes May 1 in probation, health, housing and air-pollution programs as a result of state budget cuts approved Tuesday in Albany.
The stock market, buffeted by adverse reports from Washington and by the pressures of mutual-fund "portfolio dressing," suffered yesterday its fourth decline in a row.

WASHINGTON, March 29 -- Postmaster General E. T. Klassen outlined today plans to improve the reputation and performance of the financially and professionally troubled Postal Service, including a 90-day freeze on hiring.

ALBANY, March 29 -- A state commission called on the Legislature today to exclude future employes from the liberal benefit provisions of the Legislative-Executive Plan -- the most envied in the state retirement system.

WASHINGTON, March 29 -- Five white liberal members of the House of Representatives from the Detroit area signed today a petition to force a House vote on a constitutional amendment prohibiting busing.

Gusto -- simple gusto as raw as Hogarth, as lecherous as Boswell, as malicious as Pope -- has taken over the Chelsea Theater Center of Brooklyn, where at the Academy of Music it is offering a positively euphoric and joyous production of "The Beggar's Opera."

The capacity crowd of 17,250 fans exploded in wild cheers last night when Vic Hadfield scored twice within 49 seconds to give the New York Rangers a 2-2 tie with the Detroit Red Wings at Madison Square Garden.

DACCA, Bangladesh, March 29 -- The Bangladesh Government plans to try 1,100 Pakistani military prisoners for war crimes and expects to begin the trials by the end of the year, official Bengali sources disclosed today.

MINEOLA, March 29 -- The commanding officer of the Nassau County Police Department's homicide squad called today for the resignation of District Attorney William Cabs, whom he accused of "bringing undue pressure against appointed officials of the department through the power of his office."
WASHINGTON, March 29 (AP) -- The Ford Motor Company violated antitrust law when it entered the spark plug business and took over the "Autolite" name, the Supreme Court ruled today by 7 to 0.
Martin H. Rod has been elected senior vice president-operations of James Talcott Factors, the factoring division of James Talcott, Inc., the financial organization.

NABLUS, Israeli - Occupied Jordan, March 29 (AP) -- Arab voters in the first elections held in Israeli-occupied territory have chosen five new leaders more or less opposed to King Hussein of Jordan and committed to an independent Palestine state, election results showed today.
YONKERS, March 29 -- On paper, tonight's $25,000 final of the Hopeful Pacing Series figured to be a two-horse race, though nine standardbreds went postward at Yonkers Raceway.

HARRISBURG, Pa., March 29 -- About 175 young men and women, most of them seminarians, surrounded the Federal Building with a chain today to protest the Vietnam war and expressed support for the Harrisburg Seven defendants on trial within.

WASHINGTON, March 29 -- Frank Shakespeare, the director of the United States Information Agency, is at odds with William Shakespeare, the playwright, and the issue -- marvelous to say -- is the value of a name.

WASHINGTON, March 29 -- The Justice Department today charged every major American manufacturer of aircraft with engaging in an illegal agreement to suppress competition in the research and development of aircraft and patentable components of aircraft.
BERLIN, March 29 -- For the first time in six years, the Berlin wall was opened today to allow West Berliners holiday visits in the East.

HARRISBURG, Pa., March 29 -- Former Attorney General Ramsey Clark charged today that the Government had raised an "outrageously false" case against the Rev. Philip F. Berrigan and six other antiwar activists accused of a bombing-kidnapping conspiracy.

WASHINGTON, March 29 -- Charles W. Bray 3d, State Department spokesman, said today that the United States had signed an agreement with Greece providing for the sale of two squadrons of F-4 Phantom jets. A Phantom squadron normally comprises 18 aircraft.

State Controller Arthur Levitt said yesterday that he would refuse to approve the use of state funds to pay for more than $16,000 worth of newspaper advertising placed this week by the Metropolitan Transportation Authority.

VALLEY COTTAGE, N. Y., March 29 -- Federal investigators restaged today some of the events that led last Friday to the collision of a Penn Central freight train and a school bus in this Rockland County community near Nyack. Four high school students died and more than 40 were injured as a result of the crash.
On past performances, Rokeby Stable's Bold and Bright appeared overmatched in the six-furlong sixth race at Aqueduct yesterday.

A choice, surviving fragment of the city's diminishing store of architectural treasure -- the houses of Striver's Row in Harlem -- will be given a thorough inspection in the next three months with a view toward historic preservation.
APPLETON, Wis., March 29 -- Gov. George C. Wallace of Alabama disclosed today campaign contributions that covered the last three years and totaled less than $1-million.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, March 29 (AP) -- Two American soldiers were killed and four wounded in a booby-trap explosion today as they patrolled a jungle area 31 miles east of Saigon.

CLEARWATER BEACH, Fla., March 29 -- Researchers in Boston are planning a clinical test of a new kind of oral contraceptive based on a form of the female hormone estrogen that some scientists believe may lower the risk of getting breast cancer.

Denmark will phase out its high-seas fishery for the endangered Atlantic salmon by 1976, according to Richard A. Buck, chairman of the Committee on the Atlantic Salmon Emergency, who received word of the Danish-United States agreement from the State Department.

Assemblyman Constance E. Cook, a liberal Republican from Ithaca, emerged yesterday as a leading contender for the Republican and possibly the Liberal nomination for the Court of Appeals, the state's highest court.
Proved recoverable reserves of crude oil fell 2.3 per cent in 1971, the American Petroleum Institute, the oil industry's major trade association, reported yesterday.

International Longshoremen's Association locals in Philadelphia approved a new labor contract by a vote of better than 5 to 1 yesterday and ended a strike that had kept the port closed since March 14.
A 23-year-old inmate under psychiatric observation on Riker's Island hanged himself last night with a noose fashioned from strips of his trousers, the Department of Corrections reported.

When Ch. Jenmist Dougal, a Sealyham, was named best of 2,736 dogs at the Harrisburg (Pa.) show, it was the 10th time the little white terrier had taken the honors at an all-breed fixture. But Mrs. Henry Sutliff Jr., his owner, has yet to see Dougal gain the top award.

United States Attorney Whitney North Seymour Jr. accused the Patrolmen's Benevolent Association yesterday of working against the interest of both the people and the policemen of New York in its attempts to discredit the Knapp Commission.

MILWAUKEE, March 29 -- Democratic candidates in the April 4 Presidential primary are frantically hopscotching around Wisconsin these days in pursuit of an electorate whose voting vagaries are as unpredictable as the early spring weather.

College and high school basketball teams will no longer take one foul shot after each of the first six common fouls charged to an opponent during a half. Starting next season, the team that is fouled will, instead, put the ball in play "from the point out of bounds nearest to the point of the foul" after those early infractions.
The fifth international Reykjavik tourament, a 16-man round robin, ended in a victory for Fridrick Olafsson of Iceland with 11 points, with the scoring on the Sonneborn Berger system.

Directors of the Great Western United Corporation announced last night in Denver that they had deferred indefinitely a previously announced recapitalization plan in which the company's $1.88 cumulative preferred stock would be re-classified as 1.5 shares of common stock each.
The deficit-plagued research libraries of the New York Public Library will receive up to $500,000 in Federal funds -- if the same amount can be raised from contributions between now and June 30.

CAMDEN, Ala., March 24 -- Every so often, as the morning plodded along, the soft-voiced black woman would leave the table at the front of the second-grade classroom and walk over to the line of dusty windows.
The recent criticisms of the press by two important advertising agency executives probably upset a lot of people.

PARIS, March 29 -- Monetary authorities from 10 industrial western nations, reaffirming their determination to defend the Dec. 18 currency realignment, established today that only four countries have had to absorb unwanted dollars since the December accord and that dollars had begun flowing back to the United States.
John Sebastian was at Philharmonic Hall Tuesday and Wednesday night, wearing his familiar tie-dyes, smiling his nonstop smile and exuding good vibes in all directions.

COLUMBIA, S. C., March 29 -- The South Carolina Democratic party, a free - wheeling mixture of old party regulars, Negroes and reform - minded college students, elected tonight 32 uncommitted delegates to the Democratic National Convention.

It is an entirely subjective notion that Senator Muskie "has lost momentum" or has "suffered slippage" in his campaign for the Democratic Presidential nomination as a result of his showing in the New Hampshire and Florida primaries. To be sure, the Senator is no longer regarded as the "front-runner," but the reality of that role was wholly confined to the imagery used by the media to describe the campaign.

Tell me: Who are the giants? Who will be remembered a century from now? Please pick two and advise by return mail.

A suit, believed to be the first of its kind, was filed yesterday in Federal Court in Newark by a young woman charging that a corporation executive attempted to make having sexual relations with him a condition of her continued employment and thus discriminated against her on the basis of her sex.

WASHINGTON, March 29 -- A little-known and never-used decision by the Federal Communications Commission would require radio and' television networks, if asked, to grant equal time to candidates opposing President Nixon if he held any broadcast news conferences between now and the Nov. 7 election.

WASHINGTON, March 29 (Reuters) -- The Senate today passed a bill temporarily extending to Aug. 1 the present system of controls on exports to Communist countries while Congress works out a new system.

The New York Clearing House Association, whose 11 member banks include six of the 10 largest banks in the country, has quietly introduced a new electronic money transfer system that portends major changes in the operation of the nation's money market.

WASHINGTON, March 29 -- The National Endowment for the Humanities, which has received scant public attention compared with its sister agency, the National Endowment for the Arts, which deals with such glamorous matters as theater, opera, film, orchestras and museums, is setting its sights on Middle America.

With some southern Vermont areas having reported subfreezing temperatures yesterday morning and the weather in general having remained cold, several dozen ski centers from the Poconos to Canada's Laurentians should stage their annual Easter fun programs without difficulty this weekend.

SANTIAGO, Chile, March 29 -- The "confiscation" of the properties in Chile of the International Telephone and Telegraph Company was proposed today by one of the minor parties of the governing Popular Unity coalition

Rogers has informed House Speaker Carl Albert that House Democratic Leader Hale Boggs and Republican Leader Gerald R. Ford have been invited to visit the Mainland.

Representative Shirley A. Chisholm, opening her New York State primary campaign for the Democratic Presidential nomination yesterday, announced the names of 32 delegate-candidates and then took to the streets for a bit of midtown and uptown sidewalk campaigning.
A special study group of the accounting profession released yesterday a long report proposing changes in how accounting standards are set and who sets them.

It's hard to believe after the stock market blood bath of 1969 and 1970, but it appears that wealthy investors are beginning to seek super-performance once again.

DACCA, Bangladesh, March 29 -- As a column of horsecarts carrying bagged rice plods along a dirt track on the edge of Faridpur, ragged children scramble in the dust for a few kernels that have escaped from a hole in a bag.

It is too early to be optimistic about Northern Ireland but there are encouraging developments in the aftermath of the suspension of the Stormont Government. Even William Craig, leader of the extremist Ulster Vanguard, has implored the Protestant majority to confine its actions to boycotts, strikes and civil disobedience, rather than engage in violence.

Playing a game contract from opposite sides of the table made a difference of two tricks on the diagramed deal from the Vanderbilt semifinal last Saturday between the defending Aces and the Precision team that won the title.

MIAMI, March 29 -- The New York Yankees will probably carry only two catchers, Thurman Munson and John Ellis, on their roster when the season begins, and the reasoning behind the decision offers some insight into the kind of problems baseball managers really think about.
The time has come, once and for all, to explode two myths that keep persisting about George McGovern.

Passover began at sundown yesterday, and Temple Emanu-el celebrated with a Seder last night. "Why is this night different from all other nights?" Russell Coyne asked the celebrants, and the Rev. Nathan A. Perilman answered:

SEATTLE, March 29 (AP) -- A Federal grand jury has indicted Leslie Bacon, the antiwar activist, on charges of committing perjury before a grand jury last year when she denied being inside the United States Capitol hours before a bomb exploded in a men's room.

Short - term interest rates came under renewed upward pressure yesterday, partly reflecting technical factors, while bond prices showed only narrow changes. Among the key money - market rates that climbed were those on commercial paper, certificates of deposit and the level at which the Federal Reserve extends temporary credit to dealers in Government securities.

Bausch Lomb, Inc., reported yesterday that five lawsuit have been brought against the company, charging that it violated Federal securities laws by failing to make prompt, public disclosure of an estimate of first-quarter earnings.

Dun Bradstreet, nine other corporations and 40 individuals, including an officer of the credit-rating concern and the No. 3 man in the Hempstead, L. I., insuring office of the Federal Housing Administration, were named in Federal indictments yesterday in an alleged multi-million-dollar housing fraud scheme.

The United States Equestrian Team's three-day squad -- Jack LeGoff, the coach, four riders and 12 horses -- left Kennedy Airport on a chartered KLM airliner yesterday for five months of pre-Olympic competition and training in Europe.

MACON, Ga., March 29 (UPI) -- Phil Dent of Australia upset second-seeded Cliff Drysdale of South Africa, 3-6, 6-3, 7-6, tonight in the second round of the fifth annual Macon international tennis tournament.
BUENOS AIRES, March 29 (UPI) -- The kidnappers of a Fiat executive, Oberdan Sallustro, indicated today he was still alive despite expiration of the deadline for payment of ransom for his release.

COLLONGES-AU-MONT-D'OR, France, March 29 -- If you read the French restaurant guides for 1972, haute cuisine is in trouble. The venerable Guide Michelin, out earlier this month, gave stars to eight fewer restaurants than it did last year, and Maxim's dropped one rooster in the ratings of the less renowned Guide Kleber.

WASHINGTON, March 29 -- King Hussein of Jordan avoided direct comment today on a report in The New York Times that his country and Libya had provided American-built combat aircraft to Pakistan during her war with India last year.

WASHINGTON, March 29 -- King Hussein of Jordan proposed today that, as part of a final peace agreement, his country and Israel should share the administration of Jerusalem as "a unified, open city -- a meeting place for the three great religions of the world."
Delta Air Lines announced yesterday it had signed a purchase agreement to buy 14 Boeing 727's from the Boeing Company at a cost of about $100-million.

PHILADELPHIA, March 29 (AP) -- Two minority stockholders in the syndicate that owns the pacer Albatross have obtained an injunction preventing removal of the horse from the stable of Stanley Dancer at Liberty Bell Park.

WQXR, the radio station of The New York Times, will not be sold, the board of directors of The New York Times Company announced yesterday. The board said it had decided to take the AM and FM outlets off the market and to continue to operate them.

ALBANY, March 29 -- The state's Commissioner of Correctional Services said today that a controversial "maximum program, maximum security" prison would be created out of an existing prison facility in the state and that the first inmates would be moved into it about May 1.

ALBANY, March 29 -- Two bills that would authorize the state Housing Finance Agency to issue an additional $1.5-billion in bonds and notes to finance mortgage loans for limited-income housing and for hospital and nursing-home facilities were submitted today to the Legislature on the Governor's behalf.
TORONTO, March 29 (UPI) -- Four first-period goals enabled the Toronto Maple Leafs to beat Boston, 4-1, tonight and snap the unbroken string of the Bruins' goalie, Gerry Cheevers, at 32 games.

The Reynolds Metal Company said at Richmond, Va., yesterday that it had filed a proposal with the Atomic Energy Commission to organize a consortium of companies that would build, own and operate a gaseous diffusion plant to enrich uranium fuel for nuclear-power generating plants.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 29 -- In a surprise move today, the Mets optioned Charlie Williams, a pitcher, to their Tidewater (Va.) farm as well as Tim Foli, an infielder; Don Hahn, an outfielder, and seven other players of lesser note.

Police union delegates yesterday overwhelmingly rejected a new contract proposal that would have raised annual pay and benefits to $16,894 and also would have provided for a revision of patrolmen's work schedules.

A decline in electric utility projects in February brought the total value of nationwide construction contracts awarded in that month to their lowest level in three months, the F. W. Dodge division of the McGraw-Hill Information Systems Company reported yesterday.
ALBANY, March 29 -- Long Island Rail Road work gangs were found more idle than in the past, wasting more than a quarter of their time, according to clandestine observations made by state auditors.

BRATSK, U.S.S.R., March 23 -- Across the vast expanses of Siberia, the prospect of President Nixon's visit to the Soviet Union this spring stirs little excitement. People are more interested in knowing about American cars, books, rock groups and fashions.
The American Stock Exchange and the over-the-counter market took beatings yesterday as both lists dropped sharply in quiet trading.

Manhattan Assemblyman Franz Leichter was not precisely right when he labeled a boondoggling bill expanding membership on New York City's Board of Elections as one creating a "soup kitchen for retired politicians." The bill establishes not one but five soup kitchens. They loom as sanctuaries in which financial sustenance can be found for the faithful who, for reasons of age or otherwise, no longer can stand the heat of the hustings.

SAN JOSE, Calif., March 29 -- Angela Davis, in an emotional declaration of her innocence, said today that she had purchased some guns but vigorously denied that she had given them to a group that tried to free George Jackson from prison.
LA PAZ, Bolivia, March 29 -- The Bolivian Government has ordered 119 members of the Soviet Embassy staff to leave the country within seven days, Foreign Minister Mario Gutierrez said tonight.
WASHINGTON, March 29 -- John B. Connally, the Secretary of the Treasury, has emphasized to anyone who will listen or cares to ask that he has no plans to switch to the Republican party.
BOSTON, March 29 (AP) -- The Boston Celtics returned to the National Basketball Association playoffs they once ruled with a 126-108 triumph over the Atlanta Hawks tonight.

WASHINGTON, March 29 -- Henry A. Kissinger, President Nixon's adviser on national security, will fly to Tokyo on April 15 for three days of informal discussions with Japanese leaders, the White House announced tonight.

Crime and adventure series will make up the major part of the new programing the National Broadcasting Company will present next season, a first look yesterday at its fall scheduled disclosed.
ROME, March 29 -- The Vatican said today that 13,450 Roman Catholic priests abandoned their vocations from 1964 through 1969.

BOSTON, March 29 -- Samuel L. Popkin, an assistant professor of government at Harvard, was held in contempt today by a Federal District judge for refusing to answer nine questions before a grand jury investigating the release and distribution of the Pentagon papers.

PARIS, March 29 -- Sixteen creditor nations in effect rejected today a proposal by the Chilean Government of Dr. Salvador Allende Gossens for a consolidation of debts. They made a counteroffer, however, that seemed as favorable as that granted the previous Chilean Government

TRENTON, March 29 -- Gov. William T. Cahill announced today that he was sending medical and dental units of the New Jersey National Guard into the state prison here in response to inmate demands for improved care.

WASHINGTON, March 29 -- The Senate began debate today on a bill that its sponsors contend is necessary to check the war-making powers of the presidency. The Administration has protested that the measure is unconstitutional and unwise.

GREENSBORO, N. C., March 29 -- "It was a stupid decision," Lee Trevino said today about his voluntary two-year options from the Masters golf tournament. Here to compete in the $200,000 Greater Greensboro open that starts tomorrow, Trevino is looking ahead to the Masters, which begins in Augusta, Ga., a week from tomorrow.

MOSCOW, March 29 -- A current of thought worrying its way through the West, the idea that economic growth has ecological limits that may be reached in the next few generations, has not yet reached the public in the Soviet Union.

PALM BEACH, Fla. -- "Palm Beach is not particularly a rhinestone town," Ceil Day said. She was explaining why there are so few rhinestone collars in her Poodle Paradise, a shop dedicated to keeping rich people's pets looking like rich people's pets.

Who speaks for the majority, the weakly unionized and the white collar worker?

WASHINGTON, March 30 (AP) -- Secretary of Agriculture Earl L. Butz today criticized the European Common Market for having raised import levies on United States corn by 11 per cent last week.

JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, March 30 (UPI) -- France's unseeded nonwhite tennis star, Wanero N'Godrella, provided the first upset in the men's singles today when he eliminated 15th-seeded Dick Crealy of Australia in straight sets in the second round of the South African open championships, the first multiracial tennis tournament in this country.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Friday, March 31 -- North Vietnamese gunners poured up to 4,000 rounds of their heaviest artillery, rockets and mortars into South Vietnamese bases and towns along the demilitarized zone yesterday in the biggest attack since the sieges of Conthien and Khesanh more than four years ago.
