WARSAW, March 30 -- The Roman Catholic Church in Poland accused the police today of raiding a chapel in a village on the outskirts of Warsaw and forcibly removing its tabernacle.

NEWARK, March 30 -- A prominent Bergen County physician disclosed here today that he had performed two abortion this morning at his Englewood Cliffs office, in defiance of a directive by the State Attorney General that such abortions were still a criminal act in New Jersey.

In an effort to attract ethnic-group fans, the New York Cosmos of the North American Soccer League announced yesterday the signing of two star players on the international scene -- Cinesinho of Lanerossi Vicenza of Italy and Helenio Herrera Jr. of Real Madrid of Spain.

The Museum of Modern Art called off yesterday its scheduled showing of six Cuban films that are among 23 the Treasury Department has been trying to seize since last week as alleged smuggled contraband.

CLEARWATER BEACH, Fla., March 30 -- A series of studies, including an investigation of 32,000 families with pet cats, has turned up absolutely no evidence of a link between cancer in the animals and leukemia in man.
DETROIT, March 30 (AP) -Ford Motor Company announced today it had completed the purchase of 483,750 shares of its own Class A stock from the Ford Foundation for approximately $35.5-million.

ATHENS, March 30 -- An authoritative Government source said today that unless President Makarios bowed to Greek demands, Greece would proceed toward a solution of the Cyprus problem without consulting the Cypriote Government.

The Federal Reserve System pumped $1.3-billion into the money market this week in an apparent attempt to slow the recent sharp rise in short-term money rates, the central bank's weekly statement showed yesterday.
WASHINGTON, March 30 -- The Nixon Administration is reported to be seriously concerned over the increased casualty rate in the air war in Indochina.

MONTGOMERY, Ala., March 30 -- Alabama's state highway director has abruptly resigned amid reports that top state officeholders have been under pressure to make personal contributions to the Presidential campaign of Gov. George C. Wallace.

The Roman Catholic priest who bought a full-page advertisement in Playboy magazine last January to stimulate recruitment for the Order of the Most Holy Trinity (Trinitarians) has come up with an ecclesiastical bonanza.

The question is rather how to make the Federal Government's involvement more effective.

CHUB CAY, the Bahamas -- On the final day of the Crown Colony Club's recent his-and-hers billfish tournament, Edwin J. Gould of New York City boated a 549-pound Atlantic blue marlin on 30pound test line.

SAN JOSE, Calif., March 30 -- The state's first witness in the murder trial of Angela Davis said today that her testimony may have been influenced by the prosecutor.

ROME, March 30 -- Rome's City Hall announced today that bus and streetcar fares would be permanently abolished during rush hours.

HARTFORD, March 30 -- A Federal Court here today declared unconstitutional Connecticut's controversial plan for reapportioning the General Assembly. The ruling stunned the state's legislative and political leaders.
BALTIMORE, March 30 -For the New York Knicks, the National Basketball Association playoffs would not be authentic without a rugged series against the Baltimore Bullets.

TEMPE, Ariz., March 30 (UPI) -- Marvin Miller, executive director of the Major League Baseball Players Association, said today on the eve of a critical vote on whether to call a strike against the game, "it's all up to the players now."

FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla., March 30 -- Fritz Peterson pitched a two-hit shutout tonight, the first complete game by a Yankee hurler this spring, and defeated the Montreal Expos, 4-0. The White House announced yesterday that President Nixon would sign an Executive order blocking for at least 60 days two strikes threatened tonight against the nation's railroads.

Following is the text of a letter by Dr. William J. Ronan, chairman of the Metropolitan Transit Authority, to W. Paul Stillman, chairman of the selection committee of the Port of New York Authority, withdrawing his name from consideration for the post of executive director of the Port Authority:

LIMA, Peru, March 30 (AP) -A Peruvian appeals court has turned down an appeal against an order forcing the publisher Pedro G. Beltran to resign as director and sell his stock in the Lima newspaper La Prensa.
WASHINGTON, March 30 -Common Cause announced today details of its plans for a national program to monitor political campaign contributions.

PHILADELPHIA, March 30 (AP) -- The Philadelphia Flyers rallied for three goals in the third period tonight to defeat the Buffalo Sabres, 3-1, and gain sole possession of fourth place in the West Division of the National Hockey League.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, March 30 -- They sell cars to G.I.'s in the PX and hunt for Vietcong in the jungle. They live in air-conditioned bungalows called Palm Springs and marry willowy Vietnamese. They are the handful of Americans, out of two million soldiers and 50,000 civilians, who have stayed on, year after year, as people back home have become discouraged and disillusioned with the war in Vietnam.
WASHINGTON, March 30 -The Agriculture Department announced today a decline in its index of farm prices after five consecutive months of increases.

LONDON -- British officials have a way of questioning whatever worldpolitical trends happen to be fashionable at the moment, so they are watching the Soviet Union's new "reasonable" diplomacy with detached skepticism.
A Federal grand jury yesterday indicted five individuals and a brokerage cooncern for allegedly defrauding stock purchasers by using a false and misleading offering circular in the sale of stock.

To the Editor: Your lighthearted March 15 editorial "The People's Pandas" struck a sensitive nerve in stating that the arrival of the pandas will offset the loss of the Washington Senators baseball team. It was a clumsy comparison at best.

POMONA, N. Y., March 30 -Survivors of the train-school bus collision in nearby Valley Cottage a week ago, along with members of the train crew and a 10-year-old boy who saw the crash from his bedroom window, recalled the accident in vivid detail here today at a Medical Examiner's inquest.

SPRINGFIELD, Ill., March 30 (AP) -- Disorderly conduct convictions of 13 persons, including Murray Kempton, the political commentator, arising from demonstrations in Chicago at the 1968 Democratic National Convention, were upheld today by the Illinois Supreme Court.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., March 30 -- United States and United Nations sources today announced their satisfaction with the efforts being made to relieve war and faminen in Bangladesh although the progress seems slow.

WASHINGTON, March 30 -The Secretary of the Interior, Rogers C. B. Morton, said today that the United States consumed 69,010-trillion British thermal units of energy last year, 2.3 per cent more than in the previous year and more than ever before in history.

ALBANY, March 30 -- The state and the Civil Service Employes Association reached a tentative agreement today that would give most state workers a 4 per cent increase in their salary rate, but no actual cash raises for the next 12 months.

Former Mayor Carl B. Stokes of Cleveland, recently signed by the National Broadcasting Company as co-anchorman of WNBC-TV's 6 P.M. newscasts, said yesterday that in view of his contract he would not serve as a delegate to the Democratic Convention if elected.

The New York Stock Exchange announced yesterday that it had censured and levied a $25,000 fine against a former managing partner of Newburger, Loeb Co. and had barred him from having any association with any clearing member firm without prior approval from the exchange.

To the Editor: In his letter of March 24, Controller Abraham D. Beame argued against the editorial position taken by The Times and in favor of formal Board of Estimate and City Council approval of detailed, itemized schedules of Capital Budget "lump sum" appropriations. The Controller conveniently -- but to my mind incorrectly -- combined two very different matters in discussing this technically complex issue.
JERUSALEM, March 30 -A desolate courtyard where Israeli and Arab soldiers faced each other for 19 tense years is yielding dramatic archeological evidence of the Jerusalem of the time of Jesus.
WASHINGTON, March 30 (AP) -- The Civil Aeronautics Board approved today a series of international airline agreements providing for fare increases ranging from one-half of 1 per cent to 10 per cent.

Daniel K. Ludwig, the publicity-shy shipbuilder, sent his regrets and warm regards in a hand-delivered letter. James Foley, former vice chairman of Texaco, sent a telegram. Robert C. Hills, former president of Freeport Sulphur, and Joel Hunter, once president of Crucible Steel, wrote from retirement in New Orleans and Delray.

JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, March 30 -- Roy Wilkins, executive director of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People, today challenged interpretations placed by news agencies on his recent remarks about United States business involvement in South Africa.
With John Mallano riding to victory for the first time in his career, Mrs. Lafayette E. Thomas's Noble Splash took the feature race at Aqueduct yesterday.
A $160-million increase in New York Telephone Company rates that has been in effect since Feb. 3 was approved by the Price Commission yesterday.
TOKYO, March 30 (AP) -- Muhammad Ali and Mac Foster will meet in Japan's first heavyweight fight on Saturday.

SMITHTOWN, L. I., March 30 -- Senator James L. Buckley today made his first endorsement of a local candidate since he was elected to office in 1970. He backed a Conservative incumbent Assemblyman, Charles Jerabek.

Trading in meat futures on the Chicago Mercantile Exchange yesterday was described by a Chicago commodity broker as "nervous." He said there was no doubt that trading was affected by Secretary of the Treasury John B. Connally's recent meeting with heads of major supermarket chains in an effort to stabilize rising meat prices at the consumer level.
Elgin National Industries, Inc., incurred a $13,234,147 deficit last year compared with a loss of $895,576 in 1970, despite increased sales.

DALLAS, March 30 (AP) -Don Dunfield, who was runnerup seven times previously, captured the men's one-meter title for the first time today in the National Amateur Athletic Union indoor diving championships.
MOSCOW, March 30 -- The Soviet Union announced today the completion of a strategic 500-mile oil pipeline that will ultimately extend from the west Siberian fields across Siberia to the Pacific.
A technical rally led by glamour issues and some soothing monetary comments from Europe combined to send stock prices briskly higher yesterday.
David A. Schwartz' bag is package testing. Or is it his package that is bag testing? Well, whichever it is he uses a tachistoscope to do it.

WASHINGTON March 30 -The Equal Employment Opportunity Commission has strengthened its regulations on job discrimination against women and has broadened the rules to include for the first time employer policies on pregnancy and childbirth.

A subcontractor who has built a key part of Consolidated Edison's new nuclear power plant at Indian Point, N. Y., has asked the Atomic Energy Commission to withhold the licensing of the reactor because of "inadequate, incomplete and questionable design" of parts of the reactor that pose "a serious problem of plant safety."

The Association of the Bar of the City of New York is considering the feasibility of conducting an inquiry into what it has described as compelling evidence that serious breaches of the law of war have been committed by all parties in the Indochina war.

Moved by some strange compulsion to revisit the scene, Bob Short returned to Washington the other day to tell 400 listeners in the National Press Club why he took their baseball team to Texas. They paid $4 each to hear him, which is a measure of inflation; six months ago, $3.50 would have enabled them to watch Frank Howard swing a bat.

WASHINGTON, March 30 -At least 40 million families and individuals are having too much Federal income tax withheld this year, and the question of what to do about the problem has started an intense dispute within the Nixon Administration.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., March 30 -- The Soviet Union closed the door today on its participation in the planned Stockholm conference on global environmental problems -and then cautiously reopened the door a crack.
Dr. William J. Ronan, the chairman of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority, yesterday withdrew his name from consideration for the post of executive director of the Port of New York Authority.
WESTPORT, Conn. -- "I don't know if it's really possible to be free and married," says a Fairfield County housewife. "I think of marriage as an oppressive institution."

Most interest rates continued to creep higher yesterday in a quiet session dominated by holiday and end-of-quarter influences. A scattering of money-rate increases was recorded in bankers' acceptances, commercial paper and certificates of deposit, but some of these represented catch-up moves of in stitutions that did not raise rates earlier.
A new dance theater will be opened next fall in the Lincoln Center area to house the Harkness Ballet and other performing groups.

Directors of the Clorox Company and Martin-Brower Corporation yesterday approved the terms under which Clorox will acquire Martin-Brower. An agreement in principle was announced by the two concerns on March 6.

FRANKFORT, Ky., March 30 -- Former Gov. Louie B. Nunn strode into the state capitol 28 minutes before the midnight deadline and filed last night to run for Senator in the Republican primary. Minutes later, John Y. Brown Jr., the fried chicken millionaire, who had been considering entering the Democratic primary, drove away from the premises without filing.

SANTIAGO, Chile, March 30 -- The Chilean Congress has decided to investigate past activities of the United States Central Intelligence Agency and the International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation reportedly aimed at keeping President Salvador Allende Gossens from taking office in 1970.
Bankers in 24 states have been quietly experimenting with high-risk loans to the poor, a leading American banker disclosed here yesterday.

WILMINGTON, Del., March 30 -- After three years of mostly unsuccessful attempts to persuade the White House to do more for the troubled central cities, George Romney began a last-ditch effort today to get some action.

KIEL, Wis. -- There are 12 candidates on the Democratic ballot in Tuesday's Wisconsin Presidential primary, but only three seem to excite Kiel, a city of 2,858 in the dairy country northwest of Sheboygan ("home of world champion cheddar cheese," says a sign outside town).

MOSCOW, March 30 -- A Soviet space official disclosed today that the primary mission of Venus 8, an unmanned spacecraft launched earlier this week, was to determine the chemistry of the surface of Venus.

LA PAZ, Bolivia, March 30 (UPI) -- The Soviet Ambassador in La Paz today denied any wrongdoing on the part of his embassy and said it had only 40 attaches in Bolivia and not the 119 the Government had asked be withdrawn.
WASHINGTON, March 30 -The giant United States Government machine is slowly gearing itself for President Nixon's trip to Moscow in May.

James Pope-Hennessy has written a most peculiar book. WASHINGTON, March 30 -- Western diplomatic sources reported today that the Soviet Union transferred some of its jet warplanes from Egypt to India last December to replace Indian Air Force losses during the Indian-Pakistani war.
A State Supreme Court justice upheld the sanctity of a burial ground and barred a 71-year- old man from selling a part of a cemetery plot that has been in his family for more than 100 years.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass. -- American university students seem more relaxed and tolerant today than two or three years ago, less tense, less hysterical and less given to violent protest against governmental policies with which they disagree or against intellectuals associated with such policies.

Not for the first time in the Ulster agony the Catholic Primate of all Ireland has made a timely contribution to sanity and peaceful advance. Cardinal Conway says he "would not shed a single tear" if the Irish Republic's Constitution were amended to eliminate the special status of the Catholic Church and to provide for legal divorce as it now obtains in Northern Ireland.

BELFAST, Northern Ireland, March 30 -- On his last day as Prime Minister of Northern Ireland, Brian Faulkner made an unexpected plea today for "complete integration" of Northern Ireland into the United Kingdom.
ALBANY, March 30 -- The Public Service Commission today authorized the Long Island Lighting Company to impose an average electricity rate increase of 2.3 per cent on 800,000 customers.

DETROIT, March 30 -- "You see these plans, the sketches -- it's a fever," was the way Sal Ciaramitaro, a fruit and vegetable man, explained what has happened.

It would be pleasant to praise the films of Robert Nelson, if only because they openly invite praise and aggressively associate themselves with the most obvious signs and symbols of entertainment.

Healthy variety and good craftsmanship rather than originality marked the New York debut of the Ririe-Woodbury Dance Company from Salt Lake City Wednesday night at the Louis-Nikolais Dance Theater Lab, 344 West 36th Street.

HARRISBURG, Pa., March 30 -- The conspiracy case of the Rev. Philip F. Berrigan and six other antiwar activists went to the jury this afternoon after a charge by Federal District Judge R. Dixon Herman that was denounced by defense attorneys as "a summation for conviction."
WASHINGTON, March 30 -The Treasury announced today its final regulations under the 1970 law aimed at curbing the abuse of secret foreign bank accounts by organized and "white collar" criminals.

MILWAUKEE, March 30 (AP) -- Kareem Abdul-Jabbar scored 25 points tonight to lead the Milwaukee Bucks to a 118-93 victory over the Golden State Warriors. The triumph squared their National Basketball Association Western Conference semifinal playoff series at 1-1.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, March 30 -- Communist gunners and ground troops staged a series of heavy, apparently coordinated attacks on eight South Vietnamese fire support bases along the demilitarized zone today, and the fighting reportedly continued into the night.
GREENSBORO, N. C., March 30 -- J. C. Snead, whose golfing uncle, Sam, had won here before he was born, shared the first-round lead today in the $200,000 Greater Greensboro open at 66.

Beard's former secretary, said in an interview here today that the International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation regularly did favors for members of Congress and that she herself handled a request from Senator Vance Hartke last summer for use of one of the company's jet planes.

Although the Vanderbilt Cup, with 64 teams competing, was the prestige event in the Spring Nationals of the American Contract Bridge League in Cincinnati last week, it was numerically overshadowed by the Swiss teams, which attracted 224 teams for two days of play.

Restaurants reviewed on this page on Friday are rated both for their food (four stars to none) and for their atmosphere, service and decor (four triangles to none).

WASHINGTON, March 30 -- Manufacturers' inventories declined $100-million in February, thus continuing the inventory sluggishness that has prevailed for more than a year, the Commerce Department reported today.
ANKARA, Turkey, March 30--The police stormed a house in a mountain village today and killed 10 leftist terrorists after the terrorists had murdered three foreign hostages, the Government reported.

HANOVER, West Germany, March 30 (Reuters) -- Health authorities here today quarantined 193 more people known to have been in contact with a Yugoslav migrant worker suffering from smallpox, raising the total isolated to nearly 450.

Good Friday, the day Jesus died on the cross and one of the most sacred days in the church year, was observed in solemn reverence yesterday by millions of Christian churchgoers.
WEST ALLIS, Wis., March 31 -- Senator Edmund S. Muskie called today for an $18-billion cut in defense spending over the next four years, with the savings to be channeled into domestic programs.

DETROIT, March 31 (AP) -Domestic auto production fell sharply this week as auto plants closed for Good Friday.

VEGA BAJA, P. R., March 31 -- Thousands of young people from the East Coast of the United States and from Puerto Rico flowed onto a 429-acre former dairy farm just three miles from this small town today, joining more than 5,000 already there for the Mar y Sol Pop Music Festival planned for this weekend.

JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, March 31 -- A passenger train plunged off the rails today, killing 38 persons and injuring 174. Railroad investigators reported later that they had found "signs of sabotage" at the scene of the crash, about 200 miles north of Johannesburg.
DALLAS, March 31 -- The Major League Baseball Players Association voted today to strike against Organized Baseball, effective with exhibition games scheduled to be played tomorrow.

A 27-year-old freelance writer has accused the Church of Scientology in a lawsuit filed here of "intentional' interference" with her constitutional freedom of speech and press, charging that the organization threatened her in the form of libel suits and wiretapping after her critical book about the quasireligious organization was published last fall.

The Senate Judiciary Committee's inquiry into Deputy Attorney General Richard Kleindienst's involvement in the settlement of the I.T.T. antitrust case has cast startling light on the conduct of the Justice Department during the Nixon Administration. HARRISBURG, Pa., March 31 -- About 30 demonstrators were seized by the military police today after they scaled the fence of the New Cumberland Army Depot near here in attempts to plant small trees. WASHINGTON, April 3 (UPI) -- Describing a manned spacecraft as "a microsociety in a miniworld," a scientific group said today that the social needs of crew members must be taken into account in planning long duration flights of up to two years.

MILWAUKEE, April 3 -- As the leading contenders in tomorrow's Wisconsin Democratic Presidential primary campaigned around the state today, Gov. Patrick J. Lucey predicted that Senator George McGovern of South Dakota would win the election.

Most interest rates floated higher across a broad front yesterday, extending a general trend in force for several weeks. Investors continue to fear an unsuccessful attack on inflation and increasing demands for credit.

The City Stores Company, operator of the W. J. Sloane furniture chain, will open a Levitz Furniture-type of warehouse-showroom store, with the first unit in a proposed chain to begin operating late this year in New Orleans.
DACCA, Bangladesh, March 29 -- Less than four months after its birth, the new nation of Bangladesh is struggling against many divisive forces as it seeks order and stability.
SALT LAKE CITY, April 3 (UPI) -- The Utah Stars rallied in the fourth quarter tonight to beat the Dallas Chaparrals, 113-107, in the American Basketball Association's Western Division playoffs.

City officials estimated yesterday that individual welfare families' grants would be cut nearly a third below basic needs if the State Legislature enacted a proposed freeze on over-all spending on family and home relief caseloads.

WASHINGTON, April 3 (Reuters) -- The United States Supreme Court left standing today a lower court's ruling that Fisons, Ltd., a major British chemical producer, must stand trial in an Illinois Federal Court on antitrust charges brought by the Federal Government.

Racial tensions, distrust, some fist fights and a near total segregation in all but classroom activities characterize the relationships between black and white students on many major American college and university campuses.

Three members of the Congress of Racial Equality who allegedly took two students from a Bronx high school and beat them in retaliation for an alleged assault and threats on the son of the national director of CORE pleaded guilty yesterday to charges of assault.

WASHINGTON, April 3 (UPI) -- Mr. Volcker said he did not anticipate any resumption in the near future of the convertibility of the dollar into gold. Mr. Nixon suspended convertibility last Aug. 15 as part of his new economic policy.

WASHINGTON, April 3 (AP) -- President Nixon signed legisation today formally devaluing the dollar, saying the action was only part of a move toward a more stable international economic order. The dollar has been devalued, for practical purposes, since last December to a varying degree in terms of other currencies.

Robert J. Witt has been elected an executive vice president of Hart Schaffner Marx, a major manufacturer and retailer of men's apparel. He was also named chairman and chief executive officer of the Chicago-based company's retail store division.
Voicing dismay at the curtailment of services in the city's 18 public hospitals, the system's senior physicians have voted to disband the Advisory Council of Medical Boards.
One hundred union printers struck The Morning Telegraph yesterday, shutting down the racing newspaper, which has a 50,000 daily circulation. About 275 employes were made idle.

WASHINGTON, April 3 -Bruce Herschensohn, who recently accused Senator J. W. Fulbright of having "very naive and stupid" views, resigned abruptly today as director of the United States Information Agency's motion picture and television division.
Stretched out across the centerfold of this month's British Cosmopolitan magazine is a muscular nude, his right leg strategically bent to keep him modest.

HEMPSTEAD, L. I., April 3 -- The Federal Housing Authority's office here has begun recently to take a new direction -- actively improving the quality, not only of new housing in the suburbs, but also of older housing in the core city, where the houses of most of those who receive F.H.A. mortgage insurance are located.
HARTFORD, April 3 (UPI) -- Major revisions in a proposed no-fault auto insurance plan in Connecticut, including the grounds for filing lawsuits, were announced today.
A detective chasing a suspect was shot to death in the vestibule of a Queens shoe store yesterday by a uniformed patrolman who apparently mistook him for a criminal.

The Anti-Defamation League of B'nai B'rith announced yesterday that it had been successful in protesting a state announcement limiting applications for some prison jobs to blacks and Spanish-speaking people.

WASHINGTON, April 3 -- The powerful North Vietnamese offensive across the demilitarized zone into Quangtri Province illustrates at once the weakness of the so-called Vietnamization program and the paradox of President Nixon's domestic political position.

Three colts who are eligible for all three jewels of this year's Triple Crown, and two who could start in at least one of them, faced five rivals in a seven-furlong contest that preceded the feature at Aqueduct yesterday. All 10 carried identical weights -- 121 pounds.

ALBANY, April 3 (UPI) -Representatives of the Association of Off-Track Betting Municipalities are joining forces with horse owners and drivers to fight Governor Rockefeller's proposed one-year moratorium on off-track betting outside New York City, spokesmen for the group disclosed today.

TRENTON, April 3 -- The New Jersey Real Estate Commission today charged Joseph M. Ryan, an East Orange real estate broker, with misconduct and "dishonest dealings" in connection with the sale of homes to indigents under a Federal mortgage guarantee program.

Kenneth Elstein's letter of March 20, accusing Senator Muskie of excluding the "rank and file" from the delegate process, must have come as a surprise to the thousands of people who have received letters inviting them to open public meetings. It must also have come as a surprise to the uncountable thousands who have seen advertising in their local newspapers inviting them to the open meetings held in each Congressional district of New York State.
MONTPELIER, Vt., April 3 (AP) -- Deane C. Davis announced today that he would not seek a third two-year term as Vermont's Governor.

The recent Times editorial on the Office of Economic Opportunity's performance contracting experiment seriously distorts O.E.O.'s conclusions and even the intent of the experiment. It leaves the impression that our conclusions were hastily prepared and at variance with results of the Rand evaluation, which is in fact not the case.
A rise in business activity during the month of February was indicated yesterday by data from various sources.

Civil Court Judge Ross J. DiLorenzo was reinstated to the bench yesterday after the Appellate Division of the State Supreme Court in Brooklyn censured him for discussing a Waterfront Commission investigation with a commission lawyer.
China yesterday issued its first known invitation to an American company to attend the Canton Trade Fair.
The Chesapeake Ohio Railway announced yesterday that its earnings were the highest for any first quarter since it gained control of the Baltimore Ohio Railroad in 1963.
The 14-man table-tennis team from China is scheduled to arrive in Detroit on April 12 for the start of a two-week tour of the United States.

WASHINGTON, April 3 -- The Supreme Court ruled 5 to 2 today that unwed fathers, like unmarried mothers, cannot be denied custody of their illegitimate children without an opportunity to prove that they are fit parents.

ATLANTIC CITY, April 3 -Three young women and a millionaire heroin pusher were killed here today in what the police said was a wild nightclub shootout by gunmen from rival Philadelphia narcotics rings.

KOROR, Palau Islands, April 3 (Reuters) -- United States and Micronesian negotiators began full-scale talks here today on the future political status of the United States Trust Territory of the Pacific.
The most protracted event in the New York bridge season and perhaps also the hardest to win, is now approaching its final stage.
ALBANY, April 3 -- Governor Rockefeller recommended today that the state establish standards and regulatory authority for the franchising and operating of cable television across the state.

WASHINGTON, April 3 -The United States accused Hanoi today of launching an "invasion" of South Vietnam and said Washington was leaving open all retaliatory options -- including renewed American bombing of North Vietnam.

Prices on the American Stock Exchange and in the over-thecounter market ended mixed yesterday in moderate trading.

Charles F. Barber, chairman of the American Smelting and Refining Company (Asarco), complained of a Times editorial, "Threat to the White Cloud Peaks," in a letter (March 4). His letter seemed remarkably reasonable unless the reader is familiar with the issue. But ldahoans are well aware of the White Clouds controversy and even the most polished of Asarco's public relations efforts ring false.

The New York operations of Farley Manning Associates and Selvage, Lee Howard, both public relations companies, have merged to become Manning, Selvage Lee and, with their subsidiaries and affiliated firms, have established the Manning, Selvage Lee Group.

The Horn Hardart Company, operator of restaurants, retail shops and cafeterias, has elected Frederick H. Guterman as president, chief executive officer and a director. He formerly was a group executive at International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation, in charge of aerospace, tubes and electro-optical operations.

Even at one game each in their four-of-seven-game first-round National Basketball Association series, the Knicks and Bullets shift the scene of combat tonight to Baltimore's Civic Center for game No. 3.

The Columbia Broadcasting System and the American Broadcasting Company announced their fall schedules yesterday, and between them they are canceling 14 of this year's programs and bringing in the same number of new shows.
VIENTIANE, Laos, April 3 (UPI) -- Laotian forces have recaptured three helicopter pads on a ridge overlooking the base of Long Tieng, Laotian and American sources reported today.
The last of the Hudson River sidewheelers, a descendant or Robert Fulton's Clermont, made her final voyage yesterday, to a retirement mooring in the East River.

The state committee of the Liberal party endorsed two judges already selected by the Democrats and one judge selected by the Republicans as the Liberal candidates for three vacancies on the State Court of Appeals.

YONKERS, April 3 -- Yonkers Raceway, usually the habitat of trotters and pacers, will sponsor for the first time the 37th annual Yonkers Marathon on June 11. The grueling foot-racing test will start and finish at the harness racing track, with the competitors making five or six exits and entrances while running 26 miles 385 yards.
You've got to admit that a gift-wrapped Madison Avenue bus is a strange sight. But stranger still is a gift-wrapped Madison Avenue bus full of people drinking champagne.

The merger trend, which lost steam in the fourth quarter of last year, moved ahead in the first quarter of this year, according to a survey by W. T. Grimm Co., a Chicago-based financial - consulting firm that specialies in mergers and acquisitions.

In a move that underscores the diversification trend in Wall Street, Reynolds Securities, Inc., disclosed plans yesterday to acquire the business and most of the assets of Phelps, Fenn Co., one of the few remaining major independent municipal-bond houses.
NEW DELHI, April 3 (UPI) -- The Government today banned the import of 160 items and slashed import quotas of 87 others in a move to save foreign exchange reserves.

ANKARA, Turkey, April 3 -- President Cevdet Sunay has called for a suspension of political activity in Turkey and a period of Government rule by executive decree. The proposal was made in a letter from him to party leaders presented in talks during the week and was made public today.
Witnesses scheduled to testify against four men accused of beating a customer and a waiter in a Queens night club "are fearful of their lives," an assistant district attorney said yesterday.

JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, April 3 (UPI) -- A South African Davis Cup hopeful, 21-year-old Pat Cramer, scored the best victory of his career today when he upset Manuel Santana to reach the quarter finals of the $50,000 South African open tennis championships.

CINCINNATI, April 3 (UPI) -Gale Catlett, 31 years old, who has been an assistant basketball coach at various colleges for the last nine years, today took his first head-coaching job -- at the University of Cincinnati.

An associate of Ralph Nader charged yesterday that Lazard Freres Company, an investment banking firm intimately involved with the International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation, sold hundreds of thousands of shares of I.T.T. stock to the public, and to trust and pension funds, shortly before the announcement last July of an antitrust settlement by the corporation that resulted in depressing the price of the stock.

SAN DIEGO, April 3 (AP) -- Republicans said today that they had accepted $340,000 in convention pledges and expected to raise the final $60,000 after turning down most of a controversial Sheraton Hotel offer.

When Thomas J. Carroll, president of the Carmcley Corporation, sold his first $40,000 worth of 10-year United States Treasury bonds to an individual back in November, 1971, he discovered that the only safe way to make delivery of these similar-to-cash certificates was by hand.

Mrs. Edward F. Cox made an appearance at the traditional White House Easter Egg Roll, signed autographs and posed with a 5-foot white rabbit. The annual egg roll attracted more than 1,000 people to the South Lawn.

There is a fundamental difficulty in writing about Gil Hodges. Voices in the background keep screaming for restraint and yet every instinct is to succumb to temptation and spill forth the superlatives. Today would have been his 48th birthday. He didn't make it. A massive heart attack felled him on Easter Sunday just after he had completed 27 holes of golf, and death came with stunning swiftness.

In observance of the fourth anniversary of the death of the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr., Channel 11/WPIX-TV is presenting tonight Ely Landau's documentary "King: A Filmed Record . . . Montgomery to Memphis."

CHUB CAY, The Bahamas, April 3 -- Our Bahamian guide, Alfred Dawkins, was poling us up a shallow, wide tidal stream when A. J. McClane, who was in the bow, cried, "Hold it! Hold it!"

ELIZABETH, N. J., April 3 -- In an effort to combat the city's rapidly rising crime rate, Mayor Thomas G. Dunn initiated today an eight-point program he termed the first phase of "an all-out war on street crime."

Whatever Olivier Messiaen's eventual place in music, he surely will have a claim to be numbered among the eccentrics. For instance, he seems to be hypnotized by birds and bird calls, and is constantly using them in his music.

The early morning assassination of a 24-year-old Philadelphia drug dealer in Atlantic City was characterized by authorities in both cities yesterday as the latest upheaval in a six-month war between rival gangs of drug pushers in Philadelphia.

NASHVILLE, April 3 -- Earl Buford Ellington rose from a country storekeeper to be the last of Tennessee's all-poweful Governors, serve as an aide to President Johnson and then win re-election as Governor before retiring to private life.

A king in the United States today, which he left as an official outcast 20 years ago, Charles Spencer Chaplin is as mellow as only a man can be who has ridden the wheel of fortune until it turned, as he was ever certain it would, to his favor.

Senator Clifford Case of New Jersey has launched a campaign to redirect the misplaced energies of the Army Corps of Engineers. Declining prices of meat futures on the Chicago Mercantile Exchange yesterday reflected traders' uncertainty about the possibility of stiffer Government regulations of food prices and weakness in cash meat markets.

While other exhibits at this week's International Automobile Show feature sleek new cars and hostesses in low-cut gowns, one exhibit is trying to attract customers with a film about car collisions and a monograph on improving school buses.

WASHINGTON, April 4 (Reuters) -After spending hundreds of millions of dollars over nearly a decade of development work, the Navy still does not have a missile capable of effectively defending its ships from hostile aircraft, according to a report to Congress.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Wednesday, April 5 -- South Vietnamese troops abandoned one of their remaining defense points on the north bank of the Cua Viet last night and North Vietnamese tanks were reported moving south toward the embattled city of Quangtri, capital of South Vietnam's northernmost province.

Archie R. Boe, 51-year-old vice chairman of the Allstate Insurance Companies, became board chairman and chief executive officer of the insurer yesterday following the retirement of Judson B. Branch, who had held the posts. Mr. Branch was 65 in December.

Scientists at Michigan State University have isolated viruses from drinking water, apparently for the first time in the United States. Because of the circumstances of the finding, the scientists say that it points to a potentially serious health hazard that may exist in many water supplies.

PARIS, April 4 -- North Vietnam and the Vietcong sought today to reopen the suspended peace talks but were indignantly turned down by the United States and South Vietnam.

Responding to Vietnam, the Javits bill would radically change the constitutional relationship between Congress and the Presidency in making foreign policy.
What is there about a ramshackle clubhouse in a shabby storefront that draws teenagers like birds to a roost?

Then lift your pencil and start to answer the following questions. No more than two days (48 hours) may be spent on any one question.

WASHINGTON, April 5 -- The Securities and Exchange Commission warned corporations today to take more care, when preparing their news releases, to highlight and explain unusual or non-recurring transactions that have affected their earnings.

Paul Kolton, the president of the American Stock Exchange, said yesterday that the extensive improvements that had been built into the systems of member firms, the exchanges, transfer agents and others were enabling the industry to handle the expanded share turnover of recent months without operational difficulties.

Mayor Lindsay returned to the city yesterday to face a crowded agenda. Price changes -- generally upward -- were announced yesterday in a variety of metals and fibers. The Reynolds Metals Company said in Richmond that it planned to raise list prices of aluminum extruded shapes and drawn and extruded tubing by a minimum of 1.5 cents a pound over present prices.

The owners of the major league baseball clubs seem determined to enshrine the ghosts of Tom Girdler and Ernest T. Weir alongside those of Babe Ruth and Ty Cobb in baseball's hall of fame. OLYMPIA, Wash., April 6 (AP) -- The Washington Supreme Court overturned today an injunction that had blocked mandatory busing to achieve racial balance in Seattle public schools.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., April 6 -- The mass communications forum at the Black Conference on National Priorities offered a list of strong recommendations today to counteract what it called the "rampant, sustained and vicious" racism of the media.

Mayor Lindsay ordered some flags on city buildings in Manhattan lowered yesterday to half staff in tribute to the memory of Adam Clayton Powell. The order was extended to all flags on city buildings in Manhattan, following an objection by Borough President Percy E. Sutton to the limited scope of the tribute.

Sizable numbers of Wisconsin Republicans appear unhappy with the Nixon Administration, particularly over its performance in the economic sphere, according to detailed analysis of The New York Times/Yankelovich cross-section survey conducted after the state's primary on Tuesday.
It would be hard to think of any group organized for a competitive activity that raises more money for charity than those made up of duplicate-bridge players.
Some 600 stockbrokers rallied at the Manhattan Center yesterday to protest a recent wave of cuts in their share of the brokerage dollar on Wall Street.
ANGOSTURA, Mexico -- An archeologist looked ruefully at a thousand-year-old pyramid covered with earth and grass.

WASHINGTON, April 6 -- The Federal Power Commission disclosed today that it planned to let natural-gas producers raise their prices on new supplies, and perhaps on some existing contracts as well, in hopes that the prospect of bigger profits would lead to more exploration and discoveries.

DALLAS, April 6 -- In the most significant development of the current United States Olympic swimming timetable, Susie Atwood and Gary Hall shattered American records in the 400-yard individual medley tonight.
City officials were cleared yesterday to accept occasional "food or drink of moderate cost" or free tickets to civic gathering from people doing business with the city.

WASHINGTON, April 6 (AP) -- A Senate Labor subcommittee was told today that a shake-up in the staff of Action, President Nixon's superagency for volunteer service programs, would not result in any diminution of strength in the regional offices.

PARIS, April 6 -- North Vietnam issued a statement here claiming 10 American planes downed in its territory today. The delegation joined the Vietcong delegation in denouncing the American air attacks on the North as "a new military venture of extreme gravity."

New York City is "unduly self-critical," Dr. William J. McGill, president of Columbia University, said yesterday. He declared that it was producing its own "malaise" with an exaggerated "rhetoric of social conflict" that brought on "handwringing" by the communications media.
The rate of monetary expansion spurted upward this week as the Federal Reserve System poured funds into the money market, the central bank's weekly statement showed yesterday.

BRIDGEPORT, Conn., April 6 -- Seventeen residents -- most of them Puerto Rican or black -filed a class-action suit today in Federal Court against the Mayor, members of the Police Department and other city officials, charging police brutality during a civil disorder on May 20, 1971.

BOSTON, April 6 (AP) -- Jim Harrison's goal at 2 minutes 58 seconds of sudden death overtime lifted the Toronto Maple Leafs to a 4-3 victory over the Boston Bruins tonight, squaring the National Hockey League's playoff series at one victory apiece.
Off court and in court basketball made even bigger news than on court yesterday.

There is one angle of the dreadful Nyack bus tragedy that has never been mentioned to my knowledge. That is the disorder and bedlam that the school children can create in a school bus. Anyone who has seen and heard a school bus at close range has observed a mad chaos in operation.
TRENTON, April 6 -- A lastditch attempt to break a legislative deadlock on Congressional redistricting in New Jersey collapsed today in the Assembly.
BEIRUT, Lebanon, April 6 -Premier Kosygin arrived in Baghdad today on a five-day state visit amid speculation that Iraq and the Soviet Union would conclude a treaty of friendship and cooperation.

The City Stores Company, which includes the Franklin Simon and W. J. Sloane stores in its 141 department, specialty and furniture - store chain, returned to profitable operations in the fiscal year ended Jan. 29, the annual report disclosed yesterday.

When Yogi Berra is inducted into the Hall of Fame next August, the standing-roomonly crowd at the Baseball Museum in Cooperstown, N. Y., will eagerly await some laugh-provoking line from the new Met manager, the kind of twisted English that is so integral a part of his image.

PHILADELPHIA, April 6 -The University of Pennsylvania rejected today a faculty-endorsed proposal for a blackonly living and counseling project on the campus by ruling that all students must be admitted to the project.

Former Deputy Mayor Richard R. Aurelio, who managed Mayor Lindsay's unsuccessful Presidential campaign, said yesterday that he had "no plans" to return to city government and "absolutely no idea" which, if any, of the remaining Democratic candidates he would work for.

In your issue of April 1, Professor Falk ends a letter attacking the Government in regard to Vietnam, and Admiral Moorer as its spokesman, by appending the title of his position at my Alma Mater. Lest readers assume that Princetonians all feel the same way, I ask the courtesy of your columns to raise a contrary voice.

Although Mayor Lindsay may never have been "more than a telephone call away" from his responsibilities to the City of New York, he returned from the Democratic Presidential primary trail this week for good to a desk so cluttered with reports and papers in "every program area" that he could hardly find his own telephone.

MOSCOW, April 6 -- The Soviet Union's refusal to grant a visa to a representative of the Swedish Academy has reportedly not killed Aleksandr I. Solzhenitsyn's hope for a ceremony here to receive his 1970 Nobel Prize for Literature.

A one-hour dramatic program to combat venereal disease, with material by such writers as Jules Feiffer, Arnold Schulman, Eleanor Perry, Walter Jones and Israel Horovitz, will be televised nationally on public television, including Channel 13 here, next October.

WASHINGTON, April 6 -Adm. Thomas H. Moorer, Chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, said today that air strikes in North Vietnam would reach farther north than 40 to 50 miles from the border, the area in which the first strikes took place today.

MOSCOW, April 6 -- Premier Aleksei N. Kosygin flew to Iraq today on a mission to underscore the increasing Soviet role in the Iraqi economy and possibly to conclude a new friendship treaty with Baghdad.
A young man with a long record of arrests for post-office and bank robberies was found shot to death yesterday morning near his home in the Queens Village section of Queens.

Retail business boomed last month in thousands of stores operated by a large segment of the country's leading retail merchandisers, who reported yesterday substantial gains in March sales over the year-earlier levels.

A photograph of the former Mayor of Newark, Hugh Addonizio, appeared recently as he surrendered to begin his prison sentence. Mr. Addonizio was handcuffed. Was there some expectation that he would make a dash for freedom or that he would overcome the powerful guards who were on each side?
New Yorkers will be told how nice they really are in the hope that they'll be even nicer.

This month, from Chesapeake Bay to the Hudson River, striped bass are nosing their way up fresh-water streams to spawn, and in New York State the fight to have them declared a gamefish is taking on bitter overtones.

HANOI, North Vietnam, April 6 (Agence France-Presse) -Alarm bells rang for an air raid practice here today, sending factory workers to stations on the roofs where they took up positions behind heavy machine guns.

Representative Bella S. Abzug was endorsed by a Reform Democratic club last night for the party nomination in the 20th Congressional District, while her opponent Representative William F. Ryan, was being endorsed by another Reform club.

As some neighborhoods in the city began emerging this week from under mounds of accumulated garbage and debris removed in an intensive Sanitation Department spring cleaning, one crew reported uncovering several streets in the Willets Point section of Queens that had been all but lost under 1,000 tons of dumped refuse.
DONGHA, South Vietnam, April 6 -- No one is sure how many North Vietnamese are fighting on this front, but estimates run from 10,000 to 40,000. From evidence observed today, there must be many.

Charles Chaplin, the sole living link to Charlie Chaplin, the beloved Little Tramp of the silent screen, went to Gracie Mansion late yesterday afternoon to receive the Handel Medallion, the city's highest cultural award.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Friday, April 7 -- Hundreds of American Air Force and Navy fighter-bombers struck for the second day today at North Vietnamese troop concentrations and surface-to-air missile sites as clear weather permitted heavy air attacks both above and below the demilitarized zone.

WASHINGTON -- Richard Nixon is not the only American statesman awaited next month by Leonid Brezhnev, the Soviet boss, for, after eight years' absence, Fidel Castro, still sputtering visions of Latin revolution, also intends to visit Moscow in May.

ALBANY, April. 6 -- State Controller Arthur Levitt issued an audit today of New York City's Offtrack Betting Corporation, praising its management as "highly innovative" and suggesting areas where improvements could be made.

ROME, April 6 -- After weeks filled with sinister talk of plots and bombings, Italy suddenly has something to chuckle about -- romance between a woman correction officer in Rome's model prison and a convicted murderer named Vulcano.

Four persons were arrested and one injured last night as mounted policemen clashed with picketing members of Typographical Union No. 6 who were preventing other workers from entering the midtown offices of The Morning Telegraph, the police reported.

The Pennsylvania Life Company announced yesterday that its wholly owned insurance-brokerage subsidiary, Penn General Agencies, Inc., has reached a preliminary agreement to be acquired by Coleman, Kerstein Love, Inc., a publicly owned insurance broker.

Two Harlem tenement residents died and one was injured in a fire yesterday, the Fire Department said, possibly because the nearest fire engines had responded minutes earlier to a false alarm many blocks away.

The Data Transmission Company announced yesterday at Vienna, Va., that it had received initial construction permits from the Federal Communications Commission for its proposed national data communications network.

STONY BROOK, L. I., April 6 -- The State University of New York at Stony Brook has embarked on a major drive to recruit black and women faculty members -- hoping within the next three years to fill twothirds of 100 anticipated vacancies with blacks, of whom half would be women.
PHILADELPHIA, April 6 -- A Pennsylvania law compensating parents for tuition paid for pupils in nonpublic schools was declared unconstitutional here today by a three-judge Federal court.
WASHINGTON, April 6 (AP) -- President Nixon will visit the Shah of Iran in Teheran May 30-31 after his eight-day stay in the Soviet Union.

MILWAUKEE, April 6 (AP) -The Milwaukee Bucks, aroused by a third-quarter fight between Lucius Allen and Fritz Williams, rallied to beat the Golden State Warriors, 108-100, tonight to win their National Basketball Association playoff series, four games to one.

MINEOLA, L.I., April 6 -Henry L. Diamond, Commissioner of the State Department of Environmental Conservation, led a posse of armed conservation officers on a raid of garden-supply stores today to seize banned pesticides.
The money and bond markets yesterday halted their headlong rush to higher interest rates and turned in a steady performance in subdued trading.

LONDON, Friday, April 7 (Reuters) -- Sir Eric Drake, chairman of British Petroleum, today warned that demands by Middle East oil-producing states for part ownership of oilfield concessions might push up oil prices again.

MINNEAPOLIS -- Given the continued intolerably high unemployment and slack in the economy under Mr. Nixon's policies, the need for the "Jobs Now" program -- Congressman Reuss's proposal for 500,000 public service jobs -- becomes more urgent with each passing day.
President Nixon has asked the Commerce Department to find ways to make Government-held patents more useful to industry, Commerce Secretary Peter G. Peterson told businessmen here last night.
In a scrambling, intense replay, the Rangers last night did it again, toppling the Montreal Canadians for the second straight night and taking a 2-0 lead in their first-round Stanley Cup series.

WASHINGTON, April 6 -- The Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation proposed today a new policy that would permit banks it examines to make, without criticism from the F.D.I.C., more investments in corporations or other organizations with a primarily social purpose.

HONG KONG, Friday, April 7 -- Hanoi today denounced the United States decision to resume bombing North Vietnam and ordered North Vietnamese armed forces to "deal thunder blows at the enemy" by "shooting down many aircraft, capturing many pilots and sinking many U. S. warships."

Angel Cordero transformed a routine racing program into a profitable day for himself and his followers among the 21,511 fans at Aqueduct yesterday. The ebulient jockey from Puerto Rico registered four triumphs in a half-dozen attempts on the nine-race card.

LONDON, April 6 -- A mammoth British inquiry concluded today that-Protestant and Roman Catholic street gangs caused the violence three years ago that plunged Northern Ireland into its current crisis.
AUGUSTA, Ga., April 6 -Sam Snead shot a 69 today, only 10 strokes higher than his age and only one stroke behind Jack Nicklaus, the first-round leader in the Masters tournament.
Increased stock-transfer taxes were urged yesterday by two City Council leaders as the latest maneuver in the three-sided political squabble over the city's projected budget gap.
A package containing seven sticks of dynamite was removed yesterday from the offices of the National Lampoon, a satirical magazine, at 635 Madison Avenue by the Police Department's bomb section.

Senator Hugh Scott is busily warming up for his trip to mainland China. He's brushing up on the decidedly selective smattering of Chinese phrases he picked up as a Marine in China several decades ago, using tape recordings.

PARIS, April 6 (Reuters) -France today cut the bank rate to 5 3/4 per cent from 6 per cent, effective immediately, the Bank of France announced. The rate, last reduced on Jan. 13, was the highest in Europe.

MONTGOMERY, Ala., April 6 -- On a 2-to-1 vote, a Federal court has held constitutional Air Force regulations that permit a male serviceman to presume the dependency of his wife for fringe benefit purposes while a servicewoman must prove actual dependency of her husband to receive the same benefits.

WASHINGTON, April 7 -- In a case that involves a combination of campaign financing. San Diego and the Republican party, such as the I.T.T. case, it was not too surprising that the name of Representative Robert Carleton Wilson came up.

DALLAS, April 7 -- Karen Moe, who said she didn't expect to win, and Lynn Colella, who swam two final races less than 15 minutes apart, continued the momentum in the National Amateur Athletic Union short-course swimming championships tonight.

UNIVERSITY PARK, Pa., April 7 -- Brandeis University roiled up 61 points today and gained the lead in the team competition of the 44th National Intercollegiate Women's Fencing Association championships at Penn State. Brandeis held a 1-point edge over Cornell and William Paterson College.

WASHINGTON, April 7 -- Senator William Proxmire complained today that the Navy appeared to be arranging a "backdoor bailout" for Grumman Aerospace Corporation that could add several hundred million dollars to the cost of producing the new F-14 fighter aircraft.

JACKSONVILLE, Fla., April 7 (UPI) -- Top-Seeded Mrs. Billie Jean King crushed Karen Krantzcke, 6-1, 6-2, today to become the only seeded player to move into the semifinals of the $18,000 Virginia Slims tennis tournament.

MIAMI BEACH, April 7 -- If nothing else, tonight's world light-heavyweight title match between Bob Foster and Vicente Rondon was a prizefight.

ALBANY, April 7 -- A planned midnight strike of state prison workers was averted today when a tentative two-year agreement on a contract was reached between the state and Council 82 of the American Federation of State, County and Municipal Employes.
UNIONDALE, L. I., April 7 -- You would hardly guess that Rick Barry missed tonight's New York Nets victory.

Opening day, postponed by the players' pension-fund strike, is a renewal more needed than ever, if only because so much of the pre-season baseball news has seemed tawdry or embarrassing or just plain unnecessary.

The big figure was brought about by the success of the Sunninghill Farm's Marite, under a ride by Robyn Smith in the first race, and a first-time score by Edward J. Carroll's Gentle Spring, with Sandino Hernandez up, in the second. Marite returned a win price of $25.60 and Gentle Spring paid $201.80.

WASHINGTON, April 7 (AP) -- Mrs. Mary Hamilton, an associate professor of finance at Loyola University in Chicago, has been chosen by President Nixon to fill a vacancy on the seven-member Price Commission.

The trial of Assemblyman Hulan E. Jack and five co-defendants on charges of conspiracy and violation of conflict-of-interest statutes opened in Federal court here yesterday, with a Government prosecutor charging that the six took part in "a sordid scheme to abuse union power."
WASHINGTON, April 7 -- The Senate passed by a 62-to-0 vote today a bill designed to provide a massive program to combat diseases of the heart, lungs and circulatory system.

NEW HAVEN, April 7 -- In the Brecht canon "Happy End" is considered a failure, a hurriedly written attempt in 1929 to capitalize on "The Threepenny Opera." But for Kurt Weill "Happy End" is an astonishing success and one is deeply indebted to Robert Brustein and the Yale Repertory Theater for reclaiming this work and restoring it to theatrical life. The musical opened last night and continues in repertory.

AUSTIN, Tex., April 7 (AP) -- The world record-holder, Jim Ryun, desperately trying to round into shape for the United States' Olympic trials, sped to an impressive 20-yard victory in a special 880-yard run tonight in the Texas Relays.

CHARLOTTSVILLE, Va., April 7 (AP) -- Former President Lyndon B. Johnson was taken to a hospital here early this morning after suffering chest pains while staying at the home of his son-in-law and daughter, Mr. and Mrs. Charles Robb.

The controlling interest in I.O.S., Ltd., the Swiss-based mutual fund group, has been sold for $200,000 in cash and slightly less than $1-million in promissory notes, documents filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission showed yesterday.

TOKYO, April 7 -- Japanese businessmen, worried and embarrassed by the poor United States export showing in Japan, are sending a mission to the United States next month to teach the Americans how to do better.

WASHINGTON, April 7 -- The nation and the Nixon Administration received moderately encouraging news on inflation and employment today with the Wholesale Price Index rising only one-tenth of 1 per cent in March after increasing sharply in the December-February period. Kleindienst to be Attorney General.

WASHINGTON, April 9 -- The Federal Trade Commission's growing aggressiveness as a consumer protection agency has brought to a boil a long-simmering dispute over the extent of its authority to police the market place.

Beard, the ailing lobbyist for the International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation, since she was admitted to Rocky Mountain Osteopathic Hospital on March 3.
