SAIGON, South Vietnam, April 12 -- North Vietnam's two-week-old offensive has seriously weakened the defenses of the most populous area of South Vietnam -- the Mekong Delta.

John A. Lafore, president, chief executive officer and director of the American Kennel Club, was the chief speaker at yesterday's monthly meeting of the Dog Fancier's Club in the Green Room of the Hotel Mc-Alpin.

The Westinghouse Electric Corporation reported yesterday record first-quarter earnings, up 27.1 per cent on a 14.5 per cent gain in sales from the year-earlier period. The quarterly report placed sales at $1,179,300,000, up from $1,030,124,000.

WASHINGTON, April 12 -- The Price Commission, concerned that its anti-inflation program may be off target, has split over a proposal to change its rules so as to permit manufacturers to raise prices only enough to reflect actual cost increases, a member of the commission disclosed today.

WASHINGTON, April 12 (UPI) -- Mississippi's "loyalist'' Democrats lobbied in the Senate today on behalf of a party rules change that would deny seniority to Senator James O. Eastland, Mississippi Democrat, unless he joins their party faction.
Each season a team of relatively unknown players enters the Von Zedtwitz Double Knockout Team Championship and turns in a series of expert performances.

A meeting of 300 union taxi cab drivers broke up 15 minutes after it started last night in a melee of shouting, chair-throwing and punches. The police said one man was treated for head injuries and an another was arrested and charged with assault.
WASHINGTON, April 12 (UPI) -- Twelve liberal Republican Senators, dissatisfied with President Nixon's law-and-order record, offered their own reform bill to revitalize his program against crime.
" We were flat," said Capt. Vic Hadfield of the Rangers.

It was interesting to note that the printed program for the duo recital given by Ingrid Dingfelder and Rita Koors-Myers at Carnegie Recital Hall on Tuesday night listed both performers names in the same size of type.
Hanns Weinberg was astonished when he was asked, before the reception, if he planned to put away any of of his highly breakable porcelain treasures.
WASHINGTON, April 12 -- Secretary of State William P. Rogers hinted today at an easing of United States coolness toward Cuba, provided Cuba changed her policies.
Four-year National Merit Scholarship awards to 1,275 high school seniors were announced yesterday.
WASHINGTON, April 12 -- Total business inventories rose only slightly in February, continuing a long-standing sluggishness in this aspect of the economy, the Commerce Department reported today.

Half a dozen newcomers to the cast of Mascagni's "Cavalleria Rusticana" and Leoncavallo's "Pagliacci" were seen at the New York State Theater on Tuesday night in the performance of the double bill given by the New York City Opera.

PHUBAI, South Vietnam, April 12 -- About 50 United State infantrymen of a 142-man company refused to move for an hour and a half today when ordered to go out and patrol the rolling hills around Phubai, 42 miles south of the demilitarized zone.
Higher prices for chemical stocks helped the American Stock Exchange index to edge upwards yesterday. Volume increased sharply, up 28 per cent to 7,691,00 shares from Tuesday's trading.
LONDON, April 12 -- Labor party Members of Parliament opposed to British entry into the Common Market won a new victory today in the struggle over party policy.
Two businessmen, an engineer and the state tax commissioner of Vermont pleaded guilty in Federal Court here yesterday to charges that they had violated sanctions against trade with Rhodesia.

The Kaiser Aluminum and Chemical Corporation said yesterday it was increasing the actual selling price for soft alloy aluminum extrusions by 1.5 cents a pound in all areas of the United States except the West Coast.

Barbara Weisberger is an artistic split-personality. As director of the Pennsylvania Ballet, now at the City Center, she is proving a fine judge of young dancers but a poor judge of young ballets. Her company has offered a fair selection of modern Balanchine classics but the new works have all proved, at best, mildly disastrous, and, at worst, mildly horrendous.

WASHINGTON, April 12 -- The financially hard pressed Democrats have finally managed to unloose their so-called "greatness fund," more than $700,000 raised in 1965 from corporations that bought advertising space in a partisan magazine extolling the works of Lyndon B. Johnson.

Fifty-three per cent of Americans say they approve of President Nixon's performance in office, the Gallup Poll reported today, while 37 per cent express disapproval and 10 per cent do not express an opinion.

ROCHESTER, April 14 -- A former inmate of Attica prison today told a state panel investigating last September's bloody uprising about arbitrary rules, contraband goods in wide use and the danger of homosexual attack.

FIRE BASE BIRMINGHAM, South Vietnam, April 12 -- The besieged artillery base known as Phuxuan, which constitutes the main outlying defense of Hue, was still held today by South Vietnamese troops, but supplies of food and ammunition were running critically low.

MOSCOW, April 12 -- The campaign against the Nobel prize-winning novelist, Aleksandr I. Solzhenitsyn, continued here today with the publication of 11 letters denouncing him for "hatred" of the Bolshevik Revolution and linking him with anti-Soviet emigre groups of Russians.
MINEOLA, April 12 -- A two-year investigation of the Nassau County jail by undercover agents "sentenced" by a cooperating judge was made public today by the Nassau County District Attorney.

BOSTON -- The Chinese attitude toward President Nixon's historic visit to China has clearly demonstrated Peking's consistent desire for peaceful coexistence with the United States. As early as 1955, Premier Chou En-lai himself suggested the possibility of and hope for peaceful coexistence between the People's Republic of China and the United States.
The Securities and Exchange Commission has begun an investigation into the seizure of $4-million belonging to the Penn Central Transportation Company.

Alfred Kazin, the critic, and James T. Farrell, the novelist, told City College students yesterday that the ethnic identity of minorities -- which appeared to them in the nineteen-thirties as "powerlessness" -- had contributed more creative power to American life and literature than any dream of a melting pot.

Mayor Lindsay and David Rockefeller, chairman of the Chase Manhattan Bank, announced a joint effort yesterday to assemble government loans and private financing for a long-range $1.2-billion development of apartments and offices that would rise on platforms above the East River, bordering the financial district of lower Manhattan.

Every year thousands of people who don't feel like taking a long, cross-country auto trip, or, maybe, don't have the time, turn over their cars to a growing list of companies that specialize in providing careful drivers for door-to-door service just about anywhere.

WASHINGTON, April 12 -- The Internal Revenue Service, in an attempt to keep taxpayers out of the hands of dishonest commercial tax-preparers, announced today that it would put 15,000 of its own personnel at the disposal of individuals who needed help in filing their tax returns before Monday deadline.
Prices of cotton futures No. 2 closed lower all across all contracts yesterday on the New York Cotton Exchange.

The Carolina Cougars selected Henry Bibby of the University of California Los Angeles, and the Floridians took Swen Nater, understudy to all-American Bill Walton on the Bruins, in yesterday's second phase of the American Basketball Association college draft.
The American Stock Exchange announced yesterday that three major automation projects, including the computerized execution of all investors' odd-lot market orders, were being implemented this week.

President Nixon's visit to Canada, which begins today, may rank well down his list as a foreign travel spectacular; but it could be one of his most important ventures abroad and is certain to be one of the most delicate. The visit comes at a time of surging anti-United States feeling in Canada, which Prime Minister Trudeau will find ever more difficult to contain as he approaches the general election expected in October.
SAN ANTONIO, Tex., April 12 (AP) -- A doctor said that former President Lyndon B. Johnson was "feeling great" after he returned to Texas today to recuperate from a heart attack.
ISLAMABAD, Pakistan, April 12 -- Informed sources said today that President Zulfikar Ali Bhutto has proposed that he govern Pakistan under a presidential form of government until August, 1973.

Two more major banks reported sharply lower first-quarter earnings yesterday. The Charter New York Corporation, parent company of the Irving Trust Company and eight small upstate banks, said its operating earnings were down 24.2 per cent in this year's first three months to 68 cents a share from the year-earlier 90 cents a share.

Chelsea Industries, Inc., announced yesterday that preliminary negotiations for a possible merger or other form of affiliation with Botany Industries, Inc., had been terminated. No reasons were given. Botany, a financially troubled large producer of men's wear, is currently closing its Weber Heil broner and Broad-street's men's retail stores.

ALBANY, April 12 -- The Democratic minority leaders of the Legislature accused the Republican majority today of disenfranchising 600,000 young voters by keeping in committee a bill that would allow 18-to-21-year-olds to register to vote up to 30 days before the June 20 Presidential primary.

WASHINGTON, April 12 (AP) -The Federal Bureau of Investigation arrested a United Mine Workers official today on Federal charges in connection with the slaying of Joseph A. Yablonski, his wife and daughter.

CONSHOHOCKEN, Pa. April 12 -- Threading his way throught a cluster of workers at the Alan Wood Steel Company here this morning, Donald Chendorain grasped the right hand of Senator Hubert H. Humphrey, pumped it and declared, "I picked a loser when I picked you last time.

WASHINGTON, April 12 -- The Senate Judiciary Committee voted today not to subpoena White House aides to testify in the hearings on the qualifications of Richard G. Kleindienst, but two influential Democratc Senators vowed to block a confirmation vote until the aides testify.
The Federal Trade Commission is expected to announce this morning it has approved the purchase of Bergdorf Goodman, the 71-year-old Fifth Avenue specialty store, by Broadway-Hale Stores, Inc.
ROME, April 12 -- The plan to provide free public transportation for Romans in an effort to reduce the use of private cars has been put off for at least two weeks.
I would like to respond to Alan Watts' "The Jesus Freaks and Jesus" (Op-Ed March 29).

Actually, no one is quite sure when or how the lower Manhattan project began. Most people say that it came about because Chase Manhattan Bank put up a new headquarters, a few say that a building at 20 Broad Street was the cause of it and one or two say that it happened because Robert Moses once talked to David Rockefeller.

The retired head of a distributing company that handled Sylvania electric bulbs and other hard goods for stores in Westchester County, the Bronx and Manhattan told a Federal court jury here yesterday he was once warned he could "be kicked out of Harlem" if he did not pay $3,000 to Coordinated Community Services, Inc., a marketing consultant concern.

The New York and American Stock Exchanges yesterday issued their latest reports on changes in stock ownership by major stockholders, directors and officers of listed companies. The reports include the following:

WEST PALM BEACH, Fla., April 12 -- Ben Chaney, brother of the slain civil rights worker James E. Chaney, was sentenced today to life in prison for the slayings of two co-eds in Boca Raton in May, 1970.

While state environmental officials toured the city by helicopter yesterday, pointing out to legislators the benefits to be expected here from the proposed $1.2-billion environmental bond issue, city officials were complaining that a key local environment program -- air-pollution control -- was threatened by cutbacks in state aid.

Barbara Roan's "The October Parade" is a small pageant of personalities, each acting out real or imagined life styles. Since the performers are so varied in themselves the work has the jumbled richness of a cross section of the telephone book.

WASHINGTON, April 12 -- Student presidents from more than 59 colleges and universities will attend an emergency conference here this weekend on increased war activity in Vietnam, the National Student Association announced today.
Question: What happens these days when a small investor calls his broker and says he has $5,000 to put in the market?

RICHMOND, April 12 (AP) -- Owner Earl Foreman of the Virginia Squires of the American Basketball Association said today he would ask for a Justice Department investigation of the signing of two of his star players by the rival National Basketball Association.
If the lower Manhattan project proposed yesterday is realized, it will add 113 acres to the 3,650 acres of land that have been added to Manhattan since the 17th century.

MONTEVIDEO, Uruguay, April 12 (AP) -- Fifteen Tupamaro guerrillas and 10 other prisoners escaped today from the Punta Carretas Penitentiary through a tunnel more than 200 feet long extending from the prison hospital to a sewer outside the prison wall.

Members of the New York Stock Exchange voted approval yeseterday for the negotiation of commissions on that part of orders over $300,000. Commissions on orders under $300,000 will remain subject to the exchange's fixed schedule of rates.

After 10 rounds of the Manhattan Chess Club championship, Arthur Feuerstein, a former champion, was ahead with 7 1/2-2 1/2. Feuerstein compiled six victories, three draws and one loss in the 14-man round robin.

ALBANY, April 12 -- Two bills that would restrict the powers of the state's Urban Development Corporation to override local regulations when building low-income and middle-income housing were passed today by the Assembly.

Has the spread of air piracy become such a danger that a large governmental force should be deployed to police the boarding of most or all the nation's airlines? The chairman of the Civil Aeronautics Board, Secor D. Browne, thinks that may well be the case, and has suggested that President Nixon name a high-level commission to explore the idea.

The Lindsay administration prodded the City Council yesterday to pass promptly $141-million in nuisance taxes as the "keystone" of a deal that would persuade Albany to help fill the city's budget gap.

WASHINGTON, April 12 -- The Senate Foreign Relations Committee today approved $85-million in assistance to Israel for resettlement of Jewish refugees from the Soviet Union. In the process, the Committee also did a favor for one of its members, Senator Edmund S. Muskie of Maine.

MOSCOW, April 12 -- The United States Secretary of Agriculture, Earl L. Butz, today forecast American grain sales to the Soviet Union running to possibly $200-million annually in the years ahead. He also disclosed that he was carrying a message to President Nixon from Leonid I. Brezhnev, the Soviet Communist party leader.

WASHINGTON, April 12 -- Administration spokesmen emphasized today that President Nixon had not decided whether to remove more American troops from Vietnam after May 1. For the first time, they left open the possibility that he might temporarily suspend or delay the withdrawal program.
Striking Macy's employes ratified a new two-year contract yesterday, ending a week-long walkout by 8,000 workers at six of the company's department stores in the city and Westchester County.
After a painful period of reluctance, Human Resources Administrator Jule Sugarman has at last fully joined the fight against waste within the city's welfare establishment.

What was originally to be a 70th-birthday tribute to Stefan Wolpe Tuesday night in Town Hall sadly became a memorial concert. The composer, who died on April 4 after a 10-year battle with Parkinson's disease, planned to attend a number of retrospective concerts devoted to his music this year -- the most recent at Columbia University last Feb. 16, when Mr. Wolpe was enthusiastically greeted by a small but faithful band of students and admirers.
A leading member of the direct marketing fraternity called yesterday for a fund to reimburse consumers bilked by the unethical practioner.

Interest rates on corporate bonds rose sharply again yesterday but investors -- perversely in the view of Wall Street -- remained a jump ahead and also raised the level at which they would commit their funds.

Production of children's sleepwear in sizes 1 through 6 will come to a halt this year if the Commerce Department does not modify flammability test methods, Roger Wilson, chairman of the apparel products flammability committee of the American Apparel Manufacturers Asociation, said yesterday.

BELFAST, Northern Ireland, April 12 -- A statement issued today by a local group of the Irish Republican Army, whose policy is to severely punish Roman Catholics considered guilty of certain offenses, listed the reasons that a pregnant 24-year-old housewife was painted and feathered. One charge was the selling and taking of drugs, believed to mean tranquilizers.
WASHINGTON, April 12 -- The Secretary of Bombing is very busy. There is, first of all, "this baseball business," as he calls it.

UNIONDALE, L.I., April 12 -- If you don't demand frosted Shakespeare -- and who wants it? -- "Ice Follies of 1972" is soothing, cooling family fun. And this we do need, on or off ice. The latest Shipstads and Johnson revue last night officially opened the Nassau Veterans Memorial Coliseum here.

On Feb. 16 Admiral Thomas H. Moorer, chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, warned Congress that if an "effective" U.S.-Soviet arms accord is not reached soon, the U.S. must procure new nuclear weapons quickly or risk the "possibility" of losing "overall strategic superiority . . . within this decade."
Red Shoes picked her way deftly toward the close to score decisively in the $27,800 Bed o'Roses Handicap for fillies and mares at Aqueduct yesterday.

BOSTON, April 12 -- The two leading Democratic candidates in the April 25 Presidential primary in Massachusetts came to this state today to search for support -- Senator George McGovern of South Dakota from the blue-collar workers and Senator Edmund S. Muskie of Maine from his own pledged delegate candidates.

Under canopies pelted by rain and amid unseasonal cold that left diplomats and their wives shivering, Premier Eisaku Sato of Japan and Mrs. Sato entertained at their annual cherry blossom party in the Shinjuku Gardens in Tokyo.

The Pabst Brewing Company has named James C. Windham, president and chief executive officer, to the additional post of chairman of the board. He will replace Harris Perlstein, who is retiring but continues as a director and chairman of the executive committee.

After the assassination of Sheik Abeid Amani Karume, the ruler of Zanzibar, by a four-man commando team Friday, the man who took to the radio to broadcast news developments to the island population was Aboud Jumbe, his 52-year-old friend, confidant and chief adviser.

WASHINGTON, April 12 -- Acting Attorney General Richard G. Kleindienst testified today that President Nixon's anti-busing legislation would permit the reopening of every school desegregation case in the country to meet standards in the proposed legislation.

The president of the Four Freedoms Foundation, Joseph S. Robinson, announced last night that an understanding had been reached with state and city officials to make available two acres of land on the southern tip of Welfare Island for construction of a memorial to Franklin D. Roosevelt.

Dwight Epps was involved in four first-place finishes and Mike McDermott in three to lead New York University's track team to a 97-56 victory over Columbia at Baker Field yesterday. Epps won the 220 and 440-yard runs and ran a leg of the 440 and mile relays.

What is involved in lower Manhattan is not just a billion-dollar development plan, but the skilled manipulation of one of the highest density areas in the world and the most expensive real estate for a particular goal: the quality of the environment. A major international banking figure called on the United States last night to play a direct role in protecting the value of the dollar.
PARIS, April 12 -- France today backed Vietnamese Communist demands for the resumption of the peace talks here.

HONG KONG, Thursday, April 13 -- Premier Chou En-lai of China said last night the American attacks on North Vietnam constituted a "serious incident of expanding the war" and declared that the Chinese Government and people were "closely following the development of this incident."

David Burnham, a reporter on the metropolitan staff of The New York Times, was named the winner yesterday of the Newspaper Reporters Association of New York City's 1972 Schaefer Gold Typewriter Award for public service.

Phase Two of the National Basketball Association playoffs begins for the New York Knicks in Boston tonight, as they face the Celtics in the opener of a four-of-seven-game series for the Eastern Conference championship. The winner will advance to the final round to bat tle Milwaukee or Los Angeles for the league title.

March earnings of the Celanese Corporation were more than 50 per cent higher than in the two preceding months, but first quarter earnings of 81 cents a share were down 12 per cent from 92 cents a share earned in the first three months last year, John W. Brooks, president, reported at yesterday's meeting of shareholders.

Although its founder and state chairman, Joseph Paul, died last month, the California Committee of Two Million has not slackened in its effort to protect the Eel, Trinity, Klamath and South Rivers from a series of water storage dams.

City welfare officials yesterday reported only minor job gains and an actual decline in placements for training under the state law that since July 1 has required employable relief recipients to pick up welfare checks at state employment centers and to take available jobs or training.

BUFFALO, April 12 (AP) -- Mrs. Bernice Gera, a Queens housewife, had a contract today to umpire in the Class A New York-Pennsylvania Baseball League, making her the apparent victor in a three-year battle with Organized Baseball.

The Board of Education yesterday held up the awarding of more than a million dollars in contracts to a private research center after a board member raised questions about possible conflicts of interest.

As someone who has traveled and done research in southern Africa since 1959, and who has recently returned from a month-long visit to that area, I was appalled by the substance and conclusions of the Op-Ed article which you published ("Communist Influence in Southern Africa") on April 4.

HARTFORD, April 12 -- Gov. Thomas J. Meskill reached agreement early this morning with legislative leaders on a taxing and spending program for Connecticut that will make the state sales tax 7 per cent, the highest in the country.

Upbeat or downbeat? Most television programing falls somewhere in the harmless middle, but the occasional extremes continue to attract the most attention, prompting concern for everything from the TV image of the United States abroad to official sermons at home on the virtues of accentuating the positive.

The New York Stock Exchange is moving to reconstruct its board of governors in line with the recommendation of the report it commissioned from William McChesney Martin Jr. The Martin report called for the Exchange to form a new governing board that would give "proper recognition. . .to its quasi-public nature and the respective interests of the public, the companies listed on the Exchange and the members of the securities industry involved."

SANTIAGO, Chile, April 12 -- An anti-Marxist crowd estimated at more than 200,000 staged a protest march today, calling on President Salvador Allende Gossens to submit his socialist program to a national plebiscite.
Stock prices boiled higher yesterday and then simmered down on late profit taking as volume on the New York Stock Exchange boomed in the second heaviest trading of 1972.

Senator George McGovern's campaign for New York's 278 Democratic National Convention delegates was given a major impetus yesterday when Meade H. Esposito, the Brooklyn Democratic leader, declared that he was "extremely impressed" with the South Dakotan.
High police officials said yesterday that a number of Mafia figures had gone into hiding, apparently to avoid questioning about the recent series of gang-style murders.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Thursday, April 13 -- Moving under cover of predawn darkness, North Vietnamese troops and tanks reportedly began an assault today against the provincial capital of Anloc, 60 miles north of here, which Communist forces have besieged since Saturday.

Unlike the men who fought in World War II, the veterans of Vietnam have served in a war over which the country has been sharply divided. The Vietnam war, moreover, called for sacrifices only of those who were in the armed forces, while their compatriots at home have remained largely unaffected.

WASHINGTON, April 12 -- President Nixon announced today that he would nominate Benjamin L. Hooks, a Memphis lawyer who is a Baptist minister, as the first black person to serve on the seven-member Federal Communications Commission.

NEWARK, April 12 -- A special three-judge Federal court today ordered a Congressional redistricting plan for New Jersey that would eliminate one of the seats held by Hudson County's two Democratic incumbents, creating in its place a new Republican district in rural, northwestern New Jersey.
WASHINGTON, April 12 (AP) -- A measure to issue cotton crop reports simultaneously with its general crop reports was backed today by the Agriculture Department.
NEW DELHI, April 12 -- Informed sources said today that preliminary talks on a meeting between the leaders of India and Pakistan were likely later this month.

Patrick W. O'Brien, vice president in charge of racing operations for the New York Racing Association, has been advanced to the post of steward representing the N. Y. R. A., Alfred Gwynne Vanderbilt, chairman of the board, announced yesterday.
John Gaherin, the owners' chief negotiator, emerged from his third bargaining session of a long day last night with a proposal that could end the strike today and get the season started Saturday.

" Women in Adult Literature" was the nominal topic of yesterday's panel meeting of the New York Chapter of the National Book Association. But that was merely a fig leaf for Norman Mailer, whose presence in the Jade Room of the Waldorf-Astoria was all the more palpable for his absence.

On the bill with the Bijou Theater's re-issue of Charlie Chaplin's 1925 classic, "The Gold Rush," is Harry Hurwitz's 60-minute documentary, "Chaplinesque, My Life and Hard Times," which was called "The Eternal Tramp" when it was shown four times on National Educational Television here, most recently Jan. 1.

WASHINGTON, April 12 -- Controller General Elmer B. Staats accused a board headed by Secretary of the Treasury John B. Connally today of being in "clear violation of the law" by failing to cooperate in a routine monitoring of the board's administration of a $250-million Government loan guarantee to the Lockheed Aircraft Corporation.

BELFAST, Northern Ireland, April 12 -- Brian Faulkner, the former Prime Minister, met for the first time today with the new British administrator of Northern Ireland and urged that British troops seek out terrorists in Roman Catholic areas. The meeting was termed cordial.
PARIS, April 12 -- A noted French author, journalist and filmmaker has written a book about her unrequited love for Henry Kissinger that will go on sale next week.

NASHVILLE, April 12 -- A districting plan intended to give Democrats five and possibly six of the eight seats Tennessee will have in the next Congress was vetoed today by Gov. Winfield Dunn, a Republican.

A most unusual brace of guitarists is sharing the minuscule bandstand at the Guitar, 10th Avenue and 51st Street. One is Bucky Pizzarelli, who, until January, was teamed in a jazz guitar duo with George Barnes.

LONDON -- No one in his right mind comes to England for the food. But the more than one million Americans who do stop here annually -- for the theater, the tweed or whatever -- should really stop complaining back home about British restaurants. It isn't easy. But the determined diner can eat decently, sometimes very well, in London, if he is very careful.

Fran Tarkenton, the quarterback the Giants traded back to Minnesota, thinks the Vikings made "a really good deal" in reacquiring his services and he regards his upcoming second career with that club as "a tremendous opportunity.

NEW CITY, N. Y., April 12 -- A Fifth victim of the Congers school bus-train collision on March 24 died in Nyack Hospital today.
The International Business Machines Corporation, the nations No. 1 manufacturer of computers, and Honeywell, Inc., the No. 3 company, announced higher earnings yesterday for the year's first quarter.
DETROIT, April 12 -- The table tennis team from China landed in Detroit today, the first stop in a two-week American tour.
PHUBAI, April 12 (AP) -- Lieut. Col. Frederick P. Mitchell today assailed television newsmen and other journalists who were present when American infantrymen refused orders to go out on patrol.
JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, April 12 -- The South African Government drew criticism from two tribal leaders today on its policy of separate "homelands" for blacks.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., April 12 -- Harvard's president Derek C. Bok, and 34 members of the Harvard Law faculty sent a letter to Congress today saying that President Nixon's antibusing legislation, if enacted, would "sacrifice the enforcement of constitutional rights, impair the functions of the judiciary under a rule of law, and jeopardize improved schooling."
SHIRAZ, Iran, April 12 (UPI) -- Everywhere there is dust, rubble, tears and the sound of wailing.
MOSCOW, April 12 (AP) -- Friends of Valery Panov, a leading Soviet dancer, say he has been thrown out of Leningrad's Kirov Ballet because he wanted to emigrate to Israel.
CHICAGO, April 12 -- "Free Dr. Mudd."
WASHINGTON, April 12 -- The State Department today called in a senior French diplomat to express its official displeasure over France's call for an immediate resumption of the Paris talks.

CAPE KENNEDY, Fla., April 12 -- The Apollo 16 countdown continued smoothly today as American astronauts prepared to embrak on man's first voyage to the rugged mountains of the moon for a look at what may be extinct volcanoes.
Family Court Judge Nanette Dembitz announced yesterday her candidacy for the Democratic nomination for the State Court of Appeals, where no woman has ever sat.

Mrs. Diane de Courseulles Riviere, widow of Jacques Riviere, a banker, was married yesterday to Baron Mario di Genova di Salle of Paris in a civil ceremony at the Town Hall in Neuilly, France. Achille Peretti, Mayor of Neuilly and president of the French National Assembly, performed the ceremony.

MINEOLA, L. I., April 12 -- None of the 15 agents, all private citizens, who spent up to six weeks in prison over the last two years as undercover investigators, had ever seen the inside of a jail before. Scores of commuters watched a chase through Grand Central Terminal during the evening rush hour yesterday that ended in a stairway shooting fray in which an alleged purse-snatcher was killed and a Penn Central policeman was wounded.
LONDON, April 12 -- One of Britain's cultural monuments, the National Theater Company, was engulfed in controversy today involving two prominent stage figures, Laurence Olivier and Peter Hall.

INGLEWOOD, Calif., April 12 -- Led by Jim McMillian's 42 points, the Los Angeles Lakers outlasted the Milwaukee Bucks in a wild final-period tussle, 135-134, to even their National Basketball Association Western Conference final playoff series at one victory apiece.

BRUSSELS, April 12 (Reuters) -- The Common Market Commission suggested a number of changes in the community's negotiating position with Britain's six partners in the European Free Trade Association, which are not joining the market.
COBLESKILL, N. Y., April 12 -- Racial hostility erupted into a cross-burning and a brief spree of vandalism early today on the campus of the State Agricultural and Technical College here.

WASHINGTON, April 12 (AP) -- While Washington contends that Moscow is a major contributor to Hanoi's new offensive because of its shipments of heavy arms, a reading of United States intelligence estimates indicates that Soviet weapons assistance to North Vietnam is actually far smaller now than earlier is the war.

Slightly more than $2-million in state aid was distributed to 110 museums, galleries and historical societies in the fiscal year ended March 31, the New York State Council on the Arts reported yesterday.

PENSACOLA, Fla., April 13 (AP) -- Dave Hill shot a 64 which he said he didn't deserve today and Lee Trevino withdrew after carding a 74 in the first round of the $150,000 Monstanto open golf tournament.

WASHINGTON, April 13 -Senior officials disclosed here today that United States warships in the Caribbean had been ordered by President Nixon to prevent -- by force if necessary -- Cuban vessels from seizing the merchant vessels of countries "friendly" to the United States.
CAPE KENNEDY, Fla., April 13 -- The Apollo 16 astronauts were given a final briefing today on lunar geology in preparation for the scheduled launching of their mission to the moon on Sunday.
A State Supreme Court jury in Queens convicted a 17-yearold Black Panther early today of slaying another Panther in an outgrowth of an internal feud over party philosophy and programs.

MONTGOMERY, Ala., April 13 -- In a landmark decision, a Federal court defined today in great detail the minimum constitutional standard for the operation of state institutions for the mentally ill and the retarded.

Joseph Overton, business agent for Local 338 of the Retail, Wholesale and Chain Store Food Employes Union, engaged in normal labor activity when he sought to establish a union shop at the Harlem River Consumers Cooperative or was he seeking to exert pressure to have the cooperative buy and display products being pushed by Co-Ordinated Community Services, Inc., a marketing concern in which he allegedly had an interest?

William D. Eberle, chief Administration trade-policy official, called yesterday for a return to the spirit of interdependence among nations in a new round of negotiations for further removal of trade barriers.
HARTFORD, April 13 -- The Connecticut House of Representatives voted 126 to 37 today for a "no-fault" insurance bill that had been pummeled into shape by many compromises.
Two economists identified with the Nixon Administration differed yesterday on how well price controls are working.
At least 22 top police officals above the rank of captain have been told by Police Commissioner Patrick V. Murphy either to retire or be demoted to captain.

Acting Attorney General Richard Kleindienst has now acknowledged that President Nixon's proposed antibusing legislation could lead to the reopening of every school desegregation case -- even where busing had not been at issue. This admission merely places on the public record what seemed implicit in the President's misleading televised statement on busing. From the outset, what was at stake was far more than a mere reassessment.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, April 13, (Reuters) -- Enemy and South Vietnamese battlefield deaths showed sharp increases in the week following North Vietnam's invasion of the south, according to figures released here today.

Albert Viton, specialist in the world sugar market, said yesterday that it was possible that the traditional sugar cycle of excessively high free market prices, followed by over production and painfully low prices would repeat itself even before the end of the decade.
Needham, Harper Steers offered 375,000 shares of stock to the public yesterday at $23 per share and it ended the day at $23.25.

The stock market paused to catch its breath yesterday after the strong upward surge that had lifted prices to their highest levels in nearly three years. "Profit taking and consolidation," said Wall street analysts.

The first half of the world championship chess match between Bobby Fischer of the United States and Boris Spassky of the Soviet Union -the subject of protracted haggling and negotiation -- was canceled yesterday.

A University of Chicago economist acknowledged yesterday that he was a paid consultant to a public relations firm for an International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation subsidiary at the time he made a widely quoted speech attacking actions by the Federal Trade Commission against the subsidiary.
In the menus below, the dishes marked with an asterisk are followed by a recipe.

DETROIT, April 13 -- General Motors, in its proxy statement sent out today, said it had set up a new committee made up of six prominent businessmen to aid the corporation in selecting nominees to its board of directors.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, April 13 -- Despite North Vietnam's offensive, which has brought a division of enemy troops within 25 miles of Saigon, most of the capital's residents appear calm and seem indifferent to the fighting.

CHICAGO, April 13 (UPI) -The free enterprise world may experience a severe steel shortage in the late nineteen-seventies unless American steel mills get better treatment from the Government, Stewart S. Cort, chairman of the Bethlehem Steel Corporation, said today.
Mayor Lindsay made his conversion to the Democratic party complete, in a sense, when he attended a fundraising dinner of the New York County Democratic Committee last night at the Americana Hotel.

The New York Times News Service and LATIN, a cooperative news agency owned by a group of leading Latin-American newspapers, have agreed to have LATIN translate and distribute a Spanish-language service for The New York Times News Service.

MONTREAL, April 13 -- On a day when President Nixon met with Prime Minister Trudeau to improve relations between the United States and Canada, the Rangers made the Canadiens give up this country's mostprized trophy -- The Stanley Cup.

WASHINGTON, April 13 -New York City would receive $158.9-million from the Federal Government this year under the revenue-sharing legislation that is currently undergoing final polishing by the House Ways land Means Committee.

A bitter statement on behalf of the city's organized black policemen charged yesterday that the fatal shooting of a black detective by a uniformed patrolman who mistook him for a criminal grew out of a "shoot first and ask questions later" attitude by policemen.
WASHINGTON, April 13 -- Senate Democrats rejected today attempts by liberals to strengthen party discipline and strip committee chairmen of the power to name the members of conference committees.

Gloom, it might be said of Abram Chasins's survey of the state of current classic and pop music, insists on breaking through. Mr. Chasins, pianist, administrator and writer on music, complains that the musical world is falling apart before his eyes and goes about crying woe. But the fact is that he is unwilling to credit his own evidence.

The First National City Corporation, as its chairman, Walter B. Wriston, predicted at the company's annual meeting last month, breasted the tide of lower interest rates in this year's first quarter. Yesterday it reported higher earnings.
The canny small investor probably knows about due-diligence reports, which are prepared either for or by the investment banker before a company goes public.

PARIS, April 13 -- William J. Porter, the United States delegate to the Vietnam peace talks, said today that President Nixon had offered to resume the talks with a session today but that the only reply of the Communists had been "a mushrooming invasion" of South Vietnam by North Vietnamese troops.

YONKERS, April 13 -Silent Majority, acquired as a yearling for $9,500 by the late Roger White and Irving Liverman, developed into an outstanding colt who won 17 of 21 starts as a 2-year-old and earned $58,190 last season. Offers to buy the colt ranged from Stanley Dancer's bid of $250,000 to the Armstrong brothers' quote of $340,000, but the pacer was not for sale.

ROME, April 13 -- A month after Giangiacomo Feltrinelli, the wealthy leftist publisher, died in a blast at the foot of a power pylon near Milan, the case is still an enigma, with many Italians convinced it will never be solved.

The North American Rockwell Corporation reported yesterday that its profits in the three months ended March 31, the second quarter of its fiscal year, rose 16 per cent from a year ago on a sales gain of 11 per cent.
MONTREAL, April 13 -- A general strike of 210,000 of Quebec's service workers, now in its third day, has apparently hit hospitals throughout the province the hardest.

LOS ANGELES, April 13 (AP) -- A Mexican man hijacked a Frontier Airlines 737 jetliner from New Mexico to Los Angeles today, kept the crew at gunpoint while he was interviewed on radio and television and then surrendered his pistol to the pilot.

WASHINGTON, April 13 -The State Department announced today that Willis C. Armstrong, Assistant Secretary for Economic Affairs, would lead the United States delegation at the negotiations on the Lend-Lease debts.

BELFAST, Northern Ireland, April 13 -- Eleven bomb explosions caused heavy property damage in six towns today in the worst spate of violence since the British Government imposed direct rule on Northern Ireland three weeks ago.

The State Welfare Inspector General, George F. Berlinger, said yesterday that his office's study of relief cases accepted at two welfare centers here in January indicated that more than 10 per cent of those accepted were ineligible.

WASHINGTON, April 13 -- The Navy has bolstered its operations in Vietnam to the highest level since the peak of the war in 1968, in response to stepped up attacks by the North Vietnamese. The attacks began two weeks ago and three days later were officially characterized here as a "massive assault."
CAMBRIDGE, Mass. -- I have been in Great Britain and have seen a rational approach to the difficult problem of heroin addiction.

Reaching the unreachable trick in the dummy if often somewhat easier than it seems at first sight. The diagramed example was played in an unusual event in the 1972 Spring Nationals, an "unmixed" pairs contest in which men's and women's pairs played as one field.

A citizens' lobby to press for vastly increased government support of the arts has grown so rapidly across the nation that it is almost as potent as the movement to save the ecology or the lobbies for organized labor and certain industries.

MANILA, April 13 (UPI) -- A special committee of the Philippine Senate today confirmed American Congressional charges that the Philippines received secret payments from the United States Government to send troops to Vietnam in 1966.
BELFAST, Northern Ireland, April 13 -- Mrs. Moira Drumm and Mrs. Catherine Dunne have much in common; both are middle-aged working-class Belfast housewives of the Roman Catholic faith.
A Queens jury yesterday urged the death penalty for two young men who were allegedly unarmed accomplices in the murder of a policeman last April.
As the baseball strike ended, the Yankees and Mets announced these plans yesterday to play ball:

WASHINGTON, April 13 -- The Senate, by a vote of 68 to 16, approved today and sent to the House a far-reaching bill that seeks to limit the President's authority to commit the nation to sustained hostilities without the consent of Congress.

TEHERAN, Iran, April 13 (Reuters) -- Four fresh tremors today shook the earthquakestricken areas of southern Iran where it is estimated that 4,000 people have been killed and thousands of others injured and rendered homeless.

ORANGETOWN, N. Y., April 13 -- The most ambitious office development probably ever attempted in the New York surburbs will open here in less than two weeks with only one tenant and with just 16,000 of its one million square feet rented.
Top city health officials are considering the sale or closing of at least five of the 18 municipal hospitals in a "bold step" to save funds.

RICHMOND, April 13 -- The New York Nets bore almost no resemblance tonight to the team that knocked off the Kentucky Colonels in the American Basketball Association first-round playoffs last Monday night.

Just because here are more Puerto Ricans in New York City than there are in San Juan, the boxing promoters at Madison Square Garden have decided to hold the bantamweight championship of Puerto Rico in the Felt Forum next Monday night.
Yale University has decided to assume an activist role as a major corporate citizen in connection with its extensive stockholdings in American industry.

The Pennsylvania Ballet is a beautiful ballet company in search of a beautiful ballet repertory. Wednesday's program at the City Center was most rewardingly danced but less rewardingly planned. What was good were Balanchine ballets that opened and closed the evening, "Four Temperaments" and "Scotch Symphony."

BOSTON, April 13 -- First blood in the championship series of the National Basketball Association's Eastern Conference went to the New York Knicks tonight at Boston Garden -- and they inflicted a deep wound.

CHICAGO, April 13 -- Unusual calm and rationality marked the final club owners' meeting here that settled the baseball strike, in contrast to the stormy session in the same Marriott Motor Hotel on April 4, a meeting that prolonged the strike the day before the 1972 season had been scheduled to start.

I have just read your March 17 editorial in which you comment upon my primary campaign in Illinois, describing it as "a fierce personal vendetta" against Senator Muskie with special reference to my having been a standin godfather to his youngest child.
OTTAWA, April 13 -- President and Mrs. Nixon arrived here tonight on a state visit, which Canadians hope will result in a better understanding of a "new" United StatesCanadian relationship.
DETROIT, April 13 -- The visiting Chinese table-tennis team toured an automobile plant here today and set up a table in a factory cafeteria on put on a table tennis exhibition.
Restaurants reviewed on this page on Friday are rated both for their food (four stars to none) and for their atmosphere, service and decor (four triangles to none).
The first general strike in baseball history ended in its 13th day yesterday when the players and owners agreed to start the season tomorrow without making up any of the 86 missed games.
WASHINGTON, April 13 -- The Pay Board held up a 15.3 per cent wage increase of New York Telephone Company workers today to restudy the raise that it tentatively approved two weeks ago.

The heavy going on the Aqueduct track yesterday proved quite to the liking of Sigmund Sommer's Hitchcock, and to Angel Cordero. The latter, enjoying a fine meeting after a late start, guided Hitchcock to a two-length success in the main event of one mile to round out a riding triple for the day.

From 25 to 30 per cent of the policemen and firemen in Yonkers called in sick yesterday as a job action by the uniformed services spread during the continuing deadlock in the Westchester city over a new work contract.

The 1972 National Book Awards were presented last night in a subdued ceremony that heard expressions of deep worry about the decline of the quality of life in the face of commercialism and technology.
A 23-year-old man was arrested outside of his East Side apartment last night as a suspect in the robbery of $20,000 in each from six Manhattan banks in the last 14 months.

Sherman J. Maisel took a retrospective look at his seven years as a member of the Federal Reserve Board of Governor yesterday and came to the conclusion that monetary policy -- for which the Reserve is responsible -- should play a far smaller role in stabilizing the economy.

The ambitious plan for the offshore development of the east side of Lower Manhattan unveiled this week has a long way to go before it becomes reality, but in size alone its impact on New York would be historic. It is not a question, however, of a dramatic change in the skyline.

WASHINGTON, April 13 -- President Nixon's secret April 1 offer to resume negotiations with the North Vietnamese reportedly included a major condition: that Hanoi suspend its new offensive against South Vietnam.
ALBANY, April 13 -- Governor Rockefeller today vetoed a bill that would have expanded New York City's Board of Elections from four members to 10.
A lot of people have spent more than half their lives in politics, but probably not many of them are still only 39 years old.

ROCHESTER, April 13 -- Two correction officers from the Attica prison and a former convict told the McKay Commission today of the emergence within the last five years of a new kind of inmate. The former convict said that, as an oldtimer, he had found it easier to relate to guards than to the new breed of prisoner.

Behind the scenes of the baseball strike, the logistics had long since been worked out yesterday for the 24 major league stadiums to come alive -- players' uniforms were hung neatly in empty lockers, medical supplies were stacked in the trainers' rooms, chartered planes and buses were standing by.
Mayor Lindsay's first budget veto since 1968 was overridden yesterday in votes that reflected more political than fiscal considerations.
Mrs. John D. Rockefeller 3d, John H. G. Pell and Eben W. Pyne have been elected to the Juilliard School's board of trustees, it was announced yesterday by David M. Keiser, board chairman.

When enthusiastic British reviewers compared Sylvia Brooke's autobiography, "Queen of the Head Hunters," to novels by Evelyn Waugh or Nancy Mitford, they were almost damning it with faint praise. Even Mr. Waugh could not have imagined a life like hers, which resembled an antique fairy tale in a modern translation -something akin to Donald Barthelme's rewriting of "Snow White and the Seven Dwarfs."

Mollie Parnis, the fashion designer who has been dressing some of the city's most elegant women for years, handed Mayor Lindsay a check for $25,000 yesterday for a contest to dress up the city's neighborhoods.

A 21-year-old man was in critical condition at Metropolitan Hospital last night after he was shot 12 times in a street gun battle with six policemen, who frustrated the attempted holdup of a music shop in East Harlem.

ST. LOUIS, April 13 (UPI) -Phil Roberto scored a goal and assisted on two others tonight to lead the St. Louis Blues to a 4-2 triumph over the Minnesota North Stars in their Stanley Cup quarterfinals.

NASHVILLE, April 13 -- Democrats in the Tennessee Legislature overrode today Republican Gov. Winfield Dunn's veto and enacted a districting plan intended to give them five and possibly six of the state's eight House seats in the next Congress.
CLEVELAND, April 13 (AP) -- It took an injury to break up the brother act of Stewart and David Pruzansky of Passaic, N. J., in the National Amateur Athletic Union wrestling championships today.

Eight months after Mayor Lindsay signed into law an air-pollution control code that he described as "the toughest and most comprehensive in the nation," citizens still have not been able to obtain the basic forms that would allow them to press action against polluters.

Except for Red Groom's "Shoot the Moon," a sporadically charming homage to George Melies made in 1962, all the films by artists that opened yesterday at the Whitney Museum are of very recent origin. I'm not sure that "Films by Artists" really means much as a principle of organization -- that it means any more than would, say, "Paintings by Movie Directors."
Acknowledging that the city's central management functions under the Office of Administration had "not worked well," Mayor Lindsay yesterday transferred the responsibility to his Budget Bureau.

PHILADELPHIA, April 13 -In the history books, Pennsylvania is the enlightened colony founded by William Penn and the Quakers, the state guided at Independence Hall by the sagacity of Benjamin Franklin.

It was extremely disappointing to read Bella Abzug's comments about the House of Representatives. [Op-Ed March 29.] She apparently feels that representing your constituents means doing what the polls indicate the majority of them want. While such behavior is often politically desirable, it will hardly earn you a chapter in "Profiles in Courage."

ATLANTA, April 13 -- The nation's Roman Catholic hierarchy today denounced the recommendations of the Presidential Commission on Population Growth and the American Future as "beset with inconsistencies" and, in the case of those involving liberalized abortion policies, fundamentally "immoral."

ALBANY, April 13 -- The Assembly today approved Governor Rockefeller's "prompt trial" bill, which is designed to head off the May 1 judicial mandate by which charges would be dropped if criminal defendants were not brought to trial within six months of arrest.
ALBANY, April 13 -- Three bills aimed at drunken drivers were passed overwhelmingly by the Senate today and sent to the Assembly.

The Justice Department said yesterday that it planned to file antitrust suits against the Columbia Broadcasting System, the National Broadcasting Company, the American Broadcasting Company and Viacom International.
The Liberal party announced yesterday its endorsement of two incumbent Democratic Representatives, Emanuel Celler and Shirley Chisholm, for re-election in November.
DETROIT, April 13 -- New-car sales dropped to 196,720 units in the April 1-10 period from 261,673 a year before.

Two men connected with the Mafia family said to be headed by Joseph A. Colombo Sr. are being sought in last week's killing of Joseph Gallo, the head of a rival Mafia group, sources close to the investigation said yesterday.

INDIANAPOLIS, April 13 (AP) -- The Indiana Pacers held on gamely to turn back a late Denver Rocket surge and win tonight, 91-89, in the seventh and deciding game of their American Basketball Association Western Division semifinal playoff series.

Stock prices dwindled yesterday on the American Stock Exchange as volume dropped almost 1.9 million shares to 5,789,185. Prices were still apparently influenced by some recent profit-taking in issues that showed recent strength. Again there were some reports of higher earnings.

Pier 86, idle for the last two years, was reopened yesterday with a face lift that included a generous application of fresh paint, better lighting, cargo elevators that actually work, and the innovative brightener of five "Golden Girls" -- bilingual college student whose job it is to help passengers make the transition from the cotton batting of shipboard life to the trauma of a New York arrival.
DAKAR, Senegal, April 13 -African countries today proclaimed a right to demand "full compensation and reparations" for any exploitation of their natural and human environment.

SANTIAGO, Chile, April 13 -President Salvador Allende Gossens put before a United Nations economic conference of 141 nations today his quarrel with the International Telephone and Telegraph Company and United States copper corporations.

Congress has taken far too long about passing an "Act for the Protection of Public and Foreign Officials" proposed to end the spate of harassment and threats against diplomats assigned by other countries to the United Nations. The bill was introduced on Aug. 6, 1971.
How strange is your April 6 editorial assessment of Adam Clayton Powell's life and work.
The flagship display in the tie-dye exhibit opening today at the Museum of Contemporary Crafts was rained out yesterday at the preview.

United States businesses operating abroad must meet their social responsibilities as well as create economic wealth, Rodman C. Rockefeller, president of the International Basic Economy Corporation, said yesterday.

WASHINGTON, April 13 -- A member of the Federal Reserve Board gave his support today to an expanded program of public service employment as the best way of cutting unemployment beyond the "moderate" reduction that will come about anyway as the economy expands.
MUNICH, West Germany, April 12 -- A major struggle over freedom of the airwaves is under way here.
NEW CITY, N.Y., April 13 -- A Government highway specialist said today that proposed Federal standards for school bus safety might be issued "in the near future."
All unusual method of rearing rainbow trout for the market is being developed by Alec Purves, an Australian fish farmer.
CINCINNATI, April 13 -- At first glance, Senator Edmund S. Muskie seems to be ideally situated for Ohio's pivotal Democratic primary on May 2, with its prize of 153 convention delegates.

There is bad news from the baseball front these days. The big league players are ending their strike before the sunny weather begins, and as any nitwit knows, watching baseball in a topcoat is almost as silly as sweating out a pro football game in August.

The proposal for a $1.2-billion lower Manhattan development in the East River drew diverse reactions yesterday from public officials, some of whom praised the plan as "exciting," others calling it "sheer insanity."
ST. PAUL, April 13 (AP) -- A Federal grand jury indicted C. Walton Lillehei, a noted surgeon, today on charges of evading $125,100 in income taxes over a five-year period.

WASHINGTON, Pa., April 13 -- Mrs. Paul E. Gilly, who has pleaded guilty in the murder of Joseph A. Yablonski, said in a confession read in court here today that her father had told her that the murder had the approval of the "big man" and to her "that meant Tony Boyle, president of the United Mine Workers."

BOSTON, April 13 -- Senator Edmund S. Muskie, Democrat of Maine, said today that any delay in the scheduled withdrawal of American troops from Vietnam would be "the height of folly" and urged President Nixon to "cease immediately" the bombing of North Vietnam.

MOSCOW, April 13 -- A Soviet delegation left for Washington today to begin critical negotiation with the United States on a large debt from the World War II Lend Lease program. The debt has long blocked major expansion of SovietAmerican trade.

RICHMOND, April 13 (AP) -- The state of Virginia argued today that unless the United States Court of Appeals for the Fourth Circuit was concerned with "the expiation of sin" in past segregation, it should reverse a lower court order for consolidation of Richmond-area metropolitan school districts.

MADRID, April 13 (AP) -Adriano Panatta of Italy upset top-seeded Stan Smith of Pasadena, Calif., in 7-6, 7-6 tiebreakers today, leaving Linda Tuero as the last American in the field in an international tennis tournament at the end of five days of play.

WASHINGTON, April 13 -Johnnie M. Waiters, the Commissioner of Internal Revenue, proposed today that fines be imposed on commercial tax-return preparers who did fraudulent or sloppy work. But he said that he did not want the Government to have the job of testing and licensing the preparers, because that would simply be too much for Internal Revenue to handle.

In a city that yearly has almost as many homicides (1,622 last year) as all of Europe, where there are more murders in a single day than in London during a fortnight, an autopsy by Dr. Milton Helpern can give the most ingenious culprit pause.

ON ROUTE 13, South Vietnam, April 13 -- A South Vietnamese officer, whose lunch had been interrupted by a Communist mortar and rocket barrage that left some of his trucks and supplies in flames, took a deep swallow from a tumbler of whisky and looked gloomily northward along the road.

BUDAPEST, April 13 (UPI) -Hungarian officials confirmed today Western press reports of disturbances in Budapest March 15, the 124th anniversary of the start of the war of independence against the Habsburg empire.

TOKYO, April 13 -- A brief sensation was created today when a Socialist member of Parliament presented to a committee hearing a document that he said had been addressed by the United States Navy to the commander of American naval forces for Japan regarding nuclear cooperation with this country.

Eddie Heywood, the jazz pianist whose highly stylized sextet was one of the most popular jazz groups of the 1940's, is back in town for the first time in 10 years, playing solo piano at the Cookery, University Place at Eighth Street.

Amid filled ash trays, empty Coke cans and coffee cups, and yellow legal paper covered with elaborate doodling, baseball's 24 player representatives reacted incredulously yesterday to the owners' decision to forget the games already missed this season.

As the nation gets increasingly concerned about the burgeoning drug problem, a variety of programs have been suggested as antidotes. Some of them run the risk of being implemented before they have been carefully thought through, in the hope of finding an instant panacea.

The Monsanto Company reported yesterday that it achieved record sales and profits in the first quarter of 1972. Net income of the big chemical concern jumped 56 per cent from a year earlier on a sales gain of 13 per cent.

The Bethlehem Steel Corporation, the nation's second largest steel producer, promised customers yesterday in a surprise move that it would not increase prices on rolled-steel products before Jan. 1, 1973.

HARRIMAN, N. Y., April 13 -- Arthur Goldberg said tonight that United States relations with the United Nations were now "so strained and attenuated" that the survival of the world organization was threatened.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Friday, April 14 -- Enemy troops, attacking yesterday with more than 40 tanks, captured half of the provincial capital of Anloc, 60 miles north of Saigon. But South Vietnamese soldiers of the Fifth Division reportedly held the other half early this morning after more than 24 hours of heavy fighting.

The body of an 18-year-old Michigan youth who fled from a Marine Corps boot camp in San Diego on Tuesday night was found early yesterday in the wheel well of an American Airlines jetliner after it landed at Kennedy International Airport.
The March 24 editorial "Pieces of a Puzzle" comments on the report "ReStructuring the Government of New York City." May I consider, one by one, points made by the editorial?

WASHINGTON, April 13 -Senator Henry M. Jackson of Washington assailed his opponents for the Democratic Presidential nomination today as "irresponsible" in their foreign policy stands and shilly-shallying on thorny domestic issues such as school busing.

The City Council, after an hour and a half of debate, passed a bill yesterday permiting the city to float $700million in bonds for the construction of middle-income housing and the rehabilitation of slum housing.

WASHINGTON, April 13 -- Senator Edward M. Kennedy charged today that a top official of the Justice Department, as well as the United States Attorney in Denver, knew in mid-March that the doctor treating Mrs. Dita D. Beard was under criminal investigation by the department but kept that information from the Senate Judiciary Committee.
When Santana, the rock group from San Francisco that brought Latin rhythms into contemporary pop, became a top box-office draw, it was inevitable that similar bands would soon follow.

WASHINGTON, April 13 -America as a rigidly structured and stratified society is the subject of Donald Driver's comedy, "Status Quo Vadis," which opened last night at the Arena Stage after an extended seven-month engagement at Chicago's Ivanhoe Theater.

In an unusually fast move, the underwriting group that priced $150-million of Consolidated Edison Company bonds Tuesday evening decided early yesterday that it couldn't successfully sell them at a yield of 7.90 per cent.

Mary Todd Lincoln's brooding thoughts about the shooting of Abraham Lincoln 107 years ago today -- perhaps the most emphatic known to have been set down by the slain President's voluble, distraught widow -- are in an unpublished letter to be auctioned April 20.

The body count is going up in the city these days as gunmen drill each other with shotguns, pistols and impunity. The killers are rapidly writing finis to several unfounded notions, fictional and real. To dismiss the most obvious first: all those stories honoring the Mafiosi as chivalrous family men engaged in good government or civil rights activity ought to be given indecent burial.
WASHINGTON, April 13 -The 1972 Democratic National Convention, which the party had hoped would be quieter than the one in 1968, is already off to a contentious start.

TOKYO, April 13 -- Paul A. Volcker, Under Secretary of the Treasury for Monetary Affairs, arrived in Japan tonight to sound out Japanese officials on the forum for negotiating monetary and trade reforms.

KAMPALA, Uganda, April 13 -- The burned-out automobile of an American journalist who disappeared last July with a companion was found yesterday, just where a deserter from the Uganda Army said it had been hidden.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., April 13 -- Six riders -- each of whom has been training in the United States and Europe for the last four years -- will try out for places on the United States Equestrian Team's Olympic dressage squad tomorrow and Saturday at the American Dressage Institute here.

" Brian's Song," a poignant drama about a true-life interracial friendship between two athletes, received 11 nominations, the most for any single program in the entertainment category, in the National Academy of Television Arts and Science's 24th annual run for the Emmy Awards.

CAPE KENNEDY, Fla., April 13 -- As American astronauts prepare for another Apollo voyage to the moon next Sunday, their counterparts in the Soviet Union are training for long-duration flights in earthorbiting laboratories, leaving their own lunar exploration to automatic probes.

CLEVELAND, April 13 -- Senator Hubert H. Humphrey, Democrat of Minnesota, won the endorsement here today of Arnold R. Pinkney, a black leader whose support had been sought by Senator Edmund S. Muskie of Maine in Ohio's May 2 Presidential primary.

The Kroger Company, the nation's third largest supermarket chain (after the Great Atlantic and Pacific Tea Company and Safeway Stores) increased first-quarter earnings to $9.4-million, or 70 cents a share, from the year-earlier $8,743,513, or 66 cents a share.

The Ridgefield, Conn., Board of Education ordered "Boss," a biography of Chicago's Mayor Richard J. Daley, removed from a high school reading list. Use of the book had been approved by the Superintendent of Schools, but the board chose to supersede the opinion of the school administration.
Vincent DeP. Draddy, a clothing manufacturing executive, has pledged a $1-million personal gift to Manhattan College, the college has announced.
GREENSBORO, N.C., April 14 (UPI) -- Tom Meschery resigned as head coach of the Carolina Cougars today to spend a year or two searching his soul about the game of professional basketball.

MEXICO CITY, April 14 -During the last 15 months the Mexican Government has been quietly taking over some of the country's leading business enterprises. It now controls the biggest Mexican hotel chain, a leading independent television station in Mexico City and is believed to be in control of the largest newspaper chain in the country and about to take over the largest cotton brokerage as well.

The New York Mets--saddened by the death of Gil Hodges and scattered by the baseball strike--gathered for the first time in two weeks yesterday and worked out in Shea Stadium for the first time in six months.

A 33-year-old prisoner who escaped from the Trenton State Prison Farm last month -- after being denied the right to call home to check on his sick children, he said -- went on a television news program here last night to give himself up.

WASHINGTON, April 14 -- A former member of the United States Board of Parole charged today that two top Justice Department officials -- John N. Mitchell and Richard G. Kleindienst -- had put pressure on the board to grant a parole to a former member of Congress.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N. Y., April 14 -- Mrs. Lois Stephens of Ossining, N. Y., riding Fasching, took a narrow lead today over John Winnett and his mount, Reinaid, in the first round of the Olympic dressage tryouts.
WASHINGTON, April 14 -Industrial production rose strongly again in March, the seventh consecutive monthly advance, the Federal Reserve Board reported today.

WASHINGTON, April 14 -Chile accused the United States today of trying to block development loans for Chile in multinational lending agencies and to frustrate Chile's efforts to win postponement of payments on her international debts.
The third largest diamond ever found -- 969.8 carats and valued at $11.7-million -- has been discovered in the West African Republic of Sierra Leone, it was reported here yesterday.

There is no doubt that the authors of the Constitution intended that the President and both houses of Congress share the awesome power to commit this nation to war. James Madison and his colleagues would be astonished -and probably horrified -- at the spectacle of two administrations waging a major war for more than seven years without ever obtaining a formal declaration of war from Congress.

The 21-year-old fiancee of a city patrolman was stabbed to death and possibly raped some time during the early morning hours yesterday as she was sleeping in her groundfloor bedroom in the Ozone Park section of Queens.

INDIANAPOLIS, April 13 -With Indiana's regular Democrats showing no apparent enthusiasm for either Hubert H. Humphrey or Edmund S. Muskie in this state's May 2 primary, party leaders are giving Gov. George C. Wallace of Alabama a good to excellent chance of winning a large share of Indiana's 76 convention delegates.

Your March 26 editorial "Retreat From Reason" does not accurately reflect the influences that have caused a slowdown in racial integration. To describe the opposition to busing as "the old lingering fears of an integrated America" is an oversimplification to say the least.

The prime rate, which has been moving up rapidly in recent weeks, was increased again yesterday by three major banks to 5 1/4 per cent from 5 per cent. Only a little over a month ago, the prime rate was as low as 4 3/8 per cent at some banks.

Spokesmen for the major television networks yesterday called the Justice Department's antitrust action against them and Viacom International "absolutely ridiculous" and a move that "would make a shambles" of television schedules if the suit were successful.
