The BankAmerica Corporation, the parent company of the nation's largest bank, reported yesterday that it was in the select inner circle of major banks able to post higher earnings in the first quarter.

WASHINGTON, April 14 -- A computer on the East Coast can query one on the West Coast in only a tenth of a second in an experimental network that may help bring to realization a new era in scientific computation.

WASHINGTON, April 14 (AP) -- The Agriculture Department, noting the higher prices of groceries, announced today a $4 increase in monthly food stamp allowances but restricted the increase to lower income families.

The mother of an 18-year-old Marine Corps recruit whose frozen body was found after he stowed away in the wheel well of a San Diego-to-New York jetliner Thursday said yesterday that her son had complained of being beaten at the marines' San Diego boot camp.
Joseph E. Seagram Sons, Inc., is moving out of half the space it occupies in the Seagram Building on Park Avenue, one of New York's most prestigious properties.

An agreement by American Export Industries, Inc., with banks deferring the maturity on a domestic term loan and a Eurocurrency loan was announced yesterday by Ellis B. Gardner Jr., president of the concern.
SANTIAGO, Chile, April 14 -- President Salvador Allende Gossens took up Chile's critical foreign debt problem today with officials of the United States, France and West Germany, the major creditors.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Saturday, April 15 -- The battle for the provincial capital of Anloc, 60 miles north of Saigon, continued today as powerful enemy reinforcements of infantry and at least 10 tanks moved in again on the town despite heavy American air strikes.

Stock prices on the American Stock Exchange inched upward yesterday to close at 28.53, a rise of 0.06 as measured by the Amex index. However, the small movement masked some sharp swings among certain issues.
LONDON, April 14 -- The seven-week coal miners' strike this winter forced Britain's balance of trade $122.2-million deeper into deficit in March.
WASHINGTON, April 14 -Their address is 1600 Pennsylvania Avenue, but they do not live in the White House.

Lieut. Gen. Harry E. Goldsworthy of the U.S. Air Force argues [Op-Ed March 23] that our nuclear arsenal is necessary for defense, considering the disputes and contests among nations which might otherwise lead to the obliteration of our culture. He points to the example of ancient Rome and its culture, which was extinguished because of insufficient defenses, and felicitates us on "defense" costs of only (only?) $70 billion a year.

Yale University has decided to exercise its right to speak out when business corporations in which it has invested appear to be engaged in anti-social activities. Yale thus becomes the first major university to resolve this controversial issue by abandoning the role of the passive institutional investor. Its decision is certain to influence trustees of other leading academic institutions.

One of the most difficult jobs for the Knicks on Thursday night at the Boston Garden -- certainly more difficult than their runaway 116-94 triumph over the Celtics -- was to contain a natural pleasure of solid accomplishment and to assess realistically that the victory was only one of four needed to win the National Basketball Association's Eastern Conference championship.
BALTIMORE, April 14 -- The New York Yankees arrived here this evening full of enthusiasm for a return to business as usual: playing baseball.
DETROIT, April 14 (AP) -Domestic auto production declined by some 5,000 units this week from the 196,172 of last week.

The Federal Government rested its case yesterday in the trial of Assemblyman Hulan E. Jack and five other defendants on charges of participation in a labor-management fraud in Harlem in violation of the TaftHartley Act.
COPENHAGEN, April 14 -The special committee of the Davis Cup tennis nations voted today to exclude South Africa from this year's competition.

The city's Board of Correction issued a report yesterday citing what it called "accomplishments" in improving the city's jails, but warning that "the prisons stand as a monument of our failure" and were still in need of basic, sweeping reform.

Dr. Kenneth Jacobs wrote to the director of the School of Engineering Science and Mechanics at Georgia Tech to admit having committed a wrong. "In reviewing my past class records I have come upon a judgment error I made in the winter quarter of 1951,"

The Meadow Stable, which currently has such good 3year-olds as Riva Ridge, Spanish Riddle and Upper Case, unveiled another formidable prospect yesterday at Aqueduct. Quill Gordon, a son of First Landing, carried the Meadow silks to a thrilling victory in the 1 1/8 feature race, beating Herbert Bryant's Second Bar by a head.
Half a century of West 23d Street died yesterday, with tears but sedately as it had lived when it was a promenade for carriage-driven shoppers and theatergoers.

NEWARK, April 14 -- Imamu Amiri Baraka, the black activist and poet formerly known as LeRoi Jones, announced plans today for a screening process aimed at choosing a consensus black candidate to run in the new 10th Congressional District.

In these times of economic austerity and attrition programs, prohibitive insurance rates and a general reluctance to lend fragile art objects, museums have become increasingly reliant on their own resources for exhibitions.

TEL AVIV, April 14 -- Israel disclosed this week some new items in her arsenal including American-made planes, tanks and field guns. They will be publicly displayed on Independence Day next Wednesday.
TOKYO, April 14 -- The postponement of Henry A. Kissinger's visit to Japan, which was to begin tomorrow, has disappointed officials here.
ROME, April 14 -- The Communist party today denounced violence by ultraleftists in Italy's electoral campaign and said that they were playing into the hands of rightists.
WASHINGTON, April 14 -Representative Florence P. Dwyer, a liberal Republican from New Jersey who is completing her 16th year in the House, announced today that she would not seek re-election.

Cotton futures No. 2 closed 50 cents to $3.80 a bale lower yesterday on the New York Cotton Exchange. Recurrent flurries of liquidation by speculators and trade selling extended losses to as much as $5.25 a bale before the market steadied.

BONN, April 14 -- After resting modestly for almost 200 years in English hymnals, the ode "Amazing Grace" by the London divine, John Newton, became a hit song in Europe this week, topping popularity charts in Britain and on the Continent.

ALBUQUERQUE, N. M., April 14 -- Cheryl Boone is a 28-year-old former Playboy bunny who works as a cocktail waitress at a popular restaurant near the State Capitol in Santa Fe. She also is a Democratic candidate for the United States House of Representatives -- and she has a distinct advantage over her competition.

NORFOLK, Va., April 14 -- The New York Nets announced today the dates of two home games at the Nassau Coliseum against the Virginia Squires in the American Basketball Association's Eastern Division final -- and triggered a reaction that was at least as negative as New York's 47-point loss to the Squires last night.
Mrs. Faith A. Seidenberg, a Syracuse lawyer active in the women's liberation movement, announced yesterday her candidacy for a Liberal party nomination for the State Court of Appeals.

LOS ANGELES, April 14 (UPI) -- James H. Doolittle and 43 of the men who flew with him on the first American bombing of Tokyo during World War II hoisted silver goblets today in memory of "those who have gone."

CAPE KENNEDY, Fla., April 14 -- The space agency announced that, when operational, the manned space shuttle would be launched from two bases, the Kennedy Space Center here and Vandenberg Air Force Base in California.
PHILADELPHIA, April 14 -Spring and the Democratic primary campaign came here today, competing for public attention this warm, breezy afternoon. Spring won.
CARGESE, Corsica, April 2 -- Across the green terraces the two churches still confront each other, no longer hostile, merely redundant.

ABU DHABI, Union of Arab Emirates -- The Arabian Princess lifts the lower part of her dark blue veil to answer the shiny new telephone, a precious link to the outside world for 22-year-old Sheika Salama, cloistered in this desert sheikdom.

PALM SPRINGS, Calif., April 14 (UPI) -- Mrs. Judy Rankin shot a three-under-par 69 to take the first-round lead in the 54-hole, $110,000 Dinah ShoreColgate Winners' Circle golf championship at the Mission Hills Country Club today.
YONKERS, April 14 -- A State Supreme Court justice tonight issued a show-cause order temporarily restraining policemen and firemen here from picketing at city buildings and installations.

WASHINGTON, April 14 -Dr. Herbert Stein, chairman of President Nixon's Council of Economic Advisers, said today that the Administration expected "to reduce considerably" the number of companies covered by price controls.

The new-issue market last week was described by several brokers as "active" with trading volume paced by the initial offering, on Thursday, of 1,750,000 common shares of Hartz Mountain Pet Foods, Inc., and the initial offering, on Wednesday, of 550,000 common shares of the Newell Company.

PHILADELPHIA, April 14 -Eddie Noll of Philadelphia won the United States professional handicap court tennis championship for the second straight year by defeating Joe O'Donnell of the New York Racquet and Tennis Club, 6-3, 6-0, 6-3, today at the Racquet Club.

OTTAWA, April 14 -- President Nixon called today for a new approach to CanadianAmerican relations based on a frank recognition of the "separate identities" of the two allies and the "significant differences" between them.

CHICAGO -- The answer to dangers raised by the unthinking, massive use of chemical insecticides lies not in prohibiting their use. (Most American state governments were forced to do so by overenthusiastic conservationists.) It does not lie in depending on mysterious "natural" forces which, according to some, protect members of "natural" ecological systems from destruction by biological enemies.

HARTFORD, April 14 -- Telephone rates for calls made within Connecticut will rise by 15 per cent in a couple of weeks, but rates will be lowered for residents of the state who make only limited use of their noncommercial telephones.

The Conservative party organization of Staten Island endorsed a candidate last night to run next fall against State Senator John J. Marchi, a Republican who has always had Conservative backing.

The official union of the island of Zanzibar with Tanganyika to form the United Republic of Tanzania in 1964 was never actually consummated. Sheik Abeid Karume, who had overthrown Zanzibar's Arab-Asian oligarchy in a bloody coup 32 days after the island had been granted independence by Britain, ruled harshly and absolutely. He was the nominal First Vice President of Tanzania but would tolerate no interference or guidance from President Nyerere's mainland Government.

Postel, a frequent foe of the board, who made the charges against Mr. Walsh.

STRATFORD, Conn., April 17 -- Noam Chomsky, an antiwar activist and linguistics professor at Massachussetts Institute of Technology, was among 60 persons arrested today during a peaceful demonstration in front of United Aircraft's Sikorsky Division plant here.

Charges of "political favoritism" in filling jobs and of threats of "job reprisals" in Harlem's School District 5 have led to a joint investigation by the State Education Department and City School Chancellor Harvey B. Scribner's staff.
COLUMBUS, Ohio, April 17 -- A three-judge Federal court declared unconstitutional today anew state program of reimbursement to parents of nonpublic school children.

BELFAST, Northern Ireland, April 17 -- The homecoming of Harry McKeown, freed after eight months internment as a suspected terrorist, has not been a happy one. He lost his business, his house and his income and, he says, his wife is not the pleasant woman she used to be.

Purple with turquoise accents sashed snugly at the waist with a matching multicolor print? Aquamarine piped in black? Persimmon worn with accessories of one's own choice? Comfortable, casual pants? Hardly typical prison garb.

WASHINGTON, April 17 -Overwithholding of personal income taxes this year plus an increase in corporate-profits taxes above expectations will raise Treasury revenues in the current fiscal year about $5billion above the January estimate, a high official disclosed today.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Tuesday, April 18 -- The United States command announced today that two American warships were damaged in separate actions off the coast of North Vietnam during the weekend and that there were casualties on both ships.

Prices of soybean futures advanced 3/4 cent to 2 cents a bushel on the Chicago Board of Trade, after opening on a weak tone in an apparent carryover of selling from Friday's session, when prices dropped more than 4 cents a bushel.

DETROIT, April 17 -- The Chrysler Corporation today reported first-quarter net income of $35.8-million, or 70 cents a share, more than triple the $10.8-million, or 22 cents a share, the year before, making the profit for the quarter just reported the best since 1969.

SAN JOSE, Calif., April 17 -A shotgun purchased by Angela Davis just two days before an escape attempt at the Marin County Civic Center in August, 1970, was identified today as the weapon used to shoot a judge who was taken hostage by the convicts involved.
Jack Anderson, the Washington columnist, was honored last night at the annual awards dinner of the Society of Silurians, the New York journalism group.

President Nixon said the right things with grace and good humor during his brief visit to Canada. Many Canadians who had expected a cold, reserved guest were astonished to discover instead a relaxed, friendly President who seemed to get on well with the man of very different style who is their Prime Minister.
Irwin Alfin has been elected president and chief operating officer of Chanel, Inc., perfumes. He formerly was executive vice president.

DANANG, South Vietnam, April 17 -- The South Vietnamese say that they have killed more than 6,000 North Vietnamese and have destroyed about 100 enemy tanks since the beginning of the offensive more than two weeks ago.

ATLANTIC CITY, April 17 -- A group of protesters tried to disrupt the convocation ceremonies of the American College of Physicians today with a demonstration against Dr. Saul Krugman, a leading figure in hepatitis research.
WASHINGTON, April 17 -The Pentagon disclosed tonight that a United States missile frigate was attacked yesterday in the Gulf of Tonkin, apparently by a North Vietnamese gunboat.

In refusing to permit Mr. Flanigan to testify, it has formally invoked the doctrine of "executive privilege."

Wilson Yambo connected on so many good long-range shots to the head last night that he outdid himself, injured his right hand and lost the battle billed as the bantamweight championship of Puerto Rico to Davey Vasquez of the Bronx.

WASHINGTON, April 17 (AP) -- The Supreme Court agreed today to review a ruling that the Occidental Petroleum Corporation could not be required to forfeit some $19.5-million in profit from a 1967 deal involving about 20 per cent of the stock in the Kern County Land Company of Bakersfield, Calif.

WASHINGTON, April 17 -Those ghastly rumors circulating this weekend that China had sent a 19-year-old female panda far beyond the age of romance as half its gift to the United States were quashed forever today.

ATLANTA, April 17 (AP) -- Willie Davis belted a two-run homer and had a run-producing infield single tonight as the Los Angeles Dodgers trimmed Atlanta, 8-3, in the Braves' home opener.

MOSCOW, April 17 -- The Soviet Union, stepping up public pressure on the Nixon Administration to curb the air war over North Vietnam, published a protest note tonight accusing the United States of having damaged four Soviet merchant vessels during the raids on Haiphong.

BRIGANTINE, N.J., April 17 (AP) -- A man wanted in connection with the shooting of a Missouri state trooper threatened to kill his 3-year-old son today, when he was trapped by the police in a beachfront home here.

WASHINGTON, April 17 -A high official of the Grumman Corporation said today that his company's major Long Island subsidiary was "financially unable" to build 48 more F-14 jet fighters for the Navy unless the Government "restructures" its contract for the planes.
ROME, April 17 (AP) -- A 30year-old native of New York hijacked a Rome-bound Swiss liner from Geneva today by threatening the passengers and crew with what turned out to be a box of cigars.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., April 17 -- The Chinese table tennis team has agreed to play an exhibition match here with members of the United Nations international team.

A dispute over the right of Bronx landlords to terminate their contract with building services employes is scheduled to go to arbitration tomorrow before James D. McFadden, former City Labor Commissioner.

WASHINGTON, April 17 -Richard J. Ramsden, the Wall Street consultant who was hired by the Government to analyze the financial consequences of antitrust action against the International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation, testified today that the Justice Department had overstated his findings.
Earth Week opened here yesterday with some discouragement about what really had been accomplished to save the environment since the last Earth Week a year ago.

Old jokes about Americans going through museums on bicycles may have to be updated and given a new twist. Today, the Museum of the City of New York opens an exhibition that zips through the history of New York from 1524 to 1972 in 17 minutes flat, as timed by a computer that can slice centuries as thin as sandwich meat.

WASHINGTON, April 17 -The House Ways and Means Committee formally approved today a revenue-sharing bill that would provide $5.3-billion this year to state and local governments and about $30billion over the five-year life of the bill.

BOSTON, April 17 (AP) -- Tom McCraw belted a three-run homer in the eighth inning off Bill Lee, a reliever, and Milt Wilcox checked Boston on two hits today as the Cleveland Indians spoiled the Red Sox's home opener with a 4-0 victory.

WASHINGTON, Pa., April 17 -- A defense request for postponement of the trial of 63-year-old Silous Huddleston, one of six persons charged with murder in the 1969 shooting deaths of Joseph Yablonski, the United Mine Workers official, and his wife and daughter, was provisionally denied today.

The Sadler's Wells Opera, the popular London company noted for its performances in English, has a new managing director. He is the Earl of Harewood, a cousin of Queen Elizabeth II. The 49-year-old Earl, who has been director of the Royal Opera House, Covent Garden, and artistic director of the Edinburgh International Festival, succeeds the late Stephen Allen.

The Xerox Corporation reported yesterday that its net income in the first quarter of 1972 was 16 per cent higher than in the corresponding period last year. Revenues of the manufacturer of business-copying machines and computers rose 22 per cent from a year earlier.
PHILADELPHIA, April 17 -Gov. George C. Wallace of Alabama suddenly shifted strategy today and put in a full day's campaigning from one corner or Pennsylvania to another.

Some retrenchment developed on the American Stock Exchange yesterday with declines outnumbering advancing issues and a resultant drop in the Amex index to 28.49 from 28.53 on Friday.

PANAMA, April 17 -- Jamaica defeated Panama hero this afternoon in the final of the first. Central American team championship. Less than a generation ago, venereal diseases were still not discussed in polite society, let alone in the press and on the radio. WASHINGTON, April 18 -The White House moved today to eliminate a major stumbling block to Richard G. Kleindienst's nomination to become Attorney General, as Peter M. Flanigan, an economic aide to President Nixon, offered to give limited testimony before the Senate Judiciary Committee, which is holding inquiries involving the International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation.

Lawyers for Assemblyman Hulan E. Jack and five other defendants charged with conspiracy rested their case in Federal Court here yesterday with the completion of testimony by Mr. Jack and brief statements by character witnesses for two other defendants.
JERSEY CITY, April 18 (AP) -- Joseph V. (Newsboy) Moriarty, a longtime numbers defendant, was arrested here tonight by state police, who said he had $20,000 in numbers slips in his possession.
HONG KONG, April 18 -Asian countries are reacting along predictable lines to the renewed American bombing attacks on Hanoi and Haiphong.

A bigger share of the billions of dollars in annual tax remembrances that New Yorkers have just finished sending to Washington may soon be coming back, in the form of Federal revenue sharing. That welcome prospect has been brought closer by House Ways and Means Committee approval this week of an improved version of the sharing plan President Nixon put at the top of his legislative priority list more than a year ago.

WASHINGTON, April 18 (UPI) -- George Meany, head of the A.F.L.-C.I.O., said today that he had become disenchanted with strikes and had appointed a committee of labor leaders to search for an alternative weapon.

In recent years musical archeologists have dug up a succession of scores or chunks of scores by composers such as Mahler, Paganini, Schubert and Mendelssohn. Some of these shards were lost, a few were suppressed by the artists, and others were left unfinished in one respect or another.

Seven members of the Gay Activists Alliance have filed assault charges against at least six unknown assailants and the head of the firemen's union who, they said, attacked them at a gathering of political writers at the New York Hilton Hotel Saturday night.

MANILA, April 18 (UPI) -The Philippine Government has named five auto companies, including three of Detroit's Big Four, to build cars for its new automobile industry. Ending a study, the Government's Board of Investments chose General Motors, Ford Motor Company, Chrysler Corporation, Volkswagen of Germany and Toyota of Japan.

UTAPAO, Thailand, April 16 -- At this huge B-52 base sprawling against the Gulf of Siam there is a new and evident tension among the bomber crews, who for the first time are coming under close fire from North Vietnamese surfaceto-air missiles.

As Earth Week becomes an annual feature of the calendar, it incurs the danger inherent in all anniversaries -that pious observance may replace inspiration. Since Earth Day was observed in 1970 too much has been done in improving the American environment to warrant despair, but too little to warrant complacency.
MINEOLA, L.I., April 18 -- A 24-year-old Army veteran who had reported finding his parents slain in their Glen Cove home early today was arrested here this afternoon and charged with murder.
The head of the United Service Organizations said here yesterday that "preliminary findings" indicated that four or five former employes had been involved in alleged financial irregularities.

SACRAMENTO, Calif., April 18 -- Some candidates have "made a mockery" of California's campaign spending reporting laws, Edward G. Brown Jr., Secretary of State, said today as he announced a strong enforcement plan this year.
Following are the names of persons listed in a compilation by the Citizens' Research Foundation as having contributed $25,000 or more to political campaigns in 1970.

NUREMBERG, West Germany, April 18 (Reuters) -- Two Czechoslovak miners hijacked a plane today, shot and wounded a co-pilot and forced it to fly to West Germany so they could request political asylum. When they got here, they surrendered peacefully to the police, who took them into custody.
The Boston Celtics encountered a second problem yesterday. It could make the first problem -- that of beating the Knicks tonight in Boston -- even more difficult.

A plan that would provide Manhattan by 1976 with enough state and city court facilities for the rest of the century -- without constructing any additional buildings -- was announced yesterday by the city's two presiding justices of the Appellate Division of State Supreme Court.

WASHINGTON, April 18 -- The House Judiciary Committee today approved a New York-New Jersey compact to enable the Waterfront Commission of New York Harbor to oversee cargo security at airports in the metropolitan area.
It took a year of effort and more than $100 in costs, but Hyman Asheroff, a 56-yearold lawyer from Glen Cove, L. I., won a battle yesterday that many motorists would love to have triumphed in.

President Nixon's decision to turn the clock back four years by escalating the bombing of North Vietnam from its southern panhandle to the Hanoi-Haiphong area is an exercise in folly and futility. It revives a strategy fried for three years and abandoned finally by President Johnson in 1968 because it was demonstrably a failure. The mystery is why it is being tried again.

Robert Pollack has been named president of the Colonial Penn Insurance Company, member of the Colonial Penn Group of Philadelphia, which specializes in automobile insurance of older drivers, Colonial Penn Group announced yesterday. Mr. Pollack was formerly senior vice president of the Colonial Penn Group.

CHICAGO, April 18 -- Continuing to accomplish the improbable, the Amazing Rangers played tonight without their top goalie, a key defenseman and their leading playoff scorer, but nevertheless won their second straight hockey playoff game at Chicago Stadium against the Black Hawks, 5-3.

Prices of world No. 11 sugar contracts rose on the New York Coffee and Sugar Exchange yesterday, with all nine active months showing increases. The four nearby months, May, July, September and October, were up the trading limit of one-half cent a pound.

The Los Angeles Dodgers, behind the hitting of Jim Lefebvre and Chris Cannizzaro, rallied from a 1-0 deficit to defeat the Braves, 3-1, last night in Atlanta.

HARRISBURG, Pa., April 18 -- Pennsylvania issued today a consumers' guide to life insurance -- the first of its kind -showing that the costs of some basic policies were almost three times those of others providing the same coverage.

The Republic Steel Corporation and subsidiaries reported yesterday higher first-quarter net income despite slightly lower sales. W. B. Boyer, president, pointed out that net income for the first three months had run 22.1 per cent higher than a year ago despite shipments, which ran 11.6 per cent behind the 1971 first quarter.

Understandably wearied by being categorized as a New Critic, Cleanth Brooks, in the introduction to this collection of his essays on the writer's craft, rejects such facile nomenclature. "Now it is bad enough," he writes, "to live under any label, but one so nearly meaningless as 'The New Criticism' -- it is certainly not new -- has peculiar disadvantages," and he proceeds to list some of them.

Miss Mary Melissa Bertholf and Carter Detre Cafritz; son of Mrs. Gwendolyn Cafritz of Washington and the late Morris Cafritz, were married in Washington on April 8 at St. Alban's Episcopal Church by the Rev. Robert Whitridge Estill.

HARTFORD, April 18 (AP) -- Welfare Commissioner Henry C. White has turned up seven state lottery winners on the welfare rolls and will require them to pay back the prize money, Gov. Thomas J. Meskill announced today.

SANTIAGO, Chile, April 18 -President Salvador Allende Gossens announced today that he would ask Congress to nationalize the properties in Chile of the International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation, which he accused of "imperialist penetration."

Tartar Chief, the Elmendorf colt who is a candidate for the Triple Crown, demonstrated his fitness at Aqueduct yesterday in taking a six-furlong sprint.

Duffy, president, told 400 stockholders today at the annual meeting here.

Richard R. Aurelio, the former Deputy Mayor who left City Hall to manage Mayor Lindsay's short-lived Presidential campaign, remains a key mayoral adviser who continues to exert substantial power in city government.

On Monday evening, the Washington Square Methodist Church, 135 West Fourth Street, was filled with an audience that foot-patted, bobbed and weaved and occasionally stomped as they listened to John Ashby and the Free State Ramblers, a fiddle band from Virginia.

The Chase Manhattan Corporation -- highlighting a movement in the banking industry that is rapidly becoming a trend -- announced yesterday that it planned to set up a new subsidiary to take over the bulk of its $12-billion investment management business.

WASHINGTON, April 19 -Representative Les Aspin, Democrat of Wisconsin, read into the Congressional Record today the text of purported interviews with two former United Service Organizations employes giving details of alleged fraud and black market activities by U.S.O. officials in South Vietnam.

MOSCOW, April 19 -- A 25man advance party preparing for President Nixon's visit to the Soviet Union arrived here today amid indications that the atmosphere of crisis between the United States and the Soviet Union was easing here.
Those heavy clouds that have been hovering over the financial statements of the airlines are apparently lifting.
HONG KONG, April 19 -China has rejected a Soviet proposal for united action in support of the Vietnamese Communists, according to a Moscow radio broadcast beamed to China and monitored here.

The number of applications for admission to the Ivy League colleges made a strong recovery this spring after a sharp drop last year, while the less expensive and closer-to-home state universities are experiencing the lowest growth in freshman applications in 10 years.

The ubiquitous "developer" has come to Tanzania's Serengeti National Park and Kenya's Lake Nakuru, just as he has to the Adirondacks, the Sierras and the Everglades -- and with just as great a potential for harm.
LONDON, April 19 (AP) -A 192-foot dirigible, the first built in Britain in 20 years, broke loose from its moorings and crashed into a farmhouse garden early today. No one was aboard.

MOSCOW, April 19 (AP) -Chess officials here declared today that the world champion, Boris Spassky of the Soviet Union, was willing to meet the American challenger, Bobby Fischer, in Paris this summer.

WASHINGTON, April 19 -The Federal Trade Commission, contending that one nonprescription pain killer is about as effective as another, accused the manufacturers of Anacin, Bayer Aspirin, Bufferin and Excedrin today of deceptive advertising.
WASHINGTON, April 19 -The Senate Finance Committee sought today to stem rising welfare costs with a series of steps designed to pry child support payments from runaway fathers.
NEWARK, April 19 -- A coalition of elected officials, union leaders and civic organizations today demanded that New York television stations give more attention to New Jersey.

WASHINGTON, April 19 -The United States Senate argued for its constitutional prerogatives before the Supreme Court for the first time today, as two Senators urged the Justices to block a Federal grand jury's investigation of Senator Mike Gravel's publication of the secret Pentagon papers.
The credit markets, which had started to perk up Tuesday, got their first real breath of fresh air yesterday.

NEWARK, April 19 -- Confronted with a unified drive here to nominate and elect New Jersey's first black House member, Representative Peter W. Rodino Jr. was reported tonight to be considering running against his Washington roommate and fellow Democrat in the new, predominantly white Essex County suburban district.
HOUSTON, April 19 -- Apollo 16 rocketed into an orbit of the moon today and was in position to attempt man's fifth lunar landing tomorrow afternoon.

James D. McFadden, the designated arbitrator in a dispute involving rent increases for Bronx landlords, agreed yesterday to seek an alternative solution with high city officials to avoid precipitating a strike.
Summer paid New York a visit yesterday, but wasn't ready to live here.
Despite the smiling handshake they continue to offer on their tour, China's table tennis wizards don't use the shake-hands grip when they play. They use the penholder.
" It just doesn't fit. This is a choirboy kind of guy, a war hero, a nondrinker, a nonsmoker."

WASHINGTON, April 19 -Representative Cornelius E. Gallagher of New Jersey charged today that the Federal Bureau of Investigation sought to "blackmail" him into quitting Congress after he refused to help J. Edgar Hoover in a feud with the late Robert F. Kennedy.

WASHINGTON, April 19 -Adm. Elmo R. Zumwalt disputed today the contention of the Grumman Aerospace Corporation that it could not meet the terms of a contract to produce 48 more F-14 fighter airplanes for the United States Navy.
MOSCOW, April 19 -- The Soviet Union announced today that its trade with China tripled last year, reversing a steady downward trend over the past decade.
LONDON, April 19 -- An official inquiry absolved the British Army today of gross misconduct in the killing of 13 Roman Catholics in Londonderry, Northern Ireland, on Jan. 30.

Eastern Air Lines announced yesterday that it had made leasing arrangements covering the $88-million cost of five of the 15 Lockheed Aircraft Corporation L-1011 Whisperliners to be placed in service by the company before the end of the year.

Numbered Account started her 1972 campaign with an impressive victory in the $27,450 Prioress at Aqueduct yesterday. And the achievement caused her owner, Ogden Phipps, to evince no small degree of elation.

NEWARK, April 19 -- D. Louis Tonti, the former operating head of the Garden State Parkway and an unsuccessful candidate for the Democratic nomination for Governor of New Jersey in 1969, was indicted by a Federal grand jury today on charges of bribery, income tax evasion and extortion.

Prof. Jewell M. Garrelts, associate dean of Columbia University's School of Engineering and Applied Science, has been named to receive the Egleston Medal in recognition of his contributions to the field of civil engineering.

CLINTON, N. Y., April 19 -The three forensic gladiators from Hamilton and Kirkland Colleges had been primed for two weeks with data on treaties, invasions and deportations so they would be ready to face three debaters from the Soviet Union who, they assumed, would be equally primed.
R. J. Reynolds Industries, Inc., announced yesterday that it achieved record sales and earnings in the first quarter of 1972.

TRENTON, April 19 -- Gov. William T. Cahill announced here today that he was abandoning his legislative proposals for providing $12-million in state tuition grants to the parents of private and parochial school students in New Jersey.
Three former executives of the L. W. Frohlich Intercon agency have just set up their own agency in the health field.

If two trends continue -the back-to-nature movement and inflation, that is -- more families than ever will plan camping vacations this year. A word of warning, though: Camping equipment is highly specialized these days and may cost more than you think.

PNOMPENH, Cambodia, April 19 (AP) -- Severe fighting was reported today along Route 1, the highway connecting Pnompenh with Saigon, and enemy forces were said to have cut it at the town of Kompong Trabek.

MADISON, Wis., April 19 -- About 150 angry beer tavern owners from throughout the state took over the State Assembly chambers today, delaying the opening of a special legislative session for more than two hours.
NORWALK, Conn., April 19 -- The Society to Advance the Retarded has been given $110,409 in Federal funds toward construction of a $526,246 center for handicapped children here.

It is all too easy to overpraise young musicians, particularly conductors. So, just once, let's try not to. Many impressive talents go off like Roman candles early in their careers, and then trail off into obscurity, leaving only a faint glow in the memory.

Following is a statement issued jointly yesterday by the presidents of the eight Ivy League universities and the Massachusetts Institute of Technology concerning the war in Vietnam and campus demonstrations protesting the war.

Jacques Kosciusko-Morizet, for the last two years France's representative at the United Nations, boarded a Metroliner yesterday and went to Washington to take up his new duties as Ambassador to the United States.

I should like to respond to your April 10 editorial "Church and State" and particularly the comment, "It is surely an illusion that privately established institutions which rely on government for a major part of their support can long remain independent. . . ."

I was rather surprised to read your April 13 news story "U.S. Hints at Easing Coolness Toward Havana," which suggests that there has been a change, or hint of a change, in the attitude or policy of the Nixon Administration toward Cuba. On the contrary, there has been no shift at all in official U.S. policy or attitude, and domestic political considerations obviously rule out the possibility of movement until after the Presidential election.
Also as usual at Albany, electoral reform remains disgracefully neglected.

WASHINGTON, April 19 -- One of the most critical periods of life begins when man discovers that his child has become an adolescent. After a few years of trying to live with this discovery, many people simply quit. Others, more realistically perhaps, commit suicide.

In a letter published April 8, Dr. B. H. Rosenberg describes police indifference to theft of his office in Brooklyn and implies that the police would have been more zealous "on Manhattan's East Side." Let me reassure him that his borough is not suffering from discrimination.

EASTON, Pa., April 19 -- The hilltop campus of Lafayette College was quiet and peaceful today, with Frisbees swooping and floating in the spring sunshine. Some students said they had scarcely noticed the new outbreak of antiwar protests at Harvard, Columbia and other colleges.

MONTREAL, April 19 -- Canadian raindrops kept falling on Yogi Berra's head today, washing out tonight's game between his New York Mets and the Montreal Expos and sending him home as the general of an idle army.

HARRISBURG, Pa., April 19 -- The shape of Senator Edmund S. Muskie's campaign in Pennsylvania -- the closest thing to a do-or-die state he has yet faced in his quest for the Democratic Presidential nomination -- has changed radically in the last 10 days.

WASHINGTON, April 19 -The Democratic leadership of the Senate thwarted an attempt by a group of Republican conservatives today to rush through a resolution condemning the North Vietnamese as aggressors and endorsing United States policies in Vietnam.
MERCURY, Nev., April 19 (UPI) -- Scientists detonated an underground nuclear explosion today. It was the first announced test by the United States this year.
If you've got thousands of dollars invested in a cooperative apartment -- but would like to be able to put some of that money to work elsewhere -- you can't do it right now unless you sell.

Sentimentalist that he was, Pie Traynor wanted his protege, Richie Hebner, to wear No. 20 on his Pirate uniform. Sentimentalist that he is. Richie was flattered to use the number that had once graced the back of the legendary Traynor, the model of all third basemen. But when death fell the great Pie a month ago. Hebner rebelled.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Thursday, April 20 -- North Vietnamese and Vietcong troops overran the town of Hoaian in South Vietnam's central coastal region yesterday, forcing the Government battalion defending it to withdraw and reportedly causing heavy casualties.
Wall Street's bull market turned a bit timid yesterday as some favorite fast-climbing growth stocks backed away from recent highs.

A center for the promotion of "made-in-Puerto-Rico" manufactured products was opened here yesterday by the island Commonwealth Government's Economic Development Administration at 2 Pennsylvania Plaza.

MINEOLA, L. I., April 19 -The general counsel of the Long Island Lighting Company said today that the procedures of the Atomic Energy Commission in granting construction and operating permits for nuclear power reactors were causing intolerable delays for power companies in the United States.
WASHINGTON, April 19 (AP) -- The Supreme Court ruled 7 to 1 today that local governments can tax airline passengers to raise money for airport facilities.

BOSTON, April 19 -- Representative Paul N. McCloskey Jr. of California, the Republican party's most outspoken critic of the war in Vietnam, urged Massachusetts voters today to support Senator George McGovern, Democrat of South Dakota, in next Tuesday's primary to repudiate current war policy.
Secretary General Kurt Waldheim's urgent appeal for more funds for Palestinian refugee relief is a timely reminder of the human as well as the monetary costs of nonpeace in the Middle East.
WASHINGTON, April 19 (UPI) -- The Pentagon announced today the assignment of Maj. Gen. Frederic Ellis Davison as the first black officer to command a United States Army division.
The International Harvester Company announced yesterday price reductions on 15 models of heavy-duty trucks in an action it attributed to "competitive market conditions."

Suicide is one of the ultimate human gestures, capable of several different meanings. In the West, religion has usually condemned it as the supreme expression of the sin of despair. Psychology empties suicide of its significance by describing it as an irrational act by a mind out of control.
Any investor who has owned shares in such producers of television sets as Motorola, Zenith, Admiral and Magnavox knows the consequences of competition from a Japanese company.

LONDON -- Some Londoners wouldn't be caught dead in the slightly out of the way and heavily Australian Earls Court section of their city. They are missing out on one of Britain's most accomplished and exotic restaurants, Sri Lanka.

No composer seems quite so English as Sir Edward Elgar. No composer seems more American than William Schuman. Music by the two collided fascinatingly in the first half of the Philadelphia Orchestra's concert in Philharmonic Hall Tuesday night, with Thomas Schippers as guest conductor.

A Federal District Court Judge ruled here yesterday that the Federal Government had to make certain there was adequate integrated low-income housing, in an area where a Federal facility is situated, for both the employes of the facility and the entire population of the area.

The Charter New York Corporation, parent company of the Irving Trust Company, announced yesterday a reshuffle of its senior management due to the decision of Oren Root, its chairman and second in command, to take early retirement.

JERUSALEM, April 19 -- At 6:59 o'clock last evening, the air raid sirens sounded across the land and Israelis paused in whatever they were doing to remember the dead of their three wars. After three minutes the whining noise faded off, and with it the thoughts of war.

James R. Schlesinger, the chairman of the Atomic Energy Commission, said yesterday that research now being undertaken by his agency could bring about a major shift away from the gasoline-powered automobile engine and its excessive pollution within 10 years.

PHUCAM, South Vietnam, April 19 -- The people of this small, prosperous town on the outskirts of Hue don't like the war, they don't like the Communists and they don't much care for Government officials or Americans either.

RIDGEFIELD, Conn., April 19 (AP) -- The local Board of Education reversed itself and voted 4 to 1 last night in favor of sanctioning the use of the book "Boss," which is about Chicago's Mayor, Richard Daley.
HARTFORD, April 19 -- Insurance companies in Connecticut said today that they welcomed the "no fault" anto insurance program approved by the General Assembly late last night.
SAN JOSE, Calif., April 19 -A Soledad Prison guard read into the record at the Angela Davis trial today a portion of one of the controversial letters that she wrote to George Jackson.

Darius Milhaud, the French composer, is celebrating his 80th birthday this year by continuing to write music, and since his output has been astonishingly prolific it is impossible to imagine how many pieces he has composed as of this moment. In any case, they are so numerous that many remain unheard here.

In an action aimed at heading off more campus disturbances, the presidents of the eight Ivy League universities and the Massachusetts Institute of Technology issued a joint statement yesterday deploring the recent heavy bombing of North Vietnam.

Although the Bryan and Keys Duo recital at Alice Tully Hall Monday night was a New York debut, both Keith Bryan, flutist, and his pianist wife, Karen Keys, are seasoned veterans, with several recordings and more than 10 years of international concertizing behind them.
Preliminary 1970 Federal census reports show 811,834 persons of Puerto Rican birth or parentage in New York City -far less than other estimates, including the state's projection of 1,051,200.

Prices of pork belly (bacon) futures declined 1 cent a pound yesterday on the Chicago Mercantile Exchange. The biggest price decline in several weeks, it reflected sustained heavy slaughter of hogs and increasing cold-storage supplies of pork bellies.
The Penn Central has been authorized to increase fares 20 per cent on its New Haven Division commuter lines as of May 1.

PRAGUE, April 19 (Reuters) -- The Czechoslovak Foreign Ministry has asked West Germany to return two men who hijacked a Czechoslovak airliner to Nuremberg yesterday. The Communist party newspaper Rude Pravo reported today.

After the usual desultory start, when sessions came but once a week and lasted only a few hours, the State Legislature has suddenly become caught up in a frenzied push for early adjournment. It is as if the Van Winkles at Albany awoke to the fact that this is an election year.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, April 19 -- Ohio, which has been something of a wallflower in the last two weeks as the leading Democratic Presidential hopefuls have devoted most of their efforts to wooing voters in Massachusetts and Pennsylvania, finally got a flurry of attention today.

WASHINGTON, April 19 -The National Public Affairs Center for Television reported today that a survey of Indiana Democrats showed Senator Hubert H. Humphrey of Minnesota with a substantial lead over his rivals in that state's Presidential primary, set for May 2.

NEW ORLEANS, April 19 (UPI) -- Shouting, laughing, jeering hecklers caused Senator Robert Dole of Kansas, the Republican National chairman to abbreviate a speech at Tulane University tonight in which he defended renewed bombing of North Vietnam.
Premier Chou En-lai said in an interview televised yesterday that China would support Vietnam's Communists to the end in their fight against "the United States Government's war of aggression"

The New York Stock Exchange and American Stock Exchange yesterday issued their latest reports on changes in stock ownership by leading stockholders, directors and officers of their listed companies. The reports include the following:

PARIS, Thursday, April 20 -The United States and 11 other creditor nations agreed early today to grant Chile a major degree of credit relief, while obtaining a promise of "just compensation for all nationalizations, in conformity with Chilean and international law."

ALBANY, April 19 -- Despite efforts to quash a bill calling for a run off election in New York City party primaries for Mayor, City Council President or Controller when a candidate does not receive more than 40 per cent of the vote, Republican leaders said today that they would press for passage of the measure in the Senate.

WASHINGTON -- There is today before Congress and the American people a proposal by the President for a legislative moratorium on court decisions relating to busing of public school students. This proposal is embodied in the proposed Student Transportation Moratorium Act of 1972 and the Equal Educational Opportunities Act of 1972.

WASHINGTON, April 19 -Richard Lewisohn, Finance Administrator of New York City, said today that governmental units that manage pension funds for public employes should be allowed to become members of stock exchanges.

NORMAN, Okla., April 18 -For more than three years a group of former Army officers have been struggling in vain to prompt a full-scale investigation of their charges of widespread irregularities at an Army nuclear weapons base.
Three of the four major metals companies that reported first-quarter earnings yesterday showed declines from yearearlier levels.

WASHINGTON, April 19 (AP) -- Senator Lawton Chiles, Democrat of Florida, introduced a resolution today to open United States Treasury records on the $250-million Federal loan guarantee to the Lockheed Aircraft Corporation for inspection by the General Accounting Office.
WASHINGTON, April 19 -The missile frigate Sterett is described by a Navy official as "one of the little workhorses" of the Seventh Fleet.

MINEOLA, L. I. April 19 (AP) -- Police tapes were played in State Supreme Court here today, and in the clandestine recordings Howard Holder repeatedly denied that he and his co-defendant, Lynnor Gershenson, were involved in the chloroform murder of his wife.

HOLLYWOOD, April 19 (AP) -- Pat Paulsen, the comedian, announced yesterday that he was withdrawing from the Republican Presidential race because of a Federal Communications Commission ruling that he said prohibits him from appearing on television as a performer as long as he is a candidate.

Prof. William B. Gould [letter April 10] defends the Department of Health, Education and Welfare for imposing goals or quotas for women and minority faculty members on colleges and universities, writing that "the courts . . . have supported racial quotas as a means to remedy past discrimination."

JACKSON, Miss., April 19 -A three-judge Federal court has held that Mississippi may continue to furnish free textbooks to private, segregated academies in the state because of the state's historical policy to give books to all educable children.

Like many of the younger choreographers, Pat Catterson has no hesitancy in mixing wildly different dance styles. Her fascinating program at St. Clement's Church Tuesday evening used bits of such charmingly diverse approaches as Merce Cunningham and Killer Joe Piro.

WASHINGTON, April 19 -Peter M. Flanigan, one of President Nixon's senior advisers, agreed today to broaden the scope of his proposed testimony before the Senate Judiciary Committee. He also agreed to testify tomorrow in the hearings, which involve Richard G. Kleindienst's nomination to become Attorney General.
With one bold stroke, Gene Michael grabbed the team leadership in runs batted in and powered the Yankees past the Milwaukee Brewers, 3-2, yesterday.

WASHINGTON, April 19 -Adm. Rufus L. Taylor, the former Deputy Director of Central Intelligence, said today that as far as he knew, his former executive assistant, Victor L. Marchetti, had never revealed intelligence secrets.

ANDERSON, Ind., April 19 (AP) -- Four free throws by Freddie Lewis in the last 29 seconds gave the Indiana Pacers a 116-111 victory over the Utah Stars tonight, their first after losing twice in the four-of-seven-game playoff for the American Basketball Association Western Division championship.

WASHINGTON, April 19 -The first filing deadlines under the new Federal Election Campaign Act have passed, and officials responsible for enforcing the law said today it was "obvious" that there had been widespread noncompliance with its provisions.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., April 19 -- Table tennis replaced speeches tonight at the United Nations as the visiting team from China wound up the first day of its visit to New York with an exhibition that induced many spectators to leap from their seats in cheers and applause.
Winners of the art and architecture awards for 1972, given jointly by the National Institute of Arts and Letters and the American Academy of Arts and Letters, were announced yesterday.

The bombs that thundered down on North Vietnam from American B-52's have fractured two years of campus peace. The renewed student antiwar protests make it plain that many youths never relaxed in their distaste for the bloody misadventure in Indochina. But the lid stayed on so long as hope was retained that the Administration would fulfill its pledge to end American involvement.
Two giants of the rubber industry, the Goodyear Tire and Rubber Company and Uniroyal, Inc., announced yesterday increased earnings for the first quarter of 1972.

WASHINGTON, April 19 -Judge George H. Boldt, the chairman of the Pay Board, told the Joint Economic Committee of Congress today that the walkout of four labor members from the board had had "no noticeable effect" on compliance with wage controls.
Sir Georg Solti brought the Chicago Symphony to Carnegie Hall Wednesday evening, and events followed a predictable course. The house was sold out and the audience sat there simply oozing worship.
ALBANY, April 20 -- The Senate approved today a bill to promote sex equality in public schools, including the increased mixing of girls and young men in sports.

The 21st United States Chess Championship Tournament begins Sunday at 230 West 41st Street. The event which will end May 15, is also a zonal tournament of the World Chess Federation, with the two top finishers qualifying for further competition, leading to a challenge for the world chess championship in 1975

NEW HAVEN, April 20 -- "A very common comment on my book is that it might be basically fascist -- that it gives aid and comfort to fascism. Maybe it does in a sense, but whether it gives advantage to fascism depends entirely on whether other ways of life are able to take advantage of what we are learning about human behavior. This is a warning."

In 1905 somebody made a brief movie called "Tom, Tom, the Piper's Son." The movie, which has been preserved by way of a copyright print in the Library of Congress, consists of a series of remarkably vivid stage-set scenes through which Tom leads an almost inexhaustible following of mischievous kids and angry adults into doorways, out chimneys, up ladders, and down haystacks -- until he is finally caught in the bucket of a well.

J. T. Bailey, president of the Warner Swasey Company, has been elected to the additional post of chief executive officer of the Cleveland-based builder of machine tools, construction equipment and textile machinery.

Just about 300 years ago -- and I confess I am always shaky on history -- William Wycherley wrote a marvelous comedy called "The Country Wife." The point of the comedy was that its hero, a Mr. Horner, was regarded as impotent by most of the male members of the cast, and anything but impotent by the ladies. He was a hero who did protest too little.
The 3,500 hospital workers who staged a "sick - out" Wednesday in 15 municipal hospitals were back at work yesterday.
WASHINGTON, April 20 -George Meany called on the Government today to control all prices effectively -- including food prices -- or else to drop wage and price controls entirely.

The Poetry Society of America, an organization not noted for its militancy, took time out from its 62d annual dinner at the Plaza last evening to condemn the recent statement by Pablo Neruda, a Nobel laureate in literature, that the controversy surrounding the award of the Nobel Prize to Aleksandr I. Solzhenitsyn was "a big bore."
UNIONDALE, L.I., April 20 -- China's touring table-tennis team brought its Ping Pong diplomacy to the Nassau Coliseum today in a pleasant exchange of smiles, gifts and slams.
HARTFORD, April 20 -- A comprehensive program to protect Long Island Sound and Connecticut's coastline from oil spills was announced today by Gov. Thomas J. Meskill.

Without slighting the fashions, the hit of the annual State of Israel bond-drive luncheon yesterday was obviously the flock of models. There were Mrs. Richard Aurelio ("what a nice face"), Mrs. Harry Belafonte ("what a good shape"), Mrs. Vidal Sassoon ("I didn't know he was married") and Mrs. David Susskind ("she's much younger than he is").

The Federal Reserve Board has rebuffed an attempt by the BankAmerica Corporation, the parent company of the nation's largest bank, to get into the real-estate syndication business. In so doing, the Board tightened somewhat its definition of the scope of activities allowed to bank holding companies.

While Walt Tkaczuk was manhandling the Chicago Black Hawks, three of his lesserknown teammates took care of the scoring last night as the Rangers gained a commanding 3-0 lead in their Stanley Cup series with a 3-2 victory at Madison Square Garden.

ALLENTOWN, Pa., April 20 -- Senator Hubert H. Humphrey stepped up his attacks today on Gov. Milton J. Shapp, on Philadelphia's Democratic chairman, Peter J. Camiel, and on the party organizations they lead.

The abduction of the 19-yearold daughter of a Brooklyn bank manager last Aug. 3 came to light with the arrest yesterday of a truck driver on charges of plotting to extort $150,000 of the bank's money for her release.

Two large food organizations announced plans yesterday to enter other branches of the business. The Kroger Company, a Cincinnati-based retailing and food manufacturing company, said it was going into the franchised convenience store business.

Three historians, Carl N. Degler, Robert Middlekauff and Samuel Eliot Morison, were awarded the 1972 Bancroft Prizes last night for "books of exceptional merit and distinction in American history, American diplomacy and the international relations of the United States" published in 1971.
The Wimbledon championships, already threatened with the absence of top men contract professionals, may lose some of the top names in women's tennis for this year's tournament.
ROME, April 20 -- The neoFascist party, which had begun its campaign for the general elections next month with ostentatious confidence, seems worried now.
WASHINGTON, April 20 -The Price Commission discovered an "administrative error" today in allowing a railroad fare increase for the New Haven line two days ago and withdrew the decision.
Two teen-aged boys were sentenced yesterday in Family Court to remove graffiti they had sprayed on subway walls.

I applaud wholeheartedly your March 31 editorial approval of the statement of Cardinal Conway, Primate of All Ireland, that he would not shed a tear if the Republic changed its constitution to eliminate the special status of the Roman Catholic Church and to permit divorce in line with the legislation of Northern Ireland.

MONTPELIER, Vt., April 20 -- Senator George McGovern scored a surprising victory in Vermont last night when his supporters at local Democratic caucuses gained a majority of the delegates chosen for the state Democratic convention.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Friday, April 21 -- North Vietnamese tanks attacked the besieged town of Anloc again yesterday after a heavy artillery barrage, but they were beaten back with the loss of six of the heavy Soviet-made tanks, allied military commanders here said.
The pace of monetary expansion accelerated over the last four weeks, the Federal Reserve reported yesterday.

CHARLESTON, W. Va., April 20 -- A class action suit asking $295-million from six national oil companies has been filed here by three Kanawha County residents who charged the companies with assessing illegal rates of interest on revolving charge accounts.
ATHENS, April 20 -- The circumstances of a political prisoner's recent departure from Greece brought a warning to Washington today from the Athens Government.

FARGO, N.D., April 20 -- Senator George McGovern has made a strong showing in precinct caucuses in North Dakota. The caucuses were held primarily in the larger cities Monday night. Almost all the precincts in the smaller towns and rural areas will meet in May.

SEATTLE, April 20 (UPI) -- Tom Nissalke, coach of the Dallas Chaparrals of the American Basketball Association, was named coach today of the Seattle SuperSonics of the National Basketball Association.

MINEOLA, L.I., April 20 (AP) -- Howard Holder, a former Brooklyn school principal, said that his problem was "to do away with" his wife but that he never said he planned to kill her, a Nassau County detective testified today.

STUTTGART, West Germany, April 18 -- Large and lively crowds, vigorous efforts by independent voter groups, insinuations by conservatives that Chancellor Willy Brandt has sold out West Germany to the Russians in secret negotiations -- these have been among the highlights of the campaigning for the state election Sunday in Baden-Wurttemberg.
SAN JOSE, Calif., April 20 -- The prosecution in the trial of Angela Davis was granted the right today to use her personal letters to show the extent of her love for George Jackson.
Trade news in the world sugar market yesterday involved China, Yugoslavia and Cuba.

WASHINGTON, April 20 -The Tariff Commission found today that the domestic industry making large power transformers was being injured by imports from five countries sold in the United States at "dumping" prices.
WASHINGTON, April 20 -The capital's newest celebrities were at home and receiving today, but were so busy gobbling up the refreshments that they didn't have time to notice the guests.
Net income of the Southern California Edison Company in the first quarter fell to $26.3-million, or 48 cents a share, from the year-earlier $30.6-million, the company announced yesterday.

Since the Columbia University Senate was formed out of the campus turbulence of 1968, with the goal of providing students and faculty members a voice in the university administration, it has often served as a safety valve to student dissent.

In an exceptional case of law enforcement cooperation, the State Attorney General began court action yesterday to close a West 58th Street apartment building that the New York City Police Department said it had been unable to move against despite the presence there of prostitutes, narcotics peddlers and other "despicable characters."

Works of aphoristic brevity, monumental grandeur and every degree of complexity in between have been churned out by Darius Milhaud in his long life (he will be 80 next Sept. 4). It makes possible programs of infinite variety, and this is what the Milhaud retrospective concert at the McMillin Theater Wednesday night had. It was the last of this season's excellent and valuable composer surveys presented by the Performers' Committee for 20th-Century Music.

Only through sheer abdication of responsibility could the Democratic nominee this summer not assail the President's renewal of a Vietnam "victory" through air power. It would be equally strange if either the White House, Hanoi or Moscow chose its moves in this latest round unmindful of next November's election.

Eight foreign films will have their commercial premieres in a series opening next month at the New Yorker Theater. The effort may prove to be a kind of commercial "Last Hurrah" in America for independently made foreign films, as the theater owner, Daniel Talbot, sees it.
GENEVA, April 20 -- The Soviet Union accused the United States and other Western powers at the disarmament conference here today of stalling on the issue of banning chemical arms.

RANCHO LA COSTA, Calif., April 20 -- Hubert Green, who applauded himself on occasion, and Gardner Dickinson, who almost missed a shot when a bee alighted on his ball, shared the first-round lead today in the Tournament of Champions with 68's.

WASHINGTON, April 20 -- The Nixon Administration had no substantive comment today on the North Vietnamese statement giving Hanoi's version of the Paris negotiations that preceded the 1968 bombing halt and the understanding between the two sides.

PARIS -- To understand the power relationships involved in the latest Vietnam crisis it is advisable to remember a little-understood episode during the recent India-Pakistan war. Last December, while the conflict was at its height, the U.S. nuclear carrier Enterprise sailed into the Bay of Bengal. The maneuver was explained by Washington as designed to help evacuate threatened American citizens; in fact it symbolized an entire policy.
The position of the United State delegation to the U.N. in opposing admission of the German Democratic Republic to membership in the World Health Organization is untenable.

Barbara W. Newell, a labor economist and educator, will become the 10th president of Wellesley College. She succeeds Ruth M. Adams, who has resigned to become the first woman to be a vice president of Dartmouth College.

WASHINGTON, April 20 (AP) -- The Food and Drug Administration announced today the nationwide recal of nearly 13,000 dozen pieces of imported dinnerware that it said contained dangerous amounts of lead and cadmium.

WASHINGTON, April 20 -- House Democrats, denouncing both the Nixon Administration for its "dangerous escalation" of the war and North Vietnam for its invasion of South Vietnam, voted overwhelmingly today to support legislation that would set a termination date for the American military involvement.

HAUPPAUGE, L. I., April 20 -- Suffolk County was designated an employment disaster area today by the Federal Government, making it eligible for hundreds of thousands of dollars in emergency relief funds and loans to private industry.

Although George Wallace is being transformed from an outworn Southern politician to a prophet of a new social and economic order in this election year (Op-Ed article by Prof. T. Short interest on the New York Stock Exchange, a widely watched technical indicator of stock-market trends, rose sharply in the latest monthly reporting period to the highest level in more than a year.

WASHINGTON, April 20 -Peter M. Flanigan declined today to answer the questions of Senators about contacts he might have had with Richard G. Kleindienst or officials of the International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation about the settlement of three Government antitrust cases against I.T.T.

The stock market, shrugging off the intensified fighting in Vietnam, gave a good account of itself yesterday. Although a majority of issues declined on the New York Stock Exchange, the Dow-Jones industrial average overcame a loss of nearly 5 points at 11 A.M. to finish at 966.29 with a gain of 1.51.

The first new magazine from Time Inc. since Sports Illustrated was started in 1954 is due in the fall.

PHILADELPHIA, April 20 -Senator Edmund S. Muskie, in a stinging attack on special privilege for big business, called on President Nixon today to withdraw the nomination of Richard G. Kleindienst for Attorney General.

MOSCOW, April 20 -The Soviet Union announced today it had recovered a cosmic/ray satellite for study. The satellite, named Intercosmos 6, was launched April 7 as part of a joint space exploration effort by nations of the Soviet bloc.

The question to be asked about Robert Davidovici is not whether he is a good violinist, but what kind of good violinist he is. Mr. Davidovici, a 24year-old native of Rumania, won this year's Naumburg String Competition and as a result made his New York recital debut on Wednesday night at Alice Tully Hall.

WASHINGTON, April 20 -Advance elements of the last North Vietnamese combat division remaining on northern soil were reported tonight to be entering the demilitarized zone toward the battle in South Vietnam.

PLEIKU, South Vietnam, April 20 -- Hoaian, a district capital, was yielded to North Vietnamese forces yesterday before they had even attacked it, a witness to the operation disclosed today, and the defending troops fled in disorder.

WASHINGTON, April 20 -- Brig. Gen. Brent Scowcroft, the head of the advance party in Moscow preparing for President Nixon's trip there, is described as a "very quiet and very forceful man" who has specialized in Russian affairs during his Air Force career.
The Kraftco Corporation, one of the world's largest food processors, had sales in the first quarter of this year of $779,818,000, an increase of 5.7 per cent over the corresponding quarter of 1971.

There were several new faces in the City Opera performance of "Rigoletto" Wednesday night, the most prominent being that of Norma French, who made her debut as Gilda. Miss French has had considerable background in musical comedy, films and television, but this was apparently her first appearance in a major operatic role.

BOSTON, April 20 -- The St. Louis Blues should take up music. At the Boston Garden tonight, before the usual sellout crowd of 14,995 fans, the Blues were routed by the Bruins, 10-2, in the second game of their semifinal Stanley Cup playoff series.

WASHINGTON, April 20 -William J. Casey, chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission, described today in emotional terms the harm he thought would come from permitting brokers who are affiliated with financial institutions to become stock exchange members and do business only or mainly for their affiliates.

The culture world's newest achievement award, already known as the Sandy, was bestowed last evening on Alfred H. Barr Jr., the noted art historian and founding father of the Museum of Modern Art.

Rich Hinton, whose spring training was cut short by mononucleosis, was struck down again yesterday. This time he suffered the fate that rain brings to a pitcher who is the fifth man in a four-man rotation.

LONDON, April 20 -- Britain's railroad unions decided tonight to obey an order of the new National Industrial Relations Court and end their four-day work slowdown, which has disrupted passenger and freight traffic throughout the country.

For the traitor or the thief, of course, no oath was, is or ever will be a barrier.

BALTIMORE, April 20 (AP) -Paul Blair's fourth-inning home run, one of two Baltimore hits, provided the winning margin as Pat Dobson hurled the Orioles to a 1-0 victory over the Detroit Tigers tonight. Dobson allowed only three safeties.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Friday, April 21 -- Another encounter between North Vietnamese and American naval vessels in the Gulf of Tonkin was reported yesterday by the United States command.
SANTIAGO, Chile, April 20 -- China brouhgt the Vietnam rescue to a United Nations conference here today, condemning what she called "criminal acts of war expansion" by the Nixon Administrations.

WASHINGTON, April 20 (AP) -- Representative Shirley Chisholm of Brooklyn, a Democratic Presidential candidate, said today that two of her rivals, Senators Hubert H. Humphrey of Minnesota and Edmund S. Muskie of Maine, were tired, irrelevant and mediocre.

The Aluminum Company of America, the Armco Steel Corporation and the Anaconda Company reported yesterday improved results for the first quarter. However, the Kennecott Copper Corporation disclosed that earnings were almost cut in half despite higher sales.

WASHINGTON, April 20 -- Senator Henry M. Jackson and Governor George C. Wallace, hard-liners on Vietnam among the Democratic Presidential candidates, both declined today to defend the Nixon Administration's new bombing policy in Vietnam.

PRAGUE, April 20 (UPI) -- A hard - fighting Czechoslovak hockey team captured the world amateur title today by beating the Soviet Union, 3-2. It is the first team since 1962 to take the title away from the Russians.

PARIS, April 20 -- North Vietnam and the Vietcong today formally proposed resuming the stalled peace conference next Thursday and indicated that they would agree to meet whether the United States halted its bombing attacks or not.
Britain's Royal Ballet will present six local premieres during its six-week season at the Metropolitan Opera House from Monday through June 3.

Bronx Borough President Robert Abrams said yesterday that youth gangs had spread a "reign of terror" in the borough, threatening the safety of citizens on the streets, in subways and buses and in the schools.

Schirra Jr., the former astronaut, backing a bill to subsidize railroads, Senator Fred. R. Harris, Democrat of Oklahoma, said today.

By JANE E. BRODY By analyzing the cells of an unborn child early in pregnancy, Swedish doctors settled a paternity dispute and established the husband as the child's probable father. The analysis spared the couple an abortion and a divorce because they had applied for both "unless it could be shown likely that the husband was the father of the fetus," the doctors said.

ISLAMABAD, Pakistan, April 20 -- India and Pakistan will hold talks next week in preparation for a meeting of their heads of state.
