Mayor Lindsay asked the City Council and State Legislature yesterday for authority to impose payless furloughs on 280,000 public employes, saying a two-week furlough could save $110-million in city taxes.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, April 23 -- Eavesdropping by the enemy on radio messages of South Vietnamese and American forces in the field has made secrecy during combat operations almost impossible in recent weeks.

The Port of New York Authority announced yesterday the award of $23.5-million contract for construction of the third and last passenger terminal building in the $500-million redevelopment project at Newark Airport.
Fifteen demonstrators were arrested yesterday afternoon during a two-mile protest march through the Brownsville section of Brooklyn by squatters who had recently been evicted from a housing project.

NICE, France, April 23 (UPI) -- Ilie Nastase of Rumania posted his third Grand Prix victory in a row today when he defeated Jan Kodes of Czechoslovakia, 6-0, 6-4, 6-3, in the final of the $30,000 Nice tennis tournament.

The exiled Greek cabinet minister Andreas G. Papandreou said at a rally here yesterday that "our struggle for freedom will inevitably proceed to a confrontation with the junta, no matter what the cost."

Tournament players today tend to take the prosperity of the American Contract Bridge League for granted. But it was not always so. For the first two decades of its existence, under the carefree guidance of William McKenney, the league was always struggling to pay its bills.
WASHINGTON, April 23 -- The Nixon Administration has prepared slides to support its contention that the tax laws are reasonably fair as they stand and that tax reform is unnecessary and undesirable.
Secretary of the Treasury Connally has poured scorn upon Democratic Presidential candidates hoping to exploit the economic issue this year.
WASHINGTON, April 23 (AP) -- The nation's rate of population growth fell below 1 per cent last year for the second time since 1940, the Census Bureau said today.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, April 23 -- The North Vietnamese and Vietcong have set up a small district administration in the captured town of Locninh in Binhlong Province, just south of the Cambodian border, according to some refugees who escaped from there last week.
The long-delayed American Basketball Association Eastern Division series between the New York Nets and the Virginia Squires will resume tonight at the Nassau Coliseum with game No. 3.

Cool logic, perhaps the source of their semifinal victory over the Chicago Black Hawks, pervaded the Rangers' dressing room last night. Across the hall, the Hawks were trying to explain logically what had happened.

RAWALPINDI, Pakistan, April 23 -- President Zulfikar Ali Bhutto said tonight that he was prepared to re-establish diplomatic relations with India before talks with Prime Minister Indira Gandhi of India and that he did not rule out attendance at those talks by Sheik Mujibur Rahman, Prime Minister of Bangladesh.

RANCHO LA COSTA, Calif., April 23 -- Bobby Mitchell found a way to get his name in headlines today. The 29-year-old golf professional from Danville, Va., who considered himself underrated by the public and overlooked by the press, won the Tournament of Champions by beating Jack Nicklaus, the odds-on favorite, with a birdie at the first hole of a sudden-death playoff.

The work of Joseph Papp, Off Broadway's gift to Broadway, ran off with the top honors last night in the theater's Antoinette Perry Awards, as two of his productions -- one originating uptown, the other downtown -- swept to victory in a surprise outcome.

The Eastman Kodak Company realized a 31 per cent increase in earnings in its first quarter on a sales gain of 13 per cent, both setting record levels for the period, Gerald B. Zornow, president, reported over the weekend.

SCRANTON, Pa. -- "The unions are putting lots of pressure on us to vote for Humphrey," Stan Drugacz, a 50-year-old electronics worker, said gruffly early one morning this week as he ordered a second cup of coffee at a dilapidated diner off Cedar Avenue here.

What does one do for an encore? A few years ago the British playwright Tom Stopard scored an enormous success with "Rosencrantz and Guildenstern Are Dead." Recently he has apparently achieved another success with "Jumpers," which, like its predecessor, has been staged by Britain's National Theater.

SAIGON, Monday, April 24 (AP) -- United States B-52 bombers renewed their raids over North Vietnam on Monday and one was damaged by enemy fire, military sources reported. The United States command said the bomber landed safely at Danang Air Force Base, with no injuries to the crew, but the command would not disclose the plane's mission.

Three critics are quoted on the dust jacket of "The Bride Wore the Traditional Gold." One says, "I enjoyed every page of it"; another calls the book a delight and finds that it displays "an elaborate imagination and casts a real, lasting spell"; the third describes it as "a unique and happy debut, from by-line to last line."

PITTSBURGH, April 23 -- Steel officials were starting to talk records last week. Predictions included record consumption in May, record shipments in the second half and record shipments for the full year.

DACCA, Bangladesh, April 23 -- Seen from the air, village after village in the green countryside of Bangladesh is dotted with thatched roofs of lighter hue than the others, indicating that the houses are new.

Without a backward glance at their roller-coaster history, the Rangers advanced to the championship round of the Stanley Cup last night with a powerful, clever and commanding 6-2 trouncing of the Chicago Black Hawks.

Israela Margalit closed out the Sunday afternoon series at Hunter College with her first New York recital and her only appearance here since her 1970 debut with the Philharmonic (conducted by her husband, Lorin Maazel).

First-quarter corporate profits continued to show a strong recovery from the initial three months last year when the economy was emerging from a recession and the effects of the General Motors strike.

Still keeping up with the Joneses? Or, to put it another, updated way, smitten with things Chinese as others appear to be in this city? Then a place to visit is ffolio 72 at 888 Madison Avenue (between 71st and 72d Streets).

The New Federal Theater has broken in its new home away from home with an arresting trio of one-act plays. The program, which started last Wednesday, is tentatively scheduled to close tonight at 240 East Third Street (the former Ellen Stewart Theater, near Avenue B).

MOSCOW, April 23 -- The Soviet Union disclosed today that a chemical warfare school in northern Russia recently helped control a major fuel-oil spill that threatened to pollute a lake in a picturesque recreation and fishing area.
The Mets offered no relief for Leo Durocher's sore throat yesterday.
The Strebig-Dobben award for journalism was presented to Robert E. Bedingfield, assistant to the financial and business editor of The New York Times at a dinner last night in Phoenix, Arizona.
WASHINGTON, April 23 -- The United States has yet another trade complaint against the European Common Market.

PHILLIPSBURG, N. J. -- I live opposite an empty field. I like it because it gives me in a largely developed township the illusion of living in the country. In West Jersey -- I enjoy telling visitors from the east -- we tolerate an empty field here and there; the unused spaces represent our distinct character, our ideological separation from the bricks-and-mortar mentality of urban dwellers.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., April 23 -- Samuel L. Popkin is an assistant professor of government at Harvard whose special interest is Vietnam village life. He takes a relatively unemotional line on Vietnam by today's standards; he is critical of American policy but also speaks of excesses and mistakes on the other side.

Manhattan College's varsity eight-oared crew seemed to have the Gen. John Glover Cup well in hand yesterday, leading the New York A.C. by 1 1/4 lengths as they passed the 500-meter mark at the Orchard Beach lagoon. But misfortune followed and the N.Y.A.C. eventually won the 2,000-meter race by four lengths.

SALT LAKE CITY, April 24 (UPI) -- The Utah Stars posted a decisive 139-130 victory over the Indiana Pacers tonight and took a 3-to-2 lead in the Western Division playoffs of the American Basketball Association.

A lieutenant at the Attica Correctional Facility told the McKay Commission yesterday that a suggestion for augmented security that was made the day before prisoners rioted was rejected for economy reasons.

ARLINGTON, Tex., April 24 (UPI) -- Two-run singles by Toby Harrah and Larry Biittner in the sixth and seventh innings tonight paced the Texas Rangers to a 6-4 victory over the California Angels and a fourgame sweep of their first home series.

MERION STATION, Pa., April 24 -- In other places, such as Philadelphia's graffiti-spattered slums, the main event in the Pennsylvania Democratic primary tomorrow will be between the two major campaigners, Senators Hubert H. Humphrey of Minnesota and Edmund S. Muskie of Maine.

Consumers may expect "hundreds of millions of dollars" in price reductions as the Federal Price Commission enforces limits on business profit margins, the commission chairman, C. Jackson Grayson Jr., asserted here yesterday.

The National Broadcasting Company Television Network announced yesterday its 1972-73 Saturday morning program schedule for children, comprising six new shows, three returns and a revised version of a program cited for special mention in this year's Peabody Awards.
The Phelps Dodge Corporation yesterday reported a decline of $6.2-million in firstquarter net income despite a gain of $10.8-million in gross income.

WASHINGTON, April 24 -- The Price Commission denied today a 4.45 per cent price increase sought by the Ford Motor Company for several of its product lines, including engine parts and Capri automobiles.

In his testimony before the Senate Foreign Relations Committee, Secretary Laird said that he would "not rule out the possibility" that the United States might blockade the harbor of Haiphong or mine the channel leading to it.
DALLAS, April 24 -- The chairman of the International Business Machines Corporation warned today that limiting the freedom of American business to operate abroad would cost the economy jobs at home.

HOUSTON, April 24 -- The Apollo 16 astronauts, to their obvious distaste but to their better health, are gulping gallons of a potassium-spiked orange drink -- just as are millions of earth-bound humans who are benefiting from major advances in medical physiology that have taken place since World War II.

WASHINGTON, April 24 -Senator Charles H. Percy, one of the authors of a low-income home ownership program that has undergone widespread fraud and abuse, proposed today that the Federal Housing Administration be "completely restructured" into a consumeroriented agency.

Amyas Ames, Lincoln Center's chairman of the board, had spoken a few warm words of welcome, the Monteverdi-Chor from West Germany stood poised on the Philharmonic Hall stage, and the third Lincoln Center International Choral Festival was about to begin.

MINEOLA, L. I., April 24 -An exchange of property between the Federal Government and Nassau County to permit the construction of a $74-million Federal Office Building at Mitchel Field was announced here today.

The city's Commissioner of Corrections and the Bronx District Attorney joined 45 civic groups yesterday in a vehement protest to the bill now before the State Assembly that would reinstate the death penalty for homicides.

The present push on the part of Right to Life, Knights of Columbus and similar groups to repeal New York's present abortion law would make sense only if that law required women to have an abortion. Since all the law does is permit those women who wish them to have abortions by physicians, it leaves entire freedom of choice to all women in this state.

WASHINGTON, April 24 (AP) -- The United States Supreme Court declined today to review a ruling that could make it tougher for dissident shareholders to mount proxy fights against corporate managements.
Ralph S. Saul, 50 years old, who joined the First Boston Corporation last year as vice chairman, has been advanced to chairman of the executive committee of the investment banking firm.
In recent years, the average angler has become acutely aware of the remarkable sensitivity of fish to water temperature.
WASHINGTON, April 24 -- In a very unusual move, a high official of the United States Government predicted today a further upward revaluation of the Japanese yen.

MOSCOW, April 24 -- The Soviet Union announced today the completion of the second model of a unified series of modern computers that will ultimately form a national network of process-control and management - information systems for the country's planned economy.

The May and July cotton No. 2 futures contracts of the current crop year reached life-of-contract highs yesterday on the New York Cotton Exchange of 42.90 cents a pound and 42.56 cents, respectively. The final prices were lower -- May closed at 42.50 cents a pound, up from 42.22 cents on Friday, and July closed at 42.20 cents, up from Friday's 41.97 cents.

Sunday was Broadway's night but, not insignificantly, television controlled the ground rules. Scheduled to begin at 9 o'clock on the network of the American Broadcasting Company, ceremonies for the 26th annual Antoinette Perry Awards were delayed about 20 minutes as the TV time slots were adjusted for earlier coverage of the Apollo 16 space shot.

WASHINGTON, April 24--The Supreme Court declared unanimously today that Federal courts had inherent power, beyond the specific antipollution remedies legislated by Congress, to stop municipalities and corporations from polluting the air and waterways.
ALBANY, April 24 -- The Assembly voted final approval this evening of the first broad revision of the state mental health law in 45 years.

WASHINGTON, April 24 -Representative John E. Moss, Democrat of California, demanded today that the public be given information about deliberations in the industry-Government committees that are working on fundamental reorganization of the stock markets.

JERUSALEM, April 24 -- The Gaza Strip, symbol of uprooted Palestinian refugees for two and a half decades, is gradually being assimilated into Israel. A pattern of carrot-and-stick tactics by the occupation administration is slowly becoming apparent and is stirring political disputes.
WASHINGTON, April 24 -With the help of some telephones and a widespread network of friends, a group of antiwar activists has become a novel source of information on military activity in Vietnam.

LUXEMBOURG, April 24 (AP) -- Foreign ministers from the 10 countries of the new Common Market agreed today on the urgency of creating a European economic and monetary union, but disagreed over priorities.

FRANCONIA, N. H., April 24 -Spring in Washington. What did it amount to, after all? Tulips and death. You could hear the human spirit shriveling all over the city. Half-mad with hunger for America the beautiful, the brave, the innocent, the big-spirited, land where our fathers died, land of the Pilgrims' pride, whose banners made tyrannies tremble, we gassed the car and fled.

Massenet's "Manon" returned to the City Opera Friday night. The performance marked something of an event for the conductor, Charles Wilson, who was celebrating to the day his 10th anniversary with the company.

Four incumbents and two new directors were elected to the 18-member board of The Associated Press yesterday.

Stock prices gave ground yesterday in the face of several unfavorable factors. The trading pace was restrained, however, as the volume of 14.65 million shares on the New York Stock Exchange represented the lowest turnover in three and a half weeks.

ATLANTIC CITY, April 24 -- In the corners of the huge Convention Hall here and in the hallways and rooms of the Dennis Hotel a few blocks down the boardwalk, Paul Schrade may be making his last stand.

In slow trading stock prices eased slightly on the American Stock Exchange yesterday. The exchange's index closed at 28.20, down 0.10 from Friday's level. Over-the-counter stocks were down generally in light trading and the NASDAQ industrial index closed at 140.44, off 1.00.

A red-haired, 235-pound patrolman named Walter Corley stepped off a scale at the Police Department's first mass weigh-in yesterday and consulted a wall chart. He found he was 29 pounds over the "maximum ideal" weight for his height of 6 feet and his age of 37.

MIAMI BEACH, Fla., April 24 -- The Republican Party moved closer today to switching the national convention from San Diego to Miami Beach. The Republican National Committee was called to meet on the proposed shift on May 5 and 6 in Washington.

BOLOGNA, Italy, April 23 -Anti-Communist orators in election rallies in the medieval piazza of this city talk a lot about Czechoslovakia these days, and Communist campaigners all over Italy talk a lot about Bologna, which is governed by Communists.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Tuesday, April 25--South Vietnamese forces in the Central Highlands, splintered into small and disorganized groups after an enemy assault with tanks and artillery on their headquarters at Tancanh, were falling back toward the provincial capital of Kontum today with the North Vietnamese in pursuit.

The Union Oil Company of California and Pennzoil United, Inc., announced yesterday that earnings inched ahead during the first quarter of 1972, and Ashland Oil, Inc., reported record earnings for the quarter and fiscal six-month period ended March 31.

She complains that women constitute 53 per cent of the electorate but only 2 per cent of the Congress, and that blacks, people with Spanish surnames and young people are also underrepresented.

The related causes of Western European unity and East-West detente in Europe sustained setbacks over the weekend in voting in West Germany and France. By far the more serious result was the solid victory of the Christian Democratic Union in the Baden-Wurttemberg state election, which left in acute danger both Chancellor Brandt's West German Government and the friendship treaties it had negotiated with the Soviet Union and Poland.

MINEOLA, L.I., April 24 (AP) -- Tapes of wiretapped conversations were played today at the murder-conspiracy trial here of a former public school principal and a woman who used to teach at the school.

The Board of Higher Education last night amended its policy on professional obligations of City University faculty members, to limit "supplemental" outside activity to an average of one day a week or its equivalent.

ALBANY, April 24 -- In an attempt to hurdle a major stumbling block to adjournment, the Assembly is preparing "no fault" automobile accident insurance bill that would meet some of the objections to two such bills stymied in the Senate.
PHILADELPHIA, April 24 -As far as delegates are concerned, Pennsylvania will hold one Presidential primary tomorrow that means nothing and 50 that mean everything.
WASHINGTON, April 24 -- Japanese and Soviet scientists believe they are "well on the way" to developing methods for earthquake prediction, it was reported here today.
WASHINGTON, April 24 (AP) -- A ship repair company, two of its subsidiaries and 17 individuals were indicted for fraud today by a Federal grand jury.

SALT LAKE CITY, April 24 (UPI) -- Howard Eckersley, a top aide to Howard R. Hughes, the billionaire industrialist, said yesterday that stock fraud charges against him were groundless and were brought by a private individual, not the Canadian Government.

CAIRO, April 24 -- President Anwar el-Sadat, who will fly to Moscow in the next few days for talks with the Soviet leaders, said today that President Nixon in a message last year had acknowledged Egypt's policy of independence from all foreign powers.

ROME, April 24 -- Finance Minister Valery Giscard d'Estaing of France signaled the beginnings of a new dispute today between the European Common Market and the United States -- over the type of forum for negotiating the shape of a new world monetary structure.

A painting by Francisco Zurbaran, the 17th-century Spanish artist, said to be among the world's finest still-life paintings, has been purchased by the Norton Simon Foundation for around $3-million.

MORRIS TOWNSHIP, N. J., April 24 -- John T. Kissinger, President Nixon's adviser on national security, at the request of the President on Jan. 21, 1969. WASHINGTON, April 25 (AP) -- The House passed today aI $673.8-million budget authorization for the Nation'al Science Foundation. The vote was 329] to 16. The bill, sent to the Sen-[ ate, covers the year beginning July 1.

Except for the Bach C major Concerto, the music came from the 20th century: Poulenc's Sonata and Lutoslawski's Paganini Variations, played with some regularity, and Rieggers Three Dances and Rorem's Four Dialogues, presented with such rarity as to seem like novelties.

The Continental Can Company and the American Can Company, the nation's two largest container producers, forecast higher earnings for 1972 over those of last year at their annual meetings yesterday.
Louis Cirillo was convicted in Federal Court here yesterday as a major distributor of heroin smuggled into this country from France.

Because of its religious leadership, there is no city like New York City, both Mayor Lindsay and retiring Episcopal Bishop Horace W. B. Donegan agreed yesterday as they spoke optimistically of the city's future.

Sales in the month of April so far have been "very good" at the W. T. Grant Company, following a 21 per cent rise in business over 1971 during February and March, Richard W. Mayer, president, told the annual meeting here today.

DACCA, Bangladesh, April 25 -- United Nations relief officials here have been irritated by public criticism of their mission's efforts in this war-damaged country, while the relatively small role of the Soviet Union has received high praise.

MONMOUTH, Me., April 25 -- Fifty-one oils and water-colors valued at "well in excess of $250,000," and descirbed as part of a collection of American paintings, "which tells the story of this country," have been stolen from the summer estate of Mrs. Norman B. Woolworth.

The House of Representatives recently passed a water pollution control bill which would provide up to $18 billion to build sewage treatment plants and to purify the nation's fouled waters. The Senate had previously passed an even more ambitious bill.

NEEDHAM, Mass., April 25 -- Edwin Herbert Land, the inventor of practical one-step photography, has fulfilled his promise of a new generation of equipment that "revolutionizes the revolution" he created in picture taking.

With his father watching from a choice seat in the Yankee bull pen, Mike Hegan rapped a pinch-hit run-scoring double in the 12th inning that gave the Oakland Athletics a 4-3 victory over the Yankees last night.

Paul Miller, chairman and chief executive of the Gannett Company, was elected yesterday as chairman of the board of The Associated Press, a new title for the newsgathering cooperative. He had been president since 1963.

In 1890 Frederick Law Olmsted, the designer of Central Park, wrote to a friend, "In the last thirty years I do not think that there has ever been a period of two years in which there has not been a strong and respectable movement to destroy some part of the park in order to establish provision for some other form of recreation than that for which it was established.

DETROIT, April 25 -- The Ford Motor Company announced today a second recall on 436,000 of its 1972 Mercury Montegos and Ford Torinos to install new rear axles and bearings because of a possible safety hazard.

With the dissolute air of a cynic, the impeccable British diction of a fop and a sneer that marked him as a cad with a soul beyond redemption, George Sanders became one of Hollywood's busiest and best-paid cinema villains.
Carl (Spider) Lockhart, one of the few sought-after players on the New York Giants' roster, resolved his salary difficulties with the club and yesterday signed a contract for the 1972 season.

SAN JOSE, Calif., April 25 -- The jury in the murder, kidnapping and conspiracy trial of Angela Davis heard today three of the intimate letters that the 28-year-old black activist had written to George Jackson.

The United States, which only yesterday thought itself so rich in energy resources that it could afford the luxury of tightly limiting fuel imports and permitting lavish use of all forms of energy, is waking up to the realization that it has been powering itself into an energy crisis.
Mrs. Andrew Sage, with a round of 79, led Piping Rock to victory over its clubmates, Piping Rock II, as the Women's Metropolitan Golf Association's interclub matches opened yesterday.

Because the urban gospels say that big towns like this one have to build safe, sensibly priced housing to keep the middle class from fleeing to the suburbs, I've been patient and thoughtful and have counted to 72 hours before criticizing an ostensibly daring and innovative plan -- the largely privately financed, $1.2-billion Manhattan Landing Project.
WASHINGTON, April 25 (UPI) -- Ruling that the benefits outweigh the risks, a Federal hearing examiner recommended today that the Government reverse its proposed ban on DDT.
For over 60 years Deerfield Academy evolved around the quietly dominating personality of Frank Learoyd Boyden, one of the most original and eventually the best known American headmaster of his times.

The Ranger practice session yesterday at Skateland in New Hyde Park, L. I., seemed more like the opening of training camp, which took place 6 1/2 months ago, than a New York drill before the start of the Stanley Cup final playoffs.
ATLANTIC CITY, April 25 -- "The U.A.W. is ready to enlist in his cause" if Senator Edward M. Kennedy seeks the Presidency, Leonard Woodcock, president of the auto workers union, said today.

FLEMINGTON, N. J., April 25 (AP) -- The Eastman Kodak Company expects to market its own self-developing film for use in Polaroid cameras and is making progress on its own, in-camera film-processing system, its president, Gerald B. Zornov, told shareholders today.

WASHINGTON, April 26 (AP) -- The Securities Industry Association proposed today that the Securities and Exchange Commission make an in-depth examination to determine whether it is in the public interest to continue with a system of fixed minimum commission rates.

ELIZABETH, N. J., April 26 -- The Union County Democratic chairman, James J. Kinneally, was indicted today by a Union County grand jury on charges of perjury, conspiracy, misconduct in office and receiving money under false pretenses.

ALBANY, April 26 (AP) -- An Attica prison inmate, attracted by the sunlight reflecting off a shiny object in a prison yard, discovered a tear-gas canister buried in the ground, the State Department of Correctional Services disclosed today.

WASHINGTON, April 26 -The National Research Council, the operating arm of the nation's most prestigious scientific group, is to be totally reorganized so that it can deal more effectively with the major problems of American society.

The chairman of the City Board of Education's finance and budget committee said yesterday that the school system lacked the funds to employ additional security guards, despite requests from principals and parents for increased security.

Until last week the score was: Manhattan, 4; Long Island, 3; Queens and New Jersey, 2 each; Brooklyn, l; Staten Island, Bronx and Westchester, each 0. These figures refer to the number of open bridge clubs with permanent facilities and a full program of duplicate games and other activities, and it is good to report that the void in Westchester has now been filled, and filled in a convincing manner.

Robert Moses' opinions on contemporary sculpture [news story April 12] are embarrassing. To have said that Henry Moore is a sculptor who "punches holes in the heads of his subjects'' is unworthy of Mr. Moses.

East and West -- and the South -- met on Tuesday night in the second program of the International Choral Festival at Philharmonic Hall. The Gandharva Choir from the Gandharva Maha Vidyalaya (College) in New Delhi, shared the evening with the London Student Chorale from the University of London, the Bela Bartok Choir from the Eotvos Lorand University in Budapest and the University of San Juan (Argentina) Choir.

PHILADELPHIA, April 26 -The labor unions gave Senator Hubert H. Humphrey his first and most important political base in the Pennsylvania primary campaign, and after yesterday's voting they were naturally getting plenty of credit.
LONDON, April 26 -- Close to 10 months of tennis wrangling ended today. Rod Laver, Ken Rosewall and the other World Championship Tennis pros probably will play at Forest Hills.

Awards totaling $34,029 have been given to six independent moviemakers by the American Film Institute, created in 1965 by the National Foundation on the Arts. This brings the sum granted by the Institute to more than $450,000, given to 72 filmmakers, since the inception of its awards program according to George Stevens Jr., director of the A.F.I.

The Sterling National Bank and Trust Company of New York said yesterday that it would provide adequate working capital to Botany Industries, Inc., and its apparel-manufacturing subsidiary, H. Daroff Sons, Inc.

There was a touch of Alice in Wonderland about the concert by The Seventh Century Tuesday evening at Town Hall: Intermission first, program later. This arrangement was necessitated to allow time to rustle up a drum set to replace one that, it was announced, had been "stolen or mislaid."

Veronica Tyler, who had been absent from the New York City Opera for three years, returned Tuesday night as Mimi in the third "La Boheme" of the spring season. Miss Tyler, an uncommonly refined soprano, did not create a sensation in the role (would you tolerate a Mimi who created sensations?).

A deferred tuition loan plan will enable students in New York's public and private colleges -- through direct loans by the state -- to put off paying up to $10,000 in room, board and tuition fees without having to borrow from a bank.

WASHINGTON, April 26 (UPI) -- X-rays have disclosed the portraits of a man and a woman painted under an existing picture entitled "Venus With a Mirror" by the 15th-century Italian Renaissance master Titian, the National Gallery of Art announced today.
BOSTON, April 26 -- Senator George McGovern's sweeping Democratic primary victory in Massachusetts turned into an avalanche today.

In a beautiful nod of recognition to the emerging nation of California, the board of directors of Clinton E. Frank, Inc., Chicago, has elected Thomas W. Lowey, its West Coast headman, president of the agency.
ROME, April 26 -- Whatever the forum that is finally selected for negotiations to reform the international monetary system, the United States wants the terms of reference as broad as possible.

DETROIT, April 26 -- Ford Motor Company announced today record earnings of $252-million in the first three months of 1972, up 49 per cent from the January- March period last year. It also said that it was cutting car and truck prices an average of $13 per unit.

SAN JOSE, Calif., April 26 -- The lawyer who represented the late George Jackson was called as a witness today at the Angels Davis trial, but he refused to answer virtually every question the prosecutor asked.
PARIS, April 26 -- The four parties to the Vietnam peace conference agreed today to hold the first full session in more than a month tomorrow.

Consolidated net income of the Panhandle Eastern Pipe Line Company in the first quarter climbed to $17.7-million, or $1.18 a share, from $13,067,000, or 95 cents a share, in the like period last year, Richard L. O'Shields, president, yesterday told the annual meeting here.
Tenneco, Inc., a widely diversified company whose operations range from natural gas pipelines to shipbuilding, announced yesterday record revenues and profits for the March quarter.

Senators Hubert H. Humphrey and George McGovern, now the two front-runners for the Democratic Presidential nomination, came out of the Pennsylvania primary Tuesday with strongly different constituencies and with their contrasting public images even more sharply drawn.

Three companies of the Allegheny Power System, Inc., filed suit yesterday against the Westinghouse Electric Corporation seeking compensation for damages in excess of $17-million. The action alleged breakdowns and a failure to meet operating and design specifications of two 540,000-kilowatt steam-turbine generators made by Westinghouse.

LONDON, April 26 -- "Gone With the Wind," the best-selling novel and equally popular film, came to London tonight in a lavish musical replete with Southern accents, the burning of Atlanta, Civil War battles and a royal audience.
Lyndon B. Johnson was released from the Army's Brooke General Hospital in San Antonio and flown home to Johnson City to continue his recuperation from a heart attack suffered April 7.

WASHINGTON, April 26 -The index of leading economic indicators, which is supposed to turn up or down before the economy as a whole, showed another strong rise in March, the Commerce Department announced today.

MINNEAPOLIS, April 26 -Two antiwar proposals sumitted at the annual meeting of Honeywell, Inc., here today were decisively defeated by the management of the computer-electronics manufacturing concern.

ST. LOUIS, April 26 (UPI) -- The St. Louis Cardinals acquired Gary Cuozzo from the Minnesota Vikings today in exchange for a receiver, John Gilliam, and second and fourth-round draft choices next year.

Buckwheat, appropriately enough, is a rock group that comes to New York from Oklahoma via California. In their set at the Gaslight at the Go Go Tuesday night, they were a classic illustration of some of the problems confronting a just-arriving new act.

Arnold A. Hutschnecker sees only two immediate difficulties in implementing his drug-abuse prevention plan (Op-Ed March 22) -- lack of trained personnel and possible conservative opposition. But there are others:

PLEIKU, South Vietnam, April 26 (AP) -- A United States adviser was pulled aboard a helicopter and flown out of a beleaguered Central Highlands base despite his demands to be left behind with South Vietnamese troops, field reports said today.

WASHINGTON, April 26 (AP) -- Senator Robert Taft Jr. proposed today a constitutional amendment permitting Federal income tax credits for part of the tuition paid by parents of private and parochial school pupils.

Pearl Primus has had many careers in her 50 some years -- dancer, anthropologist and teacher, not to mention a short stint as a welder. But this Trinidad-born resident of New Rochelle, N. Y., has really been pursuing one goal, whether she was stunning the ballet public with her vigorous renditions of African dances in this country or gathering data about village life, from sculpture to cooking, in Liberia.
WASHINGTON, April 26 -- President Nixon said tonight that he was continuing his troop withdrawal program despite the heavy enemy offensive in South Vietnam.

WASHINGTON, April 26 -Paul A. Volcker, the Under Secretary of the Treasury for Monetary Affairs, said today he thought there would be agreement in a few weeks on a new "Group of 20" to negotiate reform of the world monetary system.

The office of Manhattan District Attorney Frank S. Hogan decided last week to press perjury charges against Jay L. Kriegel, a mayoral assistant, but then suspended its decision pending receipt of a final legal memorandum from Mr. Kriegel's lawyer.
Here comes the bride, all dressed in . . . pink and white eyelet . . . red and white dots . . . yellow and white daisies . . . purple embroidery. Weddings aren't always what they used to be.

The very heart of Britain's Royal Ballet is to be found in the choreography of Frederick Ashton. His choreography is the company's style and the company's soul. Yesterday at the Metropolitan Opera House, the company gave the first performances this season of "The Dream," together with repeats of Kenneth MacMillan's "Triad" and Rudolf Nureyev's restaging of Petipa's "La Bayadere."
Following is a transcript of President Nixon's broadcast address on Vietnam last night, as recorded by The New York Times:

INGLEWOOD, Calif., April 26 -- The Knicks were "happy but cautious" after their 11492 victory tonight in the opener of the National Basketball Association championship playoff. The Lakers appeared to be in shock.

The lawyer for service employes in rent-controlled apartment buildings in the Bronx suggested yesterday that the city permit 7.5 per cent rent increases to go into effect immediately pending the issuance of official maximum base rent orders.

Although the Democratic party is a house of many mansions, it contains only two centers of power. The first consists of the trade unions who can furnish money and invaluable manpower in getting out the vote. The other comprises intellectuals and students on the nation's campuses and their middle-class liberal allies who have the personal commitment and the leisure time to devote to political canvassing.

The fleet taxicab industry yesterday accused the Taxi-drivers Union, Local 3036, of damaging or destroying 250 taxicabs in the last two months in an attempt to force the fleets into paying higher driver commissions.

ALBANY, April 26 -- Mayor Lindsay visited leaders of the Legislature this evening in his annual search for extra fiscal aid, then left to make a political speech that was devoid of any sharp criticism of the Republican leaders.
Net income of the Ford Motor Company soared in the first quarter of 1972, outstripping most expectations. The company also announced a price reduction averaging $13 a car.
An eight-foot avocado plant named Gwen beat out an upstart called Edward and a nine-footer that answers to no name to win the blue ribbon at the Great National Avocado Pit Growers Contest yesterday.

INGLEWOOD, Calif., April 26 -- With a dazzling display of marksmanship, the New York Knicks swept to a 114-92 victory over the Los Angeles Lakers tonight in the first game of the four-of-seven game series for the National Basketball Association championship.
Prices of soybean futures fell 4 1/4 cents to 5 3/4 cents a bushel yesterday on the Chicago Board of Trade under heavy liquidation that encountered stop-loss selling, mostly by public accounts.

MURREE, Pakistan, April 26 -- When Aziz Ahmed was a young civil servant in East Bengal in 1938, he was confronted by a spreading wave of attacks on the shops of Hindu money lenders by Bengalis so far in debt that they were seeking to burn the debt records.

PHILADELPHIA, April 26 (AP) -- About 200 antiwar students barricaded themselves inside the University of Pennsylvania's main administrative building here tonight and vowed to remain there until the university abolished its R.O.T.C. program.
ROME, April 26 -- In Italy, where strikes have long been a way of life, an unusual twoweek experiment started today: Almost every man is doing his job.

Judy and Jane do not appear in Arthur Whitney's "The Divorce of Judy and Jane," which opened last night at the Bijou, but there are seven other women on stage -- all Lesbians. Each is direct from Central Casting.

BLOOMINGTON, Ind., April 26 (AP) -- The Indiana Pacers overcame sharp shooting by Utah to beat the Stars, 105-99, tonight. The victory evened their American Basketball Association Western Division championship series at three games apiece.

KUALA LUMPUR, Malaysia, April 26 (Reuters) -- Puerto Rico has offered to be host for the chess match between the world champion, Boris Spassky of the Soviet Union, and his American challenger, Bobby Fischer. The International Chess Federation president, Dr. Max Euwe, announced the Puerto Rican offer here today.

WASHINGTON, April 26 -The highest black officials in the Nixon Administration told the President in a report today that his policies against busing were of doubtful constitutionality and threatened to increase distrust of government in the Negro community.

WASHINGTON, April 26 -- Leonid I. Brezhnev, the Soviet Communist party leader, personally initiated Henry A. Kissinger's secret weekend trip to Moscow, a well-placed Administration source said today. Mr. Brezhnev and Mr. Kissinger discussed the Vietnam situation and other issues sure to arise during President Nixon's visit to the Soviet Union next month.

Reacting to what Wall Street considered an extremely bullish refunding announcement, the capital markets staged a vigorous price advance late yesterday and extended the recent decline in interest rates.
Ikuko Mizuno, a Japanese violinist who has been a member of the Boston Symphony Orchestra since 1969, made her New York recital debut at Carnegie Recital Hall Tuesday night.
With a flourish of mint juleps, Southern fried chicken and black-eyed peas, the Offtrack Betting Corporation reined its second Kentucky Derby Special toward the starting gate here yesterday.
HOUSTON, April 26 -- Apollo 16 was on course tonight and aiming for a splashdown in the Pacific Ocean at 2:44 P.M., Eastern standard time, tomorrow.

Approval by the New York State Assembly of a measure that imposes a one-year moratorium on "the compulsory assignment of public school pupils" illustrates the mischievous effect of President Nixon's anti-busing rhetoric. More precisely, it shows that the anti-busing message has, in fact, signaled an all-out retreat from school integration. A reading of the Albany bill shows that it is not merely a moratorium on busing; it is a prohibition against further integration.
LOS ANGELES, April 26 (UPI) -- Six men and a New York holding company were convicted today of plotting to conceal illegal ownership of the Frontier Hotel in Las Vegas, Nev.
The National Steel Corporation and the Inland Steel Company yesterday outshone the industry's two giants with gains in first-quarter revenues and earnings.

BOSTON, April 26 -- During the Boston Bruins' 5-3 victory last night in St. Louis that qualified them to oppose the New York Rangers in Sunday's opener of the Stanley Cup final, Bobby Orr was slow to get up from a collision with Barclay Plager, a Blues' defenseman.

WASHINGTON, April 26 -The Treasury is so flush with cash as a result of higher-than-expected revenue connections that it will pay off, rather than refinance, nearly a third of the $2.4-billion of publicly held securities maturing in mid-May.

LEXINGTON, Ky., April 26 -- Riva Ridge is expected to strengthen his position as the best of the 3-year-olds thus far this season when he competes in the Blue Grass Stakes at the Keeneland track tomorrow.

WASHINGTON, April 26 -C. Jackson Grayson Jr., chairman of the Price Commission, said today that a new rule on productivity would go into effect on May 1 and that, as a result, permitted price increases would be smaller.
Rheingold Breweries, Inc., filed an antitrust suit yesterday against seven companies, including Anheuser-Busch, Inc., of St. Louis, the country's No. 1 brewer.

A state police film showing the assault on Attica prison's rebellious inmates from the time the hostages were brought into view with knives at their throats to the time the prisoners were subdued, stripped and made to crawl on muddy, ground was shown publicly for the first time yesterday at hearing of the McKay Commission.
Chief of Detectives Albert A. Seedman said yesterday that he planned to file his retirement papers tomorrow and to relinquish his command next Monday.

In a recent issue you published a letter signed by Victor Sanchez Cardona and Tomas Morales Cardona of the University of Puerto Rico commenting on the subject of the environment in Puerto Rico. The letter states that mining companies are only waiting for the availability of the electrical power in order to establish a copper mining complex in Puerto Rico.

Diamond, Whitey, Herbie, Lefty and Louie were joking and swaggering lightly outside the Manhattan House of Detention for Women at noon yesterday, jaunty in their cotton tennis hats and blue denim uniforms with the names and symbols of their gangs emblazoned on the backs of their jackets.

The Federal Reserve Bank of New York said yesterday that it was investigating the service by Howard C. Harder, chairman of CPC International, Inc., on the boards of both the Chemical Bank and the Peoples Trust Company of New Jersey for a possible violation of Section 8 of the Clayton Act.

HOUSTON, April 26 -- Antiwar protesters picketed the annual meeting of the General Electric Company today, but the company's board chairman, Fred J. Borch, said that G.E. owes it to the nation to continue to develop new weapons.

BOSTON, April 26 -- As a result of yesterday's primaries, Senator Hubert Humphrey said in Pennsylvania that he had captured the "vital center" of the Democratic party. Senator George McGovern said here that he was building a "new center." And the man who has suffered most at their hands, Senator Edmund Muskie, apparently is contemplating withdrawing from active candidacy.

Dr. Andrew W. Cordier, the 71-year-old former president of Columbia University and now dean of the university's School of International Affairs, moved quietly among the people lined up in front of his school at 118th Street and Amsterdam Avenue yesterday describing the tactics that were to be used to keep the building open.

Once again the American Stock Exchange index slid downwards, and yesterday's drop took it to 27.97, down 0.05. However, in the over-thecounter market the NASDAQ index gained 0.11 to close at 139.23 in what brokers called "moderate trading."

Senator George McGovern's victory in the Massachusetts primary and his relatively strong showing in Pennsylvania have moved him from an underdog to a viable national candidate. Tuesday's results were more convincing than his previous victory in Wisconsin, where he won with only 30 per cent of the vote and where heavy Republican participation in the Democratic primary cast doubt on the validity of the result.

SANTA FE, N. M. -- The Indians are sitting in front of the Palace of Governors. Most of them are old, their hair graying, their mouths toothless except for one or two stumps, their copper faces rutted with lifelines. The men wear bandannas around their foreheads, the women wrap themselves in bright-colored shawls, which contrast with their bloated bellies.

WASHINGTON -- As a realist, I must say that about the only real power Congress has left is the negative power of denying funds. Surely this was never the intention of the framers of the Constitution, nor has it come about by the proper procedure of constitutional amendment. Take the bill to limit the ability of the executive to carry on indefinitely an undeclared war.
ALBANY, April 26 -- Governor Rockefeller's proposal to shorten the period in which legal abortions may be performed will be introduced in the Legislature this week, informed sources said today.

ALBANY, April 26 -- The Senate today unanimously approved a bill authorizing the state to create a $1.15-billion environmental conservation bond issue to provide funds for air, water and land environmental projects across the state during the next five years.

The board of directors of Haryou-Act, the Harlem anti-poverty agency, yesterday demanded an apology from Representative Charles B. Rangel for what they called "the inaccurate, illogical and irresponsible statements he has made" against the corporation.

NEW DELHI, April 26 -During the six years that Prime Minister Indira Gandhi has been in power she has used many people as her emissaries for various tasks but there has been no one like Durga Prasad Dhar, who is her principal envoy to the talks that opened with Paki stan today in Murree.

Stock prices steadied somewhat yesterday, following two days of broad setbacks. The Dow-Jones industrial average edged up 0.45 to 946.94. Losers outnumbered winners on the New York Stock Exchange, however, by 869 to 567.
The American Broadcasting Company will present four new Saturday children's television series beginning in September.

Richard Anthony Allen (call me Dick) was born in Wampum, Pa., on March 8, 1942. The name of his birthplace is somewhat symbolic of Allen's tempestuous career because annually he is one of the major league's stanchest holdouts.

WASHINGTON, April 26 -Representative Lionel Van Deerlin acknowledged today that he had asked Mrs. Dita D. Beard, lobbyist for the International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation, to arrange for a camping vehicle to meet him and his family in Le Havre, France, last summer.
Three organizations of doctors and nurses that have persistently attacked the municipal hospital system joined yesterday in support of the system's threat to sue City Hall.

WASHINGTON, April 26 -- Prof. Lionel Trilling of Columbia University depicted tonight a crisis of confidence in the American academic community about its goals, its standards and its historic belief in rational thought.
The Lockheed L-1011 Tristar, the wide-body airliner Congress saved by authorizing guarantees of up to $250-million in loans, flew its first paying passengers yesterday.
COLUMBUS, Ohio, April 26 -- Senators Hubert H. Humphrey of Minnesota and George McGovern of South Dakota hurried to Ohio today to try to ride the momentum of yesterdays victories to another triumph.

ATLANTIC CITY, April 26 -The United Auto Workers are considering holding a convention in Miami Beach, and Paul Schrade, the West Coast regional director, has lost his high-ranking post within the union.

PHILADELPHIA, April 26 -Even as he gave a few more hours' thought to his apparent decision to withdraw from the Presidential contest, no real options remained to Senator Edmund S. Muskie of Maine. To be sure, he could move on to Ohio for one last, desperate attempt to recoup his credibility as a candidate, but there was not one Democratic politician in 100 tonight who thought it would do any good.

HOUSTON, April 26 -- Donald K. Slayton, the 48-year-old astronaut who is back on flight status after being grounded for a decade because of a heart problem, is studying Russian in the hope of piloting a RussianAmerican joint space mission that could be launched some time after 1975.

WASHINGTON, April 26 -- The Senate Armed Services Committee voted 9 to 7 today to kill the Army's controversial Cheyenne helicopter project as it cut $450-million from the Pentagon's weapons programs.

BONN, April 26 -- A mood of grimness spread out from Bonn across West Germany today on the eve of the crucial parliamentary test of strength between Chancellor Willy Brandt and his conservative challenger, Rainer Barzel.
An early Easter helped to lift chain and catalogue sales to record levels in March, according to a survey by The New York Times.

PARIS, April 26 -- A maverick committee of the French Senate today accused the Government of negligence and many of the leading figures of the French broadcasting system of complicity in a high plot to get commercial plugs on the air.
CAMBRIDGE, Mass., April 26 (UPI) -- A group of about 40 blacks who had occupied Harvard University's Massachusetts Hall since last Thursday left the building today.
Imagine 13 barefoot young people wearing jumpsuits and floating around a loft studio while interpreting the Eros and Psyche myth. What the world needs now? Could be. Anyway, Brooklyn has it.

The chairman of the General Motors Corporation contended here yesterday that proposed Government rules for automobile safety and pollution control could waste resources "in perhaps vain pursuit of arbitrary standards based more on emotion than knowledge."

ATLANTA, April 26 -- After heated debate, the general conference of the United Methodist Church declared today that homosexual had "sacred worth" but that homosexuality was "incompatible with Christian teaching."

DALLAS, April 26 -- Jack Nicklaus arrived today with a repaired driver and a slightly swollen hand. Golf's leading money-winner is seeking his third consecutive victory in the $125,000 Byron Nelson Classic at the Preston Trail Country Club course.
WASHINGTON, April 26 -- Senator Edmund S. Muskie will reportedly withdraw tomorrow from an active campaign for the Democratic Presidential nomination.

The United States Bureau of Labor Statistics yesterday confirmed what most New Yorkers have suspected: the cost of maintaining a family in this metropolitan area is higher than the urban average for the nation.

Deputy Inspector William Stoller took command of Harlem's troubled 28th Precinct yesterday and said he hoped "to meet soon with community leaders to get a clarification of procedures" at Muhammad's Temple No. 7, the scene of a shooting on April 14 in which a patrolman was fatally wounded.

Lou Rawls, a black soul-andblues singer with a social conscience and a message gleaned from a trip from rags to riches, shared the glory of success with an audience of Harlem high school students yesterday, who were appreciative but not bowled over.
MOSCOW, April 26 -- The Soviet Government showed growing nervousness today over the future of its relations with West Germany as the fate of the Bonn coalition hung in the balance.

The weather has not been favorable this spring, and two who know this best are Todd Jesdale of Cornell and Pete Gardner of Dartmouth, coaches at two of college crew's northern outposts. Both coaches send out their varsity eights for their first competitive blooding on Saturday, and both were more cautious than ever in estimating their chances yesterday as they spoke by telephone to the weekly crew luncheon here at Mamma Leone's.

I write to take strong exception to your editorial of April 14, "Threat to Desegregation." The President's proposals for a temporary moratorium on new or additional busing in school desegregation cases and for a legislative solution to some of the major remedial problems posed by those cases clearly do present questions of policy as to which reasonable men can differ.
WASHINGTON, April 26 (AP) -- The Central Intelligence Agency agreed today to disclose its case against a former agent, Victor L. Marchetti, to lawyers defending his right to write about the agency.

MINEOLA, L. I., April 26 (AP) -- An anesthesiologist said today at the murder-conspiracy trial of Lynnor Gershenson and Howard Holder that a note found in Mrs. Gershenson's apartment could have described a death by chloroform.
HONOLULU, April 26 (AP) -- Even as he became the youngest champion in boxing history, the junior lightweight Ben Villaflor showed he had a long way to go.
It used to be Zients of Gimbels. Now it is Zients of Gamble's -- and a few other companies.

At the end of a day of spring and quiet and even classes under flowering dogwood trees. Dr. William J. McGill, the Columbia University president, said last night that he was going to allow demonstrating students to continue to hold five campus building without summoning the police.
WASHINGTON, April 26 -John Kenneth Galbraith, the economist, proposed today a new, experimental program of public service jobs for unempolyed scientists, engineers and similar persons.

Gus Hall, General Secretary of the United States Communist party, who was in North Vietnam during the recent bombings of Hanoi and Haiphong, charged last night that American bombers had hit schools, apartment buildings, playgrounds and marketplaces.
LONDONDERRY, Northern Ireland, April 22 -- Hooded teen-agers gripping submachine guns and carbines patrol the streets of the Bogside. They control traffic, wave on motorists and stop strangers.
MURREE, Pakistan, April 26 -- Four and a half months after the end of their bitter war, India and Pakistan began peace talks here today.

YONKERS, April 26 -- A spectacular three-horse accident didn't mar the season debut of Tarport Adios, one of the top 3-year-old pacers in the country, at Yonkers Raceway tonight. The sulky entanglement probably helped Tarport Adios win.

WASHINGTON, April 26 -- The United States Board of Parole granted today paroles to Dr. Martin Sweig, a 50-year-old former administrative assistant to former House Speaker John W. McCormack, Democrat of Massachusetts, and to Anthony De Angelis, the key figure in a $150-million salad-oil swindle.
The Longines-Wittnauer Watch Company has named Leonard Sadow executive vice president administration and counsel and Leonard Soloman as senior vice president-sales.

KONTUM, South Vietnam, April 26 -- With Saigon's military leadership in the Central Highlands seemingly close to paralysis as a result of recent defeats, South Vietnamese troops and their American advisers are preparing to make a do-or-die stand at this key city.

WASHINGTON, April 26 -- A study prepared by the Environmental Protection Agency has warned that, without much more stringent emission controls than those now employed, the once high air quality of the Southwest "will be increasingly and significantly degraded" by projected electric power plants in a four-state area.

WASHINGTON, April 26 -- J. Lee Rankin, New York City's Corporation Counsel, appealed to the Environmental Protection Agency today to reject requests from the country's automobile manufacturers to postpone for a year the stringent antipollution standards for 1975-model cars.
BERLIN, April 26 -- East and West German negotiators announced tonight that they had concluded a general transport agreement between the two countries intended to ease travel in both directions.
To get to the point, Alvin Ailey's two premieres for the Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater Tuesday night at the City Center were mildly disappointing.

Evidence concerning alleged payoffs from gamblers to more than a dozen Brooklyn policemen was presented to a grand jury on Wednesday, law enforcement officials said yesterday.

" What's the point of doing a play like this at this time?" Gore Vidal asked himself recently about "An Evening with Richard Nixon . . .," which opens Sunday at the Shubert. Then he explained that the work was his "small and cheerful contribution, I hope, to the decline of the American empire."

A Federal grand jury accused a Queens lawyer yesterday of false statements that obstructed a Securities and Exchange Commission investigation in 1970 of manipulation of the stock of Globus International, Inc.
A law that provided $28-million a year in state funds for parochial schools was declared unconstitutional yesterday by a special three-judge panel in Federal court here.

WASHINGTON, April 27 -The United States accused North Vietnam today of acting in bad faith by renewing attacks in South Vietnam just as the American delegation was returning to the negotiating table in Paris.

WASHINGTON, April 27 -Richard G. Kleindienst won the approval of the Senate Judiciary Committee today, 11 to 4, clearing the way for the full Senate to consider his nomination to become Attorney General.

PITTSBURGH, April 27 (AP) -- Ted Uhlaender's first National League hit, a tie-breaking bases-loaded single in the ninth inning, and Denis Menke's sacrifice fly helped the Cincinnati Reds to a 5-4 victory over the Pittsburgh Pirates tonight.

Chancellor Willy Brandt's Government has narrowly survived the opposition's unprecedented attempt to overthrow it; but West Germany remains mired in crisis. The fact that Rainer Barzel of the Christian Democratic Union fell two votes short of replacing Mr. Brandt in the Bundestag's "constructive vote of no confidence" was hardly a cause for rejoicing by the Social and Free Democratic coalition partners.

ROME -- The tests now being faced by U.S. foreign policy in Asia, Europe and superpower summitry add new dimensions to the debate on whether the machinery which formulates and applies this policy is effective.
The American Stock Exchange index dropped another 0.05 point to close at 27.92 yesterday in a slow-moving day, with 3.9 million shares traded.

In his current appearance, the British writer George MacDonald Fraser is wearing two hats: a steel bonnet as the chronicler of Anglo-Scottish border history and the plumed hat of the picaresque novelist. He is convincing in both fashions, although I would not equate the order of accomplishment. "Flash for Freedom" is fun, but the other is better entertainment.

The New York Press Photographers Association announced yesterday that Dr. Frank Stanton, vice chairman of the board of the Columbia Broadcasting System, and Arthur Ochs Sulzberger, president and publisher of The New York Times, would be awarded the association's 1972 Freedom of the Press awards.
PITTSBURGH, April 27 -- The Jones Laughlin Steel Corporation has joined the United States Steel Corporation and the Bethlehem Steel Corporation in posting lower firstquarter sales and revenues.

Arthur T. Roth, who built the Franklin National Bank into a $2-billion institution before stepping down as its head in 1968, used its annual meeting yesterday to open an attack on the present management.

SAN DIEGO, April 27 (AP) -- Dr. Gaylord B. Parkinson, who served as national campaign chairman for Richard M. Nixon in 1967, said yesterday he could not in good conscience support the President for re-election.

RAHWAY, N. J., April 27 -Shareholders of Merck and Company, Inc., gave their approval here today to a 2-for-1 stock split and rejected two proposals that had been submitted by an organization known as the Project on Corporate Responsibility.

TOKYO, April 27 -- An unusual display of militance by 1.6 million Japanese transportation workers virtually paralyzed the nation's trains and subways today and disrupted airlines and taxi service in Tokyo.

Governor Rockefeller said yesterday that he was ready to approve a new executive director of the Port of New York Authority "tomorrow morning" so long as the mall was "outside the Port Authority staff."
HOUSTON, April 27 -- The Apollo 16 astronauts brought their 11-day moon voyage to a successful conclusion today with a safe splashdown in the Pacific Ocean.
Kwame Nkrumah, the deposed President of Ghana and the first man to lead an African colony to independence after World War II, died yesterday in exile in Conakry, Guinea, at the age of 62.

WASHINGTON, April 27 -The Navy's first woman admiral is a straightforward easy-going nurse more given to "reasoning" with people. than hounding them. Capt. Alene Bertha Duerk, director of the Navy Nurse Corps, was driving alone through Ohio today, on the way to her mother's home in Holgate, when she first heard the radio reports of her nomination by the President.
WASHINGTON, April 27 -President Nixon announced today his intention to appoint Jeffrey M. Bucher, a California banker, to the Federal Reserve Board.
SAN DIEGO, April 27 -- The New York Mets completed a sweep of their series against the San Diego Padres tonight with a 4-3 victory, their sixth straight and their longest streak in two seasons.

Pianists especially. The work is so expertly laid out, so grateful to play, so difficult, so effective, that it sets the little hearts of pianists pounding away like a Geiger counter exposed to an atomic pile.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, May 1 -- As the two leading contenders in tomorrow's Ohio Democratic Presidential primary worked hard today to pry out the last possible vote, their campaign strategists fretted over what they agreed had become an increasingly tight race.

AHOY Antiquarians and nautical buffs worth their salt could do worse than hoist anchor and set a course for P. J. McNally's at 144 Chambers Street, just west of West Broadway. Those familiar with the store when it was situated on Water Street will find that all the delightful clutter has been transported intact to the new location.
TAIPEI, Taiwan, May 1 -- The Government disclosed today that eight persons, including a noted writer, were convicted of sedition by a military tribunal in March.

HUE, South Vietnam, Tuesday, May 2 -- The South Vietnamese abandoned Quangtri, their northernmost province capital, yesterday, giving the advancing North Vietnamese their biggest prize so far in their month-old invasion.

These negotiations were deadlocked years ago when we asked $800 million and the Soviets offered $300 million in payment for the $12 1/2-billion worth of goods shipped to the U.S.S.R. during World War II.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., May 1 -- The Derby Trial, which had been dwindling in the esteem of owners and trainers in recent years, will bounce back to a point of considerable importance in the 3-year-old picture tomorrow with its 36th running.

"Our Lady of Late" is a murky dance both in content and lighting. The work, created by William Dunas, had lighting that called for a steady lowering of intensity as the dance progressed. This made it difficult to see, though even noon light might not clarify its shadowy thematic line.
A revival of activity at the Chelsea piers on Manhattan's Lower West Side appears imminent, Edgar C. Fabber, the city's Commissioner of Port and Terminals, said here yesterday.

ITHACA, N. Y., May 1 -- Faced with a court order and lack of campus support, some 100 student antiwar demonstrators ended their six-day occupation of Cornell University's Carpenter Hall Library today just before 2 P.M. University lawyers, unaware that the occupation had ended, were arguing successfully for a preliminary injunction against the building take-over in State Supreme Court as the protesters exited on campus.

WASHINGTON, May 1 -- The impression is growing here that North Vietnam's capacities for sustained challenge in South Vietnam have been underestimated and perhaps misjudged as badly as they were during the engagements in Cambodia and Laos in 1970 and 1971.

Mayor Lindsay said yesterday that he was "deeply distressed" with the conditions of the streets and parks throughout the city after last weekend. WASHINGTON, May 1 -- Jack Anderson, the newspaper columnist, urged Congress today to pass a law to require the automatic declassification of Government documents that are two years old.

Once again efforts for reform of New York's automobile insurance system are coming to naught. Its obvious purpose is to bump the Gordon bill, which is currently before the Legislature.

A welfare family moved yesterday from a hotel where the city-paid rent was $1,200 a month to a renovated apartment in a Harlem tenement, marking the start of a program to relieve two of the city's most chronic problems -- welfare and housing.

DACCA, Bangladesh, May 1 -- Sheik Mujibur Rahman, Prime Minister of Bangladesh, announced a broad program today to help impoverished workers and peasants in an economy shattered by war.

WASHINGTON, May 2 --The president of the International Longshoremen's Association asked the Pay Board today to approve in full the wage settlements negotiated for dock workers on the Atlantic and Gulf Coasts to "assure three years of industrial peace in the longshore industry."

GENEVA, May 2 -- An American legal expert suggested today that anyone who murders or kidnaps, or inflicts "grievous bodily harm" on a foreign diplomat or visiting government official be punished as an international criminal.

Wow! Here at last is the perfect Broadway play of the season, perfectly acted and perfectly staged. There is only one minor thing wrong with it. It happens not to be on Broadway. The play is Jason Miller's "That Championship Season," and it opened last night at the handsome Newman Theater in Joseph Papp's New York Shakespeare Festival Public Theater complex. It is gorgeous and triumphant.

SAN FRANCISCO, May 2 -- Willie Mays was on the bench for the fifth straight game tonight as Gary Gentry pitched the New York Mets to a two-hit 4-2 victory over the San Francisco Giants that moved the Mets into first place in the Eastern Division.
ALBANY, May 2 -- Although Governor Rockefeller has said he would veto it, the Assembly Codes Committee today let out on the floor a bill to repeal the state's liberalized abortion law.

YONKERS, May 2 -- As had been anticipated, the scheduled $25,000 Overcall Pace, a one-mile, free-for-all event that Ed Parker, the racing secretary, had hoped to stage at Yonkers Raceway Friday night, failed to fill. The horsemen's demand for a higher purse and a shortage of horses were the principal reasons.

Finally getting his stuff together, Mel Stottlemyre, the ace of the New York Yankee staff, won his first game of the season last night as he scattered seven hits and shut out the California Angels, 5-0, at Yankee Stadium.

LIMA, Peru, April 29 -- Traditionally, the tone of political jokes in Lima and the popularity of a political party that has spent all of its 40 years in opposition have been good guides to popular moods in Peru.

MOUNT LAUREL, N. J., May. 2 -- In what was regarded as a breakthrough for legal attacks against exclusionary suburban zoning practices in the country, this Burlington County community in southern New Jersey was ordered today to provide for its present and future housing needs for the poor.
The governing body of the American Institute of Certified Public Accountants, as expected, approved yesterday a basic overhaul of the machinery through which accounting rules are determined.

BONN, May 2 -- Chancellor Willy Brandt's Government held talks behind the scenes with its Opposition today to seek a compromise leading to ratification of Bonn's controversial treaties with the Soviet Union and Poland.

One might suppose that in the 46-year history of the game every major aspect would have been made the subject of a book.
