WASHINGTON May 2 (AP) -- Tighter state rules on welfare eligibility have had a braking effect on national relief costs, which hit a record total of $17.7-billion last year, Government statistics showed today.

Two of labor's oldest and most respected leaders, Jacob S. Potofsky and Frank Rosenblum, have decided not to seek re-election as top officers of the 385,000-member Amalgamated Clothing Workers of America.

SEATTLE, May 2 (AP) -- The Federal Government charged two Washington men today with a plot to impersonate an airline hijacker known as "D. B. Cooper" in order to extort more than $30,000 from a former contributing editor of Newsweek magazine.

While I harbor no illusions about Governor Rockefeller's motives in supporting the work of the Scott Commission, I question whether Professor Sayre's partisan argument against political decentralization of New York City [Op-Ed April 8] is either valid or relevant.

" It took my breath away," said Dr. Rene Dubos, the retired Rockefeller University microbiologist, on learning he had won the first $50,000 Institute of Life prize for his work devoted to environmental problems.
Tornadoes swept through at least two western New York communities last night, causing damage to homes and barns and killing livestock. No human injuries were reported.

SYDNEY, Australia, May 2 -- The Federal Cabinet will meet here tomorrow to begin framing new guidelines to control foreign take-overs of Australian companies -- a move given added impetus by the future over the International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation's proposal to buy into the Australian food industry.

NEWARK, May 2 -- Federal officials moved today to mediate a dispute between Mayor Kenneth A. Gibson and the Newark Housing Authority that threatens the survival of Federally financed urban renewal and housing programs.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Wednesday, May 3 -- Senator Henry M. Jackson withdrew last night from active contention for the Democratic Presidential nomination after finishing a weak fourth here despite weeks of campaigning.

Your recent "Energy Crisis" editorial limits alternatives to the worsening power shortage by not recognizing the inefficient production of electricity as a more fundamental remedy to be sought. It is the anachronism of the industry, aided by years of permissive public service commissions, that foisted an infectious assent to cheap energy, discriminatory rate-making and uncontrolled growth.
ROME, May 1 -- Romans were again able today to travel on municipal buses and streetcars without paying any fares, and city officials hoped that many commuters would leave their cars at home.

The president of the Board of Education charged yesterday that some principals were raising the issue of violence in the schools in an effort to discredit the leadership of Chancellor Harvey B. Scribner and to pressure the board to "buy up his contract."

KENT, Ohio, May 2 (UPI) -- Acting just two days before the statute of limitations expired, the Ohio branch of the American Civil Liberties Union named 29 National Guardsmen today as co-defendants in a $1-million damage suit resulting from the 1970 disorders at Kent State in which four persons died.

Big-time drag racing comes to the metropolitan area this weekend with meets at Raceway Park near Englishtown, N. J., and New York National Speedway at Center Moriches, L. I. As is customary in the East these days, the major interest will be in the funny cars, the wolves in sheeps' clothing that resemble conventional "muscle" sedans.

The decision of a Federal judge upsetting the scandal-tainted 1969 election in the United Mine Workers will give the nation's coal miners their first chance in a half-century to practice genuine trade union democracy. The judge's findings validate rank-and-file charges that the union's treasury, staff and publications were converted into a ruthless machine for suppressing effective challenge of the dictatorial rule of the U.M.W. president, W. A. Boyle.

WASHINGTON, May 2 -- Representative Seymour Halpern of Queens, the only Republican member of the House from New York City, officially announced today that he would not seek re-election to an eighth term.
BOSTON, May 2 (UPI) -- Vida Blue signed a one-year contract with the Oakland today, ending a lengthy salary dispute.
Messrs. Newfield and Greenfield's "new" populism [Op-Ed April 12] is going to exacerbate the conditions they hate so much.

WHITE SULPHUR SPRINGS, W. Va., May 2 (UPI) -- Republican Governors approved today a resolution endorsing and urging Congressional support for President Nixon's foreign and domestic program, but made no mention of the Administration's. Vietnam bombing policy.
ALBANY, May 2 -- The Senate voted today to amend the Constitution to permit the legalization of various forms of gambling that are now illicit.
Bowing to the anti-abortion pressure exerted on them at Albany, members of the Assembly Codes Committee yesterday reported a bill that would totally repeal New York State's model abortion reform law.

WASHINGTON, May 2 -- J. Edgar Hoover, who directed the Federal Bureau of Investigation for 48 years and built it into a dominant and controversial force in American law enforcement, died during the night from the effects of high blood pressure.

HOUSTON, May 2 (UPI) -- Geologists reported today, after quickly examining some of the Apollo 16 moon rock collection, that the astronauts may have returned with a "fantastically lucky" cross section of the upper lunar crust, exceeding all expectations.

BRAWLEY, Calif., May 1 -- In one of the largest allocations of the public domain in United States history, Secretary of the Interior Rogers C. B. Morton dedicated today 19 tracts in the Southern California desert, covering 4,200 square miles, as Recreation Lands.

WASHINGTON, May 2 -- A House Interior subcommittee reached tentative agreement today on a Gateway National Recreation Area at the entrance to New York Harbor that would include more land than the Senate authorized for the project last year.

The strong offensive by North Vietnamese troops that resulted in capture of Quangtri, undertaken almost simultaneously with the trip to Paris of Hanoi Politburo member Le Duc Tho, could not have been coincidental. The military-diplomatic character of the current Communist offensive has been evident from the start. That offensive, designed to improve the Communist bargaining position in Paris, is now challenging President Nixon's Vietnam policies as never before in this long and fruitless war.

ITHACA, N. Y. -- The American people are learning, many with surprise, that their President has been telling them the truth about his commitment of U.S. air power to the Indochina conflict. Mr. Nixon evidently means business with his bombers. However, the spectacular air strikes which occasioned this surprise are only the tip of the iceberg. The other nine-tenths of the monster are submerged -- the ton-a-minute, workaday blasting of Indochina.
A dispirited stock market absorbed its second large loss of the week yesterday. After a rally at midsession failed to hold its token gain, prices sank steadily during the afternoon.

Amtrak moves into its second year almost as trouble-beset as the railroads whose inadequacies spawned it. Far from reviving intercity rail passenger service, the corporation created by Congress in hope that self-support would come quickly through the improvements it generated seems destined primarily to swell the Federal deficit.

SHOREHAM, L. I., May 2 -- The Long Island Lighting Company is planning to build a second nuclear power-generating facility next to the site of one for which the utility still has not received an Atomic Energy Commission construction permit.

A new round in the perennial battle between capitalists and Socialists has begun. The opening gong was sounded by the Penn Central bankruptcy, the Lockheed bailout, the I.T.T. consent decree that permitted it to acquire Hartford Fire Insurance, the scandals in urban housing.

Suffolk County Executive John V. N. Klein submitted to the County Legislature in Riverhead, L. I., yesterday a $700-million, three-year capital program and what he said would be an annual "environmental report." The report proposed that the county engage in the cleanup of all major oil spills, demanding reimbursement by the polluter or the Federal Government.

WASHINGTON, May 2 (AP) -- The National Football League Players' Association, which has insisted that installation of synthetic turf and player fines are negotiable items, was upheld today by a regional office of the National Labor Relations Board.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, May 2 -- The loss of South Vietnam's northernmost province and the collapse of two of its combat divisions in the last week have brought the Government of President Nguyen Van Thieu to a perilous stage.
WASHINGTON, May 2 (AP) -- The White House announced today President Nixon's appointment of 12 persons to three-year terms on the National Highway Safety Advisory Committee.
BIRMINGHAM, Ala., May 2 -- Senator John J. Sparkman took a commanding lead tonight over six challengers in his race for renomination in the Alabama Democratic primary.
Commissioner Walter Kennedy of the National Basketball Association sought to clarify yesterday three issues in question the last two weeks.

Dame Margot Fonteyn made her first appearance of the Royal Ballet's season at the Metropolitan Opera House Monday night, and the roars that greeted her testified to the special place she will always hold in the collective heart of the New York audience.

DALLAS, May 2 -- Evidence is accumulating that the Vietnam war, though it has produced the lowest rate of psychiatric casualties during combat of any major war, is causing a remarkable number of delayed psychiatric problems that emerge only after the veteran returns to civilian life.
The former editor in chief of Essence, the service maga- zine for black women, is now publisher of Encore, a new magazine for both sexes.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Wednesday, May 3 -- With the city of Quangtri lost, two South Vietnamese fire bases on the approaches to the former imperial capital of Hue were reported under enemy attack yesterday.

BURBANK, Calif., May 2 (AP) -- Daniel J. Haughton, chairman of the Lockheed Aircraft Corporation, predicted at the concern's annual meeting today that profits this year would be slightly more than the $15.4-million, or $1.36 a share, earned in 1971.

Three police sergeants, 20 patrolmen and one patrolwoman were arrested and suspended from the Police Department yesterday after they were indicted and accused of taking a quarter of a million dollars annually in payoffs to protect gamblers linked to the Mafia.
ALBANY, May 2 -- The Assembly gave final passage today to a bill designed to kill the controversial Forest Hills low-income housing project.

WASHINGTON, May 2 -- The word drifted down through the bureaucracy of the Federal Bureau of Investigation here this afternoon just about the time an informal meeting was taking place in the office of the Attorney General-designate, Richard G. Kleindienst.

WAYNESVILLE, N. C., May 1 -- There was a sprinkling of rain along about midafternoon yesterday, but most of the people who celebrate spring by standing around eating high-intensity spring onions called ramps didn't seem to notice.

Twelve youths, aged 14 to 16, were arrested in the Morrisania section of the Bronx last night when the police uncovered a cache of 15 Molotov cocktails on a roof. A loaded hunting rifle was also confiscated when one of the youths allegedly pointed it at policemen on the roof.

SAN JOSE, Calif., May 2 -- Angela Davis took the stand for the first time in her murder-conspiracy trial today in a defense attempt to bar the testimony of a prosecution witness. She testified in the absence of the jury.
Voters in Nassau, Suffolk and Westchester Counties went to the polls yesterday to choose members of their school boards and vote on school budgets for the 1972-73 academic year.

The Administration has exempted about five million small businesses -- those with sixty or fewer employes -- from wage and price controls. The Cost of Living Council says that this action will enable it to focus its enforcement efforts on the larger companies, which have much greater market power, and upon the construction and health-service industries, which, it says, "continue to have a serious inflationary impact."

REYKJAVIK, Iceland, May 2 -- On the basis of the understanding with the Soviet Union announced in Washington yesterday, the United States reportedly assumes that the first agreement on limitation of strategic armaments will set numerical limits on land-based and submarine-based offensive missiles as well as on defensive ones.

WASHINGTON, May 2 -- Everyone here agrees that the highly successful "Civilisation," Kenneth Clark's 13-part television series reviewing the cultural history of Western man, is a hard act to follow. But it has now been followed by none other than Lord Clark himself, with "Pioneers of Modern Painting," a new series on the work of key 19th-century art.
BEDFORD, England, April 27 -- Even with London now exercising direct rule over Northern Ireland, most people in Britain show a surprising indifference toward events in the troubled province.

A late rally accompanied by a short covering sharply reversed a 2 1/2-cents-a-bushel loss in soybean futures yesterday on the Chicago Board of Trade, and the commodity closed 2 3/8 cents to 1 1/8 cents a bushel higher.

Sammy Reshevsky of Spring Valley, N.Y., defeated Orest Popovych in an adjourned fifth-round game and then drew with Arthur Feuerstein, a one-time Manhattan Chess Club champion, in the 21st Annual National chess championship.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., May 2 -- Key to the Mint, in his first appearance since March 15 at Hialeah, demonstrated today that he could run a mile competently enough as he won the Derby Trial at Churchill Downs.

The selection of a jury began yesterday in State Supreme Court in Queens in the murder-arson trial of four Black Panthers charged with the 1971 slaying of another Panther, Samuel Napier, in what had been termed a factional feud over party philosophy.

MONTCLAIR, N. J. -- What happens to a family when a young mother suddenly becomes ill? Who takes care of the children? Last November, Mrs. Angels Clifford of Harrison needed an immediate answer to that question.

Dave McNally, a 20-game winner the last four seasons, seems to be right back in his southpaw groove. Last night in Baltimore, McNally set down the Chicago White Sox on four hits in pitching the Orioles to a 3-0 decision.
BETHLEHEM, Israeli-occupied Jordan, May 2 (AP) -- Arabs living under Israeli occupation ignored guerrilla warnings today and turned out heavily in an election test of Arab-Jewish coexistence.

A 19-year-old youth was elected yesterday to a local school board upstate, despite an opinion by Attorney General Louis J. Lefkowitz on Monday that persons under 21 could not hold elective office under present state law.

The bond market, which had advanced for the better part of two weeks, stumbled over several giant financings yesterday and fell head over heels. As a result, long-term interest rates rose on a broad front, though rates in the money market remained largely unchanged.

The president of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company, Robert D. Lilley, warned yesterday that despite voluminous consumer complaints about poor phone service "we are going to have to charge higher prices."

The highlight of the New York City Ballet's spring season will be its extraordinary tribute to Igor Stravinsky from June 18 through June 25. Tuesday night, the company opened up shop at the State Theater more quietly with three ballets from the repertory.

TEL. AVIV, May 3 -- Local elections in the Israeli-occupied West Bank of the Jordan River yesterday went against the Arab incumbents.

BOSTON, May 3 -- The United States Court of Appeals for the First Circuit barred a Federal grand jury today from asking a key witness in the Pentagon Papers case to disclose his "opinion" about who possessed the secret war study before its unauthorized publication last June.

WASHINGTON, May 3 -- Gen. Creighton W. Abrams, the commander of United States forces in South Vietnam, is reported to have advised Washington that the most critical military situation was developing in the central region, where three enemy divisions are said to be trying to cut the country in two.

A survey of Queens pharmacists by 50 St. John's University students shows a wide range in prices for the same prescription drugs, with the prices much higher in poorer areas than in middle-income or high-income neighborhoods.

PITTSBURGH -- In the afternoon of May 4, 1970, my wife and I learned, through telephone calls and radio newscasts, that our daughter Allison had been killed at Kent State University. Several hours later we arrived at the hospital in Ravenna, Ohio, to witness a scene of military activity in the town which recalled for me similar scenes from the last months of the war in France and Germany.

A suit was filed yesterday in the Federal District Court at Washington, D.C., seeking to prohibit the use of nitrates and nitrites as coloring agents in cured meat products, such as hot dogs, sausages and bacon.
MINEOLA, L. I., May 3 -- A former principal of a public school in Brooklyn and one of his fourth-grade teachers were convicted today of conspiring to murder the principal's wife in August, 1970.

SANTIAGO, Chile, May 3 -An inter-American assembly of "Christians for socialism" led by left-wing Roman Catholic priests endorsed today a "strategic alliance with Marxists" to achieve socialism in Latin America.
LONDON, May 3 -- The Church of England rejected today for the second time in three years reunification with the Methodist Church.

SOFIA, Bulgaria, May 3 (UPI) -- Four Turkish students armed with hand grenades hijacked a Turkish airliner to Bulgaria today and threatened to blow up the plane and its passengers unless Turkey freed three condemned guerrillas, Bulgarian authorities said.
PALERMO, Sicily, May 1 -Giorgio Almirante, the suave rightist who wants Italians to choose neo-Fascism in a democratic election, returned here this week and declared: "In Sicily, we are at home."
ROME, May 3 -- Premier Giulio Andreotti said today that his Christian Democratic party would never collaborate with either the Communists or the neo-Fascists.

The steampipe explosion which killed seven persons in a financial district skyscraper yesterday indicates that the city's new fire safety code for high-rise office buildings needs broadening even before its adoption by the City Council.
WASHINGTON, May 3 -- Vigorous attacks from three directions were made today on the bill that would permit the American and National Basketball Associations to merge.

We've mentioned several times that one good way to invest is to avoid the hurly-burly of the stock market -its ups and downs, its bull and bear phases. Buy quality growth stocks and put them away -- forget them.

The Broadway Savings Bank and the Prudential Savings Bank, both based in Manhhattan, confirmed yesterday that they are planning to merge, subject to approval of Federal and state regulatory authorities. The combined bank would have assets of roughly $600-million, and 10 offices, plus two more branches that have been authorized but are as yet unopened.

KAMPALA, Uganda, May 3 (Reuters) -- A commission of inquiry received testimony from a Uganda Army deserter here today that he had helped to dispose of the bodies of two Americans allegedly killed by troops in southwest Uganda last summer.

HONG KONG, May 3 -- Senators Mike Mansfield and Hugh Scott, Democratic and Republican leaders of the Senate, arrived here from Canton today and disclosed that they had discussed the Indochina question and other matters with Premier Chou En-lai for eight hours during their 16-day visit to China.

WASHINGTON, May 3 -- John Connally had a big barbecue at his Texas ranch the other day. The President came. So did a number of guests -- "powerful Texans," The New York Times called them; the kind of people who fly around in private jets, according to The Washington Post.
YONKERS, May 3 -Jamele's Pride, a 5-year-old trotter, and Jim Tallman, a 30-year-old driver, are enjoying the best starts of their careers in harness racing.

Mayor Lindsay indicated for the first time yesterday that he would be willing to compromise on the Forest Hills housing controversy if the scatter-site project plan was resubmitted to the Board of Estimate.
MIAMI BEACH, May 3 -- The City Council of Miami Beach extended a formal invitation to the Republican party today to hold its national convention here starting Aug. 21.
BELFAST, Northern Ireland -- At night squads of British soldiers -- faces and hands blackened so they cannot easily be seen -- patrol the Roman Catholic areas of Belfast where they are most despised.

The city Board of Education, overruling School Chancellor Harvey B. Scribner, has reinstated a controversial junior high school principal who was denied tenure by Community School Board 3 and removed from office in late 1970.

Back in October 1970 President Nixon proposed for the first time a cease-fire in place throughout Indochina. On May 3, 1971, the United States went a step further at a private meeting, offering the withdrawal of American forces in return for a cease-fire and the exchange of prisoners. On Jan. 26, 1972, when President Nixon made public this offer, he specifically renewed it.

For many months, it was the hope of some starry-eyed Democrats that their party would settle early upon one strong contender for the Presidency, thereby avoiding the bitterness of a protracted struggle for the nomination and saving money and energy for the main battle against Mr. Nixon. But the smooth logical resolution of its problems is not the Democratic party way, and could hardly be expected from such a complex heterogeneous coalition.

OTTAWA, May 3 -- Most business leaders, including heads of United States-controlled branch establishments, reacted favorably today to the Federal Government's proposals to oversee future foreign take-overs of sizable Canadian business.

ALBANY, May 3 -- The Senate, trying for the third consecutive year to find a constitutional way for the state to help finance parochial-school education, voted today to provide $33-million in state aid for nonpublic schools.
Risking the wrath of Reform Democrats, Mayor Lindsay praised Patrick F. Cunningham, the Bronx Democratic leader, last night as "my kind of politician."

NASHVILLE, May 3 -- Gov. George C. Wallace, glowing with optimism over his prospects in Tennessee's Presidential primary tomorrow, told state Democratic leaders today that the party was in for "tough sledding'' if he does not receive delegate votes to which he is entitled.
The three major broadcast networks have reportedly chartered a plane as an escape vehicle for their news crews in Hue, South Vietnam.

Jerry Finkelstein sat over lunch at the Twenty One Club yesterday wondering why Governor Rockefeller had named him to the Port of New York Authority. He readily admitted that he knew almost nothing about the vast bistate agency and that he had little more than a "waving acquaintance'' with some of the other Commissioners.
CROTON - ON - HUDSON, N. Y. -- Two days of striped bass angling on the Croton and Hudson Rivers, yielded, it is somewhat embarrassing to disclose, only one undersized fish.

WASHINGTON, May 3 (UPI) -- Representative Les Aspin, Democrat of Wisconsin, released new charges today of wrongdoing by United Service Organizations personnel in South Vietnam, which he said might link the organization's executive director with a "major multimillion dollar scandal involving the cheating of our G.I.'s in Vietnam."

GLADSTONE, N.J., May 3 -The United States Equestrian Team's Prix des Nations (jumping) squad leaves for a pre-Olympic tour of major European horse shows tomorrow night and Bert de Nemethy, coach for the last 17 years, is taking a cautious attitude toward the Games in Munich.

WASHINGTON, May 3 (UPI) -- The House passed and sent to President Nixon today legislation authorizing $115-million for a three-year effort to curb sickle cell anemia, a blood disease that afflicts one of every 10 black Americans.

CONWAY, Mass. -- For many years after she died Eleanor Roosevelt was still here in time with the rest of us -- more here, it sometimes seemed, than we were. But years pass even for the most living of the dead and sooner or later they too drop back into that distance we call history. The scholarly rites are performed, the letters, records, photographs, memorabilia, are collected and arranged. And there is a second parting.

BONN, May 3 -- Prospects for a parliamentary compromise leading to ratification of West Germany's disputed treaties with the Soviet bloc took a turn for the worse today as opposition leaders raised new demands on the Government of Chancellor Willy Brandt.

DALLAS, May 3 -- For weeks after John's doctor told him that his life depended on a kidney transplant and that the best chance of success was with a kidney donated by a close relative, John could not bring himself to ask for a volunteer.

BIRMINGHAM, May 3 -- Gov. George C. Wallace has dashed the hopes of insurgent Democrats in Alabama to embarrass him at home while he ranges over the rest of the country in search of votes to bolster his national political ambitions.

The major taxpayer revolt predicted for the New York suburbs failed to materialize last night as voters approved most of the school and library budgets in Nassau, Suffolk, Westchester and Rockland Counties.
The Canadian Government's plans for tightening controls over the acquisition of Canadian businesses by foreign companies were termed "rather mild" yesterday by business and financial executives here.
Are you beginning to wonder why it is that with so many advertising people coming up with ideas to make things better, things aren't better?

" Who would have ever dreamed that somebody like me would make it to the Whitney in New York? I'm a 77-year-old Negro woman, after all, who was born in Columbus, Georgia." But Alma Thomas has made it to the Whitney Museum, where she is being honored with an exhibition of her lively and colorful abstract paintings, and she has made it to other places as well.

Seven persons were killed yesterday when a high-pressure steam riser pipe exploded in the 36th-floor offices of General Public Utilities Corporation at 80 Pine Street, a 12-year-old building in the heart of the financial district.

Sid Davidoff, who resigned as a $30,000-a-year administrative assistant to Mayor Lindsay last December to work for the Lindsay '72 Committee in the Mayor's bid for the Presidency, is rejoining the City Hall staff.

" I felt I wasn't helping the team," said Dave DeBusschere of the Knicks, in explanation of his sitting on the bench for the entire second half in New York's playoff loss to the Lakers last night at Madison Square Garden.
WASHINGTON, May 3 -- Consumer installment credit rose by record amount in March, the Federal Reserve Board reported today.

WASHINGTON, May 3 (AP) -- The head of a House subcommittee investigating Government secrecy asked President Nixon today to postpone indefinitely the June 1 effective date of a new Executive order on the classification of documents.

WASHINGTON, May 3 -- The Nixon Administration endorsed today "the basic objectives" of a bill to permit publicly supported charitable organizations to spend at least a portion of their funds on lobbying activities without loss of their tax-exempt status.
LONDON, May 3 -- For the fourth day, gold was traded here today at record prices of more than $50 an ounce, with indications that the high prices may themselves be driving the price even higher.

WASHINGTON, May 3 -Senator William Proxmire charged today that John B. Connally, the Secretary of the Treasury, had "deliberately insulted" Congress by refusing to testify on the administration of the Government's $250-million loan guarantee to the Lockheed Aircraft Corporation.
The Royal Ballet's new production of "Swan Lake," seen for the first time in America at the Metropolitan Opera House on Tuesday night, is not really new but old. Let me not confuse the issue.

RICHMOND, May 3 -- With mountain people demonstrating outside the doors and several minor stockholders voicing concern from within, the Pittston Company held its annual stockholders' meeting here today.
The Boys' Clubs of America announced yesterday the establishment of a J. Edgar Hoover Freedom Award to perpetuate the late F.B.I. director's "memory and his inspiration to millions of American boys."
Groucho Marx, opponent of women's lib incarnate and in person, slipped into New York this week.

WASHINGTON, May 3 -- The Price Commission announced today that it was suspending all price increases for about 1,500 major corporations that had failed to submit required profit margin reports on time.

Canada has projected a surprisingly modest first step toward greater control of its own economy by means of Government procedures for screening foreign bids to take over Canadian businesses. The limited nature of the move reflects Canada's sharp debate about foreign investment and the Liberal Government's cautious approach to legislation on this subject.

For nearly a half century J. Edgar Hoover and the Federal Bureau of Investigation were indistinguishable. That was at once his strength and its weakness. The extraordinary -- and extraordinarily valuable -- institution that he created became so identified with his personality and his character that, long before the end, Mr. Hoover had become an institution in himself, increasingly and unfortunately remote from the mainstream of American life and thought.

First-quarter operating profits of the CNA Financial Corporation were 49 per cent higher than a year ago, while net income, including gains from the sale of investments, was more than double results in the 1971 period, the diversified financial services company reported yesterday.

The Legislature did its deceptive best to create the impression that its new public housing bill aims at speeding construction and saving money. In fact, the measure will delay construction, or block it altogether. This may reduce spending, but at the cost of worsening the city's public housing situation -- already a disaster.

WASHINGTON, Pa., May 3 -- Silous Huddleston, a Tennessee local president of the United Mine Workers of America, confessed today that he had directed, and handled the payoff for, the murder of Joseph A. Yablonksi with what "I believe" was union money.
DETROIT, May 3 -- The American Motors Corporation today reported March quarter profits of $6.3-million, or 23 cents a share.

WALTHAM, Mass., May 3 (AP) -- Former Chief Justice Earl Warren today became the first recipient of Brandeis University's Samuel C. and Minna Dretzin Prize. To commemorate the occasion, Mr. Warren was asked to plant a willow tree on the campus.

ALBANY, May 3 -- The Assembly today passed a bill establishing strict controls over the manufacture and distribution of amphetamines, barbiturates, narcotics and other dangerous drugs. It would also require doctors to issue prescriptions for dangerous drugs in triplicate, with one copy going to the state for availability to check on abusers.

TEANECK, N.J., May 3 -- Carl Barisich, a junior, won the shotput and the discus throw for the second year and led Princeton to its second straight New Jersey track title at Fairleigh Dickinson University today.

PARIS, May 3 -- Qualified diplomats and international monetary specialists in Paris believe the Soviet Union is preparing to raise the possibility of its participation in a new world monetary and trading system when President Nixon visits Moscow later this month.

Prof. Charles E. Townsend's April 23 letter questioned why the United States Information Agency made the film "Czechoslovakia 1968," which was shown on one of Senator James L. Buckley's recent television programs.
Annina Celli, a mezzo-soprano from New York who has studied and sung in Germany, gave a recital at Carnegie Recital Hall on Tuesday night with David Garvey as her piano accompanist.

Mayor Lindsay announced yesterday that the city would investigate allegations of "procedural improprieties" in the Office of Neighborhood Government, whose director has taken a leave of absence pending the investigation.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, May 3 -- The Saigon Government's replacement of its senior commander in the northern military region and the initiation of court-martial proceedings against a key division commander are the first official admissions of a general failure of leadership that is widely seen as the root of the South Vietnamese defeats in battle.

WASHINGTON, May 3 -John E. Ingersoll, director of the Bureau of Narcotics and Dangerous Drug's, has formed a special secobarbital intelligence force to track down a "gigantic" operation in the California-Mexico border area that he says is flooding the country with the drug.

Rutgers University and three other American institutions of higher education will take part in a one-year-trial of materials used by Britain's Open University, which offers work at the college level to students in their homes.
DETROIT, May 3 -- Sales of new cars soared to a record for the final third of April and for the full month, evidence that Detroit is basking in a spring boom.

WASHINGTON, May 3 -- Most candidates committed to the Rev. Walter H. Fauntroy maintained huge leads today over their opponents for delegates to the Democratic convention and seats on the Democratic Central Committee of the District of Columbia.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Thursday, May 4 -- Senator Hubert H. Humphrey of Minnesota won the most delegates in the four Presidential primaries Tuesday, late returns indicated this morning. He also appeared to have won the closely fought Ohio contest, the centerpiece in the day's events.

SAN JOSE, Calif., May 3 -The Aagela Davis murder-conspiracy trial heard today from a prosecution witness who said that Jonathan Jackson borrowed her car three days before the attempted breakout at the Marin County Courthouse on Aug. 7, 1970, in which Jackson and three others were killed in a gun battle.
CLAYTON, Mo., May 3 (AP) -General Dynamics Corporation today reported its fifth consecutive profitable quarter at an annual meeting of shareholders here.

GENEVA, May 3 -- The all-Swiss International Committee of the Red Cross proposed today that severe restrictions on the bombardment of civilians be added to the four Geneva conventions of 1949 for the protection of war victims.

WASHINGTON, May 3 -- A sudden flood of large contributions is irrigating Senator George McGovern's Presidential campaign, which survived largely on a trickle of $10 and $20 contributions until his first primary victory in Wisconsin a month ago.
WASHINGTON, May 3 -- President Nixon today appointed L. Patrick Gray 3d, an Assistant Attorney General and long-time personal friend, as acting director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation.
A 21-year-old man who was found guilty Tuesday night of stabbing to death a policeman in the Brownsville section of Brooklyn will receive a hearing May 8 on a possible death penalty.

Forty-two seniors in New York State high schools have been selected for National Merit scholarships given by the colleges they will attend, the National Merit Scholarship Corporation announced yesterday. Half of the 42 are from New York City and Westchester, Rockland, Nassau and Suffolk Counties.
BELFAST, Northern Ireland, May 3 (AP) -- Seven persons were wounded by gunfire in Northern Ireland today, the authorities reported.

MIAMI, May 3 (AP) -- Premier Fidel Castro of Cuba began a nine-nation tour of African and East European countries today. The Cuban leader is scheduled to spend six or seven days in each place, with a longer stay in the Soviet Union.

WASHINGTON, May 3 -- Repeated failures by the Sunshine Mine in Idaho to correct safety hazards within time limits set by Federal inspectors were disclosed today in reports to the Bureau of Mines. More than a score of miners were killed in a fire at the mine yesterday.

One of the major surprises of the young New York thoroughbred racing season was registered at Aqueduct yesterday when Ogden Phipps's fast-closing Numbered Account, last year's 2-year-old filly champion, failed to catch Dave Erb's Stacey D'Ette by a nose in the $27,150 Comely.
When Botany Industries, Inc., filed for reorganization last week under Chapter XI of the Bankrupcty Act, shock waves were felt throughout the men's apparel industry.
CHARLESTON, S. C., May 3 -- Vice President Agnew said in Charleston today that the Pulitzer award to The New York Times for "the theft of Government documents demeans the Pulitzer Prize."
WASHINGTON, May 3 (UPI) Antiwar protesters, maintaining a 36-hour vigil on the Capitol steps, were demonstrated against tonight by young supporters of President Nixon's Vietnam policies.

REYKJAVIK, Iceland, May 3 -- Iceland assured Secretary of State William P. Rogers today that her Government had no plans to press for a withdrawal of American Naval and Air Force personnel from Iceland.
Rudi Gernreich upheld the honor of American design, Christian Aujard showed how they do things in Paris and Deanna Littell straddled the issue as fall fashion openings continued on Seventh Avenue.

Civil Court Judge Bernard Klieger of Brooklyn went on trial in Federal Court here yesterday on charges of perjury and conspiracy involving political contributions to the 1965 mayoral campaign of City Controller Abraham D. Beame.
PARIS, May 4 -- The United States and South Vietnam declared an indefinite halt in the Paris peace conference today.
WATERFORD, Conn., May 4 -- The fish kill that destroyed more than 10,000 menhaden here this week was caused by warm water discharged from an atomic power plant, state officials said today.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., May 4 -- Everybody was satisfied with the draw today for the Kentucky Derby. The famed 1 1/4-mile race for 3-year-olds will have its 98th consecutive running at Churchill Downs on Saturday, and 16 names were sent through the entry box this morning, on payment of $1,000 each.

BUCHAREST, Rumania, May 4 -- Premier Golda Meir of Israel opened three days of talks with the Rumanian Government today, aimed at tightening the tenuous and controversial relations between Israel and her only friend in the Communist world.

WASHINGTON, May 4 -- The Nixon Administration ordered more than 50 additional fighter-bombers to the Vietnam theater today and decided that, for the first time in the war, six aircraft carriers would operate off Vietnam. This will increase the American air strength in Indochina to nearly 1,000 combat aircraft.

QUANTICO, Va., May 4 -- Fred Thompson says putting Cheryl Toussaint and Mrs. Madeline Manning Jackson on the same track for an 880-yard race is the women's equivalent of a Marty Liquori-Jim Ryun mile showdown.

WASHINGTON, May 4 -- Bipartisan support began appearing in Congress today for a prompt increase in Social Security benefits for 27 million Americans.

CLEVELAND, May 4 -- Two days after the Presidential primaries in Ohio, the Cuyahoga County Board of Elections here was simultaneously trying to find misplaced returns from 92 precincts, begin an official count before completing the unofficial count of the results, conduct a semiofficial search for mistakes in the tally and prepare to hold the election in 16 locations where the polls never did open on Tuesday.

WASHINGTON, May 4 -- L. Patrick Gray 3d, named yesterday acting director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation, said today that he had been instructed by President Nixon to operate the F.B.I. in a totally nonpolitical way.

PARIS, Ky., May 4--The maternity ward where the Kentucky Derby favorite was born is a black barn with a red roof that stands on a knoll overlooking the sweet green acres of Claiborne Farm. Frederick Wiseman, producer of such widely praised but controversial documentaries as "Titicut Follies," "Hospital" and "Law and Order," has been signed by WNET/13, the national programing division of Channel 13 here, to produce one documentary a year for the next five years for public television.

ALBANY, May 4 -- While dozens of lobbying lawyers swarmed through the Senate ante-chamber, button-holing lawmakers to express their opposition to "no fault" automobile insurance, the Senate today postponed scheduled debate on two conflicting bills that deal with the controversial issue.

WASHINGTON, MAY 4 (UPI) -- John H. Chafee retired as Secretary of the Navy today and received a farewell from Secretary of Defense Melvin R. Laird that virtually amounted to a kickoff for a Chafee campaign for the Senate.
TRENTON, May 4--The Assembly voted overwhelmingly today to lower the legal age of majority in New Jersey from 21 years to 18.

NASHVILLE, May 4--Gov. George C. Wallace won his second Democratic Presidential primary here today, aided by an absence of organized opposition and by an overwhelming sentiment against federally ordered school busing to achieve integration.

A 48-year-old former police lieutenant, James H. Harding of 544 West 157th Street, was sentenced yesterday in State Supreme Court in Brooklyn to up to three years in prison for taking bribes to protect a policy gambling operation.

NORFOLK, Va., May 4 -- Breaking away from an 88-88 tie with 3 minutes 20 seconds to play and holding the opposition scoreless the remainder of the game, the New York Nets captured the Eastern Division championship of the American Basketball Association tonight by downing the Virginia Squires, 94-88, at the Scope.

Continuing a price decline that began two and a half weeks ago, the May contract, the most actively traded of the Maine potato futures on the New York Mercantile Exchange, closed at $2.22 per 100 pounds yesterday, down 17 cents from Wednesday.

As members of the State Assembly consider a bill to repeal New York State's model abortion reform law today, they would do well to give weight to the statistical record on the estimated 350,000 abortions performed in this city since enactment of abortion law reform. Warner Communications, Inc., announced yesterday that it had reached a verbal agreement in principle to acquire the Cypress Communications Corporation, operators of cable television systems, for stock valued at $58.5-million.
John Marion, whose auction gavel has signaled the sale of more than $200-million of art and other valuables, yesterday was named president of the Parke-Bernet Galleries.

WASHINGTON, May 4 -- There has usually been a difference in American politics between the strategy for winning the primaries and the strategy for winning the Presidency, and George McGovern is rapidly reaching the point where he will have to choose between the two.
WASHINGTON, May 4 -- The Pay Board suddenly canceled today a scheduled announcement of its decision on the wage contracts of East and Gulf Coast longshoremen.

CANNES, France, May 4 -- The 26th Cannes International Film Festival opened here tonight with massive American participation. But while in former years the United States was represented by standard, big-budget Hollywood films, which provided much of the traditional festival glitter, what the Cannes officials and European cinema circles seem to want from America these days is the counter-culture.

GENEVA, May 3 -- A Swedish Government expert demanded today the inclusion of a specific ban on area bombing, napalm and other "horror" weapons in proposed supplements to the Geneva Conventions of 1949.
ALBANY, May 4 -- Creation of a state commission to regulate the burgeoning field of cable television was approved today in the Assembly.

A printing company owner testified yesterday that he had submitted fictitious bills to several corporations at the direction of Civil Court Judge Bernard Klieger during the mayoral campaign of City Controller Abraham D. Beame in 1965.

SOFIA, Bulgaria, May 4 (UPI) -- Four Turkish hijackers today gave up efforts to force Turkey to free three condemned guerrillas and released the passengers and crew of the plane they hijacked yesterday and had threatened to blow up with all aboard. No one was hurt.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, May 4 (AP) -- The South Vietnamese and United States commands reported today a decrease in their casualty tolls during the fourth week of the North Vietnamese offensive. Saigon headquarters said that the number of enemy soldiers killed last week increased.
DALLAS, May 4 -- A team of Detroit researchers says that schizophrenia may be caused by the lack of a certain regulator chemical in the brain.

A professor and his wife at the University of California have developed a method to identify -- unambiguously, they believe -- the quarry from which marble in ancient Greek statues and monuments was obtained.

MOSCOW, May 4 -- The Soviet Union published today a detailed report on its latest lunar soil sample, brought back to earth in February, confirming the existence of two basic geological subdivisions on the moon, the low-lying seas and the so-called Continental Highlands.

HUE, South Vietnam, May 4 -- South Vietnam's President, Nguyen Van Thieu, made a hurried trip to the shattered northern front today, as his Government seemed to be making hectic efforts to keep the situation from crumbling further.

FORT LEE -- New Jersey's building industry is pictured as ready to break out of its long slump and to begin meeting Governor Cahill's goal of 50,000 new housing units annually. But builders say the boom will come only if the state rejects rent control and pushes a uniform building code, and if local communities adopt more balanced zoning.

HUE -- First came the civilian wave, running south from the doomed city of Quangtri, choking Highway 1 with tens of thousands of people, animals, furniture and food. They had to travel through a gantlet of fire, for North Vietnamese troops were dug in on both sides of the road, shooting machine guns and artillery. The road became a slaughter house.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, May 6 -- South Vietnamese journalists back from the embattled northern regions of the country report that soldiers and civilians are speaking with resentment of the United States, placing the blame for Saigon's military reverses on a failure of American support and suspecting collusion between Hanoi and Washington.
WASHINGTON, May 6 (AP) -- Domestic automobile manufacturers recalled almost 8.8 million cars last year in 182 safety defect campaigns, according to the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration.

The safeguarding of our citizens against economic insecurity and self-perpetuating dependency is a problem too complex to be solved by sentimental generosity on the one hand and vindictive penalization on the other. The Senate Finance Committee apparently prefers to disregard long years of accumulating experience in order to satisfy its members' emotions rather than to use that experience to move constructively in meeting a pressing national need.

TALLADEGA, Ala., May 6 -- In stock-car racing it helps if you lower your ground clearance below the legal limit, if you conceal the true size of your engine, if you tinker the carburetor into drawing more fuel-air mixture than it's supposed to, if you get below the minimum weight limit, if you flatten the angle of the windshield or if you get away with unauthor ized tires.

ROME, May 6 -- The Government has vetoed the last of a series of regional measures that would have declared open season on millions of migratory birds now ed from shooting at birds in the spring, by a 1970 national law that expired with the institution of the regional councils.

WASHINGTON, May 6 -- The Price Commission released today its first list of major companies that it said had failed to file required quarterly reports of profit margins and warned of penalties if the companies did not promptly comply.

WASHINGTON, May 6 -- The biggest problem facing us today is not Communism but garbage disposal. The Government has been too slow to grasp this reality. Governments, maybe because they are so often dominated by military men, are almost always slow to leave the comfortable unreality of the past for the uncertainty of the present.

QUANTICO, Va., May 6 -- On his last attempt, while his wife beamed proudly, Milt Sonsky recorded the finest javelin throw of his career today. He hit 267 feet 2 inches, one of the best performances in the United States this year, at the Marine Corps Relays.

The basic difficulty of Kenneth MacMillan's new ballet "Anastasia," which was given its American premiere by the Royal Ballet at the Metropolitan Opera House Friday night, is simply the story. The idea of basing a ballet on the woman who claimed to be the Grand Duchess Anastasia, a sole survivor from the Russian Czar's family when it was murdered at Ekaterinburg in 1918, was ill-judged.

Walter J. Degnan, president of the Council of Supervisors and Administrators of the city school system, declared yesterday that, because of the bargaining power the council developed last year by joining organized labor, "nobody in New York City has lost a job" as a school supervisor.

BUCHAREST, Rumania, May 6 -- Premier Golda Meir of Israel completed an intensive round of talks with President Nicolae Ceausescu of Rumania today but reportedly found no new openings to break the Middle Eastern diplomatic deadlock.
